fields.headline: Sugar, spice and aliens
fields.trailText:
Girl
New Art Gallery, Walsall
***
fields.body:
Girl
New Art Gallery, Walsall
***

"I made him lick the dishes, I made him lick the floor, I made him lick a baby's bum, in 1994." This extract from a playground song is quoted in the catalogue for Girl, an exhibition on the theme of girlhood and girlishness at the New Art Gallery in Walsall. The song is a snippet of girl-power mischief in the making, of actual girl-culture as it is enacted when teachers, parents and all the other adults aren't looking. The 20 women artists who present work here, however, are alien grown-ups working from memory.

This may account for the general air of enchantment, artists' memories tending to be enlivened by fantasy. Girlhood comes across as a state of half-entranced fascination with life's little things. Elizabeth LeMoine's doll's house surrealism contrives cryptic meetings between a pair of silver flippers and a corset sewn with dragonfly wings. Claire Carter fills the corner of one gallery with 1,000 up-ended household brooms, their bristles spread evenly with 1,000 trinkets.

These are pleasant enough. Yet, at a time when any view of girlhood imagery can hardly ignore issues of child abuse and internet porn, the work rarely touches on sexuality, or only from an oblique perspective. It comes as something of an ironic relief when Susan Philips at least hints at defiant disillusionment. Her single photo-image shows us an overgrown corner of a council estate with a stick wrapped in silver foil standing upright in the scraggy grass. The title says it all: It Means Nothing to Me.

The unnerving highlights of the show, imaginatively curated by Angela Kingston, are in the video room. In Sarah Pucill's Backcomb a head full of raven hair creeps around a dinner table, upsetting everything and curling sensuously through the spilt milk. It's left to the terrible video-duo Jo Lansley and Helen Bendon to steal the show. Like Jean Genet's Maids, these two not-nice overgrown girls defy all expectation of proper behaviour. They steal eggs, stick them up their tights and climb trees. They trap stuffed robins in cages of dough. They make a rag doll that comes to life during the night and reaps perverse revenge by stitching up the lips of a lovely lady. Market research at the back of the catalogue mentions a fact they would, undoubtedly, identify with: the biggest toy craze among seven-to-10-year-old girls at the end of last year was Aliens in an Egg and Sticky Aliens.

Robert Clark

Until July 9. Details: 01922 654400.

Theatre

Threatening to be good

A Midsummer Night's Dream
Open Air Theatre, Regent's Park, London
**

On the first hot evening of the summer, the exquisite little open-air theatre in Regent's Park, now more intimate and secret courtesy of a lottery funded redesign, cast its customary spell. As usual though, this was in spite of the production rather than because of it.

It is disappointing because initially Alan Strachan's production threatens to be very good indeed. The slam of a door heralds the arrival of Hippolyta in high dudgeon, already tired of and irritated by her future husband, the Duke. This is no surprise, for he is a whiskered high Victorian of the most pompous kind. When Hermia is threatened with death for refusing to marry the stuffed shirt Demetrius because she loves the Byronic Lysander, Hippolyta offers the girl a flower. It is a tiny gesture of solidarity, almost unacknowledged by either party.

The play ends strongly too, with the Duke and his new bride getting quietly sozzled during the entertainment as if both know that this is the only way that they will be able to endure their wedding night and the long years of marriage ahead.

In between, Strachan's production has good ideas, but rather too many to create any cohesive whole. The wide reading that Strachan acknowledges in the programme seems to have resulted in a bit of this and a bit of that: a Jungian forest where the lovers lose their clothes, Puck is a threatening faun and the toothless fairy folk have an aggressive, earthy sexuality; a court in the grip of old-fashioned male chauvinism. The mechanicals end up beached between and barely raising a laugh. Paul Bradley's under-powered Bottom is most notable for his ass's head with its blinking eyes and wiggly ears.

The self-absorbed, comic excessiveness of the lovers is neatly played. Harry Burton makes Oberon more tender and pensive than usual, and Nicola Redmond is fine as Titania but really makes her mark as a sexy, dissatisfied Hippolyta, the future Hedda Gabler of Athens. In the end though, as so often happens at this address, it is the beauty of the natural setting and dusk turning to night, rather than the production itself, that creates the real magic.

Lyn Gardner

In rep until September 9. Box office: 020-7486 2431.

Pop

Remarkable guitar work

Nick Harper
Cecil Sharp House, London
****

It's not easy following in the footsteps of a famous father, as Julian Lennon, Ziggy Marley and even Femi Kuti have learned. There's that initial burst of interest and publicity, followed by those tedious but inevitable comparisons. Nick Harper is clearly aware of all the dangers, but is stepping out bravely in the footsteps of his wildly unpredictably, often brilliant dad, Roy Harper, the man immortalised in Led Zeppelin's Hats off to Roy Harper. Nick is clearly inspired by his father - after all, he toured and recorded with him before moving on to play with Squeeze - but has now developed a complex, wildly varied style of his own.

His dad started out playing folk clubs, although he had more in common with the rock scene, and Nick is doing the same, making his London appearance at that bastion of English traditional music, Cecil Sharp House. Old-style folkies would have been startled. The audience looked as if they had wandered up from the clubs in Camden while making their way to Glastonbury (where Nick is appearing later in June), and when he came out for a soundcheck he played so loudly that he blew the PA system, delaying the start of the show.

It was well worth the wait. He strolled in through the crowd, already playing an elaborate guitar solo, wearing a white T-shirt and suitably neo-hippy velvet trousers, and launched into a two-hour solo set that showed how far he has developed. His guitar work was remarkable, mixing bursts of rapid-fire strumming with finger picking, making delicate use of harmonics, then wandering off into unexpected chord sequences or bending notes by re-tuning the guitar in the middle of a song. All this was matched with a great sense of humour and the absurd - as when he suddenly veered into a manic treatment of Guitar Man, or wandered out through the crowd during Happy Man. Frank Zappa would have been impressed.

Harper's complex songs were not always as interesting as the instrumental pyrotechnics, but he has a good voice and his latest material, from the new album Harperspace, is his strongest yet, from the quirky lyricism of The Verse That Time Forgot to the witty acoustic psychedelia of Aeroplane. He could do with just a little less frenzy and a dash more of his dad's intensity (that inevitable comparison) but he deserves to become a major figure in his own right.

Robin Denselow

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Inflation creeps upward
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The increasing cost of mortgages pushed headline inflation last month up to 3.1%, its highest level since September 1998, government figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
The increasing cost of mortgages pushed headline inflation last month up to 3.1%, its highest level since September 1998, government figures showed yesterday.

The office for national statistics said the largest upward effect on the all-items index came from changes in mortgage interest payments.

Base lending rates were cut in April last year and the downward impact of that, reducing mortgage payments on average by 0.8%, has now fallen out of the index.

However, yesterday's figures are unlikely to alarm the Bank of England's monetary policy committee. On the underlying measure, which excludes the mortgage interest costs, inflation ticked up to 2% from the previous month's record low of 1.9%. For the fourteenth month in a row, the underlying measure was safely below the government's 2.5% target.

"There appears to be little prospect of this undershoot ending any time soon," said Richard Iley, UK economist at ABN-Amro. "But the disinflationary impact of the strong pound continues to mask genuine inflationary pressures bubbling in the domestic economy."

The ONS said utility prices registered their biggest annual fall since records began in 1987, tumbling 3.6% from a year earlier thanks to the effects of regulators demanding price cuts from utilities companies.

"Despite all the talk about the buoyant consumer sector, there are few signs of inflation," said Rob Hayward at Bank of America.

"The monetary policy committee is worried that the economy is growing too swiftly. They are keeping an eye on average earnings, and are wary of wage pressures."

Britain has the lowest inflation in Europe, by a large margin. On the internationally comparable measure which excludes all housing costs, British inflation in April stood at just 0.6% - well below the EU average of 1.7%.

The figures for May showed that inflation in Britain dropped to 0.5%. In Ireland, the only other European country for which May figures were available, inflation climbed to 5.2%.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Interviews by Cayte Williams
fields.body:
Victoria Ackerman, 30 Housing officer

I got together with my boss after an office party and we had an affair for a year. I found the cloak and dagger stuff stressful. I'd stay the night with him and next day have to act as though nothing had happened. If I talked to him in a meeting, I had to think of him just as my boss. I learned to switch off by remembering how we used to work together before we started our affair. It did affect my work because I saw him more as an equal. Rather than just jumping when he asked me to do something, I'd tell him to wait. I think that helped me cope with my anger at the situation.

Paula Barnes, 34 Office manager

In my last job, an underling made me an offer I couldn't refuse. We went from months of flirting to having sex wherever we could at work without being caught. I was older and was coasting in my job - if I'd wanted to climb any ladders, I wouldn't have had an affair. As it was, he started to get very nervous around me. I was worried people would twig, so I ended it because I needed work more than I needed sex. With hindsight, I think I'd still have had the affair, but I would have taken the sex outside work. It's fun at the time, but you're always worrying someone will find out.

Karen James, 28 Publisher

I had an affair with a good friend at work. Everyone thought we were together already because we were both flirts, but I didn't tell anybody when it started because having an affair at work is a bit like being a celebrity in a small space - everyone wants to know about it and you know they're all imagining you having sex. So what did I learn? That you have to set boundaries. I should have made it clear from the start that I didn't want to take our relationship into the office. He used to get upset if I didn't pay him enough attention when I was working really hard and suddenly all my personal space was gone.

Mark Spencer, 40 Financial director

I started an affair with a woman at work, even though we were both married. We tried to be subtle but people always gossip. I consulted her about an email which I then sent to specific people in the office. Basically it said: "I am having an affair with Jane. Say what you like about me, but don't say anything bad about her." I think it made people respect me. People don't really care whether you're having an affair, they're just worried about how it affects their work - whether your pillow talk includes giving away office secrets. I think if you are upfront, it reassures them.

Peter Harris, 38 Sales executive

I had an affair at work that backfired badly. I was very good at my job and I've always been arrogant, and I must have upset someone because a colleague - I don't know who - told my wife. She confronted me and I denied everything. In the end, she phoned my boss in tears. He called me into his office and said: "Your personal life is your own affair, but for God's sake, get it in order." My advice? Don't just worry about what people at work know. Make sure your home life can survive an affair at work.

All names have been changed

webTitle: Staff work for free to save news site

fields.headline: Staff work for free to save news site
fields.trailText: It is every company's dream - the entire workforce turning up for no pay. It is reality for the management of APBnews.com, a crime news and information site in the US.
fields.body:
It is every company's dream - the entire workforce turning up for no pay. It is reality for the management of APBnews.com, a crime news and information site in the US.

More than 100 of its 140 journalists and marketing staff have volunteered to keep showing up in the office even though the company cannot pay them. While Marshall Davidson, the former investment banker chairman of the company, scrambles to raise more money for his brainchild, for a week now staff members have stood by him.

His backers, a variety of venture capitalists that have already coughed up $27m (£18m), have told him to find a media partner to support his venture which is working on an break-even target of early 2002, four years after it was established.

The plight of APBnews.com, famed for uncovering Frank Sinatra's FBI file, comes amid signs that companies and investors are growing more wary about the dot.com sector.

On Monday, California-based Hollywood Entertainment Corp pulled the plug on its Reel.com arm, an online seller of films and provider of news about the industry. Reel.com had secured some funding from outside investors two years ago but attempts to raise new backing this time round failed. It is a trend many more dot.com companies had been forecast to join after the collapse of British online retailer Boo.com.

Many dot.coms looking for more funding are now trying to prove that they are not copycats of Boo.com, which ended amid recriminations about its entire business structure. APBnews is arguing that the logic and strategy behind the firm remain sound and coherent. "The only difference between now and six months ago is that the capital markets have closed up," an APBnews.com spokesman said.

The shake out - or "seismic shift", as APBnews put it - in dot.com stocks in March and April, when the Nasdaq mar ket fell sharply, is increasingly being cited as a potential hindrance for the survival of many start-ups.

Others will fall into the same trap, analysts say, because the venture capitalists which back the firms might be concerned that it will be harder to make a profit on their investments by floating the businesses on the stock market. The key for survival will be convincing potential investors that the strategy can work and allowing them to differentiate from the array of dot.com business being set up.

APBnews, for instance, is trying show that it is not throwing away money, insisting that by the time it reaches its scheduled break-even in the first quarter of 2002 it will have spent $60m, small beer in the terms of many dot.com start-ups.

"We always said it would take four years [to break even]. That's quite extraordinary in internet space," the APBnews spokesman said. The company had been midway through its third round of financing - raising a further $3.5m - in March and April when it was stopped in its tracks by the dot.com fall-out. That was what prompted the backers to tell the business to find an established media company to back its online capabilities - another trend that is starting to take shape in the industry.

To Richard Punt, head of Deloitte & Touche's e-business in London, the key to success for dot.com start-ups will be propositions focusing on selling from the outset, rather than setting up a site to attract customers and then look for a way to sell to them.

fields.headline: Beat the clock
fields.standfirst:
Applying for a job? A new study shows that interviewers will make up their minds about you within a minute.

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Applying for a job? A new study shows that interviewers will make up their minds about you within a minute.
fields.body:
When designer Jane Rodgers was called up by the boss of an internet start-up serving the film industry, she thought she knew what she was in for. "I researched the guy and his previous businesses, bought a new suit and lied to my boss about having to leave early for a doctor's appointment on Tuesday evening."

Rodgers met her prospective new employer not in his office but in a bar in Hoxton, an up-and-coming area of east London. "Imagine my surprise when, after five minutes of chitchat, first date questions really, he leaned towards me, stared earnestly into my eyes and told me: 'Jane, I think you're the one.' I felt like it was me as a person that was being scrutinised." He had neither seen her CV nor told her what the job involved, but he was determined to hire her. She declined the offer.

In fact, Rodgers' experience is not as unusual as it sounds. As the skills shortage in the new economy spirals out of control, your CV is likely to be the last thing on a prospective employer's mind. Last weekend, a study presented to the American Psychological Society in Miami revealed that most interviewers decide within a minute whether someone is suitable for the job.

But this is by no means an American trend. Stressed-out British executives, faced with the longest working hours in Europe, are waking up to the wisdom of employing people who may not be qualified for the job but at least will be fun to work with when the team has to pull off an all-nighter.

"Personality is becoming increasingly important," observes Andrew Swift of recruitment consultants Price Jamieson. "There's a chronic staff skills shortage in areas such as new media, so companies are looking at who will fit in with their culture, rather than who has experience. Technology is changing so fast anyway that there's no point recruiting people who have today's skills. What we need are people with creative, dynamic personalities who are not afraid to push forward into the unknown. Traditional interview rules are all well and good, but when people need staff in a hurry, they learn the benefits of intuition."

So is the job interview dead? Not quite. But research from the University of Toledo in America reveals that only the first 15 seconds really matter. Even with such a short tape, their ratings were very similar.

London-based psychologist Ros Taylor has just interviewed the chief executives of 80 blue-chip companies about the human side of running a successful business. "Really, to make a good impression, you don't even get time to open your mouth," she says, pointing out that often employers will be observing a candidate from the moment they park their car outside the office. "An interviewer's response to you will generally be pre-verbal - how you walk through the door, what your posture is like, whether you smile, whether you have a captivating aura, whether you have a firm, confident handshake. Thirty seconds is hardly enough time to think consciously, Taylor adds: "It's a very emotional response."

Ben Williams, an occupational psychologist involved in interview training, doesn't agree that a candidate has the luxury of 30 seconds. "I'd argue that it's more like a third of a second, which is basic human reaction time. A human resources officer gets a call from Satan: would she like to work in Hell? She pops down for a meeting and likes what she sees - wild partying and champagne flowing. "OK, when do I start?" fields.headline: Leicester duo back Taylor
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor was installed as Leicester's manager yesterday to highly reassuring noises from two of the players who have been so influential in the club's progress in recent years.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor was installed as Leicester's manager yesterday to highly reassuring noises from two of the players who have been so influential in the club's progress in recent years.

Muzzy Izzet sent an encouraging message to the new manager from Turkey's Euro 2000 base in Holland: "I will speak to Peter Taylor about the future and I am hoping to negotiate a new contract. I've never thought about leaving despite all the speculation and I definitely want to earn a new deal."

Izzet's fellow midfielder Neil Lennon, another player whose future was considered uncertain after Martin O'Neill's departure to Celtic last week, spoke of his admiration for Taylor and said it would be unfair to compare him with his predecessor.

Lennon is impressed by Taylor's track record with promoted Gillingham and the England Under-21s. "His recent record is outstanding," he said.

At the same time the 47-year-old Taylor offered reassurance to Stan Collymore, who must have feared a new manager might not have the faith that O'Neill demonstrated in signing the wayward striker last season.

"I would be mad to think about letting him go," Taylor said, adding that Collymore was "outstanding" with a mutual former club, Southend. "I don't see him being a problem. Stan is a great talent."

Of his own future Taylor, who has signed a three-year contract, said: "It's always been my dream to manage at the highest level. Nobody has to tell me that Martin O'Neill is an extremely difficult act to follow. But I would have had to be a madman to have turned down an opportunity like this."

 Celtic's Australian striker Mark Viduka has admitted he would be tempted by a move to Leeds and wants to resolve his future when he returns from international duty this week.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has refused to comment specifically on Viduka, saying only: "I have got David O'Leary's shopping list and I am endeavouring to bring in the players he wants."

webTitle: Spanish hopes are riding on 'perfect' Raul

fields.headline: Spanish hopes are riding on 'perfect' Raul
fields.standfirst: He creates, he scores, he has won the European Cup twice and he is not 23, writes  Jon Brodkin
fields.trailText: He creates, he scores, he has won the European Cup twice and he is not 23, writes Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
It would be stretching a point to say that not since the country went to war with Britain over Jenkins' ear has one part of one man's anatomy caused such a stir in Spain. But, for concerned Spanish fans, the case of Raul Gonzalez Blanco's thigh has been no laughing matter. On that collection of muscles rests a good deal of a nation's hopes.

From Santander to Cadiz sangrias will have been sunk at the news that the brilliant young Real Madrid forward is fit to face Norway tonight. The injury he sustained in helping his club win the Champions League final will not prevent him trying to inspire his country to a similar success. This could be some summer for a player who does not turn 23 until next week.

Asking the Spanish whether Raul is a genius is like questioning whether the earth is round. The man himself is quiet and unassuming but plenty are happy to blow his trumpet for him. Take the midfield metronome Pep Guardiola for a start: "For me, there's no discussion," he said. "He is the most important player in Spanish football, the one who is going to break records."

Even at a low-key training session in Tegelen, near the German border, it was easy in flashes to see why. Everything is done at pace and with intent. The tricks do not slither into over-indulgence. His posse of local female fans, dressed in golden crowns and screaming his name, seemed impressed by the audacious chip that almost caught out the Valencia keeper Jose Canizares.

Team-mates certainly like what they see. Raul offers not just talent but teamwork and guts. He has rescued Real on countless occasions when the cause seemed lost. "There are extremely few players who manage to impose themselves when conditions are against them," Guardiola, the Barcelona captain, said. "Raul is one of these exceptions. And in the area he's merciless; no one finishes like him.

"If I were a spectator, Raul would be my perfect player be cause nothing is more irritating than footballers who dribble when they should pass, who pass when they should dribble, who let it run when they should take a touch ... Fortunately Raul shows us how things should be done properly."

Raul is two players rolled into one harmless-looking 5ft 9in frame: a creator who often drops deep, yet also an instinctive scorer. His 32 caps have brought 16 goals. In 15 Champions League appearances last season he scored 10 times, twice at Old Trafford, despite often adopting a deeper role than for his country.

Canizares, who saw Raul slot No3 past him in the Champions League final, suggests it is easier to read Sanskrit than Raul's intentions. "In the area he improvises like no one else," he said. "There are forwards who only play one note. They are the easiest to decipher for goalkeepers. Raul is indecipherable. He's got so many alternatives at his disposal that he's a nightmare for goalkeepers."

The Spanish desperately hope he will prove as much here. Despite racking up 42 goals in eight qualifiers, Spain have often struggled to kill off tougher opponents. Jose Antonio Camacho privately made clear to his players his anger at their wastefulness against Sweden in a recent friendly. A 1-1 draw came courtesy of a penalty and since then mighty Luxembourg have been beaten 1-0.

Raul missed those games and a huge weight of expectation rests on his shoulders. With his club colleague Fernando Morientes controversially left out of the squad, he will probably operate behind the strapping Athletic Bilbao striker Ismael Urzaiz.

Few doubt that he can cope with the pressure. He made his Real debut at 17, played and scored at the last World Cup and has already won two European Cup finals. He is renowned as a big-match player. His focus and confidence are legendary.

"He's got the self-control of someone who has lived three lives," said Jorge Valdano, his first coach at the Bernabeu.

Raul's first training session with the first-team squad at Real said it all. "He wasn't intimidated by anybody," said Canizares, who was then with Real. "In no time he was trying to take people on and nutmeg them. He was shameless."

If there is a worry for the Spanish public it is that tiredness will take its toll. Today's game will be Raul's 70th of the season. Was the injury a signal that a normally durable player has pushed his body as far as it wants to go?

Raul insists he feels fine but is not expecting an easy ride. "I know it's going to be very difficult to score against [Norway]," he said. "They press very well and give you few opportunities on the ball. Norway's two most dangerous players are [Ole Gunnar] Solskjaer and [Tore Andre] Flo. They're the ones who can really hurt us."

Two seasons ago Raul seemed in danger of harming his own career. His form dipped amid rumours about his private life and he admitted fame had affected him. But taking Real's advice, he found a steady girlfriend, got married and settled down. His goals now are dedicated to his baby son Jorge and celebrated with a kiss of his wedding ring. When he visits the friends he grew up with in a working-class barrio of south Madrid he barely drinks.

Only during visits to the country to shoot and ride can Raul "lose himself". But he is happy in his hometown, worshipped by the thousands who stream into the Bernabeu and described by Real Madrid's president Lorenzo Sanz as " patrimonio " - part of the club's heritage. When Euro 2000 is over, Sanz hopes Raul will sign a contract for life. "In Madrid I have everything," the player has said.

His heart, though, was not always at Real. He began at Atletico, scoring 65 times in his first season as a boy. Only when the maverick president Jesus Gil shut down the youth team to cut costs did he move on. "Raul is my b te noire," Gil has admitted. By the end of this tournament plenty of defenders could feel the same way.

fields.headline: Political football
fields.standfirst: Civil war stopped them from playing in the 1992 finals and they opted out of Euro 96. Now Yugoslavia are taking their place on the big stage but conflict is still on their minds
fields.trailText: Civil war stopped them from playing in the 1992 finals and they opted out of Euro 96. Now Yugoslavia are taking their place on the big stage but conflict is still on their minds. Daniel Taylor reports.
fields.body:
Fifteen minutes in the company of Vujadin Boskov evokes memories of when the Germans tourists stopped off in Torquay and Basil Fawlty famously instructed his hotel guests not to mention the war.

Boskov, the Yugoslavia coach, clearly demands to talk tactics rather than politics. And when the conversation strays away from football, he sighs as though he has heard it a thousand times before.

In a tournament with the slogan "Football Without Frontiers" it is inevitable, however, that the turmoil suffocating his country will be on the Euro 2000 agenda as long as they remain in the Low Countries.

Eight years ago Uefa rescinded their invitation to take part in the finals. This time they have been allowed in - but only after a delegation of Belgium-based Kosovans lost a high court attempt to have them thrown out again.

As such, Boskov's ageing squad will have a police escort from their base in Nivelles - coincidently half-an-hour's drive from Nato headquarters in Brussels - to their opening match against Slovenia in Charleroi this evening.

Against such a backdrop their build-up to Euro 2000 has been unorthodox, to say the least. Indeed, such is the state of their affairs that the Yugoslav Football Federation failed to find a European country willing to arrange a pre-tournament friendly.

While their Group C rivals have tested themselves against the likes of Italy, Germany and France, the Yugoslavs have made do with facing a Journalists' XI in Belgrade and a five-match tour of the Far East.

Boskov claims his players are not motivated by the political situation - "the thing that motivates them is their economic situation" - but in the cases of Predrag Mijatovic and Sinisa Mihajlovic, to name but two, it is a burning issue.

Both players would have travelled to Sweden in 1992 had Yugoslavia not been os tracised and, even if they, too, would prefer to swerve the topic, it is not that they are simply fed up with the regurgitated questions but mindful of being misinterpreted.

Mijatovic went on strike at Real Madrid during last summer's Nato bombing, a deci sion that cost him his place. Now with Fiorentina, he says: "The situation is still not ideal." For Mihajlovic the issue is even more complicated. The finest player at Boskov's disposal, he threatened to pull out of Euro 2000 after it emerged that he had signed an application form for Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist Party of Serbia.

Although he protested his innocence, claiming he had been duped into believing he was applying to become a goodwill ambassador, the Yugoslav public remains sceptical; especially as television pictures showed him acknowledging a banner to the assassinated Serbian warlord Arkan during a match in the Stadio Olimpico in January.

On occasion during the Nato bombing campaign Mihajlovic, the son of a Serbian father and Croatian mother, has worn black armbands and a T-shirt bearing messages calling for peace under his Lazio shirt.

This evening he will be the defensive fulcrum of a side that has been written off by their national press as being past their sell-by date. "The midfield is slow, the forwards are cut off and the defence starts to shake every time it is put under pressure," according to the Belgrade daily Sportski Zurnan.

Nevertheless Boskov is more than optimistic about their pedigree. "We are not here as tourists, we are here to beat every other team. If we are clever we can become the European champions."

The former Aston Villa forward Savo Milosevic - or Miss-a-lot-evic, as Birmingham City's fans used to know him - should need no introduction, and Dragan Stojkovic, a veteran of the 1984 championships, has been re-installed as captain after learning via the internet last season that Boskov had given the armband to Mihajlovic.

"Eight years ago, after qualifying to play in Sweden, it was very unfortunate," says Stojkovic. "But as far as I'm concerned politics and football do not mix. I would not like to say any more than that."

Those sentiments, predictably enough, are shared by his manager: "We are here to play football, nothing else. The political situation is completely separate."

If Boskov's wish is to come true, and the Yugoslavs do manage to make football the focal issue, they will need Dejan Stankovic to drag himself out of the doldrums. The Lazio midfielder says he is "totally out of form", which will be good news for the man who is to become his brother-in-law this summer: Slovenia's Milenko Acimovic.

Although he protested his innocence, claiming he had been duped into believing he was applying to become a goodwill ambassador, the Yugoslav public remains sceptical; especially as television pictures showed him acknowledging a banner to the assassinated Serbian warlord Arkan during a match in the Stadio Olimpico in January. On occasion during the Nato bombing campaign Mihajlovic, the son of a Serbian father and Croatian mother, has worn black armbands and a T-shirt bearing messages calling for peace under his Lazio shirt. This evening he will be the defensive fulcrum of a side that has been written off by their national press as being past their sell-by date. "The midfield is slow, the forwards are cut off and the defence starts to shake every time it is put under pressure," according to the Belgrade daily Sportski Zurnan. Nevertheless Boskov is more than optimistic about their pedigree. "We are not here as tourists, we are here to beat every other team. If we are clever we can become the European champions." The former Aston Villa forward Savo Milosevic - or Miss-a-lot-evic, as Birmingham City's fans used to know him - should need no introduction, and Dragan Stojkovic, a veteran of the 1984 championships, has been re-installed as captain after learning via the internet last season that Boskov had given the armband to Mihajlovic. "Eight years ago, after qualifying to play in Sweden, it was very unfortunate," says Stojkovic. "But as far as I'm concerned politics and football do not mix. I would not like to say any more than that." Those sentiments, predictably enough, are shared by his manager: "We are here to play football, nothing else. The political situation is completely separate." If Boskov's wish is to come true, and the Yugoslavs do manage to make football the focal issue, they will need Dejan Stankovic to drag himself out of the doldrums. The Lazio midfielder says he is "totally out of form", which will be good news for the man who is to become his brother-in-law this summer: Slovenia's Milenko Acimovic.

fields.headline: Odds fellow
fields.standfirst: Fit-again Raul makes Spain a safe bet
fields.trailText: Italy, France and Holland were all short-odds winners - albeit with varying degrees of comfort - over the weekend. And favourite backers should be on safe ground again with Spain, currently a best priced 4-6 with Stan James to win Group C, to beat Norway this afternoon at 5-6 with the Tote or 4-5 tax free with the internet bookmakers Blue Square.
fields.body:
Italy, France and Holland were all short-odds winners - albeit with varying degrees of comfort - over the weekend. And favourite backers should be on safe ground again with Spain, currently a best priced 4-6 with Stan James to win Group C, to beat Norway this afternoon at 5-6 with the Tote or 4-5 tax free with the internet bookmakers Blue Square.

The news that Raul is fully fit and ready to play is heartening for Jose Camacho's team, who have the potential to trouble the best, and are also worth backing to be ahead at half-time and full-time today at 15-8 with Blue Square.

Heathorns are quoting 5-2 on a draw while a Norwegian victory, as short as 3-1 with Ladbroke's, is a top priced 9-2 with Coral.

The Norwegians should have a better chance in their other group games and Nils Johan Semb's team are worth supporting to reach the quarter-finals but to go no further at 6-5 with Coral.

Yugoslavia's meeting with Slovenia this evening looks less enticing. Slovenia are on offer at 5-1 with Coral while Chandler will give you 5-2 on a draw.

The Yugoslavs , 4-6 with Stan James, ought to emerge as comfortable winners. But, given their recent gruelling tour of Asia, stakes should be kept to a minimum. And a small sell of Yugoslav supremacy looks tempting at 0.7 with Sporting.

Sporting Index are the only spread firm running Group Indices awarding 50 points to the winner, with 25 to the runners-up and 10 to the team that finishes third. Spain are trading at 33-36 and will yield a 14-point profit if they top Group C.

fields.headline: Home thoughts from abroad
fields.standfirst: Norway will serve up some English grit
fields.trailText: Norway will serve up some English grit against Spain tonight, says Jon Brodkin.
fields.body:
The strength of English football was tested in Eindhoven last night and gets another close examination today. Kevin Keegan's boys may be resting but Norway are able deputies. Nine of their 22-man squad play in England.

Five are likely to start against Spain, and another two - the defenders Andre Bergdolmo and Bjorn Otto Bragstad - have been linked with summer moves to England. The contrast with their opponents could scarcely be greater. All of Jose Antonio Camacho's players are based in Spain.

So diverse are the two teams' styles that Barcelona's Pep Guardiola has described this as a meeting between "night and day". Just how crude Norway are has been a matter of feverish debate in recent days. Trond Sollied, one of the country's most respected coaches who takes charge of Bruges next season, claimed: "If everyone played like Norway no one would watch international matches." Nils Johan Semb, the Norway coach, offered an angry response.

There is more sophistication now than under Egil Olsen but the 4-5-1 formation and physical, hard-working basis remains. "Norway are going to be the toughest side we face in the group stage," Guardiola said after a video viewing. "Our styles are so different, it's like night playing day. Their way of playing is going to cause a lot of problems for us and we'll have to be at full concentration for 90 minutes."

All the more so because Norway's two wide midfielders, most likely Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and the Valencia-bound John Carew, turn 4-5-1 into 4-3-3 on the counter-attack and have a habit of interchanging positions with Tore Andre Flo. Some Spaniards fear for the Real Madrid centre-back Fernando Hierro, who has played only 90 minutes of football since March.

"Tiredness will not be a factor," insisted Guardiola. "For us, the problem has always been a mental one."

Spain hope their right-back Michel Salgado will recover from an ankle problem. Henning Berg should play at the centre of a Norway defence said to lack pace without the absent Ronny Johnsen.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • Robert Pires, the Marseille and France forward, yesterday confirmed he will disappoint Arsenal and intends to join his compatriot Nicolas Anelka at Real Madrid.
fields.body:
 Robert Pires, the Marseille and France forward, yesterday confirmed he will disappoint Arsenal and intends to join his compatriot Nicolas Anelka at Real Madrid.

Pires said: "I have another offer from Arsenal but my priority remains Real Madrid. Nicolas convinced me." He added that family factors influenced his decision. "My mother's name is Maribel Fernandez and she comes from Oviedo," he said. "I also have family in Madrid. It's like as if I was at home."

 Radoslav Latal, the Czech Republic defender who received a red card for dissent after being substituted in Sunday's defeat by Holland, has been banned for one game, putting him out of Friday's match with France. He was dismissed from the bench after arguing fiercely with the fourth official Kyros Vassaras following the disputed penalty which condemned the Czechs to a 1-0 defeat.

 Turkey have been fined £4,100 by Uefa after fans threw bottles, coins and other missiles on to the pitch when Italy were awarded their controversial penalty in Arnhem on Sunday.

Play was briefly interrupted to clear the debris before Filippo Inzhagi, the player adjudged to have been fouled, scored from the spot to secure Italy's 2-1 win.

 Real Sociedad have completed the signing of the Turkey striker Arif Erdem from Galatasaray for £2.4m. He teams up in Spain with his international team-mate Tayfun Korkut, who joined from Fenerbahce last month.

 Jaap Stam, who came off with a head wound in Holland's win over the Czech Republic, is confident of being fit to face Denmark on Friday.

The Manchester United defender said: "My eye was cut open and I tried to get back on with some stitches, but I felt dizzy and my vision was not completely clear." Dutch team officials said he will be closely monitored before a decision.

 Glenn Hoddle married Vanessa Shean, 41, on Sunday in a low-key ceremony at a restaurant near their Berkshire home. The former England coach, one of ITV's experts commentating on Euro 2000, flew home from Eindhoven saying he had to attend to "urgent business".

fields.headline: Euro 2000 diary
fields.standfirst: The Book has words for a Dallas repeat
fields.trailText: Lovely weather. Huge tournament. Wonderful countries. It's just a pity three of the first four matches have been settled by poor refereeing decisions.
fields.body:
Lovely weather. Huge tournament. Wonderful countries. It's just a pity three of the first four matches have been settled by poor refereeing decisions.

Emile Mpenza's goal should not have been allowed. Holland's and Italy's penalties should not have been awarded.

Sweden's Magnus Hedman spoke for everyone but Ally McCoist when he said of Mpenza's goal: "I don't think he handled it. I know he did." Johan Cruyff told television viewers in the Netherlands that "Holland should send the referee flowers" after Pierluigi Collina fell for Ronald de Boer's pantomime, which ended with him throwing himself on his back and kicking his little legs in the air. And Hugh Dallas was once again excessively generous to the team in blue when he gave that penalty to Filippo Inzaghi.

This decision was met with some dissent, but the prize for the most acidic derision goes to Clive "The Book" Thomas, whose opinions can be found on the 365 internet site (www.eurofinals.com).

In the course of telling us that Dallas should never have given the penalty and that once he did he should have booked at least two Turks for arguing, Thomas says: "I would give Dallas four out of 10 for his performance - and two of those were for turning up on time with his kit."

 L'Equipe yesterday had some fun at the expense of a Belgian, which the French are never reluctant to do. The sports daily reported that when the bewildered Filip de Wilde trod on that backpass in the opening game in Brussels on Saturday, the commentator for the French-language Belgian state television service RTBF yelled: "Quel con! Quel con!"

Con is not considered quite as de trop as its English near-homophone, but it was still embarrassing enough for RTBF to re-edit the tape before showing replays of the incident. So that now the commentator yells: "Quel idiot! Quel idiot!" De Wilde feels much better for that, you can be sure.

webTitle: Balkan reunion of outsiders and outcasts

fields.headline: Balkan reunion of outsiders and outcasts
fields.trailText: This is a meeting between the team with no chance and the team with no friends. Slovenia surprised everyone, including themselves, by beating England's recent opponents Ukraine in the play-offs to reach their first major finals.
fields.body:
This is a meeting between the team with no chance and the team with no friends. Slovenia surprised everyone, including themselves, by beating England's recent opponents Ukraine in the play-offs to reach their first major finals.

The Slovenes have been tranformed since Srecko Katanec, only 36, their greatest player and a former team-mate of Gianluca Vialli at Sampdoria, took over as coach. He has imbued his players with self-belief while switching the tactical focus from defence to attack.

Slovenia also have the advantage that some of their players, and Katanec, have the experience of playing in the former Yugoslav league.

Slovenia's pivotal player is their captain Zlatko Zahovic, who scored nine goals in qualifying and has been linked with Tottenham. He sums up the team's spirit: "Those who expect miracles might be disappointed, but they can count on us exhausting every atom throughout the 90 minutes."

But Yugoslavia's manager Vujadin Boskov will not countenance defeat. "It wouldn't be a surprise, it would be a catastrophe." he said. "They are a small country of only 1.9m people better known for tennis and skiing."

He has a strong squad capable, on their day, of matching most sides, but his problem will be welding together his ageing stars, who play in six different European leagues, plus Dragan Stojkovic of Japan's Nagoya Grampus Eight, who yesterday announced his decision to retire from international football after Euro 2000.

Yugoslavia (4-4-2, probable): Kralj; Komljenovic or Dudic, Nadj or Djorovic, Djukic, Mihajlovic; D Stankovic, Jugovic, Stojkovic, J Stankovic; Mijatovic, Kovacevic or Kezman.

Slovenia (3-5-2, probable): Dabanovic or Simeunovic; Milinovic, Milanic, Galic or Knavs; Novak, Ceh, Udovic, Zahovic, Pavlin; Rudonja, Siljak.

webTitle: Are squabbling Deutsch the new Dutch?

fields.headline: Are squabbling Deutsch the new Dutch?
fields.standfirst: The champions look a spent force.  Jon Brodkin  sees a group of average players lacking any zip
fields.trailText: The champions look a spent force. Jon Brodkin sees a group of average players lacking any zip.
fields.body:
As a comment on Germany's decline, Oliver Bierhoff's failure to react to a Thomas Hässler cross encapsulated everything. Not so much because it proved that the Milan striker can make Carl Leaburn look like George Best when the ball is on the ground, but because of the reaction that followed.

Hässler might once have trotted back with an encour aging word for his captain. That was the German way: all for one and one for all. At worst, he might have allowed himself a frustrated shake of the head. Instead he looked ready to shake his team-mate by the throat.

Crouching near the goal-line, Hassler repeatedly pointed Bierhoff to where he should have been, in at the near post before Cristian Chivu could clear. His words were not audible, but it is fair to guess they were unsuitable for early evening viewing.

Spirit and togetherness have always underpinned Germany's success. What they have lacked in talent they have made up for in unity. Now, frustrations are showing. Their famous confidence has drained and they cannot believe what is happening. It was tempting to feel Erich Ribbeck's team are in danger of becoming the new Dutch.

There were disparaging glances at misplaced passes. One look from Bierhoff at an aimless Thomas Linke punt said it all. And it hardly seemed coincidental that when Mehmet Scholl scored his fine goal he was left to celebrate more or less alone. Many teams would have collapsed in a loving heap.

Of course, these are not the first cracks. Jens Jeremies recently described the national team as "miserable" and the wing-back Markus Babbel has admitted: "There is no fire in the team. It's difficult to find someone who can make us believe." German footballers without self-belief - what next?

Even at Euro 96 one sensed that Germany believed they were invincible, despite their performances. Now that feel ing has gone and, on last night's evidence against Romania, it is easy to see why. England are capable of beating both these sides.

Ribbeck's back-line, which looked slow and vulnerable - not only to passes played in behind them but to opponents willing to take them on - will give Kevin Keegan cause for hope.

Jens Nowotny was lucky not to concede a penalty when he brought down Viorel Moldovan. The hapless Linke was easily caught out by Adrian Ilie in the lead-up to Moldovan's goal. Even Gheorghe Hagi - no Donovan Bailey - left Lothar Matthäus standing. Given the right service, Michael Owen should enjoy himself in Charleroi and there is surely a case for using Emile Heskey.

In patches, notably for a 20-minute spell in the first half, Germany showed genuine menace. But they are basically a group of average play ers, lacking zip and perhaps cowed, rather than fired up, by the incessant criticism. That the uninspiring Jeremies was one of their better players said a lot.

Hässler and Scholl at least showed they are slippery characters, often providing Germany's better moments. England will have to beware their darting runs and quick passes.

But too often their good work came to nothing. So many of Germany's attacks came through the middle that the sheer weight of Romanian bodies, or Bierhoff's weakness on the ground, brought them to a halt. Bierhoff's un derstanding with Paulo Rink was almost non-existent.

It was when the ball went wide that Germany looked most likely to prosper. From one cross Bierhoff had a header well saved, and later sent a Scholl centre just wide with his forehead.

But the wing-backs seemed reluctant to venture forward. Sebastian Deisler, brought on late for Matthäus, might offer Ribbeck's best hope given England's weakness down the left flank.

But if things go wrong for Germany on Saturday, do not bank on them offering each other consoling pats on the back.

fields.headline: Yugoslavia 3 - 3 Slovenia
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Yugoslavia: Kralj, Dudic, Djukic, Mihajlovic, Nadj, D. Stankovic, Jokanovic, Drulovic, Jugovic, Kovacevic, Mijatovic. Subs: Korac, Cicovic, Djorovic, Milosevic, Stojkovic, Komljenovic, Saveljic, Bunjevcevic, Govedarica, Kezman, J. Stankovic.

Slovenia: Dabanovic, Milanic, Galic, Milinovic, Novak, Ceh, Pavlin, Karic, Zahovic, Udovic, Rudonja. Subs: Simeunovic, Nemec, Bulajic, Knavs, Gajser, Istenic, Zlogar, Siljak, Acimovic, Pavlovic, Osterc.

Referee: M Pereira (Portugal)

1 Slovenia kick off the battle of the Balkans and not surprisingly hoof it upfield. Rudonja makes an early run down the left for Slovenia, but runs into trouble.
2 Free kick to Slovenia, awarded against Stankovic; Karic takes and launches the ball into the area but Yugoslavia clear.
3 Slovenia win another free kick from a central position when Zahovic is brought down 30 yards out. Milinovic shoots after a short lay-off but puts the ball a foot wide of the right-hand post.
5 Slovenia making all the early running as they get into the spirit of their first appearance in a European Championship.
7 Slovenia win yet another free-kick but it comes to nothing. They win another when Pavlin takes a whack in the face. Karic takes from 25 yards out, launches it into the six-yard box but Yugoslavia clear.
9 Losing count of the free-kicks as Slovenia win another; Karic again takes but he puts it into space. Yugoslavia break with Mijatovic and force a save for their first chance on goal.
10 Yugoslavia win a corner and Slovenia clear only to see the ball knocked back straight into the area. It comes out and Yugoslavia win a free-kick from deep on the right after Mihajlovic is hacked down by Karic. Comes to nothing to end Yugoslavia's first period of sustained pressure on the Slovenia goal.
15 Scrappy stuff as free-kicks are awarded left, right and centre, mainly to Slovenia.
16 Slovenia win a corner after Karic plays in Milinovic down the left for a return pass. Comes to nothing.
18 Slovenia again break down the left with Karic but his cross loops towards the floodlights.
21 This would be end-to-end stuff at the moment if only both teams could get out of the middle of the park.

Ceh swings in a cross from deep on the left and it is met well by the Slovenian hero, running through from midfield, to beat 'keeper Kralj with a fine header from 12 yards.

webTitle: Minister defends record on child poverty

fields.headline: Minister defends record on child poverty
fields.trailText: Social security secretary Alistair Darling today defended the government's record on tackling child poverty after a report suggested that Britain had one of the worst records on the issue in the developed world.
fields.body:
Social security secretary Alistair Darling today defended the government's record on tackling child poverty after a report suggested that Britain had one of the worst records on the issue in the developed world.

Britain came 20th out of 23 countries in the Unicef report and led to calls from the public service union Unison for tax increases on the better off to combat poverty. General secretary Rodney Bickerstaffe said a range of measures was needed to help the less well off. "We would like to see a new higher rate of 50% on earnings above £100,000".

Mr Darling insisted that the correct response to child poverty was getting unemployed parents into work.

"This report, which is based on figures in 1995, highlights the fact that child poverty trebled during the time the Tories were in power," he said.

He dismissed the call for tax increases on the better-off, saying that the government made a clear pledge not to raise the basic or higher rates of tax in the general election and they intend to stick to it.

fields.headline: Inquiry into blunders by doctor, 78
fields.standfirst: Government announces 'early warning system' for medical errors as James Elwood apologises for years of misdiagnosis
fields.trailText: An investigation was ordered today into a 78-year-old pathologist whose medical blunders have had "serious" results for seven patients and led to hundreds more being wrongly diagnosed.
fields.body:
An investigation was ordered today into a 78-year-old pathologist whose medical blunders have had "serious" results for seven patients and led to hundreds more being wrongly diagnosed.

James Elwood tonight finally agreed to cooperate with health bosses after being accused of "callous" and "reprehensible" behaviour for repeatedly refusing to pass on details of his employment history which could help track down more of his medical errors.

Health secretary Alan Milburn ordered the Commission for Health Improvement to investigate how Dr Elwood was allowed to work as a locum at four hospitals until last year, despite concerns being raised about his performance as early as 1995.

Dr Elwood said tonight: "I am deeply sorry if I have been the cause of distress and suffering to patients as a result of my work at the Swindon and Marlborough NHS Trust. "I will be cooperating fully with the trust in their review of this matter."

The extent of the scandal was revealed as the government announced a new "early warning system" for detecting medical errors and incompetent doctors.

Doctors, nurses and medical staff will have to report all "adverse incidents" and medical "near misses" to a national database which will then investigate and publish details of errors.

The chief medical officer for England, Professor Liam Donaldson, said the new system, similar to that used by the aviation industry to report near misses, would catch cases such as Dr Elwood before they developed into major problems.

More than 10,000 biopsies and tissue tests diagnosed by the pathologist at the Princess Margaret Hospital, Swindon, between 1995 and 1999 have had to be reviewed after concerns were raised about his performance.

The hospital said diagnostic errors in seven patients have had "serious consequences" and a further 215 people have had their diagnoses changed after the review.

One woman is believed to have had a breast removed after Dr Elwood wrongly diagnosed cancer. Others were told they were cancer-free when in fact they had signs of the disease. And one patient is in a "life-threatening" condition after a mistake in diagnosis, although hospital bosses said there were doubts about whether the patient's plight was entirely due to the doctor's error.

Trust officials would not reveal details of the health problems suffered by the seven in question but the less serious cases included one man told he had residual cancer after a prostate operation when tests later confirmed that he did not. One woman initially told a womb condition was due to a hormonal imbalance has now been contacted and told she is in danger of developing a malignancy.

Swindon and Marlborough NHS trust chief executive Sonia Mills said: "All this has been immensely traumatic. The trust deeply regrets these errors have occurred."

Three other hospitals in England and three in Ireland have also had to check results after the scandal came to light.

The Mid-Sussex Hospital in Haywards Heath, Frimley Park Hospital in Surrey and the Royal United Bath Hospital all employed Dr Elwood.

Health chiefs said that Dr Elwood had repeatedly ignored requests for him to send details of other hospitals where he had worked as a locum so that other possible mistakes could be unearthed. And he managed to evade possible disciplinary procedures by voluntarily erasing himself from the medical register last year after he was confronted with accusations of his mistakes.

Dr Elwood is still receiving an NHS pension but would only be able to work again if he applied for restoration to the register.

The General Medical Council said he would then immediately be subject to their "fitness to practice" procedures.

fields.headline: The first winners
fields.standfirst: In four regions last week teachers were chosen in the first round of the Teaching Awards 2000
fields.trailText: In four regions last week teachers were chosen in the first round of the Teaching Awards 2000
fields.body:
Tears, smiles, gasps of delight - and that was just from those of us privileged to be presenting the Teaching Awards this year.

The emotions flowed at the first of the regional ceremonies for the Teaching Awards 2000 in Winchester last week. But this being the south of England, things were more restrained than in some regions, where they will no doubt raise the roof.

And outside the city's Guildhall the stern statue of King Alfred, a lousy baker but, we were reminded, the father of English education, perhaps kept things under control.

Once again, in this second year of the awards - popularly known as Platos - it was humbling for bystanders to hear the amazing litanies of dedication recited about each winner.

In best Oscars' tradition, every winner paid full tribute to their colleagues, declaring that they could not have triumphed on their own. Only one did a Gwyneth and actually sobbed, but we won't identify her because by this stage there wasn't a dry eye in the house!

Amid all this genuine modesty, one voice - Shirley Westwood of Helenswood School, Hastings, winner of the South's Lifetime Achievement Award - brought a welcome note of defiance and reminded the world that without teachers there would be no doctors, lawyers, bankers, scientists or politicians.

fields.headline: Rocky foundations
fields.standfirst: Poor college standards cast doubt on foundation degree plan
fields.trailText: Poor college standards cast doubt on foundation degree plan
fields.body:
University funding chiefs are set to take the unprecedented step of withdrawing funds from diploma and degree courses. This follows publication of a second damning report from quality watchdogs on courses run by Stockport college in partnership with Manchester and Salford universities.

This failure to pass the inspection by quality assessors will renew concerns over government plans to establish two-year foundation degrees as part of its drive to boost student numbers. Next month the government will call for bids for the first pilot foundation degrees, most of which are likely to be run in further education colleges but validated by universities.

A report later this month from the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education will confirm that building and engineering courses at Stockport have once again failed a quality inspection. Two years ago, assessors called for a re-inspection of the college after finding that half of students were dropping out of courses. Now they have questioned the college's own monitoring procedures.

Senior academic sources say that despite its appeals, the college of further and higher education will be the first academic institution to register two consectuive unsatisfactory scores under inspection. As a result the Higher Education Funding Council for England has said it will stop funding for a course, although it will consider particular circumstances and arguments.

"Above all, we have to give priority to what is in the interests of the students, both current and future in deciding whether, and if so, when and how, to withdraw funding," said the council in a statement last week. It is thought the council may instead ask a university to take a stronger role in safeguarding standards at the college.

Senior QAA officials said they could not comment on unpublished reports, but concerns about the standards of higher education courses in further education colleges are well documented. In the agency's last annual report the chief executive, John Randall, said failings were found disproportionately in higher education programmes delivered in the further education sector. "In some cases," he argued, "this must give rise to a question of whether the college has the capacity to deliver such programmes."

Last week Randall said: "Too often problems arise through lack of experience, or lack of a critical mass of people engaging in higher education."

Ministers are keen that prestigious universities as well as colleges bid to run the new two-year courses, but most are likely to be delivered by further educationcolleges. Some fear that worries over college standards will sully the degree's reputation among businesses and students.

Stockport college's principal, Dr Richard Evans, had no comment to make. But it is understood that the college appealed vigorously against the agency's ruling. In their first report inspectors reported that a degree in building and legislation only received one formal application, with five informal inquiries. All the students entering a building diploma course in 1996 failed. "The quality of education in building, civil engineering, and electrical and electronic engineering, needs urgent improvement," the report concluded.

The inspectors also said the college followed the procedures set out by Manchester and Salford universities in a detailed manner, reacting to changes and suggestions from them with a sense of urgency and commitment. Yet improvement could be made in general monitoring of standards.

webTitle: Failure to prosecute granny spy criticised

fields.headline: Failure to prosecute granny spy criticised
fields.standfirst: More about Melita Norwood and the Mitrokhin archive
fields.trailText: MI5 was today criticised by the parliamentary committee overseeing the intelligence agencies over its failure to prosecute the KGB spy Melita Norwood.
fields.body:
MI5 was today criticised by the parliamentary committee overseeing the intelligence agencies over its failure to prosecute the KGB spy Melita Norwood.

The decision to spare 87-year-old Mrs Norwood was taken by a relatively junior MI5 officer. The then head of the service, Dame Stella Rimington, was not even informed of her existence.

The security service should have also alerted ministers to its coup in receiving a vast archive of Soviet secrets from defector Vasili Mitrokhin, the intelligence and security committee said.

Mr Mitrokhin defected in 1992, bringing with him thousands of documents copied over many years from the KGB archives.

Home Secretary Jack Straw today said that the government accepted all of the committee's recommendations but insisted that it had uncovered no evidence that democratic oversight of MI5 was inadequate.

The committee said MI5 had allowed the case of Mrs Norwood - who had passed nuclear secrets to the Russians - to "slip out of sight" for five years.

In its report on the affair published today the committee said that it was a "serious failure by MI5 not to refer the case to the law officers".

It said the failure to consult the law officers resulted in the decision whether or not to prosecute Mrs Norwood effectively being taken by the Security Service (MI5).

"The committee is concerned that the service used public interest reasons to justify taking no further action against Mrs Norwood when this was for the law officers to decide."

The committee also made similar criticisms over MI5's handling of the case of a second Soviet spy in Britain, John Symonds.

fields.bodyText: MI5 was today criticised by the parliamentary committee overseeing the intelligence agencies over its failure to prosecute the KGB spy Melita Norwood. The decision to spare 87-year-old Mrs Norwood was taken by a relatively junior MI5 officer. The then head of the service, Dame Stella Rimington, was not even informed of her existence. The security service should have also alerted ministers to its coup in receiving a vast archive of Soviet secrets from defector Vasili Mitrokhin, the intelligence and security committee said. Mr Mitrokhin defected in 1992, bringing with him thousands of documents copied over many years from the KGB archives. Home Secretary Jack Straw today said that the government accepted all of the committee's recommendations but insisted that it had uncovered no evidence that democratic oversight of MI5 was inadequate. The committee said MI5 had allowed the case of Mrs Norwood - who had passed nuclear secrets to the Russians - to "slip out of sight" for five years. In its report on the affair published today the committee said that it was a "serious failure by MI5 not to refer the case to the law officers". It said the failure to consult the law officers resulted in the decision whether or not to prosecute Mrs Norwood effectively being taken by the Security Service (MI5). "The committee is concerned that the service used public interest reasons to justify taking no further action against Mrs Norwood when this was for the law officers to decide." The committee also made similar criticisms over MI5's handling of the case of a second Soviet spy in Britain, John Symonds. Mrs Norwood's case only became public last year when a book based on his material by Professor Christopher Andrew was serialized in The Times and featured in a BBC TV series. Mr Straw ordered the committee, chaired by Tory former defence secretary Tom King, to investigate the handling of the affair after a public outcry over the failure to prosecute Mrs Norwood and other spies identified by Mr Mitrokhin. The report strongly criticised the way the book was published and said that the events surrounding the release of the material were "confused".

fields.headline: Tactics, Talent and Telly
fields.trailText: NOT HOME YET
fields.body:
NOT HOME YET

The Fiver is still sick to the stomach this afternoon. How could we not have included a fourth option ("England play alright but are still out-thought and beaten by a better side") amongst yesterday's predictions? Guess we'll never know. Much like Kelvin Koogan, who appears to be completely non-plussed as to why his England side were beaten by Portugal after taking a two-goal lead.

"We both tried to hurt each other by playing football and they won," said Koogan this afternoon, confirming what many onlookers had suspected. Denying that England were tactically lacking, he went on: "I didn't think we underestimated them because we knew what they were about. I didn't think we got the breaks but they played well."

So Koogan knew that Portugal could pass the ball all day, and that their best players were in midfield. Yet he chose to allow England to be outnumbered in this key area of the field in the belief that, by playing to their own strengths, England would win. To be fair, the tactic worked. For 20 minutes. If the lesson of the remaining 70 is that England are not good enough to beat Portugal, then no wonder Koogan is unwilling to learn it.

Koog said today that England will go into Saturday's reasonably-sized game with Germany without the injured pair of Steve McManaman and defensive rock(y) Tony Adams, the latter not even expected to recover in time for the Romanian game. What's more, Koogan insisted: "I have a style of management and that is not going to change. It would be going against myself and my beliefs." So don't expect England to drop the Kick'n'rush v2.0 tactics any time soon. But you never know, it might just work.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEVILLES' HELL

Last night, the talented and attractive England defenders Phil and Gary Neville showcased their skills in front of an amazed European audience. But being able to send the ball spinning into touch with one swing of the shin isn't enough for some people, and seasoned observers are suggesting that Kelvin Koogan should be looking for some other full-backs. Ones with talent, perhaps. But one particularly seasoned observer doesn't agree with such a ridiculous argument.

"The fact that the right is patently Phil's stronger foot invites discussion about whether he is the best choice left-back," bellowed Alex Ferguson in the general direction of the Manchester Evening News today. "There isn't exactly a crowd of outstanding left-footed candidates vying for his place," reasoned Phil's club manager before getting unreasonably bitchy. "Talk of drafting in Gareth Barry of Aston Villa is rash... the boy's pace is unexceptional."

Fergie also had time to stick up for Phil's marginally-better-but-let's-keep-that-in-context brother Gary, who had a not-useless game last night. "Gary's miseries with United in Brazil last January have blinded a lot of people to the general pattern of his form," he kindly explained to all of us too dim to comprehend information ourselves. "I admit I am inclined to be loyal to such a model professional, but loyalty only goes so far." Does that mean we can pick someone else, then? "Ultimately performance decides everything and Gary has performed." Sorry, stupid of us to ask.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"England would sometimes do far better if they played with a goalkeeper. Keegan insists on starting with that piece of meat with eyes called Seaman" - Madrid's AS newspaper offers its independent assessment of the custodian that knocked Spain out of Euro 96.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'LL BE ALL RIGHTS ON TOMORROW NIGHT

Bad news Richard Keys fans, the latest rumour a-burning up the media grapevine suggests that BSkyB may not win the right to screen live Premiership games from the 2001-2 season. Keys, the offspring of a human being and a moustachioed mandrill (hang on, that was a dream), will have to look for new work if his current employers lose the right to fill our face with unnecessary on-screen graphics every other night. And that will be a shame.

An announcement from the Premier League is expected tomorrow as to the winners in the race to snap up various different Premiership rights packages. The most valuable of these is the contract to show 66 live Premiership matches a season. Sky had been earmarked as favourites for this package, as they already hold the contract and have a good working relationship with the clubs. However, an report in London's Evening Standard suggests that each of the main bidders has passed the League's quality control tests and that the winning bid will simply be the one that offers the most money (not too dissimilar to George Graham's old Scandinavian shopping policy).

Usually this would be good news for Sky, what with possessing pockets as deep as an episode of Dawson's Creek. However, cheeky cable upstarts NTL are even more flush (see their tie-up with Rangers below) and are tipped to snatch the rights. If any company bids more than 5% higher than their nearest competitor they win the rights outright (right?). If not then League chief executive Richard Scudamore can ask for more bids. The winners will be announced tomorrow evening. Nervous Mr Keys?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal are tracking £5m-rated Brazilian defender Edmilson. Arsene Wenger apparently sees the Sao Paolo player as a replacement for Tony Adams when he retires, and recently visited South America to examine the player. According to Edmilson: "Wenger talked with me and other players, but if the transfer business does not carry through, the fact there has been interest from a coach such as Arsene already leaves me happy."

Muzzy Izzet has played down speculation linking him with Spurs and Celtic. "I haven't even thought about leaving Leicester," he said. "We have money to spend and we are in the Uefa Cup. We are also having a new stadium built, so things are looking good."

The exodus from Aston Villa continues. Sunderland are interested in Ugo Ehiogu and Steve Watson, and could offer out-of-favour full-back Michael Gray as a make-weight in the deal.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

David Beckham will face no punishment for making a one-fingered gesture to England fans after last night's match in Eindhoven. FA spokesman Steve Double explained: "As the team left the pitch some of the players were subjected to disgusting, foul-mouthed abuse from a small group who we would hesitate to describe as England fans. We would have liked to have seen them arrested for their behaviour. We believe they were drunk."

Rangers have signed a £31m media and commercial partnership with club sponsors NTL. The two parties have also formed a joint venture which will operate any prospective Rangers TV channel as well as internet and e-commerce services. Celtic were rumoured to be making a mirror announcement to Rangers but are still in talks and have announced that teaming up with NTL is not their only possible option.

Huey Lewis and The News have been forced to reschedule a concert in Copenhagen to avoid a clash with Denmark's Euro 2000 match against Holland. "The power of football is stronger than The Power of Love," quipped a spokesman for concert venue Tivoli Gardens, to absolutely no laughter.

Euro 2000 has spawned a betting market with a daily turnover of 100 million leks in Albanian capital Tirana. Some 100 professional gamblers have set up shop in Tirana's Palace of Culture, a relic of the communist past of Europe's poorest nation. The bookies are breaking the law but are unlikely to be disturbed by the police.

Bolton defender Mike Whitlow and midfielder Claus Jensen have been cleared of misconduct charges by the FA. Both players were charged following incidents in Bolton's play-off second leg against Ipswich.

Draw for the first round of the CIS Insurance Cup: Queen of South v Forfar, Peterhead v Inverness CT, East Stirling v Hamilton, Queen's Park v Stranraer, Cowdenbeath v Elgin, Stirling v Stenhousemuir, Partick Thistle v Airdrie, Dumbarton v Ayr, Ross County v Albion, Clyde v Morton, East Fife v Raith, Montrose v Berwick, Clydebank v Alloa, Arbroath v Brechin. Ties to be played August 8-9.

The SFA have threatened serious disciplinary action against Morton if they fail to settle an outstanding debt of £18,979 owed to Hearts. Morton failed to honour a sell-on clause when selling Kevin Thomas to St Johnstone.

Kilmarnock winger David Bagan, 23, has joined Inverness Caledonian Thistle.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Euro 2000 - Live (4.45pm, 1.30am)

Right. Watch Spain and Norway here. Then you've got over half-an-hour to prepare a sandwich and eat it before...

BBC1: Euro 2000 Match of the Day Live (7.30pm)

... you watch Yugoslavia play Slovenia. Once that's done you can do stuff like interact with other humans. We know it's difficult but don't worry - it'll not be long before you can...

ITV: Euro 2000 Today (11.30pm)

... watch both games again in highlight form with Sideshow Bob. At the end of the programme, we recommend a quick shower - you probably reek - but don't spend too much time towelling yourself down after it because...

BBC1: Euro 2000 Replay (12.45am)

... you can dry off wrapped in your gown, watching both matches in their entirety again unless...

ITV: Euro 2000 The Big Match (1.30am)

...you don't want to look like some sort of crazy football obsessive and just decide to watch the Spanish game again instead before creeping off to bed.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football Live (7pm)

They cover sport live, you know, and here's the evidence.

Euro 2000 Extra (10.15pm)

We don't know exactly what this is, but whatever it is there's some more of it.

Euro 2000 Nightclub (11.15pm)

This probably seemed like a good idea at the time.

Sky Sports: aren't even bothering to keep up a pretence of covering Euro 2000. Unlike talkSPORT, that is (hehe).

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (7pm)

Euro Alan!
