fields.headline: You bet your life!
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: More bets have been placed, and there have been more losses than gains. It was a good day for our Friday Flutter man, though, who scooped nearly £30 by predicting a draw in yesterday's column.
fields.body:
More bets have been placed, and there have been more losses than gains. It was a good day for our Friday Flutter man, though, who scooped nearly £30 by predicting a draw in yesterday's column.

The standings now look like this:

Sean Ingle £70.01
Mike Hodgkinson £53.75
Scott Murray £46.67
Paul MacInnes £34

Now for today's selections...

Sean Ingle

Win double: Spain to beat Norway 4/5 and Yugoslavia to beat Slovenia 8/13 (£10)

Yesterday I backed Portugal to beat England, but stupidly tried to predict the correct score as well and ended up with absolutely nothing. So now I've learnt my lesson. Next time it will be different. Honest.

For today's bet I'm backing Yugoslavia and Spain. It's almost too obvious - there's a irrational part of most people that expects the Slovenes to sneak something, or Norway to run Spain close. But in the cold light of day, Yugoslavia should beat Slovenia (who aren't as bad as people suggest but are certainly the weakest team in the tournament). And Spain, despite a tricky run recently, have Raul back, while Norway - without Ronnie Johnsen - lack pace at the back. Eight times out of ten you would favour the Spanish to win.

Both games may be close, but the win double pays just under 3-1 which can't be ignored - which is why I've got a tenner on it.

Mike Hodgkinson

Yugoslavia v Slovenia: First scorer Sinisa Mihajlovic 10-1 (£5)

You wouldn't expect odds so low on a defender to find the net before anyone else but this fella has a free kick that most match commentators compare to heavy artillery. In what promises to be a tough encounter with loads of free kicks, the Lazio man should find more than one opportunity for a dig.

Scott Murray

Yugoslavia v Slovenia: Goals scored 4 or more 9/4 (£10)

This bet is asking for trouble, especially as the tournament hasn't thrown up a goal-less match yet, never mind a shock. But to hell with the law of averages - I can't see Slovenia holding out for too long against a team which contains the likes of Predrag Mijatovic and Sinisa Mihajlovic. And if Zlatko Zahovic, the Slovenian goal-crazy midfielder we've heard so much about, can pop in a consolation goal or two, that'll help the goals tally nicely.

Paul MacInnes

Spain v Norway: Draw 2/1 (£4)

Good. Fantastic. How could England throw away two goals when I had so much riding on it? It's typical of the youth of today, no respect. Anyway, I must wager again, albeit this time with slightly less cash.

Norway, Spain and Yugoslavia will all be looking to fill one of the top two places in group C. Which means an opening match defeat could prove critical. My £4 therefore goes on a draw between Spain and Norway. The Norwegians can stifle for fun, and Spain would surely be happy with a solid start in an international tournament. A draw, yes, that will work.

webTitle: Sick pay stopped for PC cleared of assault

fields.headline: Sick pay stopped for PC cleared of assault
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard has stopped the sick pay of a black woman officer who has been off work with trauma and stress after a court acquitted her of assaulting a police sergeant.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard has stopped the sick pay of a black woman officer who has been off work with trauma and stress after a court acquitted her of assaulting a police sergeant.

PC Joy Hendricks was cleared of attacking the fellow officer with a snooker cue after telling a court that she had acted in self defence after suffering racial abuse from within the force.

Black police leaders last night branded as a disgrace the Metropolitan police's decision to axe Ms Hendricks's sick pay.

The case highlights concerns over the Met's commitment to stamp out discrimination after the Stephen Lawrence report.

Last week the force agreed a £1m settlement with former PC Sarah Locker who left alleging years of sexual and racial discrimination.

The decision to stop Ms Hendricks's sick pay was made by Assistant Commissioner Ian Johnston and is said to have left Ms Hendricks "devastated". She had been off work since March 1999 through illness which, she says, was caused by years of racist and sexual taunts.

Sergeant Mark Workman testified before Horseferry Road magistrates court that Ms Hendricks had assaulted him, and his version was supported by another male officer.

But last August magistrate Eleri Rees acquitted Ms Hendricks, who told the court Sgt Workman had described her as "dodgy" and as "Stevie Lawrence two".

"I thought he was going to hit me with the snooker cue so I punched him," Ms Hendricks told the court. The magistrate also said the evidence of another officer, PC Christopher Blair, had left her "troubled".

Scotland Yard has not given Ms Hendricks an explanation as to why her wages were stopped, but it does have discretion to continue paying them.

Ali Dezai, who represented the officer in the hearing with Mr Johnston, said: "Joy Hendricks is suffering from trauma and stress resulting from the court case and years of sexual and racial taunts.

"She feels terrible and unsupported. Her pay being cut was the last straw. She's been left with nothing to live on."

Ms Hendricks is considering suing the Met for the suffering she says she endured both before and as a result of the criminal case she faced.

David Michaels, chairman of the Metropolitan section of the Black Police Association, said: ""When somebody is under medical supervision and a doctor says they are not fit for duty, how can Scotland Yard say they are.

"When a police officer is in the dock accused of serious criminal offences, they are suspended on full pay. In this case Scotland Yard are stopping her pay when she is not accused of anything."

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We will not discuss individual cases and details of pay status are confidential to the officer concerned."

Scotland Yard has not given Ms Hendricks an explanation as to why her wages were stopped, but it does have discretion to continue paying them. Ali Dezai, who represented the officer in the hearing with Mr Johnston, said: "Joy Hendricks is suffering from trauma and stress resulting from the court case and years of sexual and racial taunts. "She feels terrible and unsupported. Her pay being cut was the last straw. She's been left with nothing to live on." Ms Hendricks is considering suing the Met for the suffering she says she endured both before and as a result of the criminal case she faced. David Michaels, chairman of the Metropolitan section of the Black Police Association, said: ""When somebody is under medical supervision and a doctor says they are not fit for duty, how can Scotland Yard say they are. "When a police officer is in the dock accused of serious criminal offences, they are suspended on full pay. In this case Scotland Yard are stopping her pay when she is not accused of anything." A Scotland Yard spokeswoman said: "We will not discuss individual cases and details of pay status are confidential to the officer concerned."

fields.headline: Tactics, Talent and Telly
fields.trailText: NOT HOME YET
fields.body:
NOT HOME YET

The Fiver is still sick to the stomach this afternoon. How could we not have included a fourth option ("England play alright but are still out-thought and beaten by a better side") amongst yesterday's predictions? Guess we'll never know. Much like Kelvin Koogan, who appears to be completely non-plussed as to why his England side were beaten by Portugal after taking a two-goal lead.

"We both tried to hurt each other by playing football and they won," said Koogan this afternoon, confirming what many onlookers had suspected. Denying that England were tactically lacking, he went on: "I didn't think we underestimated them because we knew what they were about. I didn't think we got the breaks but they played well."

So Koogan knew that Portugal could pass the ball all day, and that their best players were in midfield. Yet he chose to allow England to be outnumbered in this key area of the field in the belief that, by playing to their own strengths, England would win. To be fair, the tactic worked. For 20 minutes. If the lesson of the remaining 70 is that England are not good enough to beat Portugal, then no wonder Koogan is unwilling to learn it.

Koog said today that England will go into Saturday's reasonably-sized game with Germany without the injured pair of Steve McManaman and defensive rock(y) Tony Adams, the latter not even expected to recover in time for the Romanian game. What's more, Koogan insisted: "I have a style of management and that is not going to change. It would be going against myself and my beliefs." So don't expect England to drop the Kick'n'rush v2.0 tactics any time soon. But you never know, it might just work.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEVILLES' HELL

Last night, the talented and attractive England defenders Phil and Gary Neville showcased their skills in front of an amazed European audience. But being able to send the ball spinning into touch with one swing of the shin isn't enough for some people, and seasoned observers are suggesting that Kelvin Koogan should be looking for some other full-backs. Ones with talent, perhaps. But one particularly seasoned observer doesn't agree with such a ridiculous argument.

"The fact that the right is patently Phil's stronger foot invites discussion about whether he is the best choice left-back," bellowed Alex Ferguson in the general direction of the Manchester Evening News today. "There isn't exactly a crowd of outstanding left-footed candidates vying for his place," reasoned Phil's club manager before getting unreasonably bitchy. "Talk of drafting in Gareth Barry of Aston Villa is rash... the boy's pace is unexceptional."

Fergie also had time to stick up for Phil's marginally-better-but-let's-keep-that-in-context brother Gary, who had a not-useless game last night. "Gary's miseries with United in Brazil last January have blinded a lot of people to the general pattern of his form," he kindly explained to all of us too dim to comprehend information ourselves. "I admit I am inclined to be loyal to such a model professional, but loyalty only goes so far." Does that mean we can pick someone else, then? "Ultimately performance decides everything and Gary has performed." Sorry, stupid of us to ask.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"England would sometimes do far better if they played with a goalkeeper. Keegan insists on starting with that piece of meat with eyes called Seaman" - Madrid's AS newspaper offers its independent assessment of the custodian that knocked Spain out of Euro 96.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'LL BE ALL RIGHTS ON TOMORROW NIGHT

Bad news Richard Keys fans, the latest rumour a-burning up the media grapevine suggests that BSkyB may not win the right to screen live Premiership games from the 2001-2 season. Keys, the offspring of a human being and a moustachioed mandrill (hang on, that was a dream), will have to look for new work if his current employers lose the right to fill our face with unnecessary on-screen graphics every other night. And that will be a shame.

An announcement from the Premier League is expected tomorrow as to the winners in the race to snap up various different Premiership rights packages. The most valuable of these is the contract to show 66 live Premiership matches a season. Sky had been earmarked as favourites for this package, as they already hold the contract and have a good working relationship with the clubs. However, an report in London's Evening Standard suggests that each of the main bidders has passed the League's quality control tests and that the winning bid will simply be the one that offers the most money (not too dissimilar to George Graham's old Scandinavian shopping policy).

Usually this would be good news for Sky, what with possessing pockets as deep as an episode of Dawson's Creek. However, cheeky cable upstarts NTL are even more flush (see their tie-up with Rangers below) and are tipped to snatch the rights. If any company bids more than 5% higher than their nearest competitor they win the rights outright (right?). If not then League chief executive Richard Scudamore can ask for more bids. The winners will be announced tomorrow evening. Nervous Mr Keys?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsenal are tracking £5m-rated Brazilian defender Edmilson. Arsene Wenger apparently sees the Sao Paolo player as a replacement for Tony Adams when he retires, and recently visited South America to examine the player. According to Edmilson: "Wenger talked with me and other players, but if the transfer business does not carry through, the fact there has been interest from a coach such as Arsene already leaves me happy."

Muzzy Izzet has played down speculation linking him with Spurs and Celtic. "I haven't even thought about leaving Leicester," he said. "We have money to spend and we are in the Uefa Cup. We are also having a new stadium built, so things are looking good."

The exodus from Aston Villa continues. Sunderland are interested in Ugo Ehiogu and Steve Watson, and could offer out-of-favour full-back Michael Gray as a make-weight in the deal.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

David Beckham will face no punishment for making a one-fingered gesture to England fans after last night's match in Eindhoven. FA spokesman Steve Double explained: "As the team left the pitch some of the players were subjected to disgusting, foul-mouthed abuse from a small group who we would hesitate to describe as England fans. We would have liked to have seen them arrested for their behaviour. We believe they were drunk."

Rangers have signed a £31m media and commercial partnership with club sponsors NTL. The two parties have also formed a joint venture which will operate any prospective Rangers TV channel as well as internet and e-commerce services. Celtic were rumoured to be making a mirror announcement to Rangers but are still in talks and have announced that teaming up with NTL is not their only possible option.

Huey Lewis and The News have been forced to reschedule a concert in Copenhagen to avoid a clash with Denmark's Euro 2000 match against Holland. "The power of football is stronger than The Power of Love," quipped a spokesman for concert venue Tivoli Gardens, to absolutely no laughter.

Euro 2000 has spawned a betting market with a daily turnover of 100 million leks in Albanian capital Tirana. Some 100 professional gamblers have set up shop in Tirana's Palace of Culture, a relic of the communist past of Europe's poorest nation. The bookies are breaking the law but are unlikely to be disturbed by the police.

Bolton defender Mike Whitlow and midfielder Claus Jensen have been cleared of misconduct charges by the FA. Both players were charged following incidents in Bolton's play-off second leg against Ipswich.

Draw for the first round of the CIS Insurance Cup: Queen of South v Forfar, Peterhead v Inverness CT, East Stirling v Hamilton, Queen's Park v Stranraer, Cowdenbeath v Elgin, Stirling v Stenhousemuir, Partick Thistle v Airdrie, Dumbarton v Ayr, Ross County v Albion, Clyde v Morton, East Fife v Raith, Montrose v Berwick, Clydebank v Alloa, Arbroath v Brechin. Ties to be played August 8-9.

The SFA have threatened serious disciplinary action against Morton if they fail to settle an outstanding debt of £18,979 owed to Hearts. Morton failed to honour a sell-on clause when selling Kevin Thomas to St Johnstone.

Kilmarnock winger David Bagan, 23, has joined Inverness Caledonian Thistle.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Euro 2000 - Live (4.45pm, 1.30am)

Right. Watch Spain and Norway here. Then you've got over half-an-hour to prepare a sandwich and eat it before...

BBC1: Euro 2000 Match of the Day Live (7.30pm)

... you watch Yugoslavia play Slovenia. Once that's done you can do stuff like interact with other humans. We know it's difficult but don't worry - it'll not be long before you can...

ITV: Euro 2000 Today (11.30pm)

... watch both games again in highlight form with Sideshow Bob. At the end of the programme, we recommend a quick shower - you probably reek - but don't spend too much time towelling yourself down after it because...

BBC1: Euro 2000 Replay (12.45am)

... you can dry off wrapped in your gown, watching both matches in their entirety again unless...

ITV: Euro 2000 The Big Match (1.30am)

...you don't want to look like some sort of crazy football obsessive and just decide to watch the Spanish game again instead before creeping off to bed.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football Live (7pm)

They cover sport live, you know, and here's the evidence.

Euro 2000 Extra (10.15pm)

We don't know exactly what this is, but whatever it is there's some more of it.

Euro 2000 Nightclub (11.15pm)

This probably seemed like a good idea at the time.

Sky Sports: aren't even bothering to keep up a pretence of covering Euro 2000. Unlike talkSPORT, that is (hehe).

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (7pm)

Euro Alan!

fields.headline: Cow's milk and cancer
fields.standfirst: A new book suggests that cutting out dairy produce can reduce the risk of breast cancer.  Gillian Ross examines the evidence
fields.trailText: A new book suggests that cutting out dairy produce can reduce the risk of breast cancer. Gillian Ross examines the evidence
fields.body:
Environmental and lifestyle factors are estimated to play a part in 80% of all common cancers. So when a breast cancer survivor with a scientific background publishes a book about her own illness and her views on the role of diet and other lifestyle factors in helping to control it, it is inevitable that it produces interest from both the media and the public.

Jane Plant, the author of Your Life in Your Hands, is a geophysicist whose breast cancer relapsed in lymph glands in her neck. She sensibly underwent conventional chemotherapy - but at the same time, she withdrew dairy produce from her diet. In trying to understand why she had developed breast cancer, she began reading widely on the subject and noticed that women in China and Japan - where dairy consumption is low - have a significantly lower risk of developing breast cancer than women in western countries. So she had her number one cause: dairy produce. And having found it, she came up with a detailed theory, involving bovine hormones, about why cow's milk might cause breast cancer.

But this is far too simplistic. The fact is that, in 20 years of study, countless doctors, environmental scientists and nutritionists have failed to find simple relationships between diet and cancer risk around the world. Dietary fat content has been given particular attention, as some countries traditionally consume much less animal produce than others. Even research involving large numbers of women has not clarified a role for animal fat or dairy produce in breast cancer, but by studying women from ethnic populations with low rates of cancer, researchers have identified factors that may help cut down cancer.

One factor is a diet high in soy produce, a food that is rich in chemicals called isoflavones, which mimic some of the activity of the female hormone oestrogen and may act to block the stimulatory action of oestrogen on the breast. Women in these populations also tend to be significantly less overweight than their western counterparts, partly due to lower overall calorie intake and higher levels of physical activity, both factors also known to reduce breast cancer risk. They also drink little or no alcohol, do not smoke and on average start their families a decade earlier than modern, westernised women - all recognised risk factors for breast cancer.

Another key point is that some cultures with low consumption of dairy produce have similar breast cancer rates to those in the west. The Indian state of Kerala is a good example of the complexity of interactions of risk factors. There, women eat virtually no dairy or animal produce, but very high levels of female education mean the average age of marriage is 23 and women have their first pregnancies 10 years later than women in some other Indian states, where dietary habits are very similar but risks of breast cancer are much lower.

Hormonal factors remain the most significant and best understood of the metabolic risks for breast cancer. Early menstruation, late menopause and late or no pregnancy are all known to increase risk, but by relatively small levels compared with the "average" woman. It is equally likely that these factors also interact with other lifestyle factors, such as exercise levels, smoking and alcohol consumption, to modify risk over many decades.

I am concerned by this new book for two reasons: it is not based on proper research and in western diets, dairy produce is a major source of nutrients such as calcium. We don't want cancer patients making radical changes to their diets without proper nutritional advice from experts.

Gillian Ross is a senior lecturer in oncology at the Institute of Cancer Research and a consultant in clinical oncology at the Royal Marsden Hospital's breast unit. For more information, call Cancer BACUP on 0808 800 1234.

fields.headline: In the name of beauty
fields.standfirst: Last week 5,000 women were told to have their soya bean breast implants taken out. What few would have realised when they signed up for surgery was that such devices do not undergo clinical trials: they are never tested on people.  Sarah Boseley  reports
fields.trailText: Last week 5,000 women were told to have their soya bean breast implants taken out. What few would have realised when they signed up for surgery was that such devices do not undergo clinical trials: they are never tested on people.
fields.body:
Nipples that leak yellowish toxic yoghurt; an implant a surgeon kept in the back of a drawer and which now smells like an old chip-fryer - these were some of the stomach-churning insights into the artificial beauty business that emerged when the department of health last week advised 5,000 women with soya bean breast implants to have them taken out.

The oil, promoted as a natural alternative to the vilified silicone, may potentially degrade into toxic aldehydes that can cause cancer and birth defects. Beauty is only skin deep indeed. How many women are now left fearfully wondering what is happening underneath their enhanced curves, the D-cup of their dreams? Are their breasts stealthily seeping fermenting carcinogenic fluid? It's like a horror movie in the worst possible taste.

There has always been this powerful Frankenstein element about cosmetic surgery. The quest for beauty beyond our genetic inheritance or youth in spite of advancing time can go grotesquely wrong. Labour MP Ann Clwyd, who has been campaigning against cowboy cosmetic surgery clinics for the best part of a decade, has an enormous file of scarred and mutilated women.

"The result was dreadful, resulting in to date five operations to try to rectify the damage he had done," says one. Another speaks of "unbearable pain during surgery, tattoo scars on bellybutton and hips and post-traumatic stress disorder".

Yet even major scandals like that of the Trilucent soya bean implants seem unlikely to stem the flow of candidates for the knife. Barry Jones, president of the Association of Aesthetic Plastic Surgeons, who was on the committee that recommended removal of the implants, does not think it will have any impact. "Although common sense might say 'yes', history would say 'no'," he says. "Breast enhancement is a very common and popular operation. Body contour is very important to some people. There are a number of women who are quite disturbed by it."

The 40 women who have had Trilucent implants at his clinic all received a letter from him on the day of the announcement, inviting them to come and see him and discuss what happens next - they are the lucky ones, because most will have found out via the newspapers and television. Advice from the Medical Devices Agency, which regulates implants, was that the women should not get pregnant or breastfeed until they have been taken out.

Among Mr Jones's cohort are one who has had a baby and another who is pregnant. "They are anxious," he says with an element of under-statement. The anxiety will be worsened because he believes nothing immediate can be done. "I think the right advice is to wait until the breast is not post-pregnancy anymore. Surgery on a lactating breast is quite risky."

He will do his best to reassure them, because his personal belief is that the Trilucent implants are not a problem until they rupture and the oil meets air and oxidises - which will only happen outside the breast. He wants to involve either the MDA's scientists or the manufacturers in research on the 40 or so implants he will be removing to test the theory. "When something like this happens, for the individual concerned it is an unfortunate event, but if we don't learn from it, it is even more unfortunate," he says.

Many women with Trilucent implants will no doubt be thinking of replacing them with silicone or saline. Yet the MDA had no advice for them whatsoever last week. Under heavy questioning Dr Susanne Ludgate, medical director of the MDA, stuck to her statement that they had no evidence as to whether or not it was safe to put in a different kind of implant once the soya bean oil device had been removed. Her argument may be scientifically immaculate, but the women affected may well feel deserted. They are advised to talk to their surgeon, but how are they to trust the cosmetic surgery clinic that sold them their safe and super-natural carcinogenic implant?

The fiasco has illuminated a major problem - implants are not licensed. Although these foreign objects which can and do leak and rupture are to be inserted inside a woman's body, they do not have to be tested on people before they come on the market. They do not undergo clinical trials, as drugs must. Instead, they are given the CE mark - a kitemark that shows they meet a European standard, just like cuddly toys and dishwashers.

There are a number of commercial agencies around Europe, although mostly in Germany and the UK, that can hand out this kitemark, and they are approved by governmental bodies like the MDA here. But if TUV Munich - as happened with Trilucent - says an implant is OK, under European law the UK government is not supposed to interfere with it being sold here.

Some countries don't play the game. "The French just say 'non'," says Mr Jones. They make unilateral decisions. Like the United States, they banned silicone breast implants. But the UK sticks to the rules. The MDA now says it is pressing Europe to strengthen them, and to introduce a requirement for clinical trials for implants. None too soon.

The House of Commons health select committee expressed many anxieties two years ago about misleading advertisements, inadequate information to customers and under-trained surgeons.

The government now says it will tackle some of these issues in the forthcoming Care Standards Bill. Why else do the clinics universally require payment in advance?

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Make them buzz off
fields.body:
Make them buzz off

Q I will shortly be travelling through Thailand and Indonesia. I have read that taking vitamin B1 supplements makes your skin less tasty to mosquitoes. I would like to know if this is true.

A I couldn't find any malaria experts who'd heard of vitamin B1 acting as a mosquito deterrant - you may be on to a great discovery there. Apparently, mosquitos that transmit malaria only bite from dusk until dawn. That means long-sleeved T-shirts, and trousers tucked into socks from the moment the sun goes down. Sleeping under a mosquito net, especially one sprayed with the chemical permethrin, is a good idea, as is burning a coil which releases smoke and rubbing repellent creams onto exposed bits. I'd want to take antimalarial drugs as recommended by a GP surgery or travel clinic.

Baby infection

Q I was alarmed by a recent episode of Coronation Street in which a newborn baby died from an infection picked up from its mother during labour. I understand this infection can lie dormant in the mother and not be detected. I'm pregnant with my first baby and am very worried. Can you reassure me?

A Coronation Street has highlighted a potentially serious bacterial infection called Group B streptococcus (GBS for short). Estimates vary, but around 5-10% of us carry this bug. A tiny but unpredictable proportion of pregnant women carry a virulent type in their vagina which can pass to the baby during labour, causing life-threatening blood poisoning (septicaemia) to mother and baby. GBS can be detected by a vaginal swab. It is treated by giving antibiotics into a vein during labour. Treating it earlier in pregnancy with oral antibiotics is too unreliable. Only those considered to be at high risk are screened in this country: pregnant women with vaginal discharge; evidence of GBS - eg in the urine; those who get a sudden temperature during labour or those who've had previous unexplained rupture of membranes and premature labour. It is likely that all pregnant women will soon be offered a vaginal swab. Meanwhile, anyone who wants the test should ask.

For more info: www.gbss.org.uk

Trussed up

Q I've got hernia in my groin and have been told to have it operated on. I'm terrified of hospitals and wondered if I could get a truss.

A Chances are you've got an inguinal hernia; a bulging of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall. Hernias never just go away and always get bigger with the passage of time. Trusses are uncomfortable and very unfashionable-aesthetically and medically. I'd get the hernia repaired as soon as possible; if you're generally fit you should be able to have day case surgery and spend very little time in hospital.

It's in the blood

Q I'm a 52 year old man with high blood pressure that seems particularly difficult to treat. My GP said that it was because I'm black, which I found offensive.

A The remark almost certainly wasn't meant to sound offensive, but why not tell your GP how it made you feel? The fact is that many caucasians with high blood pressure have high levels of renin, a hormone produced by the kidneys. Two groups of drugs commonly used to treat high blood pressure, beta blockers and ACE inhibitors, work by lowering this renin level. But many black people share an inherited disposition to low renin levels and so these drugs don't tend to work well. Thiazide diuretics such as bendrofluazide, or a calcium channel blocker such as nifedipine, can work more effectively. Meanwhile, restrict salt, cut down on alcohol, exercise regularly, lose excess weight and cut down on cholesterol and smoking.

Fair, fat and 40?

Q My mum developed gallstones and had to have her gallbladder removed. What can I do to prevent them?

AI was taught at medical school that gallstones afflict those who are "fair (ie female), fat and 40". But a recent US study showed that the higher your intake of vitamin C, the less your risk of gallstones.

These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Burning issues
fields.standfirst: Summer's on its way - and with it comes the hotly-contested question of whether it's safe to do the odd bit of sunbathing.  Jane Bartlett  finds powerful arguments for and against baring our flesh
fields.trailText: Summer's on its way - and with it comes the hotly-contested question of whether it's safe to do the odd bit of sunbathing. Jane Bartlett finds powerful arguments for and against baring our flesh
fields.body:
Here comes summer, just about, and despite years of vigorous health campaigns many of us will still be surrendering our milky-white bodies to the mercy of the sun. We find it hard to give up burning our flesh, even though it is now as much maligned as smoking or stuffing down cream cakes. One 1997 survey showed that despite high levels of awareness about the dangers, more than a third of men and around half of women who did not have a naturally black or brown skin had tried to get a tan the previous year.

Ironically, people say that a good roasting improves their sense of wellbeing, and that a tan makes them feel healthy, sexy even. Are they right? Could sunbathing be good for us? If this article were being written in the early 1900s the health-giving aspects of the sun would be exalted.

It was found during the first world war that wounds healed quicker if left exposed to the sun, and patients with tuberculosis were healed in clinics where they were wheeled out onto balconies or into solariums. In the 1930s, sunbathing was encouraged as a public health measure. Heliotherapy (sun therapy) was also used to treat rickets, burns, varicose ulcers, osteomyelitis (an infection of bone), septic abscesses, anaemia and fractures.

Archive photographs of sunbathing hospital patients now look bizarre in an era when we are told that there is no such thing as a healthy tan and that we should cake ourselves in SFP 15 sunscreen and avoid exposure between 11am and 3pm. Those, however, were the days before antibiotics, when anything that apparently boosted the immune system had to be taken very seriously.

Sunlight has the ability to kill bacteria, even when it passes through glass, and it has been found that patients recover faster in sunny hospital wards. "In the right hands, sunlight is a medicine," claims Richard Hobday, author of The Healing Sun (Findhorn Press £9.95), a new book which explores the beneficial effect of sun on our health, and hopes to redress what the author sees as our current bias against sunlight. "Each year lack of sunlight probably kills many thousands more people in this country and others at similar latitudes than skin cancer," he says.

The sun is certainly a natural healer, so it's not surprising that this call for its reinstatement comes from those whose sympathies are based in complementary therapy: Hobday is trained in traditional Chinese medicine, and the book is published by Findhorn, the New Age community in Scotland.

However, his dramatic assertions are also echoed by four epidemiologists from the department of social medicine at Bristol University. Their article "Are we really dying for a tan?", published in the British Medical Journal last summer, controversially claimed that "the exact nature of the association between malignant melanoma and exposure to sunlight has to be determined", and that "there is evidence that the potential benefits of exposure to sunlight may outweigh the widely publicised adverse effects on the incidence of skin cancer".

Hobday, who is a doctor of engineering, became interested in sunlight as medicine when investigating solar energy technologies, and learnt of a lost tradition of designing sunlit buildings to prevent disease. "Also I am particularly fond of sunbathing and only feel fit and well when I have a tan," he says.

The fact that sunlight enables us to manufacture vitamin D is key to its health giving properties. Vitamin D is essential for the growth and maintenance of teeth and bones and a healthy immune system. In Britain we get only a quarter of it from diet (the main sources are margarines and dairy spreads, fatty fish, breakfast cereal and eggs), and the rest from the sun. The evidence is sketchy, but a vitamin D deficiency may be linked to a long list of ailments, including osteoporosis, heart disease, diabetes, and cancer.

On skin cancer, of which there are now about 40,000 new cases every year in the UK, Hobday points out rather lightly that the non-melanoma variety, which accounts for a vast number of cases, doesn't matter too much because it is treatable. Malignant melanoma, (about 4,000 cases annually) he argues, is most prevalent amongst people who spend long periods indoors and then go for the burn on their two-week holidays, rather than people who work outdoors.

Writing for the British Medical Journal in response to "Are we really dying for a tan?", Professor Hawk, an expert in dermatological photobiology at London's St Thomas's Hospital, argues that the "warmth and light of sunlight are the only rays we need, and ultraviolet radiation exposure is definitely harmful to human skin". He says vitamin D is readily available in the normal diet and "there is therefore no evidence whatsoever that ultraviolet radiation avoidance leads to vitamin D deficiency".

Hobday argues that there are no internationally agreed figures for the amount of vitamin D required to stay healthy. He is dismayed that we have to rely on fortified foods to keep up supplies. "There is a great deal to be said for getting out in the sun for short periods during the spring and summer," he says.

So should we dare to bare? The International Smart Tan Network is an American organisation which promotes moderate suntanning and sunbed use. Joseph Levy, its director argues that "sun abstinence only makes people more likely to sunburn when they do go outdoors", and that the gradual development of a moderate tan is the best and natural way to protect ourselves from the sun.

If we do decide that public health messages have become too cautionary, it would be unwise to strip off with abandon. Professor Anthony Quinn, a dermatologist at the Royal London Hospital, doesn't see how the benefits outweigh the risks. "I don't think we are being cautious enough," he says.

Even Hobday advocates a highly restricted sunbathing routine. For starters, you need to stay cool. According to the heliotherapists of yesteryear, particularly Dr Auguste Rollier, who became known as the "high priest of sunlight therapy", you must sunbathe in cool conditions so that your body is simultaneously trying to generate heat. This is believed to be more therapeutic. Air temperature shouldn't be higher than 18C or 64F, which means that spring, early summer and autumn are the optimum times, and you need to find a sheltered spot if you are to avoid goose bumps.

Early morning sun is the best, and frequent short exposures are better than long periods. Don't wear sun creams, but protect the delicate skin on the face by wearing a hat. If you are very sensitive to the sun you might try the "Rollier method": cover yourself with a white sheet, and on the first day raise it to just above the ankles for five minutes. On subsequent days repeat, progressively unrolling the sheet upwards.

Sunlight in moderation it may be good for...

Brittle bones Sunlight deprivation has been linked to weak bones. Vitamin D deficiency is linked with increased risk of hip fracture. Bone density is at its lowest in the winter.

Rickets Very rare today, but develops when people are deprived of sunlight.

Tuberculosis Sunlight can help prevent it developing in susceptible individuals by keeping up their vitamin D levels. It can also prevent spread of the disease by killing bacteria in the home.

Cancer Vitamin D is involved in the growth and maturation of cells. In laboratory experiments the biologically active form of vitamin D has been shown to inhibit the growth of cancer cells. Although sunlight can cause skin cancers, studies have shown that the nearer you live to the equator the less chance you have of developing an internal cancer.

Heart disease Sunlight is effective in lowering blood pressure and cholesterol levels.

Diabetes Vitamin D has been shown to have a protective effect against childhood diabetes.

Psoriasis Heliotherapy can help clear up this skin condition.

Mental health People enjoy sitting in the sun. Seasonal variations in sunlight may underlie a proportion of episodes of depression. Suicide rates rise in winter.

Even Hobday advocates a highly restricted sunbathing routine. For starters, you need to stay cool. According to the heliotherapists of yesteryear, particularly Dr Auguste Rollier, who became known as the "high priest of sunlight therapy", you must sunbathe in cool conditions so that your body is simultaneously trying to generate heat. This is believed to be more therapeutic. Air temperature shouldn't be higher than 18C or 64F, which means that spring, early summer and autumn are the optimum times, and you need to find a sheltered spot if you are to avoid goose bumps. Early morning sun is the best, and frequent short exposures are better than long periods. Don't wear sun creams, but protect the delicate skin on the face by wearing a hat. If you are very sensitive to the sun you might try the "Rollier method": cover yourself with a white sheet, and on the first day raise it to just above the ankles for five minutes. On subsequent days repeat, progressively unrolling the sheet upwards. Sunlight in moderation it may be good for... Brittle bones Sunlight deprivation has been linked to weak bones. Vitamin D deficiency is linked with increased risk of hip fracture. Bone density is at its lowest in the winter. Rickets Very rare today, but develops when people are deprived of sunlight. Tuberculosis Sunlight can help prevent it developing in susceptible individuals by keeping up their vitamin D levels. It can also prevent spread of the disease by killing bacteria in the home. Cancer Vitamin D is involved in the growth and maturation of cells. In laboratory experiments the biologically active form of vitamin D has been shown to inhibit the growth of cancer cells. Although sunlight can cause skin cancers, studies have shown that the nearer you live to the equator the less chance you have of developing an internal cancer. Heart disease Sunlight is effective in lowering blood pressure and cholesterol levels. Diabetes Vitamin D has been shown to have a protective effect against childhood diabetes. Psoriasis Heliotherapy can help clear up this skin condition. Mental health People enjoy sitting in the sun. Seasonal variations in sunlight may underlie a proportion of episodes of depression. Suicide rates rise in winter.

fields.headline: An unhealthy debt
fields.standfirst: Private finance initiatives in the NHS force some hospitals to waste millions covering unforeseen shortfalls in obscure 'financing costs'
fields.trailText: Private finance initiatives in the NHS force some hospitals to waste millions covering unforeseen shortfalls in obscure 'financing costs'
fields.body:
A large chunk of the billions promised to the National Health Service is not going to be used to treat patients, pay nurses, buy orthopaedic beds or even wipe out the accumulated debt of recent years. Instead it will disappear into the black hole in the state's accounts opened by the Private Finance Initiative (PFI). How much nobody yet knows. But if a new study* in microscopic detail of one health area is anything to go by, hundreds of millions of Labour government largesse will be needed to pay the "financing costs" of PFI deals. PFI may yet become the ultimate revenge of the capitalist system on public provision by extracting an annual toll for banks, consultants and brokers of the order of 15% of the annual cost of maintaining hospitals. Of course the NHS would have had to borrow to finance new hospitals - it is a question of how much extra. For decades to come, up to 10p in every pound of tax money intended for healthcare will be channelled to financial institutions as a result of PFI.

A team led by Professor Allyson Pollock examined Worcester health authority's (WHA) plans for the rebuilding of Worcester royal infirmary under a PFI deal conceived during the Tory era. It is already having consequences for the area. The general hospital in Kidderminster is being scaled down - 19 seats on the local council are now held by independents opposed to what is effectively its closure. Worcestershire is an area already under-served in terms of acute beds; once the PFI deal kicks in (the new hospital is due to open in 2002) the relative number of such beds will fall further, to just over half the English average. So much for PFI being an agent of expanded healthcare.

The Worcester PFI was born in the worst of circumstances - as elsewhere - as a way of getting off the hook of a large and growing annual shortfall in funds. By selling off land, closing beds and focusing care in a revamped general hospital in Worcester, the idea was to restore the county to an even financial keel. In 1996 the board of Worcester royal infirmary committed itself to rebuilding the hospital. The site would be sold and the work done by a consortium including Bovis, the British Linen Bank and others; the hospital board would then lease the building back over 30 years, paying an annual charge. The theory of PFI is that even though the private sector's costs of raising capital are greater than if the state borrowed directly, the running costs are going to be lower because of private sector efficiencies.

It is this financial arithmetic that worries Professor Pollock most. While it was being negotiated, the PFI deal inflated. In 1996 it was going to cost £49m after land sales. By the time it got going last year, as the chart shows, costs had risen by over 100%. The hospital has never explained why. That is perhaps because the answer is "financing costs" of nearly £30m - fees paid to agents, interests on loans during the building work.

The upshot will be that every year from now on Worcester royal infirmary will be required to meet a charge up to 16% of its annual income. This is excessive, say the academics, since as recently as 1998, the notional cost of capital imposed by the Treasury was only 9.4%.

Making ends meet is going to present the WHA with acute problems leaving aside its need to cope with a pre-existing deficit. The government is putting money in specifically to "smooth" the impact of PFI costs. Worcester HA has also stepped in to help the hospital by making extensive savings elsewhere. The PFI has only become viable because the Kidderminster hospital will lose its inpatients. (It will not formally close but become an "ambulatory" centre, treating outpatients only.) Even that is not going to be enough. The sums are only going to come within spitting distance of balance if there are cuts in the number of beds in the royal infirmary itself.

Much of this has only been winkled out of the accounts with difficulty. The projections have gaps in them. Executives will not or cannot answer some basic questions about future bed numbers. When asked, health ministers give answers that "cannot be substantiated and are meaningless for NHS planning purposes". What now looks certain is that Worcester royal infirmary itself, the very point of the PFI deal, will end up with fewer acute beds than it had before - yet it is meant to be serving a wider catchment area, including Kidderminster. The PFI hospital will have fewer bodies, a 17% cut in the number of nurses and a 31% cut in the number of ancillary staff. This smaller staff will, however, have to treat patients more quickly, "admitting and discharging patients faster than ever before". Worcester will shunt elderly patients out "into the community", to be cared for - or, more aptly, paid for - by local authority social services or themselves.

Perhaps Worcester is not typical. Perhaps elsewhere PFI hospitals will lower outlays and produce better healthcare. But meanwhile something disturbing has happened. "Instead of providing a service fit for the 21st century, Worcester is embarking on an ill-advised attempt that will decrease the availability of NHS care, forcing residents to compete for care, to go privately or do without." Major changes in services are taking place without public knowledge of options, let alone consent.

Report details:
*Deficits Before Patients, Allyson Pollock , David Price, Matthew Dunnigan, University College, London: www.ucl.ac.uk/spp

fields.headline: Internet monitoring 'time bomb' for e-commerce
fields.standfirst:
Allowing MI5 to monitor people's internet habits goes further than George Orwell's worst nightmare argues Online editor Victor Keegan
Lords to fight email tap bill
fields.trailText: A new bill allowing MI5 to monitor people's internet habits goes further than George Orwell's worst nightmare argues Online editor Victor Keegan
fields.body:
Anyone who has been following it has long known that the government's RIP (Regulation of Investigatory Powers) bill is a time bomb waiting to explode.

The government has casually brushed aside strong objections of civil liberty lobbies on the grounds they don't have many votes. It is only - at the eleventh hour - when business has suddenly woken up to the dangers it presents to e-commerce that the government is being forced to take serious notice.

It reads like a script that would have been deemed unrealistic for an update of the film 1984. Under the terms of the bill - which is going through its committee stage in the Lords this week - every internet service provider will have to install a black box with a direct line to MI5.

This would enable the intelligence authorities to monitor the pattern (though not the content) of all our emails and internet habits and chat room visits - who we send emails to and which web sites we visit.

Further powers enable the authorities on production of a warrant to demand our passwords or encryption keys under pain of two years in jail. If you have forgotten your password (a daily occurrence for many net users) then you will be presumed guilty until proved innocent by the courts.

Bang goes another principle of British justice - that a person is innocent until proved guilty.

If MI5 demand that you hand over your personal or corporate encryption key then you could be liable for five years imprisonment if you tell your boss or your spouse.

Last week the government started to wake up when the Institute of Directors published a critical report. But that was mild beer compared with a devastating report over the weekend by the British Chambers of Commerce drawn up by an expert panel including professor Ian Angell of the London School of Economics.

It dismisses the bill as "entirely inadequate" in its primary aim of achieving reasonable surveillance and its effect "is likely to be loss of confidence in e-commerce, unacceptable costs to business and to the UK economy, confusion and uncertainty at numerous levels of business activity, and an onerous imposition on the rights of individuals".

The penny may at last be starting to drop in Whitehall.

If this bill goes through in its present form, far from making Britain the best place to do e-commerce in (as is Tony Blair's stated aim) it will produce one of the most draconian regimes in the world driving e-commerce to safer havens like Ireland and most countries in Europe.

Unless Tony Blair wants to create a furore that will make this encounter with the Women's Institute seem like a picnic, he should rewrite this appalling bill. Now.

webTitle: World pays tribute to Syrian dictator

fields.headline: World pays tribute to Syrian dictator
fields.trailText: Friends and enemies paid tribute to Hafez al-Assad today as the Syrian leader's body lay in state in the elaborate white marble People's Palace set on a Damascus hillside.
fields.body:
Friends and enemies paid tribute to Hafez al-Assad today as the Syrian leader's body lay in state in the elaborate white marble People's Palace set on a Damascus hillside.

His son and designated heir, Bashar al-Assad, was flanked in the funeral procession by Syria's defence minister - a symbol of the key support Syria's powerful military has thrown behind him. A political novice, the 34-year-old Bashar was meeting for the first time some of those leaders paying homage to his autocratic father, who ruled Syria for three decades before his death on Saturday aged 69.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, bowed her head briefly before the casket and then spoke privately with Bashar for about 20 minutes. The younger Assad was also warmly greeted by the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the French president, Jacques Chirac. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, who had quarrelled bitterly with the elder Assad, saluted before the coffin, then kissed Bashar, clasping his hand and speaking intently for a few moments.

Mr Arafat even had a greeting kiss for the Syrian defence minister, Mustafa Tlass, who less than a year ago castigated Mr Arafat for making concessions to Israel, calling him "the son of 60,000 whores" and comparing him to a stripper. Syria has looked askance at Mr Arafat for making concessions to Israel.

Even amid the mourning, politics was not completely set aside. Syria used the occasion to trumpet the withdrawal of Israeli troops from south Lebanon three weeks ago after a long campaign by the Hizbullah guerrillas, and to underscore its hopes of regaining the Golan Heights, captured by Israel in the 1967 war.

On the streets of Damascus, tens of thousands of mourners surged along the cortege route, waving portraits of both Assads, some fainting in the scorching heat. Soldiers handed out water to spectators, while ambulances stood by along the procession route.

"Today, the nation bids farewell to its leader," the Tishreen newspaper said in a headline. The front page of the Al-Thawraa newspaper was filled by a huge black-bordered portrait of Assad. Syrian television carried the daylong spectacle live.

But a power struggle already looms as Rifaat al-Assad, Bashar's uncle, makes his own claim to power. Rifaat al-Assad, who has been in exile in Europe since attempting to seize power in 1983, said he planned to return to Damascus at the "appropriate time" to contest his nephew's leadership.

fields.headline: Regulating doctors
fields.standfirst:
The government is setting up a new early warning system to prevent further cases of malpractise in the National Health Service. We explain why

'A rude and incompetent botcher'
Special report
fields.trailText: The government is setting up a new early warning system to prevent further cases of malpractice in the National Health Service. Simon Jeffery explains why.
fields.body:
What is the problem?
The medical profession is facing up to two more cases of bad practice. Gynaecologist Richard Neale is before a medical tribunal accused of negligent behaviour and faking qualifications on his CV. Yesterday it was revealed that specialist James Elwood had wrongly diagnosed 200 cancer patients.

Why now?
The timing of the two cases is coincidental - but these are not the only blunders have come to light. The medical profession has been rocked by a string of scandals including James Wisheart, the consultant largely responsible for the high number of deaths during paediatric heart surgery at Bristol royal infirmary in the late 1980s and early 1990s; and Rodney Ledward, the self-styled "fastest gynaecologist in the south-east".

How do you join the profession?
Medical training begins at university with a five year bachelor of medicine and bachelor of surgery degree. At the highest level the specialist training authority awards a certificate to doctors who have successfully completed a UK training programme to a standard that makes them eligible for appointment to a consultant's post. In addition, overseas qualifications are allowed.

What does "struck off" mean?
A doctor or surgeon is taken (struck) off the list that contains the names of who is eligible to practice.

Who regulates them?
All practising medical doctors in the UK must be licenced with the general medical council (GMC). Unlike the British medical association (effectively a trade union for doctors) the GMC has a legal responsibility to keep up-to-date registers of qualified doctors, foster good medical practice, promote high standards of medical education and, crucially, take action against doctors whose fitness to practise is in doubt.

And when is it doubt?
The GMC will take action when a doctor has been convicted of a criminal offence; when there is an allegation of serious professional misconduct; when a doctor's professional performance may be seriously deficient; or when a doctor with health problems continues to practise while unfit. These criteria may change when the 1983 medical act is amended to create an interim committee to suspend doctors before a full hearing takes place.

What is the government's response?
A national reporting system to log all failures and near-misses in health care is to be set up, says a report published today by an expert group led by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson.

webTitle: McManaman and Adams to miss Germany game

fields.headline: McManaman and Adams to miss Germany game
fields.trailText: Tony Adams and Steve McManaman will almost certainly miss England's next Euro 2000 match against Germany in Charleroi on Saturday.
fields.body:
Tony Adams and Steve McManaman will almost certainly miss England's next Euro 2000 match against Germany in Charleroi on Saturday.

Both men suffered injuries in last night's 3-2 defeat by Portugal.

McManaman limped off after suffering a knee injury while attempting to make a tackle in midfield, while centre-half Adams' notoriously fragile back appeared to give way as England attempted to chase the game.

England coach Kevin Keegan said: "They have both gone for a scan but the feeling is that Tony will not make the next two games and Steve will not be fit for the match against Germany."

Asked to assess England's performance, Keegan added: "I can certainly think of a fair few things we could have done better but there were a lot of plusses in there that get overlooked.

"Our finishing was good and our character was good. I'm disappointed but I still feel we've got it in our own hands.

"Yes, it's more difficult now. We probably have to win both games."

webTitle: Lords to fight email tap bill

fields.headline: Lords to fight email tap bill
fields.standfirst: Free speech on the net: special report
fields.trailText: The government's bill to allow MI5 access to encoded email last night faced the start of what may be a fatal drubbing from a cross-party coalition of peers concerned about both civil liberties and the security of business transactions.
fields.body:
The government's bill to allow MI5 access to encoded email last night faced the start of what may be a fatal drubbing from a cross-party coalition of peers concerned about both civil liberties and the security of business transactions.

As the Lords begins work on the measure, which has already passed through all its stages in the Commons, there are predictions that it will be emasculated by hostile amendments next Monday or Tuesday - to the dismay of the national criminal intelligence service.

The regulation of investigatory powers bill, known as the RIP bill, gives the home secretary power to compel businesses and others to surrender to the security service, MI5, the electronic encryption "keys" used by internet service providers.

The justification for what critics call "a massive extension of the state's powers to spy on its citizens" is the need to keep abreast of criminal, terrorist and espionage activity which grows ever more sophisticated. But it will also allow for the tapping of electronic communications to be done without a specific warrant.

The British Chamber of Commerce and the Alliance for Electronic Business yesterday warned of the crippling cost and the threat to commercial secrets - a formula which will undermine Tony Blair's declared wish to make the UK "the best place to trade electronically."

They predict that firms will move offshore as the bill is more restrictive than in other states, including the US where the right to intercept email was defeated.

NCIS director general, John Abbott, yesterday said: "Crime is currently costing the UK's economy approximately £50bn per year and poses a serious threat to the fabric of our society."

fields.headline: George Lucas makes animation move
fields.trailText: George Lucas's special effects offshoot Industrial Light and Magic is to move into film animation, it was announced yesterday. The company is looking to develop and produce full-length features and TV productions either independently or in tandem with larger studios.
fields.body:
George Lucas's special effects offshoot Industrial Light and Magic is to move into film animation, it was announced yesterday. The company is looking to develop and produce full-length features and TV productions either independently or in tandem with larger studios.

ILM's flirtation with animated film production goes back three years, when they worked alongside Universal studios on a now defunct cartoon version of Frankenstein. "That's where we first articulated the idea of breaking into animation," ILM executive Patti Blau told Variety. "Now we're really putting our weight behind it. We're disappointed Frankenstein never went ahead." fields.headline: Reel.com bites the e-dust
fields.trailText: Video retailer Hollywood Entertainment announced today that it is closing Reel.com - the four-year-old video and DVD e-tailer that won over movie buffs but continued to drag down its parent company
fields.body:
Video retailer Hollywood Entertainment announced today that it is closing Reel.com - the four-year-old video and DVD e-tailer that won over movie buffs but continued to drag down its parent company.

Despite becoming one of the web's more high-profile movie destinations, Hollywood executives say the site was simply losing too much money to survive.

"Reel.com has built an excellent website for movie buyers and those interested in movie content," said Mark Wattles, chairman and CEO of Hollywood Entertainment. "Revenue, customer traffic and customer satisfaction have all been very strong. [But] despite significant customer enthusiasm, we cannot sustain this business."

Hollywood Entertainment, the US's second largest video chain behind Blockbuster, bought Reel.com two years ago for $100m, hoping to turn it into a self-sufficient business.

But it never happened. Last year, while Hollywood's operations earned $31.3m, Reel.com lost $82.6 million, leaving the company heavily in the red, and causing a drop in share prices.

Reel.com will still provide online entertainment news and features. But once the company has honoured all its current movie orders, future video and DVD orders will be forwarded directly to net superstore Buy.com.

fields.headline: No 5: Daniel Andersson
fields.standfirst: Click here for full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: Wait, don't tell me - he's that Mickael Beck clone who played for Newcastle isn't he? No you're thinking of Andreas Andersson, who had just regained his best form after dismal spells at AC Milan and St James Park when, tragically, he suffered a knee injury which ruled him out of Euro 2000.
fields.body:
Wait, don't tell me - he's that Mickael Beck clone who played for Newcastle isn't he? No you're thinking of Andreas Andersson, who had just regained his best form after dismal spells at AC Milan and St James Park when, tragically, he suffered a knee injury which ruled him out of Euro 2000.

OK. Is it that dodgy centre half who played for Blackburn ages ago? You mean Patrik Andersson - who barely gets a game for Bayern Munich, but is still the lynchpin of the Swedish defence?

No, no - he was younger than thatThen you're probably talking about Anders Andersson, who moved to his present club Aalborg BK after an unsuccessful spell at Ewood Park, and is now valuable member of the Swedish squad.

So who's Daniel Andersson then? He's the 22 year-old younger brother of Patrik - and is regarded as one of Sweden's brightest talents.

Brighter than Freddie Ljungberg? He's certainly up there with him. Andersson made his debut for the national side at the age of 19, and soon after was transferred to Bari (in a combined $3.8m deal with fellow Swedish international Yksel Osmanovski). In his two years in Serie A, he's been one of Bari's most consistent players.

So what kind of player is he? He's not the biggest or most aggressive of central midfielders but he's technically superb and spreads the play brilliantly.

A sort of Swedish Jamie Redknapp then? Yeah, although he's not indulging in intercourse with a talentless pop star.

So what does Mr Andersson (IV) think of Sweden's prospects? "Our target is to go on to the second round," he says. "If we make it anything could happen. We are tight group and have a very organised defence. But we find it difficult to score."

Has he any view about Ljungberg's sex-ban comments? Not specifically, although intriguingly he does nominate him to be 'Euro 2000's new star.' We assume he's talking about football.

So just how many Andersson's are there in the Swedish squad? There are four (including 6ft 4ins striker Kennet) - but if Andreas was fit there would have been five.

Not to be confused with: Freddie Ljungberg, Magnus Magnusson, Ulrika Jonsson.

webTitle: Protests over Farrelly brothers' new movie

fields.headline: Protests over Farrelly brothers' new movie
fields.trailText: The US National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI) is launching a national protest against the Farrelly's Brothers' new movie Me, Myself & Irene
fields.body:
The US National Alliance for the Mentally Ill (NAMI) is launching a national protest against the Farrelly Brothers' new movie Me, Myself & Irene. The film stars Jim Carrey as a man whose two personalities are in love with the same woman, Renee Zellweger's Irene.

The non-profit advocacy group said the movie, which opens in the US on 23 June, and its marketing campaign show 'gross ignorance and insensitivity' to people with mental illnesses and their families.

There are some who might say that Bobby and Peter Farrelly, the duo behind There's Something About Mary and Dumb and Dumber, and infamous for their political incorrectness, would consider these accusations a measure of their film's success.

Nevertheless, the NAMI says Me, Myself and Irene "perpetuates a myth that schizophrenia - a severe, biologically-based brain disorder - is a split personality.''

Fox's poster campaign for the movie features the tag-line ''From Gentle to Mental'', and describes Carrey's character as suffering from ''split-personality disorder''. No explicit reference is made to schizophrenia.

 The official site.

fields.headline: Wisden's very own cover girl
fields.standfirst: In October 1998 she appeared on the cover of Wisden Cricket Monthly. But what has Isabelle Duncan been up to since? Tanya Aldred finds out
fields.trailText: Most cover girls are naked, or almost naked. They are always heavily stylised and, unless they are Anna Kournikova, they aren't sportswomen. But Isabelle Duncan was different.
fields.body:
Most cover girls are naked, or almost naked. They are always heavily stylised and, unless they are Anna Kournikova, they aren't sportswomen. But Isabelle Duncan was different.

Not only was she fully clothed, she was wearing an MCC jumper. Hardly the height of fashion, but the October 1998 issue of Wisden Cricket Monthly, which carried her image, made almost as many British headlines as Vanity Fair's naked pregnant Demi Moore cover. Duncan was chosen because she was and still is a club cricketer who not only plays on equal terms with men, but often captains her side too.

That issue of WCM ('The Women's Issue') coincided with the MCC vote (the second of 1998) on admitting women. The motion to allow women members was carried, and WCM and Isabelle had a few moments in the sun before it was back to obscurity.

But Isabelle, now 26, hasn't forgotten her moment of fame. "I tried to milk it a bit - I got all the publicity photos and coverage together and made a sort of cricket CV. Then I sent it off to Channel 4 and TMS. I had lunch with Gary Franses from Sunset+Vine [the production team behind C4's cricket coverage] but nothing really came of it ."

A four-month spell as advertising manager of a less well-known magazine Cricket World Monthly followed, but it didn't pay much so she started work at Grace Consulting, which specialises in long-term care of the elderly. But she is still determined to break through into working in cricket full time.

She had lunch with Peter Baxter, the producer of TMS earlier this year, and was supposed to do a summary for him from an early B&H match, until the weather spoilt things. But she was able to go and sit in the TMS box during the Zimbabwe Test at Lord's - to listen and learn.

"It was great. Lord MacLaurin was there and Graham Cowdrey and they got Ali Bacher on the phone talking about matchfixing. It was very interesting."

So what is her next step? "Peter Baxter told me to go and do some practice tapes at a professional game and send them in. Which I keep meaning to do but I'm just so busy playing cricket for the MCC and other teams at weekends."

She has role models in Eleanor Oldroyd (TMS) and Sybil Ruscoe (C4). But Duncan hopes to be able to offer something new. "They are very good presenters, and well-informed and professional, but they don't really do any ball-by-ball. I think that is what I can offer - something new. A woman's voice actually talking about the techniques of the game, talking to players about tactics. I think it would widen the audience, bring in women and kids."

If that does happen, she would be well-prepared to deal with the autograph hunters. "A few people have recognised me at places like Lord's. I sometimes get "weren't you the girl on that front cover?" - that sort of thing. Also when the magazine came out I was on holiday in Crete when suddenly these people who I'd chatted with in the bar came running down the beach shouting 'you're famous, you're famous.' They'd seen me in the Daily Mail."

"I enjoyed the attention. Three days of being in demand - it probably only happens for about five minutes in your life and I loved it."

Perhaps she won't have to wait much longer for some more.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her latest Women's Page, Top tips for football widows, click here

webTitle: Rasputin, star of the silver screen

fields.headline: Rasputin, star of the silver screen
fields.trailText: Paul Verhoven - the man behind Robocop and Starship Troopers, is keen to direct a biopic of mad Russian monk Rasputin
fields.body:
The worldwide success of Gladiator has convinced director Paul Verhoven - the man behind Robocop and Starship Troopers, that the time is ripe for Hollywood to turn its attentions to the mad Russian monk Rasputin.

Verhoven claims to have been fascinated since childhood by the charismatic Russian peasant and mystic who cast a spell over the weak-willed Russian imperial family, and famously survived numerous assassination attempts.

The £40m all-action Russian-set epic will rival Dr Zhivago, and filming is mooted to start next spring in Moscow and St Petersburg.

A friend of Verhoven's said: "A number of studios are already in the frame with Paramount and Universal both interested. The cost is a problem. There is no way to bring something like this in cheaply."

Among those tipped to take the lead role are Val Kilmer, Gary Oldman and Ralph Fiennes, with Minnie Driver is already the hot favourite to play the Royal beauty Rasputin seduces into his chamber.

There have been many attempts to bring Rasputin to the cinema. The Russians had a crack themselves with a black and white classic called Rasputin and the Empress in 1933. More recently, Alan Rickman's attempt to breath life into the demonic holy man failed badly in 1996 in the TV movie Rasputin .

webTitle: Rogue state opens door to 'food diplomacy'

fields.headline: Rogue state opens door to 'food diplomacy'
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran explains how US diplomacy with North Korea has paid off as the 'outlaw state' inches back into the international community
fields.trailText: US diplomacy appears to have paid off as North Korea inches back into the international community.
fields.body:
There was a time in the late 1980s, when the US watched North Korea nervously amid fears that some rash act of military adventurism from Pyongyang would drag American troops into armed conflict.

State department officials would describe to attentive congressmen various North Korean escapades such amphibious forays into South Korea and the digging of tunnels under the demilitarised zone, an oxymoron if there ever was one, as the 38th parallel bristles with troops and weapons.

For years, North Korea has ranked alongside the likes of Libya, Iran and Iraq as an outlaw state. But the Clinton administration took a gamble in the early 1990s to engage the North Koreans diplomatically as the best way to defuse the threat to some 40,000 US troops in the Korean peninsula.

In 1994, the administration signed a "framework agreement" with Pyongyang in a bid to put the brakes on North Korea's nuclear programme.

Under the scheme, the US provided North Korea with two lightweight nuclear reactors while Pyongyang agreed to freeze its nuclear programme that could produce plutonium for nuclear weapons development. Financial aid also came with the reactors.

The US was essentially bribing North Korea to behave, not just with nuclear help but with food aid as the country was hit by famine. The point was not lost on some Republicans who criticised the Clinton administration for a scheme that could not really guarantee that North Korea would desist from going nuclear or from its missile programme.

But the US pressed ahead with plans to draw out Pyongyang and in 1997 began four-party talks involving the two Koreas and China. US diplomacy had its setbacks, notably when North Korea tested a long-range missile in 1998.

Now US policy appears to have paid off as the highly-reclusive Kim Jong-il has decided that it is time to end North Korea's long isolation. Last Autumn, North Korean diplomats were quietly working the halls of the UN, schmoozing with fellow diplomats. Kim's diplomatic offensive continued apace this year.

He recently visited Beijing and invited the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, to Pyongyang. Today he surprised everyone by appearing at the airport to greet South Korea's President Kim Dae-jung personally in a lavish welcome ceremony.

Recently, when asked why North Korea agreed to this historic summit with South Korea, US secretary of state Madeleine Albright said that you could never tell why the North Koreans have decided something. "They are a very opaque society," she said. And North Korea retains its ability to confuse.

Talks on improving relations with Japan have gone nowhere and are on hold. It rushed to agree to establish diplomatic relations with the Philippines, then mystified Manila by balking at sending its foreign minister to sign the deal.

What happens in the two Koreas has wide ramifications for the region and the US. No one in East Asia welcomes the prospect of a militaristic state like North Korea with the ability to launch long-range missiles.

The US has cited the existence of rogue states such as North Korea as a justification for building a national missile defence that so vexes the Europeans. If North Korea curbs or abandons its missile development, there would be one less reason for the US to argue that it needs a son of star wars system.

webTitle: Ease restrictions on animal testing, urge scientists

fields.headline: Ease restrictions on animal testing, urge scientists
fields.trailText: Five Nobel prize-winners are among a group of 110 of eminent British scientists who have written to the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, warning him that Britain will lose its competitive edge in research unless restrictions on experimenting on animals are eased.
fields.body:
Five Nobel prize-winners are among a group of 110 of eminent British scientists who have written to the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, warning him that Britain will lose its competitive edge in research unless restrictions on experimenting on animals are eased.

"It can now take six months or longer to obtain approval for a research project using animals in the UK," the scientists wrote. "In other countries, that permission can be obtained in weeks or even days.

"If this situation persists or gets worse, as it has recently, it appears inevitable that a substantial part of the UK's research effort, in many vital areas, will either become uncompetitive or be forced abroad."

The group asked Lord Sainsbury to raise the issue with the Home Office, which issues permits for animal experiments. They argue that whilst they support current welfare standards, the system of issuing permits for experimentation on animals is overly bureaucratic.

The letter signals something of a fightback on the part of the scientific community, which now faces some of the toughest controls protecting the welfare of laboratory animals in the world.

The letter points out that new areas of medical research, such as biotechnology and genetic science, are particularly dependent on animal experiments.

But the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection (BUAV) pointed out that the UK was the biggest user of laboratory animals in Europe. In 1998, the number of animals experimented on increased for the first time in 10 years, they said, and since 1990, the number of experiments on genetically modified animals in the UK - the fastest expanding area of animal research - had soared by some 800%.

The group claimed current UK legislation protecting laboratory animals was not tough enough, and the rules were constantly being flouted.

"To call for a reduction in already inadequate safeguards flies in the face of increasing public concern over the use of animals in research at all," BUAV chief executive Michelle Thew said:

Home Office figures show that 2,772,758 animals were used in experiments in 1994, putting Britain ahead of other European countries in this area. The main species used are rats and mice, although many others, including sheep, goats and almost 200,000 birds, were also used. Most of the animals are specially bred for research by commercial breeders.
