fields.headline: Korea: a people divided
fields.standfirst: The historic meeting of the leaders of North and South Korea highlights the deep contrasts between the two countries
fields.trailText: The historic meeting of the leaders of North and South Korea highlights the deep contrasts between the two countries, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
No part of the world is more comprehensively divided than Korea. Fought over for centuries by China and Japan, its unity and independence have always been fragile. Now the 70m-plus people of the peninsula, who speak the same language and have the same cultural inheritance, live in two utterly different countries.

The heavily fortified border is one of the last remnants of the cold war. To the south lies a young, raucous democracy of 47m people, most revelling in a recently-won prosperity. To the north another 21m people live in abject and deepening poverty, under the iron rule of a one-man dictatorship.

The Koreas were born in the aftermath of the second world war. For half a century the peninsula had been an imperial Japanese colony. After the collapse of Japan, Washington and Moscow made an ad hoc deal: the Soviet forces would oversee the surrender of Japanese forces north of the 38th parallel; the Americans would do the same in the south.

There were desultory efforts to organise democratic elections in a free and united Korea. They came to nothing, and instead puppet regimes were set up in each of the occupation zones in 1948. The Americans pulled out their troops the following year, provoking a disastrous attempt by the communist north to reunite the peninsula by force.

The invasion of South Korea in 1950 was followed by a devastating and futile three-year war, which neither changed nor resolved anything. Rather, the division of the peninsula was set in stone, as interminable negotiations - going on to this very day - took place to convert truce into peace.

The contrast in fortunes of the north and south since 1953 is astonishing. Ardent US cold warriors like to portray South Korea's economic rise as a triumph of free-market democracy over the failed centralism of the North. In fact, the south has been controlled for much of its history by dictators, none more squalid than the first president, Syngman Rhee.

Its economy, too, bore little relation to the free-market model espoused by the western hawks. Instead, it was propelled by a complex mix of protectionism, state-sponsored cartels known as chaebols and rampant corruption.

The north, meanwhile, prospered in its own very different way. For almost half a century, government there was embodied in Kim Il-sung, a leading exponent of the cult of personality. By his will and edict, the state controlled of every part of the economy, tilting it massively towards heavy industry, much of it serving the rapacious demands of a bloated - but highly efficient - military machine.

The collapse of the Soviet empire in 1991 and China's long slow abandonment of state controls has left North Korea warped in time and ideology. The reins are now in the hands of Kim Jong-il, son and successor of the old dictator, and they are stretched as taut as ever.

The country has lost its export markets and its sources of materials. Production has fallen calamitously, by as much as 50%, in the past decade. North Korea can no longer even feed itself: output of basic grains is around 1m tons short of needs, and there are regular reports of mass starvation.

The south, by contrast, is booming. It is one of Asia's four so-called tiger economies, even after the financial crisis which swept the far east in the mid-1990s. Indeed, that crisis has done much to jolt the South Koreans out of their cosy protectionist ways and even to consolidate the infant democracy presided over by veteran reformer, President Kim Jae-jung.

There are now clear signs that the southern economy is growing again, even as the northern economy stagnates. South Korean exports are 180 times greater than the north's. Per capita output is 13 times greater. Only in military spending does North Korea come close to matching the south - but at the dreadful cost of soaking up around 30% of the impoverished country's resources.

The historic summit meeting of the two Kims highlights the huge disparity between the Koreas, both in style and substance. But that very disparity casts a long shadow over the polite banality of the summit communiques.

Any relaxation in tension on the Korean peninsula will be welcomed by the rest of the world. But if there is to be genuine rapprochement - any thought of unity is wildly premature - it will involve an unprecedented effort to close the vast ideological and economic gulf between the two countries.

webTitle: Historic North-South Korean summit raises peace hopes

fields.headline: Historic North-South Korean summit raises peace hopes
fields.trailText:
South Korean President Kim Dae-jung flew to the north of the divided peninsula today for a historic summit that offers the greatest
hope for peace in more than 50 years.
fields.body:
South Korean President Kim Dae-jung flew to the north of the divided peninsula today for a historic summit that offers the greatest hope for peace in more than 50 years.

As he left for the northern capital, Mr Kim said: "I wholeheartedly hope that my trip to Pyongyang will be on a path toward peace and reconciliation.

"I hope that it will be a turning point in efforts to remove threats to war and terminate the cold war on the Korean peninsula so that all 70m Korean people in the South and North can live in peace."

South Korean officials said the presidential plane, accompanied by a chartered flight carrying most of the president's 180-member entourage, would make a detour over the sea on a 70-minute trip to Sunan airport near Pyongyang.

There is no direct air travel between Korea's capitals, and hundreds of thousands of soldiers are deployed on both sides of the Demilitarized Zone, or DMZ, which separates the North and South.

President Kim said he planned to talk candidly with the North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, and hoped to learn about the thinking of the reclusive head of the totalitarian regime, though he warned that reconciliation would be a lengthy process. "I don't believe that we can resolve all problems at one meeting," he said. "We will continue working out agreements whenever our opinions coincide on an issue."

Leaders of South Korea and North Korea have never met since the two countries were founded in 1948 in the infancy of the cold war, and the conflict between two populations that speak the same language and share the same ethnic roots has been bitter and bloody.

Animosity and suspicion remain fresh half a century after the communist North, backed by the Soviet Union and joined by Chinese troops, fought the pro-Western South and its US-led United Nations allies. The 1950-53 Korean war left up to five million people dead, injured or missing, and its legacy lingers most vividly at the DMZ, a buffer area that separates hundreds of thousands of troops, tanks and artillery pieces on both sides of Korea's border.

North Korea's government, based on a personality cult that virtually deifies Kim Jong Il and his late father and national founder, Kim Il Sung, had been reclusive for so long that reconciliation seemed a doubtful dream.

Yet driven partly by desperation for economic aid to rebuild its dilapidated economy, the North has embarked on a new course over the last year, seeking diplomatic contacts with the outside world that culminated in the decision to host an inter-Korean summit.

During the three-day summit, Kim Dae-jung is expected to appeal to his counterpart to agree to reunions of separated families, a summit sequel in the South Korean capital Seoul and other conciliatory gestures in exchange for economic resources from the South.

Though endowed with long-range missile capabilities, North Korea was unable to feed its own people and is now reliant on food aid from its traditional foes: South Korea, Japan and the United States.

Reunification, the stated goal of both nations, will be difficult. Sensitive issues to resolve include North Korea's missile and nuclear programs, and the 37,000 US troops deployed in South Korea. Their role has been to deter the North, which is believed to have stockpiles of chemical weapons and one of the world's largest standing armies.

Often described as one of the most volatile places on Earth, the Korean peninsula has lived with the threat of another war for more than a generation. In 1994, concerns over the North's purported nuclear weapons programme nearly triggered a military conflict.

North Korea is hosting the summit in the mysterious style that it has often employed. It delayed the meeting for a day without a clear explanation, and has refused to announce the schedule, possibly out of concern for the security of Kim Jong Il.

The two Kims plan to meet today and on at least one other occasion, and their governments have agreed not to use national flags and anthems to avoid political or ideological frictions. North Korea has barred foreign reporters from attending the summit, allowing only 50 South Korean journalists to join President Kim's entourage.

The two countries came tantalisingly close to a summit in 1994, but North Korean leader Kim Il Sung died, aged 82, only weeks before he was due to meet his South Korean counterpart, Kim Young-sam.

webTitle: 13 June: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: 13 June: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.standfirst: Antony Hopkin's big big dinner, Spielberg's TV series heads for reject pile, John Milius joins the military, and, Dame Maggie Smith looks at Harry Potter role
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkin's big big dinner, Spielberg's TV series heads for reject pile, John Milius joins the military, and, Dame Maggie Smith looks at Harry Potter role
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins took time off from filming Hannibal in Washington DC to enjoy a Sunday dinner at the White House. Once the day's shooting was complete, the actor (who recently came in for criticism in the UK over his ads for Barclays Bank) was ferried in a big car to the big house for a big show-down with America's Mr Big. Joining Hopkins and Bill Clinton over what one assumes must have been some fava beans and a fine Chianti was the First Lady Hilary Clinton and Democratic fund-raiser Terry McAuliffe.

A TV series developed by Steven Spielberg looks set to wind up on the reject pile after missing out on a slot on NBC's autumn schedule. The series, Semper Fi, was conceived as a co-production between NBC and DreamWorks, with the drama offering a patriotic celebration of Marine corps life at the training grounds of West Point. But insiders claim that the pilot episode was delivered late and that negotiations for the following 13 episodes are on the verge of breaking down. NBC now looks likely to screen the pilot as a one-off drama. Meantime, Spielberg is busy filming his next feature, AI, and appears to have lost interest in Semper Fi's ongoing dramas. "He's not going to have time to spend 12 or 14 hours a day on a [television] series," DreamWorks TV chief Dan McDermott told Inside.com.

Gung-ho film-maker John Milius has signed up to a new job with the Institute for Creative Technologies, a fledgling organisation installed at the University of Southern California with a $45m grant from the US Army. The writer and director will help in developing virtual reality and simulation technology for use in army training. For a man who has long been fascinated with the military (Milius scripted Apocalypse Now and directed the crass commine-bashing thriller Red Dawn) the job is a dream come true. "I always wanted a military career but due to the fact that I had asthma I was never able to serve," a breathless Milius explained last weekend.

Dame Maggie Smith is in talks to take on the role of Professor Minerva McGonagall in the Warner Bros' big-budget adaptation of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, adapted from the book by JK Rowling. Imperious but eccentric, McGonagall is the deputy headmistress of Hogwart's School of Witchcraft and head of Gryffinder House, where boy-wizard Harry is a pupil. The Potter movie will be directed by Chris (Home Alone) Columbus and will be shot in the UK. The role of Potter has yet to be cast, though Warners have apparently been swamped with some 40,000 applications for eager unknowns desperate for consideration. In the meantime, Smith's involvement seems dependant on finding a window in her busy schedule.

webTitle: North and South Korean leaders meet

fields.headline: North and South Korean leaders meet
fields.trailText: Clapping for each other and holding hands, the leaders of South Korea and North Korea, in a historic meeting, exchanged hopes that they could end hostilities on the divided Korean Peninsula.
fields.body:
Clapping for each other and holding hands, the leaders of South Korea and North Korea, in a historic meeting, exchanged hopes that they could end hostilities on the divided Korean Peninsula.

The three-day summit started with a surprise welcome by North Korean leader Kim Jong-Il at the airport on the outskirts of Pyongyang where his southern counterpart President Kim Dae-jung arrived to an elaborate reception.

"The world is closely watching us. Why President Kim came to North Korea and why I accepted is a question mark,'' Kim Jong Il, one of the world's most reclusive leaders, said later in a meeting with his counterpart.

"We have to give the answer to this question during the two nights and three days,'' South Korean pool reports quoted him as saying. "I ask not only President Kim but also (accompanying) ministers to make contributions to this.''

At the airport, Kim Jong Il stepped forward to shake hands with the southern leader at the foot of the plane and the two smiled and clapped for each other. The reception included a military band, goose-stepping soldiers and women dressed in traditional, billowing Korean gowns.

The two leaders then rode in the same limousine into the North Korean capital, where an estimated 600,000 people lined block after block of broad avenues, waving bouquets of pink paper flowers. The spectators appeared to direct their emotion at Kim Jong Il, whose name they chanted in unison as the motorcade passed through the city of 2 million.

It was an unexpectedly warm start to the first meeting between the heads of the two Koreas since they were divided following World War II, a summit that offers the greatest hope for peace on the Korean peninsula in more than 50 years.

The two Kims "sometimes held hands in a show of personal intimacy'' and exchanged views in the limousine during a 40-minute ride, said Park Joon-young, South Korea's presidential spokesman.

At a guesthouse, Kim Dae-jung told the northern leader that he hoped the two Koreas "will end hostility and open a new era of reconciliation and cooperation,'' according to pool reports.

Kim Jong Il said his goal was the same. He also saluted Kim Dae-jung's courage in travelling to North Korea and said: "Beginning tomorrow, let's have dialogue without reserve.''

In one exchange, Kim Dae-jung said: "My mind is filled with a thousand emotions.''

"Don't worry. I will give you the best treatment possible,'' Kim Jong Il replied.

During the summit, the South's president is expected to ask Kim Jong Il to agree to reunions of separated families, a summit sequel in Seoul and other conciliatory gestures in exchange for economic resources from the South. Though endowed with long-range missile capabilities, North Korea was unable to feed its own people in the late 1990s and today is reliant on food aid from its traditional foes: South Korea, Japan and the United States.

Before leaving, Kim Dae-jung said he hoped to learn about the thinking of the reclusive head of the totalitarian regime. He warned that the reconciliation process will be lengthy.

"I hope that it will be a turning point in efforts to remove threats to war and terminate the Cold War on the Korean Peninsula so that all 70 million Korean people in the South and North can live in peace,'' Kim said in a speech on a runway at a military airport in Seoul.

North and South Korea were founded in 1948 in the Cold War's infancy, and the conflict between two populations that speak the same language and share the same ethnic roots has been bitter and bloody.

Reunification - the stated goal of both nations - also is likely to be a lengthy and difficult process. The first summit between leaders of East Germany and West Germany was held in 1970, two decades before the dismantling of the Berlin Wall.

Animosity and suspicion remain fresh in the Koreas a half-century after the communist North, backed by the Soviet Union and joined by Chinese troops, fought the pro-Western South and its US-led allies.

The 1950-53 Korean War left up to 5 million people dead, injured or missing. Its legacy lingers most vividly at the Demilitarized Zone, a buffer area that separates hundreds of thousands of troops, tanks and artillery pieces on both sides of the border.

In 1994, concerns over the North's purported nuclear weapons program nearly triggered a military conflict. And North Korea's totalitarian government - based on a personality cult that virtually deifies Kim Jong Il and his late father and national founder, Kim Il Sung - had been reclusive for so long that reconciliation seemed a doubtful dream.

Yet driven partly by desperation for economic aid, the North embarked on a new course over the last year, seeking diplomatic contacts with the outside world that culminated in the decision to host an inter-Korean summit.

North Korea barred non-Korean reporters from attending the summit, allowing only 50 South Korean journalists to join Kim Dae-jung's entourage.

Korea's leaders have a host of touchy issues to resolve, among them the North's missile and nuclear programs and the 37,000 U.S. troops deployed in the South. Their role has been to deter the North, which is believed to have stockpiles of chemical weapons and one of the world's largest standing armies.

fields.headline: World leaders mourn Assad
fields.standfirst: Syrian heir disputed by uncle in exile
fields.trailText: Pallbearers in scarlet berets and combat fatigues carried the body of Syrian President Hafez al-Assad through the mourner-thronged streets of his capital Tuesday, in a day of funeral ceremonies fraught with national grief and filled with political portents.
fields.body:
Pallbearers in scarlet berets and combat fatigues carried the body of Syrian President Hafez al-Assad through the mourner-thronged streets of his capital Tuesday, in a day of funeral ceremonies fraught with national grief and filled with political portents.

In dark mourning suits or flowing Arab robes, world leaders and other dignitaries paid tribute at the flag-draped casket of Assad, who died Saturday at age 69, at the elaborate, white marble People's Palace, set on a Damascus hillside.

His son and designated heir, Bashar al-Assad, was flanked by Syria's defence minister, in a symbol of the key support Syria's powerful military has thrown behind him. He passed both hands in front of his eyes in a prayerful gesture as his father's coffin was carried along a stretch of red carpet at the palace to a black-shrouded pedestal to lie in state.

Young and politically untested, the 34-year-old Bashar was meeting for the first time many of the leaders giving homage to his father, who ruled Syria with an iron fist for three decades.

Although Syria's official hierarchy has given Bashar al-Assad its blessing, it remained to be seen whether he could hold his own in the unforgiving political milieu of both Syria and the Middle East.

On the streets of Damascus, crowds of tens of thousands surged along the cortege route. Some fainted in the scorching heat. Soldiers handed out water to spectators, while ambulances stood by along the procession route. Helicopters whirred overhead, drowning out the sound of chanting and weeping.

"Today, the nation bids farewell to its leader,'' the Tishreen newspaper said in a headline. The front page of the Al-Thawraa newspaper was filled by a huge black-bordered portrait of Assad. State-run Syrian television carried the day-long spectacle live.

US secretary of state Madeleine Albright and Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak were among the hundreds of dignitaries to file by the coffin of a man with whom they sometimes clashed, but acknowledged as a powerful shaper of regional politics.

The United States listed Syria as a sponsor of terrorism, criticised its human rights record and was frustrated at delays in the Israeli-Syrian peace talks it tried to mediate. But Monday, as Albright prepared to head to Syria for the funeral, she said: "I think that it's totally appropriate that we pay our respects to a historic figure and that we express our condolences to the people of Syria.''

For ordinary Syrians, the loss of the only president many had ever known sparked a remarkable outpouring of grief that at times seemed staged, at other times almost unbearably heartfelt. They took to the streets of cities and villages, chanting praise for Assad and for Bashar.

Young men bared their chests and in a gesture characteristic of Shiite Islam, ripped at their flesh with knives. Women draped in black fainted in the hot, humid weather of recent days. "You are our leader forever!'' some shouted.

"You see all these people because Assad was a good man,'' said Hosam Chalabi, a 17-year-old student. "We have to come to say goodbye. It is the one small thing we can do.''

Some Syrians spent the night along the route. Others headed out early in the morning, dressed in black, walking in groups, silent except for the padding of their feet. The wail of Koranic verses from mosque speakers filled the streets.

Assad's final resting place was to be Qardaha, the family hometown and burial place of his eldest son and first choice as successor, Basil, who died in a 1994 car crash. The family grave in the town some 200 miles north of Damascus is dominated by a huge marble mausoleum.

Assad, known as the Lion of Damascus' - his name means lion in Arabic - rose to power through the ranks of the military and the all-powerful Ba'ath party.

Mourners since his death have lauded him for bringing stability. Syria had experienced a series of coups since independence from France in 1946. Assad's in 1970 was the last.

However, any comfort Syrians drew from the possibility of a smooth transition was shaken Monday when Rifaat Assad, younger brother of the late president, made his own claim to power.

Rifaat, who has been in exile in Europe since attempting to seize power in 1983, told the Associated Press in Beirut through a spokesman that he planned to return to Damascus at the "appropriate time'' to contest his nephew's leadership.

fields.headline: These Danes are no drones
fields.trailText: Embarrassment. That was the overwhelming feeling in the Dutch dressing room after our opening match with the Czech Republic.
fields.body:
Embarrassment. That was the overwhelming feeling in the Dutch dressing room after our opening match with the Czech Republic. The result did not seem fair to the Czechs and we were lucky to get the win. In fact, we would have been pretty lucky to get even a draw on our performance on Sunday.

I had sensed some nerves in the camp before the game, our first match in competition in two years. We were all very aware that it was not just another friendly.

As the match went on, we got more and more into the rhythm of competitive football again. During the friendlies nothing was a matter of life or death but against the Czechs everything really counted.

I am not fond of international friendly matches. During the season your club is really more important than your country. I think an international squad needs to spend five or six days as a group to gain any real benefit from a get-together. For most of our friendlies in the build-up to Euro 2000, we got only two or three days together - and everyone spends their time trying to avoid injury.

The fact is that, when you play at the highest level with your club, like when Arsenal are facing Barcelona in the Champions League, it is hard to look forward to a friendly.

High-pressure tournament games are a different prospect. I think, as a nation, the Dutch thrive on vital matches. It is just in our nature. We need that tension and those nerves because we cherish and love the big tournaments. Maybe the Czech game was not the greatest example of this but, as the competition progresses, you will see what I mean.

People accuse us of arrogance but is arrogance necessarily a negative characteristic? I think it can be extremely positive - particularly in football. It is just that a lot of us in the Dutch team have been aware from an early age that we can play football very well. We always have the belief that we are the best team in the world and no one can beat us.

One of the good things to come out of Sunday night is that I believe we have established a major psychological advantage over France, one of the teams many commentators believe can beat us.

Why? The pressure is now really on the world champions because they were on fire for their game against Denmark and ended up easy 3-0 winners. They dominated the game, played attractive football and scored a great goal through my Arsenal team-mate Thierry Henry. So now everyone expects them to win.

Meanwhile, we have had a quiet start and can feel some of the pressure lift from our shoulders. We had always looked at the Czech game as one of our biggest challenges and we have won it. Meanwhile the French have two mountains to climb when they play the Czechs, then us.

Our next game is on Friday against Denmark. Most people have them down as Group D's weakest side but I think they will be tough. Jon Dahl Tomasson has improved no end since his disappointing period in England and the Ajax midfielder Jesper Gronkjaer poses an enormous threat to defences.

The Danes, despite Sunday's eventual score, created enough great opportunities in the opening 10 minutes to suggest they could make life tricky for us.

I admire the Danes because they try to play their football the correct way - and I think we can do better against such a team. I certainly think it will be a very open match.

It has been a strange opening for the Dutch fans but as a team we will give them more to shout about as the tournament progresses. I noticed that during Sunday's second half, when we really needed our fans' support, it was the Czechs who were making all the noise. I would not blame our fans if they were disappointed in us - maybe they were just too stunned to shout or scream!

For Dennis Bergkamp's Euro 2000 diary visit his official site at www.icons.com

fields.headline: British cinema audiences up 17.7%
fields.trailText: Official figures released yesterday reveal that cinema takings in the UK rose by an unprecedented level during the first three months of the year
fields.body:
Official figures released yesterday reveal that cinema takings in the UK rose by an unprecedented level during the first three months of the year. The National Statistics Office confirmed that the complete receipts for January to March showed a 17.7% rise on the same period in 1999.

If there is one film that embodies this steep upward curve it is Toy Story 2. Disney's wildly popular sequel scooped the lion's share of the UK cinema revenue and broke the record for the highest three-day gross when it debuted in February with a weekend gross of £7.6m. But more esoteric movies than in other years might have played to a limited, art-house audience, like The Talented Mr Ripley and the Oscar-winning American Beauty, also drew in healthy box-office receipts and helped beef up the overall average.

fields.headline: Slapdash England  toss it away
fields.standfirst: Full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: Already England's participation in Euro 2000 threatens to be brief, if beguiling. Last night Kevin Keegan's team took an early 2-0 lead in the Philips stadium here only to lose 3-2 after Portugal's precise and perceptive attack had exploited some creaky defending.
fields.body:
Already England's participation in Euro 2000 threatens to be brief, if beguiling. Last night Kevin Keegan's team took an early 2-0 lead in the Philips stadium here only to lose 3-2 after Portugal's precise and perceptive attack had exploited some creaky defending.

It was the first time that England had lost in such a fashion since going out of the 1970 World Cup to West Germany in Mexico by a similar score. While last night's defeat has not finished their chances in this European Championship, Keegan clearly has a lot of work to do, especially in defence, before Saturday's renewal of hostilities with the Germans.

After the Germany-Romania draw in Liège, both sides went into the match with the added incentive of taking an early grip on Group A. For England the prospect of meeting the Germans in Charleroi on Saturday with a win in the bag must have put an extra spring in the step of Kevin Keegan's team.

So, in theory, did Keegan's preference of Steve McManaman's aggression over Dennis Wise's guile and patience on the left. If it worked this would not only pose a more direct threat to the Portuguese on that side of the field but might restrict the activities of Luis Figo, who with Rui Costa represented the most obvious danger to England.

Then of course there was David Beckham, a player as capable as Luis Figo of turning the match from a flank. The first time Portugal allowed Beckham a generous amount of space on the right, England scored.

Before the kick-off Britannia was loudly ruling the waves at the English end of the Philips stadium. And inside three minutes a large breaker had rolled over Portugal's defence.

A header from Alan Shearer following Gary Neville's throw-in, which brought Vitor Baia into action after a mere 25 seconds, had dispelled any thought that Keegan's approach might err on the side of caution. That had been just a theory anyway.

In England's next attack Phil Neville's searching long centre from the left found its way across the pitch to Beckham and the decision of Dimas to stand off the Manchester United player quickly proved costly for the Portuguese. Beckham's cross, as true as ever, reached the head of Paul Scholes and United, not to mention England, were one up off the underside of the bar.

With Portugal ready to match England move for move and shot for shot, an open game quickly developed into an intriguing contest of contrasting attacking styles. If Rui Costa and Luis Figo were pulling the strings for the Portuguese, Beckham's crossbow continued to look potent for England.

Sure enough it increased England's lead on 18 minutes. This time Beckham's centre found Scholes cleverly taking two defenders with him towards the near post, leaving McManaman unguarded as he walloped the ball first time into the roof of the net.

With their fans singing and Keegan's team swinging, it appeared that England had struck gold. Yet Portugal, too, had by then created a string of chances, with a header from Joao Pinto bouncing over the crossbar, David Seaman keeping out a shot from Rui Costa and Nuno Gomes having a goal ruled out for offside.

Then suddenly, in the 22nd minute, Luis Figo let fly from just beyond the penalty arc as Tony Adams lunged towards him and Seaman was simply left standing by the sheer pace of the shot. Clearly England had much to do but so long as Shearer, Scholes and McManaman continued to trouble defenders with their passing and movement, Keegan's players still held the initiative.

Not for long, however. England had become strung out by their own attacking enthusiasm and against a team with Portugal's ability to slip into space behind opponents this invited trouble. Paul Ince was having difficulty keeping track of both Rui Costa and Joao Pinto and by half-time another failure to close down a shooting chance had again cost England dear.

On 37 minutes, as Rui Costa's centre from the right dipped into the penalty area, Sol Campbell's challenge came a fraction too late to prevent Joao Pinto getting in an angled shot which beat Seaman and rebounded in off the far post.

For Keegan the game might have begun like a night at Manchester United but this was more like Newcastle United on one of Kev's more hectic evenings.

At half-time Keegan replaced Michael Owen's speed with Emile Heskey's power but that sinking feeling refused to go away as Seaman missed the second of two successive corners from Luis Figo. Joao Pinto wafted the chance over.

Obviously England were eager to score again but the discipline and organisation in their own half badly needed to improve if they were to hold Portugal. Whenever Luis Figo and Joao Pinto tucked in behind Nuno Gomes England's square, sweeperless defence looked there for the taking.

On the hour it was duly taken yet again. McManaman made a brief return after twisting a knee but in the 59th minute he gave way to Wise. Another minute and England were heading for defeat.

Using Adams and Campbell as markers, Rui Costa clipped a head-high ball from right to left across the penalty area to Nuno Gomes. Once more Adams stretched to intercept the danger but once more he was just too late and Nuno Gomes beat Seaman emphatically from close range.

Thus the flair which had seen England off to a flying start had been undermined by a combination of fragile, ponderous defending and Portugal's technique and vision.

Substitutes
England Heskey for Owen, h-t; Wise for McManaman, 59min; Keown for Adams, 82.
Portugal Conceicao for Joao Pinto, 76; Beto for Rui Costa, 85; Capucho for Nuno Gomes, 90.

Booked
England Ince
Portugal Baia

Referee A Frisk (Sweden)

fields.headline: Scholl saves Germany's tired veterans
fields.standfirst: Full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: From England's perspective, Germany dropped two valuable points yesterday. But Kevin Keegan will have noted many more to encourage him ahead of his team's next crucial game.
fields.body:
From England's perspective, Germany dropped two valuable points yesterday. But Kevin Keegan will have noted many more to encourage him ahead of his team's next crucial game.

The ancient foe really did look their collective age as they flagged long before the end of a tie they were expected to sail through against Romania's fleet of old steamers.

The whistles of derision generated by the German section at the end passed a fair verdict on a performance riddled with errors and misunderstandings.

Romania arrived ready to sit back and break on the counter-attack, a ploy which was helped enormously by the frequency with which Germany gave the ball away through slow thinking in defence and sloppy passing all round.

Indeed, it was a mistake by the defender Thomas Linke which led to Romania taking a fourth-minute lead through the Coventry City reject Viorel Moldovan.

Romania then survived some hit-and-miss German pressure until a glorious shot from Mehmet Scholl levelled the scores near the half-hour.

Although Germany continued to grab most of the posession, it was Romania who should have gone on to win. The hard-working Adrian Ilie was denied a clear penalty five minutes before half-time, then deep into the second half Moldovan showed more of his Highfield Road form by missing a sitter with the German defence again in disarray.

It was the long ball over the top which particularly unsettled Germany, a weakness which Michael Owen will surely have noted.

This was a game which put age before beauty, a slow-tempo exhibition of veterans' football which cried out for the electric invention of youth. The old maestro Gheorghe Hagi was reduced to walking pace early in the second half and substituted shortly before the 39-year Lothar Matthäus also trudged off.

This may be a tournament too far for both teams. But Romania's ability to counter-attack remains undimmed. When, on four minutes, Linke trod on the ball, Ilie quickly took advantage, sprinting into the area before squaring a ball to the far post where Moldovan blasted home from close range.

Romania were soon on the back foot, though, drafting in men behind the ball to cut off Germany's attacking options. Erich Ribbeck's team mainly threatened down the right but without really testing Bogdan Stelea.

Another German error handed the initiative back to Romania on 17 minutes, as Middlesbrough's Christian Ziege gave the ball away to Ilie and Modlovan headed just over. Then Oliver Kahn was forced to come racing from his area to thwart Dan Petrescu, released by Hagi's long pass.

The Germans needed to make better use of possession and were denied a goal only when Stelea's reflex save stopped the unmarked Oliver Bierhoff's header from Scholl's corner.

Two minutes later Germany equalised. A move down the right was going nowhere until Markus Babbel suddenly spun off Iulian Filipescu. He fed Paulo Rink, who in turn found Scholl, whose 25-yard shot rifled into the top corner.

Romania were in danger of allowing themselves to be pressed back too much now, with the result that their strikers were becoming isolated.

But the long ball continued to bridge the gap. Constantin Galca's 30-yard pass almost released Moldovan and on 39 minutes a vintage 40-yarder from Hagi found Ilie in the area. The striker cut back inside and had his back leg taken away by Jens Nowotny. But the referee somehow missed it. Hagi was booked for protesting.

Romania's long-range attack caused more problems after the break. Stelea's long kick was misjudged by the substitute defender Marko Rehmer and Ilie's goalbound shot was diverted wide only by a desperate lunge of Kahn's legs.

It does not say much for Germany's penetration that in this period they continued to have the bulk of possession. It was only when Bierhoff ducked in front of Gheorghe Popescu and grazed a post with a header that Germany seemed to remember that the main object of the game is to score.

But by then they were looking very tired, with hands on hips and heads bowed. When Bierhoff set up Ziege in front of goal the wing-back limply headed wide.

Again it was Romania who came closest to finding the winner on the break. Another long ball, this time from Dorinel Munteanu, found Ilie, who lost Rehme and was prevented from scoring himself only by Kahn's flying block. The ball broke to Moldovan, whose first shot was cleared by Nowotny before he blasted the rebound wide.

Germany did have a Bierhoff effort disallowed near the end but replays confirmed that he was marginally offside. It would have been cruel luck on Romania had they lost. The Germans now have five days to regroup and rest. They looked as though they will need it.

webTitle: Jeu, set et match à Roland-Garros

fields.headline: Jeu, set et match à Roland-Garros
fields.standfirst: Roland-Garros, the French Open, attracts a lot of media attention and daily crowds of over 30,000.  Zo Eisenstein finds out more
fields.trailText: Roland-Garros, the French Open, attracts a lot of media attention and daily crowds of over 30,000.  Zo* Eisenstein finds out more
fields.body:
C'est Roland-Garros, la grande rencontre des tennis menée Paris. Chaque jour, plus de 30 mille personnes se massent sur les gradins autour des courts de tennis en terre battue où s'affrontent les plus grands joueurs internationaux.

Très prisé par les passionnés du sport, Roland-Garros est aussi un rendez-vous chic où l'on croise des stars et des hommes politiques . . . on y voit aussi des acteurs tout bronzés qui arrivent droit du festival de Cannes.

Dommage, cette année, le beau temps est le grand absent sur la capitale française. Mais entre les averses, le spectacle continue. J'ai parlé du tournoi à une journaliste sportive, Kate Davenport, et deux fans du jeu, Timothée (21 ans) et Hélène (25 ans).

Kate Davenport, journaliste sportive: Certains joueurs sont déjà des numéros un mondiaux, mais des joueurs peu connus peuvent aussi se qualifier et il y a parfois des surprises. Par exemple, cette année, une jeune Espagnole qui s'appelle Marta Marrero s'est qualifiée pour les quarts de finale et c'était assez surprenant.

Les matches se passent sur de la terre battue. Certains joueurs ne l'aiment pas du tout, par exemple Pete Sampras, l'Américain qui a été numéro un pendant six ans. Il a fait tous les titres mais il n'a jamais gagné Roland-Garros. Cette année, il a été éliminé au premier tour.

L'année dernière, il faisait très beau. Cette année c'est un peu moins rigolo parce que le temps est mauvais. C'est stressant pour les joueurs aussi : quand tu es en train de gagner un match et qu'il faut t'arrêter pendant deux heures, puis revenir, c'est difficile de maintenir la tension psychologique.

À part ça je trouve agaçante l'attitude des photographes qui s'emballent sur les jolies joueuses en petites jupettes. Les attitudes sexistes qui circulent sont assez choquantes.

Que penses-tu du tournoi ?

Timothée: J'y suis allé une fois, l'année dernière. C'était assez festif. C'est un événement ce Roland Garros, c'est particulier. Le tournoi est assez mondain. Ça fait bien de dire qu'on est allé à Roland-Garros et bien sûr, c'est un événement hyper médiatique. En même temps, les gens y vont pour l'amour du jeu. Cette année, je m'y suis pris trop tard pour avoir des places, c'est dommage.

Hélène: J'y suis déjà allée plein de fois. J'ai vu tellement de matches que c'est difficile de savoir lequel a été le plus spectaculaire.

Quelle est l'ambiance pendant le tournoi?

Timothée: Tout le monde est complètement sous l'emprise du jeu, tout le monde est passionné. C'est très difficile d'avoir des places donc quand on en a, on est super content.

Hélène: C'est génial, il y a une sorte d'euphorie dans l'air. Et quand ton joueur préféré gagne, t'es trop content. Même quand on regarde les matches à la télé, ils peuvent susciter des vraies émotions.

Quel est l'importance du tennis en France?

Timothée: Je le vois comme un sport chic, beaucoup moins populaire que le football ou le rugby, par exemple. Je ne sais pas pourquoi, mais ce sport est réservé à une certaine classe sociale.

Hélène: Dès que Roland-Garros arrive, le goût pour le tennis revient chez les Français. Et pendant le tournoi, dès qu'il y a un match de tennis très important, on n'hésite pas à décaler une émission à la télé pour pouvoir suivre le match, spécialement quand il y a un Français qui joue.

Y-a-t-il un mauvais côté du tournoi?

Timothée: Le côté médiatique de Roland-Garros prend de plus en plus d'ampleur tous les ans. On exploite la figure des joueurs pour des campagnes publicitaires et la manipulation dont sont victimes les joueurs est un peu écoeurante.

Hélène: Le pire c'est la pluie. Surtout quand elle ne s'arrête pas comme cette année. C'est l'enfer pour les amateurs de tennis - t'achètes ton billet et quand il pleut, les matches sont annulés, et ils ne reprennent que quand la pluie s'arrête. Tout le monde y perd et franchement, il n'y a rien de plus triste que Roland-Garros sous la flotte.

Et toi, tu joues au tennis?

Timothée: J'adore ça, je joue tous les week-ends. Mais c'est sûr qu'il faut connaître les bons filons pour jouer dans Paris parce que évidemment, on ne peut pas y jouer n'importe où. Ça me défoule, j'aime taper précisément dans la balle. C'est un sport de concentration, un peu comme les échecs : il faut bien viser, avoir le terrain bien en tête . . . c'est toute une tactique.

Hélène: J'en ai vachement fait - même de la compet mais j'ai eu plein de problèmes aux genoux et j'ai d arrêter. En plus, j'en ai tellement fait à une époque que j'ai été un peu dégotée du sport. J'adore quand même jouer, mais maintenant c'est que du loisir.

il faut connaître les bons filons (coll.) you have to be in the know
une compet (coll.) a competition
se défouler to let off steam
être écoeurant to be sickening
être rigolo (coll.) to be funny
une figure face, personality
la flotte (coll.) rain, water
un gradin a terrace, tier
hyper (coll.) really
une télé (coll.) telly
court en terre battue a clay court

webTitle: 'He killed my mother. I want him locked up'

fields.headline: 'He killed my mother. I want him locked up'
fields.trailText: Kathy Tanner flew from Canada to watch from the public gallery as Richard Neale was accused of botching the treatment of 14 women yesterday. She had come, she said, "because he needs to be stopped". Neale, she says, killed her mother.
fields.body:
Kathy Tanner flew from Canada to watch from the public gallery as Richard Neale was accused of botching the treatment of 14 women yesterday. She had come, she said, "because he needs to be stopped". Neale, she says, killed her mother.

After the death of Geraldine Krawchuck, 40, during an induced labour in Ontario, Neale's licence to practise medicine in Canada was revoked. That was 15 years ago. He walked straight into a job as a consultant at the Friarage hospital in Northallerton, North Yorkshire. All the cases being considered by the GMC stem from that time.

Ms Tanner was 20 when her mother died. "He killed her," she said. At the time, she was told her mother's death was an isolated incident.

It was not until a television documentary was shown in Canada about the questions being asked in the UK that she realised there had been other problems. Now she says, she has laid a formal complaint with the police about her mother's death.

"I want him extradited to stand trial in Canada," she said. "I want to see him behind bars." She is in the UK to confront him with her mother's photograph.

Geraldine Krawchuck was five days overdue with her sixth baby when she was brought into hospital to be induced. She was given oxytocin, but did not seem to be in active labour. Neale decided to speed things up by administering a second drug, prostaglandin, which was not approved for use at that hospital - so he got it from another hospital.

It is not safe for the two drugs to be used together, particularly in a patient such as Ms Krawchuck, who was high risk because of her age and medical history, the report of the Canadian disciplinary committee said.

The baby was delivered so fast that her womb ruptured and other internal organs were damaged. She died later.

Neale was censured for the inappropriate drugs he used and for altering the record to suggest he had used a smaller dose.

fields.headline: Korea
fields.standfirst:
All you need to know about the east-Asian peninsula's 50-year history of conflict in links
Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the east-Asian peninsula's 50-year history of conflict  in links
fields.body:
1. The two presidents of Korea, Kim Dae Jung of the South and Kim Jong-il of the North, are due to meet today - the first summit in the troubled and bloody history of the peninsula.

2. The summit should have started yesterday, but North Korea demanded a postponement "for technical reasons".

3. No further enlightenment is offered by North Korea's Central News Agency, whose website is almost entirely free of news.

4. Trade and security issues will dominate the discussions, but there is also a piece of outstanding historical business: ending the war which broke out almost exactly 50 years ago.

5. The war started when seven divisions of North Korean troops crossed the 38th parallel to invade the South, on June 25, 1950.

6. The US led a formidable United Nations army to the rescue of democracy, or what passed for it, in the South. But when the North Koreans seemed defeated, the Chinese joined in, and the world stood on the brink of a new global conflict.

7. The Americans believed they could win the war virtually by air power alone. They came close to using nuclear weapons.

8. Three years of bitter fighting finally ended in July 1953, with the 38th parallel restored as the ceasefire line, but there has never been a formal peace treaty.

9. Throughout its 52-year history, North Korea has been a hard-line communist state. South Korea too has known despotism, but unlike its northern neighbour, it has prospered mightily.

10. The admirably dispassionate 'factbooks' published on the internet by the CIA, reveal that North Korea has a per capita GDP of just £600 - less than a twelfth of South Korea's. Between a quarter and a third of all the northern state's income goes on buying arms.

webTitle: The morning after the nightmare before

fields.headline: The morning after the nightmare before
fields.standfirst: Why England will still qualify; why Nevilles P and G scored 5.6; and why doesn't anyone want Pavel Srnicek?
fields.trailText: Why England will still qualify; why Nevilles P and G scored 5.6; and why doesn't anyone want Pavel Srnicek?
fields.body:
A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com. It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"You go 2-0 ahead and you've got to fancy your chances of winning." Kevin Keegan. Oh well.

THE EURO-TORIAL

It's over. If you listen to any of the voices calling for Kevin Keegan's head (a mere 24 hours after kissing it), England's 3-2 defeat by Portugal is a disgrace and the team should be forced to fly home before the end of the day. The coach has been castigated, the playing staff slated and even Des Lynam's banter has been criticised. Why this should happen after England's best performance for some time is a bit of a puzzler.

Sure, David Seaman was flapping like a tent door in the wind, Tony Adams showed his age, Paul Ince was missing, and Phil Neville was, well, Phil Neville. But England's performance last night was better than any other under Kevin Keegan and, with a few honourable exceptions, better than any under Glenn Hoddle, too. For the majority of the first half England passed the ball well, were compact in defence and incisive in attack. In the second half they started the better team too, only to fade badly after conceding the third goal.

If anything England exceeded their own expectations and, at two goals up, allowed their concentration to slip. One minute Paul Scholes was teasing three Portuguese midfielders, the next Figo had cracked in his 30-yarder. Echoes of Newcastle perhaps. But neither Germany nor Romania have the players to take advantage of this exuberance in the way that Portugal did, and if England can summon up two similar performances, starting in Charleroi on Saturday, they will qualify for the quarter-finals. Not that we're about to put any money on it.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A HIGHLY AVERAGE PERFORMANCE

fields.headline: Loyalist writer wins award
fields.trailText: The Belfast playwright Gary Mitchell has won the George Devine award for The Force Of Change, his controversial play about RUC collusion with loyalist terrorists.
fields.body:
The Belfast playwright Gary Mitchell has won the George Devine award for The Force Of Change, his controversial play about RUC collusion with loyalist terrorists.

Mitchell is the fifth playwright from Ireland to win the £8,000 award, the most prestigious theatre award for new writing, in six years.

The Guardian's theatre critic Michael Billington described the production at the Royal Court theatre in London as unmissable. "Last year, in Trust, he wrote a gripping play about the destructive impact of the Northern Irish Protestant ethic on its own children. Now in this even more nail-biting work he shows how both policing and terrorism are dominated by a boys' club atmosphere and by a series of interlocking collusions."

Mitchell, who lives in Rathcoole, the north Belfast housing estate where he was born, came to prominence three years ago with In a Little World of our Own. Seen early on as a lone voice grassroots loyalist, he has become a master of tense and complex thrillers.

fields.trailText: Arsenal are tracking Brazilian defender Edmilson. Teamtalk claim that Arsene Wenger sees the Sao Paolo player as a ready-made replacement for Tony Adams when he retires, and recently visited South America to examine the player at first hand.
fields.body:

The supposed exodus from Aston Villa continues. Teamtalk believe that Sunderland are interested in Ugo Ehiogu and Steve Watson, and could offer out-of-favour full-back Michael Gray as a make-weight in the deal.

Another Villa player who could be on his way out is Benito Carbone. The Daily Mail believes John Gregory will ditch the Italian and sign unwanted Manchester United striker Jordi Cruyff instead. webTitle: County cricket on the web and Lara in the press

fields.headline: County cricket on the web and Lara in the press
fields.standfirst: In wisden.com's twice-weekly gossip column, Charles de Lisle reveals how county cricketers are spreading their wings on the web, and why £25,000 represents a pay-cut for Brian Lara
fields.trailText: It's surf and turf as county dressing-rooms go on-line
fields.body:
It's surf and turf as county dressing-rooms go on-line

This season, for the first time, every county dressing-room is equipped with a computer. The laptops have been been provided by the Professional Cricketers' Association (PCA), which wants players to have ready access to its new website (cricnet.com). The computers also enable players to supply the site with their own match reports, columns and previews - categories include "duels & feuds" and "crocs corner".

Simon Ecclestone, the former Somerset captain who is now the PCA's communications manager, says: "Our aim was to find one potential journalist in each dressing-room. We've actually found two or three good writers at each county." He cites Derbyshire's Kevin Dean and Surrey's Jason Ratcliffe and Martin Bicknell as unexpected discoveries.

The PCA, which forked out over £10,000 for the partly sponsored laptops, also wishes to encourage members to air their opinions on county issues on the site. David Graveney, the PCA's chief executive, explains: "The rank-and-file player doesn't often have a chance to get his views across in public. So you may see views from the dressing-room appearing on our site. It's an extra dimension for the fan. But don't expect to find issues such as, say, the possibility of strike action being discussed."

Graveney says the new equipment is also intended to improve internal communication with the PCA's representatives at each club, as well as allowing all players to keep up with the latest cricket news from around the world. And the PCA, always concerned about members' long-term employment prospects, is anxious to give them every chance to become familiar with computers.

So the 18 county reps, some of whom have already been given some training, are showing inexperienced surfers the way. Some players already tap out their newspaper columns on the laptops, while others find them a godsend when rain stops play. Spurning the papers or the traditional game of cards, they while away the hours with computer games. As one county player puts it: "A lot of the lads play games on our laptop."

The idea that the computers might be used, as dressing-room video recorders have been known to be, for pornographic purposes, is, of course, unthinkable.

Lara takes a 50pc pay cut

Brian Lara may start the series against England this week ranked the world's second best Test batsman in the PricewaterhouseCoopers ratings, but his earning power isn't what it was. Lara is only being paid a total of £25,000 for his newspaper column in The Mail on Sunday, compared with the £40,000 the Daily Mail shelled out for his services during his marvellous season with Warwickshire in 1994. Then, Lara could dictate terms off the field as well as on it: he had just scored his Test record 375 against England.

Lara's Mail fee this time round actually represents a cut of nearly 50 per cent on that of six years ago - allowing for inflation, the £40,000 would now be about £47,000. The reduction is partly explained by the fact that Lara's thoughts will not appear every week. "He'll be a featured guest columnist most weeks, tying in with the Tests and one-day series," says a Mail on Sunday insider. Another consideration is Lara's poor time-keeping and unreliability, which at times made life difficult for the Mail sports team.

However the Mail on Sunday is concerned, most of all, that the fragile superstar may not complete the three-month tour. The paper's caution was justified soon enough: within days of signing for them early last month, Lara made himself unavailable for the Windies tour, then changed his mind 24 hours later.

For Lara, the column has already become a platform from which to reply to his critics. In his first piece, on June 4, he took the chance to describe as "untrue" reports that during those 24 hours he had held the West Indies Board to ransom over his availability - or asked for more money than his fellow tourists.

Charles de Lisle is the author, with Christopher Martin-Jenkins, of An Australian Summer: The Story of the 1998/9 Ashes Series (Faber). He can be contacted at cdelisle@compuserve.com

The Grapevine returns on Friday. For last Friday's column, featuring stories on how to watch England from a jacuzzi, and former England stars - and an ex-Prime Minister - turning out to honour Peter May, click here

webTitle: Ford bails from new Jack Ryan adventure

fields.headline: Ford bails from new Jack Ryan adventure
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford has pulled out of The Sum of All Fears, the latest Jack Ryan adventure based on the best-selling series by Tom Clancy. Ford had played the resolute post-cold war hero in two previous pictures, Patriot Games and Clear and Present Danger. His abrupt departure is being interpreted in some quarters as signalling a mounting career crisis for this most durable of movie stars.
fields.body:
Harrison Ford has pulled out of The Sum of All Fears, the latest Jack Ryan adventure based on the best-selling series by Tom Clancy. Ford had played the resolute post-cold war hero in two previous pictures, Patriot Games and Clear and Present Danger. His abrupt departure is being interpreted in some quarters as signalling a mounting career crisis for this most durable of movie stars.

According to The Hollywood Reporter, Ford had attempted to develop the project in tandem with director Philip Noyce (who directed the previous two Ryan outings), but found himself dissatisfied with the script. It is his second high-profile departure in three months, following on from his eleventh-hour hour exit from the starring role in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic (since filled by Michael Douglas).

In January, Ford signed on to an agency for the first time in 15 years in the hope of gaining access to more edgy and ambitious material from younger film-makers. The Soderbergh project looked an ideal first step in Ford's attempt to spring-clean his career, but he got cold feet only weeks before the film was set to go before the cameras.

At the time, his manager, Pat McQueeny, claimed that her client had pulled out of Traffic in order to make "an action film" widely interpreted as being The Sum of All Fears. The fact that the Ryan film too has now been passed over hints at a growing uncertainty over which direction to take, whether into unknown, risky new projects or back to familiar, big-budget conservative pictures. Neither, it seems, are satisfying Ford at present.

As a result, one of the world's most bankable movie stars finds himself in self-imposed joblessness. The last film that Ford completed was the supernatural thriller What Lies Beneath, directed by Robert Zemeckis and co-starring Michelle Pfeiffer, which opens in the US this summer. But advance word on the movie is not good. "Too bad what was lying beneath wasn't a good screenplay," quipped Harry Knowles in his review of the film on Ain't It Cool News.

fields.headline: Why Israel must help Bashar
fields.standfirst:
Israel must take a bold step for peace and help Syria's new leader defeat his political rivals

Syrian heir disputed by uncle in exile
fields.trailText: Israel must take a bold step for peace and help Syria's new leader defeat his political rivals, argues Middle East editor Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
The late President Hafez al-Assad is not yet buried, and already family squabbles have broken out over the succession of his 34-year-old son, Bashar.

Scheming Uncle Rifaat says the succession is a farce and a piece of theatre. It is a violation of the law and of the constitution, he says.

Uncle Rifaat knows all about the law and the constitution. He is the one who supervised the massacre of tens of thousands of people in Hama some years ago, and later plotted a military coup against his elder brother.

Of course, what's happening in Syria is not democratic - though amending the constitution at the drop of a hat, as happened on Saturday a couple of hours after the president's death, makes it look a bit more legitimate. But you can't have everything - especially in a country with such old-fashioned, paranoid ways as Syria.

Bashar is not merely the best of a rather grim bunch; if he succeeds he could be the biggest stroke of good luck that Syria has had for years. He may look too nerdy to be a potential Commander-in-Chief of the Syrian armed forces, but fortunately he is more interested in surfing the net than in going round shooting people.

If he is not constantly undermined by the old guard, Bashar will take his place, along with King Abdullah of Jordan and King Mohammed of Morocco, among the new generation of forward-looking Arab leaders. That will be good for Syria, for the Middle East, and for peace in the world.

It will take time, though. Bashar needs to establish himself in Damascus and his opponents will be ready to pounce at the first sign of weakness.

For that reason, it will be difficult for Bashar to make the first move towards re-starting the peace process with Israel. If he accepts a deal on the Golan Heights which is anything less than his father demanded, he will be finished politically - and nobody would be more disappointed to see him thrown out and replaced by an army general than the Israelis.

The Israelis are fond of recalling the historic ice-breaking visit that President Sadat of Egypt made to Jerusalem to address the Knesset. They often urged the late President Assad to do the same, though he refused. The political situation in Syria will almost certainly prevent Bashar from making such a visit.

The Israelis may be reluctant to do so, but if they really want a deal with Syria, they may have to take a bold initiative. fields.bodyText: The late President Hafez al-Assad is not yet buried, and already family squabbles have broken out over the succession of his 34-year-old son, Bashar. Scheming Uncle Rifaat says the succession is a farce and a piece of theatre. It is a violation of the law and of the constitution, he says. Uncle Rifaat knows all about the law and the constitution. He is the one who supervised the massacre of tens of thousands of people in Hama some years ago, and later plotted a military coup against his elder brother. Of course, what's happening in Syria is not democratic - though amending the constitution at the drop of a hat, as happened on Saturday a couple of hours after the president's death, makes it look a bit more legitimate. But you can't have everything - especially in a country with such old-fashioned, paranoid ways as Syria. Bashar is not merely the best of a rather grim bunch; if he succeeds he could be the biggest stroke of good luck that Syria has had for years. He may look too nerdy to be a potential Commander-in-Chief of the Syrian armed forces, but fortunately he is more interested in surfing the net than in going round shooting people. If he is not constantly undermined by the old guard, Bashar will take his place, along with King Abdullah of Jordan and King Mohammed of Morocco, among the new generation of forward-looking Arab leaders. webTitle: Silence will not defend the euro from its enemies

fields.headline: Silence will not defend the euro from its enemies
fields.standfirst:
Ministers are told that winning the general election is what counts

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair observed to colleagues yesterday that the chancellor of the exchequer must not be humiliated. It was an important but perhaps an academic remark.
fields.body:
Tony Blair observed to colleagues yesterday that the chancellor of the exchequer must not be humiliated. It was an important but perhaps an academic remark. Gordon Brown has variously let it be known that he will not be "bounced", or "pressured", or "driven off course", away from his determination not to admit the euro-sterling issue as a subject fit for political debate. His briefers having staked out that ground, Mr Brown, in the prime minister's view, has to be protected. So no more ministerial talk about the euro for a while. The strategy of silence, however, is rapidly being removed from politicians' control. Among other things, it touches exactly the public nerve that has sent Labour's poll lead plummeting into single figures.

The cabinet is pictured as divided over the euro. This is not the case. There aren't two camps of opposed convictions. This is not a re-run of Labour cabinets in the 1960s and 70s, in permanent battle over Europe. The divide is entirely about tactics, and not well formulated at that. If and when, after getting a second term, Mr Blair presses the button, there will not be a single cabinet dissenter.

Mr Brown's tactical attitude is not baseless. He wants to keep quiet now because he doesn't want his hands tied, but also because he wants the largest possible electoral majority. That's what Philip Gould is telling the party high command: saliency for the euro risks raising the Tory vote to 35%, and lowering the Labour majority. Even pro-euro Euros, who want a referendum and want it won, must hear that. The Brown case, shared by Blair, that the ideal time to confront the euro issue is after a big election victory, addresses seriously this most crucial of calculations.

But the strategy was born in a different era. In October 1997, when it was formed, and for two years after, the government thought it would have total control over the election agenda. It was easy to write decrees about what would and would not be debated. In June 2000, such assurance does not sing, and in May 2001 is likely to look even more remote from the facts. We're witnessing not a contest between cabinet factions, but events that are becoming bigger than both of them.

For one thing, everyone else is talking about the euro. The Brown blanket covers only a fraction of the public world. The very argument, about whether ministers should or should not discuss it, brings it to the centre of attention. This will carry on indefinitely. The imposition of silence intensifies the chatter, assisted by developments that cannot be stifled. Not one of the last 10 days has passed without a big intervention on the subject, whether from the OECD or Kenneth Clarke or the Treasury or, yesterday, an impressive, heavyweight statement of the pro-euro case from Britain in Europe, itself a body on which Blair and Brown imposed an earlier version of their non-intervention strategy.

The BiE evolution is an object lesson in the futility of this line. Euro-talk is seeping out all over. Every time a Japanese investor talks about withdrawal from the UK, it comes out further. This is certainly inconvenient. It upsets the measured approach Mr Blair laid down, forestalls the lengthy preparation he would prefer. But there it is. Uncontrollable, unstoppable, crackling the static every day, now beyond the reach of any chancellor to gag. That's the first reason why the tactical argument has a new context.

But there's a second, arising out of the calamity at the Women's Institute, which drove Philip Gould to put words round Mr Blair's dilemma: his crisis of credibility, his perceived lack of conviction, the sense he conveys of being all spin and presentation, the belief this engenders that he cannot hold to a position he believes in. None of these, I believe, are well justified perceptions. And Mr Gould was talking about issues that matter more than Europe to the voter: crime especially, asylum partly, the public services over all. Yet these depictions apply with some precision to the Blair-Brown strategy for Europe.

We know, after all, that they are both believers. Mr Blair categorically, and Mr Brown more contingently, are focused on getting into the euro. They have that clear idea, and they long ago rejected every political or constitutional argument against it. Yet they will not now say so. They favour a studied evasiveness, make a virtue out of non-debate. Is this not the very trait that Mr Gould put his finger on, in the memo leaked on Sunday? Could there be a plainer example of slippery politics, obsessed with presentation, than this concealment pro tem of a conviction which the leadership is in truth developing more strongly week by week?

The Gould answer to that would be to cite another part of his analysis, which said that Mr Blair was out of touch with ordinary people. Since ordinary people don't like the euro, the last way the prime minister could hope to remake his credentials as a man of the people is by going on about Europe. And, as far as empathy goes, that may be true. On the other hand, the costs of continuing evasion, making a ponderous virtue out of systematic silence, will soon not be sustainable.

The reason, ultimately, is rooted in truth. Because the euro has become part of the daily static, everyone knows it is the real issue, transcending all else to do with Europe. For ministers to be the only people not to talk about it will come to seem so perverse that the only intelligible explanation is cowardice, or deep, palpable, brazen cunning. Mr Brown plans to re-establish his strategy at the Mansion House on Thursday. Even if he rises to the height of his formidable grandeur to come crashing down on the euro-speculators among the pygmies who surround him in the cabinet, the mismatch between tactic and reality will remain. Unless it is reconsidered, much of the Gould critique will hang unrebutted in the air.

To change the line, making it more honest, would be painful. It would also give the Tories material to raise their game. However, that game is already going on. There's a lot of cheating with the facts, malign fantasies about the Labour programme, profound dishonesty as to the meaning of their own position. Attacking the breezy fecklessness with which William Hague would carry Britain to the irrelevant edge of the EU, prior to eventual dribbling departure, will be Labour's prime way of engaging.

But it is not enough. To recapture its name for clarity and conviction, sweeping away the fog of spin in which it has obscured itself, the government has nothing more urgent to talk about than the merits of the single currency. At present it is hooked to a policy which it denies itself the opportunity to defend. It fights with only half a heart, the silent spectator at other people's arguments. A cabinet of belief, not daring to say so. A spectacle to make one ask what happened since May 1997.

webTitle: Unions demand Labour election pledge on euro

fields.headline: Unions demand Labour election pledge on euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's leading trade unionists are to increase the pressure on Tony Blair to join the European single currency by tabling a pro-euro amendment to a draft of Labour's general election manifesto.
fields.body:
Britain's leading trade unionists are to increase the pressure on Tony Blair to join the European single currency by tabling a pro-euro amendment to a draft of Labour's general election manifesto.

Amid signs of a growing cabinet rift over the euro, the GMB leader John Edmonds will call on the party leadership to indicate in the manifesto that the next Labour government will take direct action to ease Britain's path towards the single currency.

Mr Edmonds' amendment, which will be tabled at a meeting of Labour's national policy forum, in Exeter next month, will call on the next Labour government to force down the value of sterling, thereby bringing it in line with the euro.

Pro-Europeans hope Mr Edmonds' amendment will succeed. Next month's policy forum is to be chaired by the fervently pro-European foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

Mr Cook shares Mr Edmonds' frustration with the chancellor Gordon Brown's current position on the euro - dubbed Labour's version of John Major's "wait and see" policy. The chancellor is committed to holding a referendum on British membership after the election, but only if a series of economic tests is met.

Pro-Europeans want Downing Street to firm up its position as they believe there will no hope of a "yes" vote in the referendum unless the government starts to take action now. The former Tory chancellor, Ken Clarke, will voice the Pro-Europeans' frustrations today when he warns that the government's policy has left Britain in "limbo".

His speech will be welcomed by Mr Edmonds, whose proposed amendment echoes the calls of pro-European Tories for government action to bring down the value of sterling.

His amendment, which is supported by the AEEU and the GPMU, will say: "As well as getting the UK entry date right, so must the entry rate be at the right level. The consensus is that the pound is at present too high for painless entry. Labour will not repeat the mistake that the Tories made in 1990 when the UK joined the exchange rate mechanism at a seriously overvalued rate."

GMB sources said they wanted the chancellor to "manipulate the economic levers" to bring Britain into line with its partners in euroland.

His intervention will be welcomed by members of the cabinet's pro-European wing, who are fighting a losing battle to force Mr Brown to sound more enthusiastic about the euro. The chancellor will slap down the pro-Europeans, who include Mr Cook, Peter Mandelson and Stephen Byers, in this week's Mansion House speech, insisting he will not change his "prepare and decide" policy.

William Hague will today attempt to exploit cabinet divisions over the euro and Tony Blair's relative silence on the issue. In a speech to the Institute of Economic Affairs, the Tory leader will say: "The prime minister's answer to the cabinet divisions on the euro is simple: he agrees with everyone. Supporting Gordon Brown one day and Peter Mandelson the next, Tony Blair reminds me of the line in that song: 'torn between two lovers, feeling like a fool; loving both of you, is breaking all the rules'."

Meanwhile, Rodney Bickerstaffe, the general secretary of Unison, which has 1.3m members, opened a new front against Labour as he criticised its economic policies.

The union leader echoed complaints from traditional Labour supporters in health, education and local authorities about the impact of the public finance initiative.

A report expected to be approved today by Unison's conference in Bournemouth criticises economic policies across the board. Gordon Brown, the chancellor, is due to address the meeting on Friday.

The Unison report backs a series of reforms opposed by the government, from a £5 minimum wage and 50% top tax rate to increased NHS spending and an end to the public finance initiative.

fields.headline: Border crossing
fields.standfirst: Suddenly communist North Korea and capitalist South Korea are shaking hands
fields.trailText: 13 June: Jerome Monahan explains the causes behind the conflict in Korea, the circumstances leading up to the meeting between the North and the South, and the significance of that meeting.
fields.body:
Imagine a land shaped like a downward pointing left-hand thumb. Make it jut out from northern China, with the Yellow Sea on one side and the Sea of Japan on the other and you have the peninsula shared by North and South Korea. And for more than a half century it has been a very sore thumb indeed - a place of war, division and tension. Until this week, that is, when for the first time ever the leaders of the two Koreas will meet face-to-face at a three-day summit conference in the North Korean capital Pyongyang.

Why is this meeting important?

It's important because, for more than 50 years, this has been one of the most unstable parts of Asia, if not the world. The summit is big news. It shows that the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung and the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il want to talk to each other. Its timing is also important. It comes just ahead of the 50th anniversary of the Korean War (1950-53) in which as many as 2.5m Koreans may have died.

Why has there been conflict?

It is because Korea was a victim of superpower rivalries between America and the former Soviet Union (USSR) after the second world war. This led to the country splitting into two - North Korea and South Korea - in 1948, and that led in turn to the Korean War. The war finally ended with a ceasefire not a peace treaty.

Do the two countries differ?

In every way. In North Korea there are no free elections. No one owns land privately and all the industries are told what to make by the state. Much of what the factories produce is for the army, and many things we take for granted are not available to buy. For example there is only one television set for every 10 people and even fewer telephones.

By contrast, South Korea is a capitalist country with one of the strongest economies in the world. It is a democracy - there are different political parties, and elections. The country is dominated by huge, family-run businesses. The army is very important in South Korea, too, and in the past it has behaved brutally against its own people, particularly students.

Why is the summit happening?

The South Korean president Kim Dae-jung is committed to a "sunshine policy" of positive contact with North Korea.

North Korea needs friends in the outside world because it has in trouble. Its main protector, the USSR, collapsed in the early 1990s, leaving it isolated. Cheap USSR oil supplies have dried up and there have been a series of floods and droughts. North Korea cannot feed its people and hundreds of thousands - possibly millions - have died of starvation over the past five years. No one knows for sure. More cooperation with South Korea may be its best chance of survival.

What will the summit achieve?

The two Kims will probably avoid discussing some of the most difficult topics, such as the north's missile programme or the presence in the south of large numbers of US troops. There will be time for these matters at later meetings.

But one very important agreement could be the relaxation of travel restrictions between the two Koreas, which would allow families living on opposite sides of the border to meet. Visiting the home of your ancestors is important to Koreans. There could also be agreement that the South will invest in the North. The summit could be the first small step towards final reunification of the two countries, but experts believe this is still a long, long way off.

One immediate benefit has been a change in the propaganda broadcasts across the demilitarised zone, between the two countries. Some of the usual insults have been shelved - and now the loudspeakers are sending messages of hope.

 Follow the day-to-day events at the summit at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk.
