 General information and statistics site (click on the link to Asia to find information about North and South Korea).
 Korean news services

The South Korean president Kim Dae-jung is committed to a "sunshine policy" of positive contact with North Korea. North Korea needs friends in the outside world because it has in trouble. Its main protector, the USSR, collapsed in the early 1990s, leaving it isolated. Cheap USSR oil supplies have dried up and there have been a series of floods and droughts. North Korea cannot feed its people and hundreds of thousands - possibly millions - have died of starvation over the past five years. No one knows for sure. More cooperation with South Korea may be its best chance of survival. What will the summit achieve? The two Kims will probably avoid discussing some of the most difficult topics, such as the north's missile programme or the presence in the south of large numbers of US troops. There will be time for these matters at later meetings. But one very important agreement could be the relaxation of travel restrictions between the two Koreas, which would allow families living on opposite sides of the border to meet. Visiting the home of your ancestors is important to Koreans. There could also be agreement that the South will invest in the North. The summit could be the first small step towards final reunification of the two countries, but experts believe this is still a long, long way off. One immediate benefit has been a change in the propaganda broadcasts across the demilitarised zone, between the two countries. Some of the usual insults have been shelved - and now the loudspeakers are sending messages of hope.  Follow the day-to-day events at the summit at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk.  Huge link site to all things Korean  General information and statistics site (click on the link to Asia to find information about North and South Korea).  Korean news services  First Edition is a current affairs series for schools on C4 presented this week by Jon Snow and produced in association with Guardian Education. fields.headline: The best paternal scene: Gladiator
fields.trailText: Germania. The second century AD. Following the latest triumph of the forces of Rome, the dying Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) summons his only son, the pasty, venal Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) to his quarters. Commodus is fully expecting their meeting to conclude with his being bequeathed the Empire. He stands before his father, awaiting the good news. Marcus Aurelius approaches, his voice soft but intractable.
fields.body:
Germania. The second century AD. Following the latest triumph of the forces of Rome, the dying Emperor Marcus Aurelius (Richard Harris) summons his only son, the pasty, venal Commodus (Joaquin Phoenix) to his quarters. Commodus is fully expecting their meeting to conclude with his being bequeathed the Empire. He stands before his father, awaiting the good news. Marcus Aurelius approaches, his voice soft but intractable.

"You will not be Emperor."

For a moment, Commodus appears winded. He tries to catch his breath. Eventually, he recovers enough composure to reply.

"And which older, wiser man is to take my place?"

"My powers will pass to Maximus," the Emperor answers briskly. "To hold in trust until the Senate is ready to rule once more. Rome is to be a Republic again."

Commodus swallows hard.

"Maximus."

Marcus Aurelius reaches out towards his son, but Commodus jerks away.

"My decision disappoints you?"

Commodus stares bitterly at his father, his tone growing more desperate and furious with every word.

"You wrote to me once, listing the four chief virtues. Wisdom, justice, fortitude and temperance. As I read the list, I knew I had none of them."

He chokes back a tear.

"But I have other virtues, father. Ambition - that can be a virtue when it drives us to excel."

Marcus Aurelius says nothing.

See also: The Empire Strikes Back, The Godfather, Festen, Happiness

Don't see also: The Prince Of Tides

fields.headline: Staff quit troubled school
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The London secondary school where head teacher Philip Lawrence was stabbed to death in 1995 has been hit by mass resignation of staff just months after a new head was sent in by a private sector hit squad, it was confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
The London secondary school where head teacher Philip Lawrence was stabbed to death in 1995 has been hit by mass resignation of staff just months after a new head was sent in by a private sector hit squad, it was confirmed yesterday.

Westminster city council said it had received resignation letters from eight of the 40 teaching staff at St George's Roman Catholic school in Maida Vale, north-west London, who will leave at the end of this term.

Earlier this year education chiefs declared the school "out of control" and under threat of closure after a breakdown of discipline under the headteacher, Margaret Ryan, who decided to take early retirement.

Police were called in to break up a fight, and pupils were reported to fight regularly in the classrooms, corridors and the playground. The head was blamed for retaining troublesome pupils, although her supporters said government targets to reduce exclusions did not help.

A private sector hitsquad headed by Nord Anglia was sent in to restore discipline, and a new head teacher, Marie Stubbs, was hired. But some staff have complained privately about the difficult working conditions and the personal style of Lady Stubbs, wife of Sir William Stubbs, chairman of the government's qualifications and curriculum authority.

Yesterday Tim Joiner, chairman of education in Westminster, said a 20% resignation level towards the end of the year was typical of an inner city school.The local education authority had full confidence in Lady Stubbs, he added. "She is doing a great job and school attendance levels are already up by 4%."

fields.headline: When passions fly
fields.standfirst: Academic freedoms have to be preserved but in a form acceptable today
fields.trailText: Academic freedoms have to be preserved but in a form acceptable today
fields.body:
What distinguishes higher education from other careers? Why are so many academics fiercely independent and reluctant to accept authority?

As a recent newcomer to academia from industry, I quickly found management is not always welcome, nor even familiar, in universities. And I've been taken aback at how often, when changes are introduced or old habits challenged no matter how venerable or new the institution, the same war cry is passionately invoked: "Academic freedom".

Can it be reconciled with modern notions of management? Is it a freedom confined to academic teachers - or applicable to students, too? If so, surely the interests of students must limit those of their tutors, imposing on them obligations as well as rights? And how are managers to negotiate between them?

All the academic colleagues I've spoken to take for granted the intrinsic importance of academic freedom. David Papineau, professor of philosophy at King's College, London, described it as "freedom from the ideologies of Church and State" - a reminder that these values date back to the medieval universities. Though run by the church, they strenuously upheld the privileges of their community of scholars: self-government and free inquiry.

In Britain the cloistered existence of academics has been evaporating since the 1970s, when higher education underwent rapid expansion accompanied by tough limits on expenditure and greater demands for accountability and quality assurance.

The encroachment of market forces has damaged what academics regard as their most sacred right - the freedom to pursue, impartially, their chosen field of research.

"The concept of academic freedom enshrined in our university system for the last 200 years has been gradually eroded," says Chandra Wikramsinghe, professor of applied mathematics and astronomy at Cardiff University. "Now universities tend to be much more restrictive because they want assured results."

And funding can always disappear if the research findings are uncomfortable. Richard Lacey, former professor of medical microbiology at Leeds University, was one of the first scientists to suggest BSE could be passed to humans. His funding was cut in 1995 and the NHS staff working for him redeployed.

"The concept of academic freedom is a myth," Lacey asserts, "because to have a fulfilled and successful academic life you've got to get grant money. My ideal of academic freedom is that sincere academics should be provided with central funding for research and general maintenance to pursue the research they wish."

But others believe academic freedom should embrace more than that. They fear changes in the higher education culture undermine a more basic set of values, assuming they must threaten academic freedom.

This general disquiet is intensified by the flexible use of the term itself. Some brandish it when justifying otherwise questionable actions. Others just use it as an excuse to do exactly as they wish - eg pursuing research at the expense of teaching commitments.

"Academic freedom as enshrined in the Education Reform Act is the right to question and challenge received opinion," says Tom Wilson, head of the universities department of Natfhe. "But it does not mean the right not to be managed, and should not be used as a blanket defence against managerial instruction."

In his book, The Idea of Higher Education, Professor Ronald Barnett, at London's Institute of Education, says: "The traditional discussions of academic freedom... frequently exhibit the following: a lack of specificity; a concern for the academic freedom of staff and not students; a defensive proclamation of the rights of academics; and a disinclination to say anything about the duties that should accompany academics' rights."

He then enumerates the academic freedoms that students should enjoy: freedom from indoctrination, from subjection to enforced ideology and from unfair practices in admissions, teaching and assessment; and the freedom to determine the subjects studied, to have some control over the manner and pace of study and to follow a particular interest or develop a point of view of one's own.

But the picture changes once you accept the claim of students to academic freedom. That of academics has to be defined in relation to duties as well as rights. For Tom Wilson, academic freedom, the right to question, must operate through agreed procedures which protect staff and students within the framework of the institution.

Ronald Barnett believes it should be confined to the scholarly interests of individuals. "They must be free to think and say what they wish within their sphere of academic competence." This constraint, he maintains, preserves professional and academic autonomy within the more controlled environment of the modern university.

David Papineau also concedes that academic freedom has limits: "It does not include the freedom to do poor work." For that would threaten the academic freedom of students. Managers have to balance the interests of staff and students. Far from threatening academic freedom, our job is to safeguard it.

 Sally Feldman is dean of the School of Media, London College of Printing.

fields.headline: Testimone
fields.standfirst: Andrea Andermann, creator of La Traviata as broadcast last week, explains the concept
fields.trailText: Andrea Andermann, creator of La Traviata as broadcast last week, explains the concept
fields.body:
Ci ho messo otto anni a ideare e produrre questa "Traviata" nei luoghi originali, come ne avevo impiegati dieci per la "Tosca" del '92 (con Catherine Malfitano e Placido Domingo). Citando il regista Abel Gance, potrei dire che "la demesure est ma mesure." Entrambi i progetti sono figli della dimensione del grande spettacolo. Questa "Traviata" ha coinvolto 125 Paesi e circa un miliardo di spettatori. La scommessa era congiungere un pubblico molto vasto, quasi da Giochi Olimpici, con la qualità.

Negli ultimi tre mesi abbiamo provato tutti i giorni a Parigi con 500 persone, per arrivare a una forma di automatismo nell'esecuzione artistica. Eteri Gvazava, la protagonista, ha vissuto sei mesi di "sequestro" per il ruolo di Violetta, José Cura ha provato ininterrottamente per un mese e mezzo. La televisione per me deve accadere sotto gli occhi di chi guarda. Il pubblico sente che c'è questo aspetto circense, da Colosseo, da bestie che possono mangiarsi il cristiano. La diretta dà una scarica di adrenalina agli artisti e a noi. Certo, sarebbe stato più curato fare un film. Ma questo lo chiamo un film in diretta, ed è un po' come il Barnum: tutta l'operazione era legata alla fragilità estrema della corda vocale del cantante e del cavetto della telecamera. Ci dicono che siamo stati un po' pazzi, ma ne è valsa la pena. Abbiamo scelto di girare all'ambasciata d'Italia, a Versailles, al Petit Palais e all'Ille Saint-Louis.

Il momento più da brivido è stato quando, durante il primo atto, la telecamera è andata in tilt per tre secondi: eravamo nel quartiere delle ambasciate, poco distante dalla sede del primo ministro, ed è chiaro che ci trovavamo all'intersezione di molti campi elettromagnetici. Lì per lì abbiamo persino pensato a interferenze dovute a spionaggi e controspionaggi, ma non ci risulta che oltre allo spionaggio industriale ne esista anche uno musicale! .

circense circus-like
diretta live TV
valere la pena to be worth it
da brivido chilling

fields.headline: Power and responsibility
fields.trailText: We school governors have been an integral part of the education system for many years.
fields.body:
We school governors have been an integral part of the education system for many years. Previously, local authorities "ran" schools and held all the power. Since the introduction of local management of schools, the balance has shifted towards more autonomy under the direction of governing bodies.

However, alongside this has come increasing responsibility for governing bodies and a growing ambivalence about our role.

The latest responsibility is in relation to the performance of the head. The recommendation is that there should be 10 hours' training for the governors taking part in this process, guided by an outside adviser. We all hope the outcome of performance management reviews will be agreed - but what if there is outright dispute? Most governing bodies are not the employers, so what is our position?

And if the role of the local authority is to be curtailed, is the head still to be its employee? Many heads would like more autonomy, but then the accountability is less clear. Surely this must be the role of the governing body in the 21st century; unless the government has plans for more central control.

Government ambiguity towards governors prevails. The corporate nature of the governing body, which has been its strength, is even now being undermined by the enhancement of one sector over the others - parent governors. Governing bodies have been specifically devised to represent all aspects of the local community. Parent governors are now being elected to local authorities. They supposedly represent parents, but they are elected by other parent governors - not by all parents - thus their role is also confused.

What are we expected to be? How about a body of people with proper recognition, who can contribute in a productive way to the whole programme of achievement in our schools. A "ring-fenced" method of paying expenses would be a good start, as many governors still will not claim allowances from the school's budget.

Remember it is the governing body whom Ofsted and the press hold responsible when things go wrong. Give us some high-profile support and authority. We in turn will have to be accountable for the use of that authority.

 Chris Gale is chair of the National Governors Council.

fields.headline: Grim portents
fields.standfirst: Why aren't colleges feeling more optimistic about the new bill?
fields.trailText: Why aren't colleges feeling more optimistic about the new bill?
fields.body:
I've followed the parliamentary debates on the Learning and Skills bill with deepening gloom. Members have shown their concerns to safeguard sixth forms indefinitely, to secure generous continuing support for learners with special needs, to reassure local education authorities (who have been told they are to have a central role in planning all post-16 learning) and to strengthen adult and community education opportunities. TECs have been told that their past work is valued.

But colleges haven't been much valued in the debates - especially the general further education colleges. There has been no applause for our success in the last decade in improving quality, in extending learning opportunities, in creating demand by new learners through innovative (and collaborative) local energies.

If the colleges get mentioned at all it's usually a putdown: criticism by ministers about unwise franchising (franchising having been a policy priority of the previous government, which wanted wider access to Further Education Funding Council money); criticism of the management of some colleges, and implicitly of all; and criticism of the funding council for not being interventionist enough.

My friends in the Association of Colleges tell me I am reading it wrongly, that the colleges are to be at the core of the new system, and it's important to reassure everybody else; less and less do I believe them.

Two thirds of the funding to the new Councils will be money presently managed by the Further Education Funding Council and mostly spent through the colleges (£4bn out of £6bn). Eighty per cent of this college's present budget may come through the local Learning and Skills Councils in the future (funding council funds, work-based training contracts with two TECs, subcontracting of adult and community education work from two local education authorities).

If colleges like this are not confident about future relationships and their scope to innovate, the government's agenda is not going to be met. Colleges are to have no role in setting strategy, merely to be "providers". The quotas, which are not to be called quotas, but are in fact quotas, for membership of the local Learning and Skills Councils will include pretty well everybody except those representing colleges. Nobody will be surprised if colleges are less unenthusiastic about risk-taking and are concentrating upon consolidating against an unfriendly future.

The consultation proposals for the new inspection regime conclude that all curriculum areas should be inspected. Good. The proposals are for less attention than now to be paid to inspecting support of learning, management and governance. The hint is that local Learning and Skills Councils will have an interest in such matters. Has anybody told governors? If college governors, recently in receipt of glossy files increasing further the expectation of their voluntary responsibilities, are to be answerable to local Learning and Skills Councils in which they have no investment, we might be facing tension, even a crisis in governance.

A chief education officer said to me that colleges won't need to do any strategic planning in the future because the local LSC will do it for them. I was asked recently for a sound bite about whom I would like to see as members of the Learning and Skills Councils; the crucial issue for me now is who gets chosen at senior levels in local Learning and Skills Councils, and what kind of culture of collaboration, or of control and contracting, they bring. If it's what we've experienced as work-based training contractors the prospects are depressing.

People in the colleges are as signed up to the government's agenda for post-16 learning as the government would wish: high quality learning and achievement, outreaching strategies to address social exclusion, working with voluntary agencies, collaborative activity and response in local communities.

We know that colleagues in the TECs and perhaps in the funding council feel vulnerable because of the changes proposed, that their work is implicitly devalued. People working in colleges ought to be feeling more optimistic than they are. Not long ago I asked a senior and respected DfEE official if the bill means the end of the colleges sector. He shrugged off the question and said of course not.

But it's likely that it does, and the implications aren't being addressed.

 Gordon Stokes is principal of North Warwickshire & Hinckley College.

Nobody will be surprised if colleges are less unenthusiastic about risk-taking and are concentrating upon consolidating against an unfriendly future. The consultation proposals for the new inspection regime conclude that all curriculum areas should be inspected. Good. The proposals are for less attention than now to be paid to inspecting support of learning, management and governance. The hint is that local Learning and Skills Councils will have an interest in such matters. Has anybody told governors? If college governors, recently in receipt of glossy files increasing further the expectation of their voluntary responsibilities, are to be answerable to local Learning and Skills Councils in which they have no investment, we might be facing tension, even a crisis in governance. A chief education officer said to me that colleges won't need to do any strategic planning in the future because the local LSC will do it for them. I was asked recently for a sound bite about whom I would like to see as members of the Learning and Skills Councils; the crucial issue for me now is who gets chosen at senior levels in local Learning and Skills Councils, and what kind of culture of collaboration, or of control and contracting, they bring. If it's what we've experienced as work-based training contractors the prospects are depressing. People in the colleges are as signed up to the government's agenda for post-16 learning as the government would wish: high quality learning and achievement, outreaching strategies to address social exclusion, working with voluntary agencies, collaborative activity and response in local communities. We know that colleagues in the TECs and perhaps in the funding council feel vulnerable because of the changes proposed, that their work is implicitly devalued. People working in colleges ought to be feeling more optimistic than they are. Not long ago I asked a senior and respected DfEE official if the bill means the end of the colleges sector. He shrugged off the question and said of course not. But it's likely that it does, and the implications aren't being addressed.  Gordon Stokes is principal of North Warwickshire & Hinckley College.

fields.headline: Careers advice
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Good morning. Can I help you?
fields.body:
Good morning. Can I help you?

No, can I help you? Sorry?

I want to be a careers adviser. What sort of careers adviser?

Are you trying to be funny? No more than usual.

So this isn't some wrong kind of leaves gag? No. There are government careers advisers and there are private, commercial careers advisers.

And which sort are you? I work for the careers service, which is a statutory provision for young people throughout the UK and is delivered by a number of organisations working under contract to the Department for Education and Employment in England, or in Scotland and Wales, to the Scottish and Welsh offices.

So what do you do? I help my clients to make informed, realistic decisions about their future education and training and to put these decisions into practice. I also liaise with school staff and support staff, such as educational welfare officers and social workers, and may train them in employment and training developments. I also help schools to build up information resources for the use of all pupils.

Is that it? Far from it. I have regular contact with employers and advise them of developments in education and training, on recruiting young employees and of young peoples' right to time off for study and training. In any spare time, I mug up on different jobs and training schemes, keep up-to-date with the local labour market and keep an eye out for jobs and training vacancies for young people. If I'm really pushed I may also arrange work experience placements and set up educational business projects.

So, do you only work with young people? For the most part, yes. But some careers advisers do offer a guidance service for adults, although they have no statutory duty to do so. Some advisers may even specialise in working with adults.

Are there any other specialisms? Yes. You can work with special needs clients, unemployed clients, ethnic minority clients, further education students, disaffected clients and in employer liaison. However, it is usual for a newly trained adviser to gain general experience before considering whether to specialise.

Where would I be working? Most advisers are based in offices that are open to the public, though a few may work out of schools. You will also spend much of your time in schools, colleges and with employers and training providers. From time to time, you may even visit young people and their parents or carers in their own homes. This will involve a great deal of local travel, and many jobs require career advisers to hold a full driving licence and have a car.

Fair dos. So what else will I need? Good communication skills are essential, especially liste...

Get on with it, I haven't got all day. As I was saying, you'll need good listening, speaking and writing skills, and you must be able to get on with a wide range of people. This requires self-confidence, sensitivity and a mature outlook.

You've described me to a T. Now get on and tell me what academic qualifications I'll need, sonny. There are currently three different professional qualifications. Applicants for the Diploma in Careers Guidance need either a degree, two A levels and three GCSEs or equivalent qualifications, such as GNVQ level 3. There are no set entry requirements for the NVQ/SVQ Guidance level 4 or for the Qualification for Careers Guidance.

Now, what about the dosh? There is no set salary scale. Careers companies have their own scales of between £14,000 and £21,000 a year. Senior advisers can earn up to £25,000 and chief executives more than £40,000.

Brill. When are you off?

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

 The Institute of Careers Guidance, 27a Lower High St, Stourbridge, West Midlands DY8 1TA. Telephone: 01384 376464

 Improvement and Development Agency, Layden House, 76-86 Turnmill St, London EC1M 5QU. Telephone: 0207 296 6600

fields.headline: Speak up, sir!
fields.standfirst: If the teaching profession believes that its treatment by the media is unfair, then it must fight back
fields.trailText: If the teaching profession believes that its treatment by the media is unfair, then it must fight back
fields.body:
Any reporter covering education soon learns that most teachers regard media coverage as unfair, focusing on problems rather than achievements.

Such critics accuse the media of giving disproportionate attention to atypical schools such as the failing schools "named and shamed" by the government. Indeed they could argue that the very phrase "named and shamed" is characteristic of the media's sensationalist tone.

People in education are, understandably, hurt when good news is ignored and bad news makes headlines. I am often told the media should "celebrate" the successes of schools.

Yet try applying this to other areas: do teachers expect the media to "celebrate" the successes of the government rather than focus on the problems it has yet to resolve? Should the news report that several thousand hospital operations have been completed successfully or should it highlight those that have gone wrong because of neglect, incompetence or under-funding?

But there is a simpler reason why education gets the media coverage it deserves: many educators make little effort to influence the news agenda and have abandoned the public debate to the politicians and polemicists.

Many people working in education wish it had a better image but do not feel it is their responsibility, or within their capability, to change it. Yet the media needs the input of experts and practitioners if it is to contribute sensibly to the public debate.

Sadly, it has become increasingly difficult for the media to gain access to schools and universities, especially since market forces have put them in competition with one another.

Yet when they take the plunge, it often works to their advantage. Take Gordon Brown's recent attack on the "elitism" of Oxford University for rejecting comprehensive school pupil Laura Spence. Stung by the Chancellor's attack, Magdalen College came out fighting and gave me and my film crew full access to tutors and students. The result was a report that showed a selection process that is painstakingly careful to avoid discriminating against comprehensive school pupils. Oxford students from state schools eagerly approached us wanting to correct the impression given by Gordon Brown.

Magdalen also broke with precedent and released details of the applications and acceptances for medicine, the course that rejected Laura Spence. Only one in four applicants were from comprehensive schools, yet of the five accepted, two were from comprehensives, three were women and three were from ethnic minorities. Gordon Brown's elitism charge collapsed.

It was the same with William Hague's speech on school discipline. He had hoped to do for "young thugs" what he had done for asylum seekers, arguing that the "liberal elite" were putting the interests of the minority of disruptive pupils ahead of the well-behaved majority. He cited a specific example: the Zaccheus Centre in Birmingham, which he offered as a model for his proposed off-site "progress centres" to replace the government's "gimmick" of on-site learning support units.

But a visit to the Zaccheus Centre revealed a more complex reality. It soon emerged that despite being held up as a model by Hague, it was actually funded by the Labour government. Moreover, its director believed different types of provision were needed for different pupils and rejected the Tory leader's idea of scrapping learning support units.

In both these cases, openness enabled journalists to give a clearer picture than the one presented by political rhetoric. In general, the public will trust schools and colleges ahead of most politicians but only if those institutions are not secretive.

When schools are attacked, it is usually in their interests to be open. The Ridings School in Halifax, Yorkshire, received awful coverage while it kept the media outside. Once the new acting head, Peter Clark, was in place he invited the media in. It helped to show the public the progress being made and the difficulties the staff faced.

There are some courageous headteachers and teachers who, for the good of their profession, invite the media into their school to help air important issues. Without the grass-roots evidence they provide, the public debate on education policy would be much poorer.

University education departments could also do more. In science, academics have tried to bridge the gap between themselves and the public with a scheme for scientists to shadow people in the media and a university chair for the public understanding of science.

Which university will take the bold step of appointing a professor for the public understanding of education?

Language is also terribly important. In the 1970s, as media coverage of schools became highly critical, even hostile, the education profession went on the defensive. It drew its wagons into a circle and ignored the public debate. As educators increasingly spoke only to one another, a new "education-speak" developed.

This protective jargon talks of "best practice" as if it is some self-evident truth needing no further explanation. It prefers "learning environments" to "classrooms", "diagnostic assessments" to tests.

The failure of teachers to speak in a language that parents understood led to them losing the public argument. One reason why Chris Woodhead, chief inspector of schools, is so successful in attracting media attention is the directness of his language.

There is also a need to counter the government's domination of the news agenda. Many things happen in schools that merit media attention. Unfortunately, many such stories are never reported because those involved do not think it is important.

It is also difficult to get access to schools on controversial issues such as funding shortages, teacher recruitment or discipline.

The independent school sector deals with media inquiries much more confidently. This may be because they have the professional services of their own press and information team, the Independent Schools Information Service. Few local education authority press offices can match them. Perhaps it is time state schools banded together to create a state schools information service. It could recommend schools to journalists, promote school-based initiatives, and help schools in trouble to deal with the media.

A membership fee spread between 25,000 schools need not be burdensome. Indeed, it would prove much cheaper than the costs some schools already pay for individual PR advice.

We are emerging from a period of intense policy change. Inevitably the government has dominated the agenda. But as the flow of Whitehall initiatives slows down, there will be more space for others to set the agenda. Now is the time for the teaching profession to regain its voice in the public debate via the media.

 Mike Baker is the BBC's education correspondent. This is a shortened version of his inaugural lecture as visiting professor at the Institute of Education at 6pm tomorrow. The full version is available from their bookshop (tel: 020-7612 6050).

fields.headline: Food science
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor finds out what's on the virtual menu
fields.body:
Nutrition Foundation
****
Aimed at: everyone

The British Nutrition Foundation's education section includes food posters and guidance on A-level and Scottish food technology syllabi. The A-level section also has an excellent list of links; its information on different foodstuffs would be very useful in class.

Institute of Food Science
****
Aimed at: teachers

Explains the work of the institute, which exists to further the study of food science and help practitioners to work together. Buried deep within the site is the Schools section, a series of suggested experiments and links for projects.

Food Standards Agency
**
Aimed at: everyone

A rather dull government site that sets out the steps taken to make British food safer folowing the BSE, food poisoning and GM food scares.Could be useful for A-level projects on food safety topics, but too detailed for earlier key stages.

Arizona Health Services
***
Aimed at: everyone

Sections on food safety, nutrition, recipes and the use of vitamin and mineral supplements make this a helpful site for links research, although the perspective is American rather than British (and recommended daily intakes vary between the two).

McDonald's Food Facts
**
Aimed at: teachers

"The more you know about the foods you eat, the easier it is to incorporate them into a balanced diet." Yes... Here teachers can download a detailed list of ingredients for McDonald's foods. Downloading the Burger King version (Adobe Acrobat needed for both sheets) would enable pupils to make nutritional comparisons. Avoid the rest of the BurgerKing site, which is of entertainment rather than educational value.

Seafish Education
***
Aimed at: everyone

This is run by the EC Financial Instrument for Fisheries Guidance, no less, and has plenty of classroom resources for key stages 2-4, including the Seafish Story and Talking Fish. Comprehensive and fun.

Dole 5 a day
****
Aimed at: everyone

An excitable site encouraging visitors to obtain their five portions of fruit and vegetable each day. The encyclopaedia, story books, songs and colouring book are all absorbing, and would probably entertain key stage 2 pupils.

All About Eggs
****
Aimed at: everyone

Excellent resources and activities for all key stages.

British Meat Foundation
**
Aimed at: everyone

Seeks to promote the British meat industry, although there are no teaching materials. A comparison with the equally partisan but more classroom-oriented Vegetarian Society would provide balance.

webTitle: A new angle on an old problem

fields.headline: A new angle on an old problem
fields.trailText: Proof that British design is alive and prospering can be found in a school in Salisbury.
fields.body:
Proof that British design is alive and prospering can be found in a school in Salisbury. Ellie Baker, a sixth-form student at South Wiltshire Grammar School, was forecast a respectable but unremarkable C grade in her design and technology A level earlier in the course. But thanks to a truly innovative project, Ellie not only improved her chances of gaining a far higher grade, but has also produced a way for the visually impaired and physically disabled to gain independence on the high seas, much to the delight of the Jubilee Sailing Trust.

Each year, Basingstoke and Deane Borough Council funds places for 16- to 21-year-olds to sail with the trust. Two of the four successful mariners selected from over 50 applicants are currently racing in the 55m long Lord Nelson, on the Cadiz to Bermuda leg of the Tall Ships 2000 transatlantic race.

The crew of the ship is a mixture of professionals and amateurs, although 40% must be under 25. The Jubilee Sailing Trust helps to ensure that there are no barriers on the grounds of disability. The trust's second ship, the 65m Tenacious, will be making her maiden voyage in September.

And this is where Ellie's invention plays its part. She explains: "I was at the boat show - I love sailing - and I had just lost the sailing-linked project I thought I was going to work on. My boyfriend's brother stopped me at the sailing trust stand, and told them I wanted a project. They put me in touch with Captain John Fisher [senior master of the trust] and he gave me the task of designing the rubber angle indicator for visually impaired and wheelchair-bound people." The aim is that by using the indicator in conjunction with the talking compass, which is already used beside the ship's wheel, the person steering will have greater independence and be able to ascertain in which direction they are heading.

Ellie's design allows the helmsperson to find out the angle of the rudder by a system of cables and sprung pins that are lifted to indicate the line of direction. Richard Walker, the trust's chief engineer, says he is extremely impressed with the quality and detail of Ellie's project. Whilst it is too late to be fitted to the Tenacious for her maiden voyage, he believes that with some modification, the invention will be on both Tenacious and the Lord Nelson very soon.

Steve Ungi, Ellie's teacher, is equally impressed. He explains that the project was an extremely ambitious and technical one, but that Ellie "really bit the bullet and was inspired by it. As the emphasis in this course is on the communication of a design and working with a real client, from inception through to the modelling stage, Ellie's skills in these areas have been raised considerably." In fact, Ungi will accompany Ellie to the University of Bath on July 4, where she will present her design in the final for the Young Engineer of Britain competition.

Ellie's invention will be a bonus for people like Steve Donohue, a former policeman who lost his sight but who sails regularly with the trust. He is familiar with the talking compass, but he says that if Ellie's device is as good as it sounds, he's looking forward to helming the ship in and out of port - something that is impossible at the moment.

Richard Dyson, inventor of the bagless vacuum cleaner, has said that in inventing, "99.99% of what you do is a failure". Given the enthusiasm generated by the rubber angle indicator, Ellie can proudly count herself as an exception to the rule.

For further information on the work of the Jubilee Sailing Trust, telephone 02380 449108.

fields.headline: Lecturers' chance to shine
fields.trailText: These are some of the best lecturers in England and Northern Ireland. Each one has been chosen by their university or college to go forward in the £1m awards scheme launched by the Institute for Learning and Teaching.
fields.body:
These are some of the best lecturers in England and Northern Ireland. Each one has been chosen by their university or college to go forward in the £1m awards scheme launched by the Institute for Learning and Teaching.

From the 96 nominations, 20 will be selected by a national panel for £50,000 cash fellowships to be spent as the recipient thinks fit. With a few notable exceptions like Oxford, universities and colleges appear to have responded enthusiastically and four further education colleges have entered nominations for their degree-level courses. The awards will be presented on July 12 in London.

The institute is hoping to raise the profile of teaching in higher education by recognising excellence - and putting money into it. At present, research dominates the thinking and careers of academics - good ratings in the Research Assessment Exercise bring extra money to a department and recognition for staff. In contrast, a good or bad performance in the Teaching Quality Assessments makes no immediate financial difference.

Dr Paul Clark, chief executive of the institute, welcomed the large number of entries in the first year of the scheme. "I am particularly pleased to see the nominations are from across the country and represent the whole spectrum of subjects."

Subjects range from theatrical performance - Tony Howard is described by Warwick as a teacher of "legendary brilliance and generosity" - to physiology where Cambridge said he was a meticulous and remarkably effective lecturer. Textbooks written by economics lecturer John Sloman of UWE had influenced thousands of students and he had acted as an ambassador for the subject in schools. All nominations were of extremely high quality, said Dr Clark.

fields.headline: Joint venture
fields.standfirst: Alex Benady meets the woman who has won a scholarship to develop her interest in cannabis
fields.trailText: Alex Benady meets the woman who has won a scholarship to develop her interest in cannabis
fields.body:
As the heavy sweet smell in the corridor of any hall of residence will testify, many students are more than happy to invest considerable amounts of their own time and money in exhaustive private study of hemp and its properties.

Not so Louisa Wood, a freelance fabric weaver from Southampton, who last week persuaded the Queen Elizabeth trust to part with £3,000 in the form of a scholarship to finance a month-long trip to the Chinese province of Yunnan, where she plans to study hemp production first-hand.

Her interest, needless to say, lies not in the weed's psychotropic properties, but in its potential as an up-market designer textile. On her return, she will spend three months putting together an experimental hand-woven collection of hemp fabrics.

Within a few years, she hopes to have single-handedly revived the long since defunct British hemp weaving industry, and to be churning out hemp pashminas, scarves and gorgeous hemp fabrics of every variety.

Her initiative has drawn applause from the fashion world. "About time too," says Bryony Toogood, fashion editor of Cosompolitan magazine.

"Hemp is so bloody hippy dippy and boring. Political correctness is not a consumer proposition, so any attempts to make hemp beautiful have got to be welcome."

But before Wood gets into swanky fabrics and the absolutely fabulous world of haute couture, she needs to learn all the mucky details of how to actually manufacture hemp yarn from raw materials.

Specifically, she hopes to find out from her Chinese mentors precisely how hemp fibres should be handled to get the best out of them. "There are many technical issues involved in producing a material. You need to gum and wax the fibres to weave them and then remove some, or all, of it. Silk, for instance, needs to be degummed in boiling water. How do you treat hemp? No one knows in the UK," says Wood.

She has worked as a fabric designer since leaving the Royal College of Art five years ago. She first encountered hemp as a fabric in 1997, while working as a textile designer for an American firm in Hong Kong.

"I happened to visit a Chinese factory and saw them making hemp fabrics for jeans and T-shirts. I thought, immediately, this is going to be a trend and how interesting it would be to do something more creative with it."

Her enthusiasm grew when she realised that hemp also has impeccable environmental credentials. "It's an amazing fabric. The plant grows very fast in poor soils and, unlike cotton, where the fibres are often only an inch long, the fibres are up to seven feet long, which makes them very strong. This means that insects can't eat it and it doesn't need fertilisers or insecticides."

Hemp fabric is also extremely practical. "It is three times as absorbent as cotton. It is very soft, it has the drape of linen, but it's much easier to iron," she enthuses.

In short Wood wants to reclaim hemp from its primary twentieth century associations as a recreational drug. The cannabis variety indica, used to make yarn, is legal in most countries because it has only a fraction of the THC (the active ingredient) of the more potent Cannabis sativa. "You would have to smoke a joint the size of a telegraph pole to get any kind of effect," she jokes.

Historically hemp in the west was a just a workaday source of yarn. "The American Constitution was written on hemp. And for centuries hemp was an important part of our domestic culture, used in the manufacture of sail cloth and ropes," she says. But the result of hemp first being displaced by cotton and then being associated with narcotics was that gradually the craft skills associated with the production of hemp yarn and manufacture died out. "The hemp fibre only disappeared 100 years ago, after being used as a staple for cloth for the previous 4,000 years. Now we have to relearn all those skills," explains Wood.

With such obvious enthusiasm it's easy to see why The Queen Elizabeth Trust, which specialises in helping people develop craft skills which will contribute to the UK pool of talent, was so taken with Wood's application. And before you ask, yes, she was at art school, but no she didn't inhale.

fields.headline: Money worries
fields.standfirst: Uncertainty about funding is clouding the horizon for colleges
fields.trailText: Uncertainty about funding is clouding the horizon for colleges
fields.body:
It's make your mind up time. The consultation process for the Learning and Skills Bill is almost over, and like it or not a new funding system will be in place on April 1 next year. Except no one has much idea of what it will look like and how it will work. There are a few generally accepted principles, such as simplicity and a common funding formula, but just what the numbers to insert in the formula will be or, indeed, what formula will even be used is a mystery. At this very moment the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) is still reportedly scrabbling around to find half a dozen or so colleges on which to model different ideas, so no-one is exactly filled with optimism that the DfEE will get it right first time.

There are also reports of tensions between the Treasury and the DfEE, with the former keen to see as much of the £6bn for further education going direct to providers, and the latter anxious to ring-fence some of the money for certain key areas. Small wonder, then, that the sector is extremely twitchy at the moment and that is why roughly 150 principals and chief-executives from around the country gathered in London yesterday to voice their concerns at a conference organised by the Association of Colleges.

With everything, in theory at least, still up for grabs and liable to change, there is a slight suspicion among some colleges that they are tilting at windmills but, behind a cautious welcome for the general outline of the funding proposals, which it is hoped will create a level playing field across the system, several serious, strategic concerns have begun to crystallise.

The main anxiety is the perceived lack of coherence in the differentiation between the 16 to 19 age group and adult learners. "There is a danger that adults won't get the same level of funding," says John Brennan, director of further education at the Assocaiton of Colleges, "even though they might well be doing exactly the same course as a 16-year-old."

The disparity in funding becomes more marked still when one considers that the learning needs of an adult may well be much greater than someone who has gone straight from school into further education.

Ruth Silver, principal of Lewisham College, puts it in slightly less guarded terms. "I'm all for making things more simple," she says, "but we shouldn't lose sight of the complexities of the situation. At the moment the new proposals brand 16- to19-year-old provision as education, and everything else as training. If things stay like this, then there is a real danger that a government that has done so much to widen participation will end up closing it down again."

There is equally muddled thinking elsewhere, in the differing levels of provision. Sixteen- to 19-year olds will be publicly funded up to NVQ level 3, while adults will only be funded up to level 2.

"There is a great deal of research to indicate that NVQs levels 1 and 2 make no difference to a person's employability or earning potential," says Ross Rospigliosi, principal of Plymouth College. "While I accept that there are other learning outcomes than economic, I don't think this is a good use of resources, because it may generate disaffection amongst those who have been lured back into further education with a view to improving their position in the workplace."

Elsewhere, there are concerns that the provisions for special needs learners are inadequately spelled out, and that with 20% of NVQ fees payable by output, that some colleges will pass sub-standard students and further undermine the credibility of vocational qualifications.

For the most part, though, it is the uncertainty that is getting to everyone. Ruth Silver, though, remains optimistic. "This is a learning government, and I believe it will respond to our concerns." Let's hope so.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: My child has begun to mention a school skiing trip...
fields.body:
My child has begun to mention a school skiing trip next February and this will lead up to him asking to go. I would find it hard to fund such a trip, but I allowed his elder brother to go on a French exchange two years ago. Are there funds or scholarships to help parents? Or do I argue that the skiing trip is not educational, so my child can't go?

Roger Theobald is a deputy head at a school in Middlesex and has a great deal of experience in organising school journeys and visits.

The first thing to distinguish here is between school journeys, which are residential, and school visits, which generally take place in school time. A charge can be made for a journey, but school visits can only be funded through voluntary contributions. Clearly, a skiing trip is in the first category.

As regards day trips, the school will work out the contribution that needs to be made to make the visit viable financially, but parents/carers can make whatever payment that they see fit. This can ensure that those parents/carers who do not have a great deal of money can still send their child on such trips. However, if enough money is not provided through these parental contributions, then the trip might have to be cancelled.

You want your child to enjoy the opportunities your school offers beyond the curriculum to broaden their education. It is understandable that you want both your children to have this chance. Schools, too, agonise over the range of school journeys they offer. Most try to provide different types of residential experience that take into account various interests and costs. Without the willingness of teachers to volunteer to organise such journeys there would be no chance for pupils to be away from home with their peers - an important stage in "growing up".

As far as funding is concerned, talk to the school - to the trip organiser or the person responsible for journeys and visits. This will be completely in confidence.

All schools, by law, have a governors' charging policy - ask for a copy. It will explain who is able to claim help towards journeys and visits. Also, ask the school if it has other funds to assist pupils. Some may have set aside money in their budget; others may have, as my school does, a special fund established by parents of past pupils. Would your school consider a loan? Is there a relative or friend who might help? Ask your local education authority as well.

You could also try to find out if there are any charities in your area that support educational activities. Your school or local education authority should have details, or ask your local Citizens' Advice Bureau.

If, in the end, you cannot fund the trip, explain to your child why, and what efforts you have made. Your school might offer a cheaper trip your child would be interested in joining, or there may be other companies that offer a residential experience during school holidays that you can afford.

I would challenge the assumption made by some people that a skiing trip is less worthy than a French exchange or other subject-based journey. All school trips are beneficial. They develop independence, co-operation, and living and working with others in a different environment - skills valued by employers and society. On a skiing trip, your child would also learn to ski and they would have an examination to test that skill.

Next week's query

What are the regulations on the employment of young people? My daughter is 14 and has been working at the weekend as a waitress at a local café. Her employer would like her to work five days a week over the summer holidays. Is this legal? I would like to know more about guidelines on hours, and health and safety issues.

 Last week we featured advice from Margaret McGowan of ACE. Some readers may have gained the impression that ACE only deals with parental worries on how to challenge "gifted" children. In fact, ACE provides advice on a range of educational issues that concern parents, including how to support a child struggling with schoolwork. Its helpline is 020-7354 8321.

fields.headline: Email writing style
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor on the peasures and pitfalls of netiquette
fields.body:
"Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words will never hurt me"

Anyone who remembers being bullied and teased as a child will recognise this rhyme as wishful fiction. But what happens when the verbal abuse is not just a throwaway taunt, or even an exchange of insults, but the modern equivalent of what Enid Blyton called "poison-pen" letters?

Thanks to the ubiquity of email and - for mobile phone owners - text-messaging, children who may object loudly to the notion of writing a letter on paper will happily send messages by email. It helps children to practise putting their thoughts and feelings into words, and the results should show up in the literacy hour and English lessons. It's also inevitable that they will sometimes get it wrong, and the injuries sustained by an email usually take much longer to heal than verbal wounds.

Professor Helen Petrie of the University of Hertfordshire says most adults haven't yet learnt how to use email - so it's hardly surprising that children, who don't have a full grasp of linguistic nuances, will have problems too. "All the important hedging that goes on in conversation is lost," says Petrie, whose study of email use can be found at www.netinvestigations.net. "People don't put themselves in the position of the recipient. Emails can come across as abrupt and often quite brutal."

Do unto others as you would have them do unto you, in other words. But teachers and parents can do more than merely bring out the familiar assembly theme. You could explain, for example, that some people use emoticons to communicate their mood and as a way of making it clear if they're being sarcastic. These are falling out of favour as adults become more familiar with email, but they help to avoid misunderstandings, particularly when children experiment with sarcasm.

Another important rule is to avoid SCREAMING - TYPING EVERYTHING IN CAPS. Using a pair of asterixes is a *much* better way of emphasising a word. More guidelines on email etiquette are listed at www.writerswrite.com although they will need to be adapted for use with children.

But perhaps the best advice, is never to fire off an angry reply to a unexpectedly nasty email. Just as counting to 10 during an argument helps to calm people down, leaving the computer and talking to someone can stop you replying in the heat of the moment. If you're alone, yelling a sardonic reply at the screen can also help defuse the tension.

If a child believes someone has sent them a "hate mail" of some kind, it shouldn't be too difficult to persuade them to show it to you (just as they would show off a bleeding nose). Then decide together whether to ignore it, or compose a reply.

Do you have any other strategies for dealing with difficult emails? Tell Education Unlimited about them. We'll publish a selection and the best will receive a copy of the Guardian Guide to the Internet by Jim McClellan.

But what happens when the verbal abuse is not just a throwaway taunt, or even an exchange of insults, but the modern equivalent of what Enid Blyton called "poison-pen" letters? fields.headline: Good with numbers
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers  meets the man poised to take on six million students
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers meets the man poised to take on six million students
fields.body:
Being handed a £6bn annual budget would probably make even the most experienced businessman tremble. But it's water off a duck's back for Bryan Sanderson, who as the newly-appointed chairman of the new Learning and Skills Council will be spending that sort of money on Labour's radical reorganisation of post-16 education and training.

The highly-respected corporate leader is now in the process of "unwinding" himself from the industrial giant, BP Amoco (formerly British Petroleum), where he is chief executive of the chemicals business and where, he muses, £6bn was roughly the group's entire capital expenditure.

Currently responsible for 19,000 staff throughout the world, his new job will give him responsibility for some six million learners in a daunting patch covering the entire post-16 learning sector, minus higher education. Gulp...

Fortunately big numbers and challenges don't daunt Sanderson, who climbed to the top of BP in a "cradle to grave" career with the company, spanning 35 years and much of the globe. Educated at state primary schools in his native north-east, he then attended a direct grant school in Newcastle upon Tyne - Dame Allan's - before winning a place at the London School of Economics where he took the traditional BSc (Economics) degree (and where he is now an active governor). After two years' VSO, he joined BP in 1964 and the rest, as they say, is history.

Sanderson takes up the two-day a week post, on a four-year contract, in October. And, talking again of big numbers, his earnings will sky-dive to £40,000 from the $1.4m he was paid last year. His huge wealth enables him to live in considerable comfort.

But although he is sympathetic to Labour and advised them on corporate issues while in opposition, those who know him say he is most definitely not a champagne socialist. "He remains acutely aware of his own early life, when his family was very poor," said one acquaintance.

"He doesn't forget that and recognises that his own education helped him to get where he is today." He also maintains his links with the north-east through his lifelong passion for Sunderland football club, of which he is vice-chairman.

Sanderson stresses that he applied for the job, as he approached formal retirement, because he could not imagine taking on anything more challenging at such a critical time. The new Council will largely replace old-fashioned Training and Enterprise Councils, and a key element of Sanderson's job will be giving business the chance to build links with the education system. He underlines his personal commitment to training - last year BP met a target, which he set, that all members of staff receive five days training every year.

Despite the very broad remit of his new job, he sees it, in a nutshell, as "persuading people that learning is about making the most of your own potential, as well as sucess for UK plc".

Key priorities are to appoint a chief executive to the Council, which will be based in Coventry, and to persuade businesses to take seats on the 47 local Learning and Skills Councils. In total, there will be around 700 posts to fill, of which around 300 have been reserved for business people.

fields.headline: Centres of excellence
fields.trailText: Universities are being asked to come to the rescue of English cricket.
fields.body:
Universities are being asked to come to the rescue of English cricket. The English Cricket Board has set up six centres of excellence to coach and develop young players while they are at university. Following a pilot scheme at Durham University devised by the former England batsman, Graeme Fowler, the centres will open their doors in September, each catering for about 25 players - men and women.

They are Bradford and Leeds (based at Bradford, Leeds and Leeds Metropolitan Universities and Bradford College); Cambridge University with Anglia Polytechnic University; Cardiff University with UWIC and Glamorgan; Durham University; Loughborough University; and Oxford with Oxford Brookes.

The scheme is aimed at male cricketers with potential to play first-class cricket and female cricketers of senior county standard, but students must gain the required A-level entry grades for their degree courses in the normal way.

According to Bill Butterworth, of the Leeds University sports centre, the scheme will enable players to develop their skills and keep up their cricket beyond under-18s teams. They will also be able to keep in contact with their county sides - in the old days it was often a choice between county cricket or university. Nets and fitness training in the autumn and spring terms will be followed by matches between the centres in the summer.

Ambitious young cricketers, male or female, can obtain a prospectus through School Careers Libraries, or your local Cricket Development Officer, or by calling the ECB Technical Department on 0207 432 1200.

fields.headline: United we stand
fields.standfirst: Francis Beckett celebrates a new union for Natfhe members
fields.trailText: Francis Beckett celebrates a new union for Natfhe members
fields.body:
Next week Alan John, last year's president of the lecturers' trade union, Natfhe, is to marry his predecessor as president, Moira Carr. It's one of those seminal moments in history, likely to provoke a fundamental reappraisal of our whole approach to the place of trade unionism in our society, our lives, our history and our colleges.

For I can remember the time when Natfhe's top brass were hardly on speaking terms with each other, let alone about to marry each other. It is said that a previous president once visited the then general secretary, who was in hospital recovering from a nasty operation. "Executive committee wishes you a speedy recovery," he said as he sat down and helped himself to the grapes. "Motion was carried by seven votes to five, with four abstentions."

In-fighting did the union no end of harm. "When we wash our dirty linen in public," general secretary Paul Mackney told its conference last week "we always get taken to the cleaners." And he was right.

Those were the days of windy, overblown trade union rhetoric. Middle aged union officials at the annual Trades Union Congress would talk about This Great Movement Of Ours (the irreverent called it Tigmoo), its rights, its duties and its responsibilities. Young firebrands demanded that the unions took their rightful place in the vanguard of the revolution. The two groups were at constant war with each other, and nowhere was their antagonism more bitter than in Natfhe, where it claimed the job of two of Paul Mackney's predecessors in bitter and ill-tempered re-election battles.

The young gang accused the middle-aged gang of betrayal. The middle-aged gang accused the young gang of self-indulgent posing, and of committing the sin of Onan. (They tended to put the latter accusation rather less biblically and more succinctly than I have.)

Today most of the young firebrands have become New Labour MPs and hate being reminded of their radical past, which is why I won't name them here: I'll hang on for a more embarrassing moment.

And a member of the government can go to Natfhe's conference, as lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks did last month, and face nothing worse than a little gentle hissing.

And the ex-president can marry the ex-ex-president.

Natfhe survived the bad years because it had people like Alan John and Moira Carr in it, who remembered "despite everything the Conservative government and their own comrades threw at them" what they'd joined it for. They thought their colleagues and their students deserved better than they'd get from politicians. And they remembered, what some of their colleagues forgot, that the real enemy was outside, not inside, their union.

Alan reminded his members of that last week. Whenever college employers called his members professionals, he told the conference, "they are about to ask for something for nothing".

It's a second marriage for both Alan and Moira, and a second chance for the lecturers' union they've served with fluency and dignity. Give them a thought on June 23, and wish them long life and happiness.

webTitle: In the studio: North and South

fields.headline: In the studio: North and South
fields.trailText: As final exam shows approach, students in Wimbledon and Newcastle talk about their preparations
fields.body:
Wimbledon School of Art

Hayley Skipper, 22, produces site-specific work with fairy-tale narratives, juxtaposing nursery images of home with scaffolding structures. Before her show she was sitting in an empty studio negotiating with tree surgeons over the phone to get a consignment of twigs delivered with which to build a giant nest among her other installations.

"I've got 11 days and I don't know if it will work. The pressure is building up because this is the culmination of three years' work. The final mark doesn't really mean anything. You could get a first and nothing will happen, a third and everything will happen because you've presented yourself in the right way to the right people. It's down to how you set about selling yourself as an artist."

Sam Dowd, 22, has evolved into a performance and video artist, exploring contemporary myths and "belief systems" about masculinity through the images thrown up by childhood rhymes and nonsense poetry. One of his performance installations will involve donning "armour" made from domestic items such as Marigold rubber gloves. One of his pieces was recently shortlisted at the ICA Becks awards for young film and video artists.

"All of this is very self-motivated. We are encouraged to do things off our own backs and I wouldn't say there was a house style. I haven't got a job to go to after the show, because I want to be a professional artist which I know is the hardest thing in the world. I think there's probably a let-down after art school. If you are going to get anywhere, it's not what you know but who you know."

Alice Taminiau is a mature student from Holland who first went to art school at 15 but dropped out. Wishing to return to art in middle age, she attended art school in Belgium, producing work "in a certain impressionistic way". After 18 months Alice again dropped out and applied to Wimbledon, where she has flourished."I changed completely," she said. "My work became very conceptual."

But she has returned to painting and her final show will be a series of still lifes, in which she has taken fragments from her previously academic work and blown them up and transformed them into large abstract oil paintings.

"Now I feel I am just beginning to understand a little bit about art. My show is just a start. One girl here told me she wanted to do something about emancipation and I thought: 'My God, I was around when it was invented.' I'm not interested in all that; I just want to understand what art is. At this college they shake you awake, you are constantly pushed to go one step further. I now want to make a living out of my paintings, so I hope a gallery owner picks me out because I think my work is becoming good. In Holland, galleries want to know where you have studied and if you say 'London' they think 'Wow! that's good.' "

Newcastle University School of Art

Kit Abramson, 22, chose a disused vaulted storeroom in which to present her degree show, absorbing objects found in the room itself into her art. She is interested in the nature of objects and the layers of meaning we give to them. Kit's show, therefore, includes an amplified spoon which vibrates noisily; a brass cast of her own mouth - "a prevention of language"; a video image of a door opening and closing, thrown minutely onto a rough wall; and a headless statue of a dusty muscular male nude that she has salvaged from years of storage and surrounded by soft white pillows. She also has a portfolio of paintings and drawings.

"The brilliant thing about this place is that you can make whatever work you want. Nobody is pushing you into anything at too early a stage, though the life stuff is getting less popular. I do want to work as an artist but I feel there are 101 different ways of doing that. I think the degree show has less pressure up here because you know you're not going to be shuffled off to stardom. However, there's a lot of interest in art round here and a lot going on. There is a feeling that you can make things happen."

Adam Ball, 23, will be presenting a series of videos and finely crafted abstract sculptures which transform Mondrian's paintings into still and kinetic 3D objects through which he views and celebrates the urban landscape.

One of his videos shows one of his sculptures - based on Mondrian's Broadway Boogie Woogie - "dancing" to jazz rhythms. It earned him a prize at the ICA Becks awards. Another video shows Newcastle street life after a football victory - but viewed through a "Mondrian" structure placed in the street.

Adam wants to move back to his family in London after graduating in the hope of making gallery contacts.

"The Baltic will help but London is the heart of the art world. I'm not interested in selling my work at this stage. I just want to get as good a degree as I can, because I have worked hard, and to show my work to my family and friends."

Julian Lee, 27, worked as a builder in London before applying to Newcastle. He had obtained a BTec National Diploma in Art and Design at 18, and had kept up his drawing in an observational, figurative way. He still paints landscapes - huge, dark, surreal portraits of grim urban dereliction.

"My work has changed a lot but it's very much 'open house' at this art school. As long as you work hard and what you are doing is honest and can stand up to criticism, they let you find your own way. You'd have to be a brave person to do what I'm doing down in London. I want to make a living out of my art and there's a buzzy little scene with a lot of ex-graduates going on up here. It's cheap to live and rent studio space, so you can manage. But they've also taught us to be realistic. Anybody who thinks they are going to come out and start selling work straight away is probably under an illusion."

fields.headline: Time to make tracks
fields.standfirst: Stir your stumps soon and you can plan a great university career
fields.trailText: Stir your stumps soon and you can plan a great university career
fields.body:
Our man Matthew is a sports fan and has just embarked on a Euro 2000 watchathon with the aim of seeing every game and as much of Wimbledon as is possible (he's noted England matches will only clash if they reach the semi-finals). He's also a student - coming to the end of year 1 of his A levels with some end-of-year exams, perhaps a missed GCSE to take and an AS level to worry about. Other than that it's sport, sun and summer holidays to look forward to.

True? Only partly. For every Matthew read Joanna, Abdul, Bibi, Owen... and thousands of other students preparing to make life-changing decisions about their higher education. Many will still have much work to do over the next few weeks. Some will be doubting whether to go to university, others will have changed their minds each time they saw their adviser. Whatever your situation, the issues need to be addressed now.

Perhaps the best advice at this stage is to encourage all students in this position to seriously consider and research what higher education has to offer, with the aim of applying in the autumn even if some doubts remain. After all, the UCAS system through which you apply allows you to withdraw at any stage. There's nothing to lose, and it will help you focus on your future plans. Choosing exactly what to study is not a straightforward issue for many. Just as it was impossible to come up with the magic answer to "What do you want to be when you grow up?", now there is the same problem with "What course do you want to follow at university?"

Of course, you can continue with a subject you are familiar with at A level or GNVQ, if it's one you would like to learn more about. No worries there then. If not, why not look at a new discipline altogether? Some thing you have not studied before that may not be available at school or college. Examples are social anthropology, genetics, Latin American studies and zoology. Some people, who are firmer in their career intentions, may wish to look at vocational degrees, which prepare you for one career. Examples include teaching, pharmacy, architecture, engineering, and hospitality management.

There's a danger here, of course: this option should only be followed by anyone who is sure of their future direction. Trying to choose one subject for degree-level study is a nightmare for many applicants.

If you do find it hard to narrow it down, why not think more broadly and ponder the following options? A joint degree, two subjects of equal worth, is a good choice if you have a similar interest in two areas. The subjects need not be related, although they often are, and you get the opportunity to mix new, unfamiliar subjects with old ones.

There are now many universities offering combined or modular degrees where you study two or more subjects, not always with equal weight. A key feature of such degrees is their flexibility, since they allow change at various stages. A note of caution, however - you should take advice on the teaching, assessment and career implications of these multi-disciplinary degrees.

It's clearly crucial to enjoy your subject and find it fun, so research your choice using all the reference material and advice available. Check how the subject is taught - the balance between large lectures, tutorials, seminars and practicals, lab work or fieldwork - and find out how the course is assessed. Are there frequent exams or just end of year ones? Does the course have assignments throughout which go towards your final qualification?

Always check the grades required for your chosen subject and university, and match them with the grades your teachers expect of you.

Got this far and still feeling clueless? Don't forget that your degree need bear no relation to your eventual career, so don't get stuck on this - many do, and go on to make inappropriate choices. Around 40% of all graduate jobs are open to graduates of any discipline.

 Attend any Higher Education Fairs taking place in your area and pick up some 2001 entry prospectuses
 attend any June and July Open Days
 fine tune your course choice
 fine tune your university choice
 produce a rough draft of your personal statement
 take advice, don't hide until September. If you can do all this by the end of term in July it will make life so much easier in September and October. Then you only have to worry about filling in the form.
