fields.headline: Carnival cricket
fields.standfirst: As the West Indies prepare to face England this week,  Huw Richards learns how a leading academic aims to put the soul back into his country's national game
fields.trailText: As the West Indies prepare to face England this week, Huw Richards learns how a leading academic aims to put the soul back into his country's national game
fields.body:
What do they know of cricket that only cricket know? - it's a searching question and one that the West Indian political intellectual, CLR James, once asked in his book, Beyond A Boundary.

James's question was essentially rhetorical. It underlined both the impossibility of understanding cricket without reference to its social and cultural context and the equal difficulty of understanding West Indian history and culture without reference to one of its defining popular activities. But now it is finding a more practical expression in the hands of one of James's intellectual heirs, Hilary Beckles, pro vice-chancellor of the University of the West Indies, and founder and director of its Centre for Cricket Research.

Professor Beckles, who plans to be at Edgbaston this week as the West Indies begin a five test-match series with England, has played in the highly competitive Yorkshire League. "I grew up in a cricket culture. It formed many of my ideas, and my dream was to play for the West Indies."

In the foreword to his book, The Development of West Indies Cricket, Beckles describes how that ambition died when, as a 16-year-old Warwickshire Schools player, he had a torrid time facing West Indian test off-spinner Lance Gibbs in the nets at Edgbaston. "I trundled off to Hull University and emerged six years later as an apprentice professional historian. Lance Gibbs is now a friend, but I have not forgiven him."

A thwarted international cricketer he may be, but at 44 he is a test-class historian. His book was hailed by Scyld Berry - a cricket writer well qualified to judge - as the most important book ever written on the game's history.

Its second volume, The Age of Globalization, examined the forces underlying the recent decline in West Indian cricket following its complete dominance in the 1980s. He points to a number of possible explanations. One is the range of sporting counter-attractions: "For a century cricket enjoyed a monopoly of sporting attention and talent. Now the talented 14- to 15-year-old can consider the options of football, basketball - with scholarships being offered by talent scouts from American universities - tennis, golf and track and field. Cricket is not the only automatic choice any more."

The argument for which he is most known is that West Indian cricket, and the national team, have lost their sense of identity and national pride which drove the remorselessly succesful teams led by Clive Lloyd and Vivian Richards.

Beckles argues that players in those teams had a collective sense of West Indian identity from growing up in the period when islands were campaigning for and attaining independence from Britain, but the modern player - epitomised by Brian Lara - has developed in a time of neo- liberal globalisation and sees himself as an independent craftsman.

He accepts that this is a consequence of the failure to create a succesful West Indian federation. "This is a dream that we have cherished that is getting further away from fulfilment rather than closer. The West Indies is an idea, an intellectual construct, rather than a reality."

There are two significant exceptions to this - the West Indian cricket team and the university. Beckles' aim is that the university should help sustain the cricket. That aim is close to realisation on its Barbados campus with plans underway for a purpose-built cricket academy, complete with a library and archive and the best possible playing and training facilities.

"The idea is that West Indies players should come here - starting with the under-15 and under-17 teams in 2001-2, but before long the full West Indian team as well. They would come in for modules - some concerned with the practice of cricket, physical education and nutrition but others with the history and culture of the game."

Beckles argues this is necessary because of the under-development of West Indian economies, with poverty and austerity programmes meaning that educational opportunities are dwindling for most of the population. "Players need to be educated to be effective professionals, for instance to be able to analyse performance effectively," he says.

"Every Australian player I meet is computer-literate but in the West Indian team there is only one, Jimmy Adams, because he came from a middle-class background and had the opportunities. They also need to understand enough to be able to represent their society effectively."

The academy follows on logically from existing ventures like the annual Vice-Chancellor's XI cricket match in which the best players from further and higher education in the West Indies are brought together to play an international touring team. Fifteen annual Frank Worrell scholarships, named after the former West Indies captain who was warden of the university's Jamaica campus before his early death in 1967, are awarded to outstanding students who are also achievers or leaders in some sport.

The university's next significant academic development will be a sports science department, with differing specialities on its three campuses. The Centre for Cricket Research will also continue to offer its history courses, a success in both market and intellectual terms.

"They are among the most heavily subscribed courses offered by the university," says Beckles. "Many students whose speciality is political science, anthropology and history have told me that it is only through studying 200 years of cricket history that they have come to understand the logic of Caribbean history and society."

CLR James would have understood - and approved.

fields.headline: Ace service
fields.standfirst: The future looks increasingly bright for sixth-form colleges
fields.trailText: The future looks increasingly bright for sixth-form colleges
fields.body:
For most of the past decade there has been a virtual moratorium on the creation of new sixth-form colleges. Today, however, it seems increasingly likely that a 21st century generation of these educational thoroughbreds will shortly spring into life.

A cluster of imperatives bring the question of post-16 reorganisation of school and college provision very much back on to the agenda.

Firstly, the new local and national Learning and Skills Councils, which will plan all post-16 training and educational provision from the year 2002, have a statutory duty to reorganise and upgrade local provision if existing sixth forms are deemed to be failing.

Secondly, these councils are responsible for actively deciding what pattern of post-16 provision they wish to fund locally anyway.

And, thirdly, area-wide inspections of 16 to 19 education and training - by the Office for Standards in Education (Ofsted) and, for the time being, by the Further Education Funding Council and the Training Standards Council - will identify under performance and make concrete proposals about possible school and college reorganisations.

When launching the Learning to Succeed White Paper last year, David Blunkett, the Secretary of State for Education and Employment, said:

"I want all providers - further education and sixth forms - to match the productivity and quality levels of sixth form colleges. If we can achieve that sort of quality level in every provider, we will have transformed the life chances of millions of young people."

Andrew Adonis, the Prime Minister's education adviser, has also visited a number of sixth-form colleges - there are 106 such colleges - and is known to regard them very positively as a cost-effective way of widening participation and raising standards.

Department for Education and Employment statistics suggest that it is 20% cheaper to complete three A levels in sixth-form colleges than it is in schools.

Luton sixth-form college was the first to open, in September 1966. In the 1980s sixth-form colleges were opening at a rate of a dozen or more a year. However, with the advent of incorporated colleges in 1992, local education authorities were reluctant to create new sixth-form institutions which might then cut loose and become independent entities.

The advent of Curriculum 2000 this autumn - whereby students will be examined on four or five subjects in the first-year sixth and then take three subjects in the second year, and also study key skills, such as communication and the application of number - will also place increasing strain on the resources of small sixth forms.

The government has been at pains to emphasise that the arrival of the Learning and Skills Council will not mean that all small sixth forms will close down. It has, in fact, gone so far as to give a guarantee that funding will continue at present levels, providing student numbers do not fall. However what is not clear is how long such a guarantee can be expected to last. Some observers believe it will last for just two years, others, perhaps somewhat optimistically, in perpetuity.

However, the government is very taken with deploying the sixth-form college model to meet the needs of the 16 to 19 age group. Jill Arnold, a programme director at Varndean College in Brighton, said what the government loves about sixth-form colleges is that they are comparatively cheap because class sizes are large, they offer a broad choice of study subjects, they get good results and they give students support and guidance.

Parents also like the ethos of such colleges and the fact that their children get subject reports and the teaching staff keep parents informed about their children's progress.

"What the government cannot do - because politically it is a minefield - is to close down loads of school sixth forms, because parents like them," Ms Arnold said. "The only way you could possibly do it would be if you provided parents with an attractive alternative, for example a sixth-form college or consortia sixth forms."

New independent sixth-form colleges could result from recommendations made by any one of the 47 Local Skills Councils. However the Learning and Skills Council bill also allows local education authorities to set up new sixth-form centres to replace small or failing local sixth form provision. Such institutions would also, in effect, be new sixth-form colleges, but local authority run.

Alan Jenkins, principal of Varndean College, said that, faced with the necessity to re-think their organisational structures, local authorities were more likely to plump for a pooled consortia sixth form or a sixth-form college.

Dr John Guy, principal of Farnborough sixth-form college, points out that several possible models for new sixth-form colleges have recently been created. The local education authority in Hammersmith and Fulham has set up a local education authority sixth-form centre, the William Morris Academy, which enjoys sixth-form levels of funding; and in Weston Super Mare, Weston College has created the Weston sixth-form college with Further Education Funding Council money.

Brian Howseman, principal of Luton sixth-form college, said: "It may well be that the Learning and Skills Council will be saying to local authorities: 'Look, your provision is not cost-effective and is not of sufficiently high quality, so you ought to consider rationalisation.'

"And such rationalisation is likely to be along the sixth-form college model, because it's quite clear that the government believes that relatively small institutions devoted to full-time 16- to 19-year-olds are a good thing. Certainly educational advisers in Downing Street, such as Andrew Adonis, have been saying that.

"I think the government is now quite keen on the idea of institutions that cater largely for 16- to 19-year-olds, so that the students have orchestras, drama and sports and these are very obvious and up-front in the culture and ethos of the institution."

The one hostage to fortune in all this - the grit in the oyster as Neil Fletcher, head of education at the Local Government Association, puts it - is how creating new colleges, whether local authority run or independent institutions, squares with the government's stated commitment to continue funding school sixth forms at present levels, provided student numbers do not drop. Only time will tell.

fields.headline: Art and soul
fields.standfirst: Elaine Williams talks to Christopher Frayling, rector of the Royal College of Art, about the pressures on art graduates
fields.trailText: Elaine Williams talks to Christopher Frayling, rector of the Royal College of Art, about the pressures on art graduates
fields.body:
June is the month when art students bear their souls to the world. Cluttered studios are transformed into gleaming galleries for the degree shows, as young artists work long into the night to consolidate four or five years' labour. Some submit their "greatest hits" from the period. Many more assemble totally new installations. Some completely change the way they work in the final months or weeks.

Britart prices are set to rise and rise on international art markets, and the young Turks of contemporary art are feted in a way not seen since pop art in the 60s. In recent years dealers and gallery owners have trawled degree shows to an unprecedented extent, sometimes visiting even before the shows to get first choice. And students, especially those on the London circuit, are highly aware that they are under the spotlight.

Christopher Frayling, rector of the Royal College of Art, says art students are under pressure and are exposed in a way students from other disciplines cannot imagine. "For most students the final exam might mean writing an essay or dissertation for an external examiner. Essentially it's a private transaction. But art students are baring their innermost selves in public. They make their material completely their own, it's like an autobiography, a very personal punchline to two or three years' work.

"I cannot recall since the 1960s as much interest as there has been in shows over the last two or three years. There's a lot of star-spotting going on, and art schools have become very competitive places. There's a lot of jostling for position, a definite Darwinian atmosphere. 'Can they cut it? Have they got it?' These are the questions being asked of talented students."

Frayling's favourite statistic shows that every three years in Britain we produce more art and design graduates than the whole of the population of Florence during the Renaissance. Not all of them can be adopted by a Saatchi or Serota, though new galleries are opening in London every day and more fine art students, it seems, are entering the charmed circle of living by their art alone.

However, the number of art graduates entering into art-related jobs such as commercial art, advertising or arts administration is also high. Frayling believes "passionately" in the virtue of an art school education. He says it produces a self-reliant group with the ability to transfer their visual skills into all manner of employment.

But he strikes a note of caution on the art-school tendency of producing starlets, of worshipping precocity, of feeding the polarisation between a conceptual avant garde and those concerned with the craft of painting or sculpture: "There has to be a range of options, a discipline. At 17 you cannot be a Duchamp. If you start from that basis you haven't many options of where to go on to. You have to start with an education."

The day Hirst had his first famous show, allegedly sending out invitations to all the critics and arranging for them to be picked up in taxis, he started something, says Frayling - how to stage-manage a reputation - that "we don't know how to resolve".

Students have intensified their strategies to get noticed and shock tactics are the new orthodoxy: "Every year we can expect to get some gothic shocking stuff from students who want their art to stand out on the shelf and there is nothing more depressing. It takes a maverick to stand out and say, stop the show I want to get off.

"I see our job as developing the whole person, getting students to the starting line. Art schools that see it as their job to turn out professional artists, without giving their students the business skills of how to market their work, find a dealer, run a studio, are creating a paradox. If colleges are saying 'this is a professional vocational course', then they have to equip their students accordingly."

Wimbledon School of Art has become increasingly popular with students opting for London. Its relatively small size (600 undergraduates, 90 in Fine Art) and good facilities and the top research ratings attained by its staff, all practising artists, have given it a reputation as a strong, highly focused community.

Once seen as conservative compared with Goldsmiths or St Martin's, Wimbledon maintains its painting and sculpture schools. Though there are still painters the boundaries have dissolved and its students turn out a high percentage of conceptual and installation work in any format.

From day one they are expected to behave like artists and are constantly challenged as artists by staff. The first thing required of freshers is to hold an exhibition of previous work. Throughout their three years undergraduates are encouraged to court galleries and exhibit as often as possible. Their final show is a "big deal", says staff, attracting dealers, collectors, critics and other professionals.

Students draw up a final show press release, produce a sleek, professional catalogue for which they have to seek sponsorship, set up a sales desk and wait for the cash to roll in. They might not all expect a Mr Waddington to walk their way, but they have all been given the means, says Rod Bugg, the school's head, to carry on their individual practice as artists, and most do.

Newcastle University's School of Art forms part of the university's elegant turn-of-the-century buildings. It has its own Hatton Gallery, and offers studio space of a size and proportion that students in London only dream of. Fine-art students do a four-year degree that includes art history, and are expected to build up skills, knowledge and critical appreciation across a range of areas. They spend the first year learning things like colour theory and basic materials.

The school retains its life-drawing studios, though the approach is no longer so academic. Students are encouraged to take their work in whatever direction they choose as long as it stands up to critical appraisal.

When the degree show opened last Friday, neither staff not students were expecting dealers and galleries to make it up the line from London. Though the school's reputation is growing, its sales pitch is not strident. More support comes from the great and the good from the north-east, the heads of regional art boards and contemporary art spaces. In Newcastle, then, the tension as well as the optimism is just as palpable as in London. After all, this is the home of Gormley's Angel and the designated City of Culture for 2008. The Baltic Flour Mills have been transformed to echo the Tate Modern. There is a strong community of artists.

Christopher Jones, head of painting and director of the BA fine art course, feels that being away from the London spotlight has advantages - students feel more able to follow their own inclinations rather than fashion.

fields.bodyText: June is the month when art students bear their souls to the world. Cluttered studios are transformed into gleaming galleries for the degree shows, as young artists work long into the night to consolidate four or five years' labour. Some submit their "greatest hits" from the period. Many more assemble totally new installations. Some completely change the way they work in the final months or weeks. Britart prices are set to rise and rise on international art markets, and the young Turks of contemporary art are feted in a way not seen since pop art in the 60s. In recent years dealers and gallery owners have trawled degree shows to an unprecedented extent, sometimes visiting even before the shows to get first choice. And students, especially those on the London circuit, are highly aware that they are under the spotlight. Christopher Frayling, rector of the Royal College of Art, says art students are under pressure and are exposed in a way students from other disciplines cannot imagine. "For most students the final exam might mean writing an essay or dissertation for an external examiner. Essentially it's a private transaction. But art students are baring their innermost selves in public. They make their material completely their own, it's like an autobiography, a very personal punchline to two or three years' work. "I cannot recall since the 1960s as much interest as there has been in shows over the last two or three years. There's a lot of star-spotting going on, and art schools have become very competitive places. There's a lot of jostling for position, a definite Darwinian atmosphere. 'Can they cut it? Have they got it?' These are the questions being asked of talented students." Frayling's favourite statistic shows that every three years in Britain we produce more art and design graduates than the whole of the population of Florence during the Renaissance. Not all of them can be adopted by a Saatchi or Serota, though new galleries are opening in London every day and more fine art students, it seems, are entering the charmed circle of living by their art alone. However, the number of art graduates entering into art-related jobs such as commercial art, advertising or arts administration is also high. Frayling believes "passionately" in the virtue of an art school education. He says it produces a self-reliant group with the ability to transfer their visual skills into all manner of employment. But he strikes a note of caution on the art-school tendency of producing starlets, of worshipping precocity, of feeding the polarisation between a conceptual avant garde and those concerned with the craft of painting or sculpture: "There has to be a range of options, a discipline. At 17 you cannot be a Duchamp. If you start from that basis you haven't many options of where to go on to. You have to start with an education." The day Hirst had his first famous show, allegedly sending out invitations to all the critics and arranging for them to be picked up in taxis, he started something, says Frayling - how to stage-manage a reputation - that "we don't know how to resolve". Students have intensified their strategies to get noticed and shock tactics are the new orthodoxy: "Every year we can expect to get some gothic shocking stuff from students who want their art to stand out on the shelf and there is nothing more depressing. It takes a maverick to stand out and say, stop the show I want to get off. "I see our job as developing the whole person, getting students to the starting line. Art schools that see it as their job to turn out professional artists, without giving their students the business skills of how to market their work, find a dealer, run a studio, are creating a paradox. Once seen as conservative compared with Goldsmiths or St Martin's, Wimbledon maintains its painting and sculpture schools. Though there are still painters the boundaries have dissolved and its students turn out a high percentage of conceptual and installation work in any format. From day one they are expected to behave like artists and are constantly challenged as artists by staff. The first thing required of freshers is to hold an exhibition of previous work. Throughout their three years undergraduates are encouraged to court galleries and exhibit as often as possible. Their final show is a "big deal", says staff, attracting dealers, collectors, critics and other professionals. Students are encouraged to take their work in whatever direction they choose as long as it stands up to critical appraisal. When the degree show opened last Friday, neither staff not students were expecting dealers and galleries to make it up the line from London. Though the school's reputation is growing, its sales pitch is not strident. More support comes from the great and the good from the north-east, the heads of regional art boards and contemporary art spaces. fields.headline: A flavour of Japan
fields.standfirst: Japanese schoolchildren are getting a taste of British life via the internet - starting with shepherd's pie
fields.trailText: Japanese schoolchildren are getting a taste of British life via the internet - starting with shepherd's pie
fields.body:
"It was good to eat but very strange. The taste was something I'd never experienced before," said 13-year-old Masahiro Suzukawa thoughtfully about his first encounter with shepherd's pie. With his classmates at Ikuchi Junior High School he had been trying out a recipe emailed by teenagers from the other side of the world.

Emails are beginning to fly back and forth between his school on a small island near Hiroshima and Wortley High School in Leeds, its "e-link" partner in a British Council scheme. On both sides the kids' curiosity has been aroused - what do you eat/wear/listen to? How long is the school day? What lessons do you have? What sports do you do?

The contrasts begin with the schools - one looking out over inner-city terraces, the other by the side of Japan's Inland Sea serving a farming and fishing community - and they encompass almost every aspect of the children's school and personal lives. They have only just begun to explore.

Yumi Nakamura, a keen basketball player, described herself as tall - but not as tall, it turned out, as "Mr Nigel", a teacher in the Yorkshire school. She and her classmates are working on the idea of making t-shirts based on Japanese calligraphic characters for their Leeds correspondents and would love to visit Britain in the future. Koji Uchiake said they wanted to introduce their English counterparts to Japanese food by sending them recipes. Is Japanese food better? Yes, he said without hesitation.

Helped by an English teacher, Matt Lamborne (coincidentally from Leeds himself), the Ikuchi students are creating an English website for the school, ranging from sports (basketball, volleyball, tennis and table tennis - "Our practice is very strict. We have many trophies") to the school rules. These may raise eyebrows in Leeds - no perfume, make-up or dyed hair. Students may not bring snacks, girls must not have hair below their shoulders (not an issue for boys, it seems); students living within one kilometre must walk to school - the others come by bike, no one is driven to school.

What none of the children mention, because they take it for granted, is the daily cleaning when they take up brooms and mops and clean their classrooms and corridors, the toilets and the school grounds.

The project is meant to be fun - but it is also a tiny sign of a revolution brewing in Japanese schools. The country is taking stock of what it needs to survive in the 21st century and seems to be coming to the conclusion that not only will better English be essential for global trade, but that schools and universities should be fostering young peoples' ability to think for themselves.

The results of a century of rote learning have been impressive - creating the world's second largest economy - but they are no longer enough for a nation that has to live on its wits. So the government is proposing drastic cuts to the amount of maths, science and Japanese that children have to cover and allowing schools more control over their lessons. The education ministry is even proposing to drop down from six days a week to five.

Down the coast in the city of Fukuoka, governor Wataru Aso is a passionate moderniser, pushing internet links and English language in the local schools. "The need to express themselves on the internet will motivate them to improve their English. In Japan we are pressing ahead with English as a second language but children have difficulty in speaking it fluently - they have limited opportunities to use it outside the classroom." He also wants lively debate between children in Japan and other countries through internet links and is keen to see them established. (At least 180 Japanese schools have requested e-links to Britain and the British Council is struggling to keep up with demand.)

During three years in London, he sent his daughters to St Mary Abbott primary in Kensington and is very positive about the education they received. He had been anxious they would not be able to keep up with the class and would become phobic about school, but because pupils were given different assignments according to the level they had reached they were happy and were able to progress. (Behaviour was another matter. One very un-Japanese phrase they picked up was "It's not my fault", he recalled.) "In the British system children learn to stand up for themselves and learn for themselves - that's the big difference I have found."

In the city's Chikushi high school, 38 16- and 17-year-olds are engaged in a game of whispers with their teachers Elizabeth Ottewell and Kunicko Eguchi, passing directions in English from the back to the front of the class. Success is patchy but they are opening their mouths a little.

Upstairs a very different English lesson is in progress, the students working through a rather dry text with their dictionaries, translating sentences such as "There are a number of systematic ways of learning to relax" and noting grammatical points. From time to time a pupil will stand up and mumble in answer to a question from the teacher. The setting is anything but relaxed but as the teacher, Yukihiro Hamada, explains, this is the preparation they need for the university entrance exams that dominate the final year of high school. His own spoken English is good but his students need the old-fashioned drilling for the tests.

Moves by the government to free up time in the curriculum seem set to go ahead whatever the result of next week's general election. The ruling coalition is expected to get back in, although the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, may well go after his controversial remarks about Japan as a "divine nation with the emperor at its centre". But as Masao Homma, director-general of policy at the education ministry, remarks wryly, teachers and schools are nervous. "It is difficult to change the way their minds work overnight. They keep asking what to do with this freedom."

Schools will be expected to place more emphasis on morality and citizenship - "education of the heart" - in a country shocked by the appearance of bullying, truancy and a few well-publicised incidents of school violence. The demise of the extended family and declining respect for teachers are causing a lot of unease.

This genuine anxiety seems a far cry from the orderly classrooms and well-swept corridors of Ikuchi junior high. But no doubt it will make a good topic for debate when the school's internet link progresses from shepherd's pie.

Meeting of minds

Anna Bradley (13 years old tomorrow) was intrigued to hear that her picture, along with those of some her friends at Wortley high school in Leeds, is featured on the wall of a Japanese classroom thousands of miles away. She emailed Ikuchi junior high school with her photograph and a brief rundown on her hobbies and pets and an intercontinental conversation now seems to be thriving.

"We have been talking about food. I'm a vegetarian and they have been asking for some vegetarian recipes. I have sent them a salad dish," she said. Anna was surprised to find the Japanese pupils had not heard of netball.

Eva Wai said they had exchanged photos and were finding out what Ikuchi was like. "It sounds a lot different to Leeds. It's surrounded by mountains and it doesn't sound too crowded. It sounds a lot quieter than here. We hope to find out a bit more about their culture and what sort of lessons they have, and whether they have the same bands as we do. We haven't heard of all of them."

Language is so far only a problem in slowing up responses from the Japanese children. Nigel Harness, the school's IT coordinator, said the children seemed to have things like music and football in common. "But with everything else they are gobsmacked. It really is opening up their minds. I thought it was going to be a bit of a chore, but it's good fun. And it fits into the curriculum so it will be very useful."

 Any school interested in a link with a school in Japan should contact the Central Bureau, British Council, 10 Spring Gardens, London SW1A 2BN or email school-links@britishcouncil.or.jp.

fields.headline: Problem solvers
fields.trailText: Whatever problem your child has there's sure to be a relevant book. Or fifteen. And very helpful they may be...
fields.body:
Sibling rivalry, the new baby, temper tantrums, night terrors, fussy eaters... the list goes on. Whatever problem your child has there's sure to be a relevant book. Or fifteen. And very helpful they may be.

But what about reading to the under-6s for sheer fun? Reading to celebrate the daftness and idiosyncracies of life?

Shoe Shoe Baby (David and Charles, £9.99) fits the bill exactly. Written by Bernard Lodge and illustrated by his daughter, Katherine, it's a dotty story about the shoes in a shoe shop - and the weird and wonderful characters who come to buy them. (Look out for Conchita from Costa Rica who gets shoes with a view!) Both words and pictures are a total delight; it's fresh, funny and truly original.

The Hairy Toe (Walker Books, £4.99) is guaranteed to have the nervous refusing to go to bed ever again (especially if they just happen to have picked up a hairy toe), but the tough will love it.

Daniel Postgate has illustrated this traditional American tale with real gusto: watch that huge dark shadow coming nearer... and nearer... and nearer. Any parent who enjoys showing off will have a ball with the SWOOSH of the wind and the CRE-E-EAK of the floor, let alone moaning "Where's my Hair-r-ry To-o-oe? Who's got my Hair-r-ry To-o-oe?"

Completely different (and perfectly safe for every young reader) is Where's Caterpillar? by Sarah Godwin and Louise Batchelor (Frances Lincoln, £4.99). Mouse is looking for Caterpillar, and he travels through a glorious swirl of colours and patterns before he finds her. He goes through a dark room, a forest, to the ocean, and beyond - and hidden on each page is a different animal, camouflaged in the background. Peep through the cut-out or turn the page and, bingo!, the animal appears (and the camel goes from lying down to standing up).

Daft verse has always had a fascination for the very young: "It was midsummer night in winter/ and snow was on the ground..." Ruth Brown's beautiful pictures in Mad Summer Night's Dream (Red Fox, £4.99) let the reader float gently away into a dream world of magic and enchantment. Don't rush the last page; my testers loved finding the real objects that sourced the nonsense.

David Wojowycz's Animal 123 (David and Charles, £9.99) is really a counting book, but it's such fun you don't need any educational excuse to read it over and over again. The colours zing, the birds and animals are the maddest you've ever seen, and the action takes place in an amazingly complex hotel inhabited by mice. Have you ever imagined a large lamb with a curiously strong resemblance to Boy George? Have a look at seven Singing Sheep, and see who else you oldies recognise...

And finally, the queen of the idiosyncratic - Sara Fanelli. Children - and adults - either love her or hate her, but if ever you ordered up food for the imagination, Dreamtime (Heinemann Young Books, £9.99) would have to be on the main menu. The end papers alone stand hours of scrutiny; don't flick past a single page of this book.

The story tells how Zeno, Bubu and Bird follow their dreams and help Marty the Martian find his little pet Martini. The strange scratchy drawings, picture strips and collage intrigue kids; it's a language they understand better than adults do. And the words are great - "As a reward, the teacher gave me an umbrella to protect me from shooting stars." Brilliant stuff!

webTitle: Court backs BBC over live football

fields.headline: Court backs BBC over live football
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday won a court order banning the commercial radio station Talksport from passing off coverage of Euro 2000 football matches as live when its commentators are watching the game on television screens away from match venues.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday won a court order banning the commercial radio station Talksport from passing off coverage of Euro 2000 football matches as live when its commentators are watching the game on television screens away from match venues.

Before the opening match between Belgium and Sweden at the weekend, Talk played recordings of the two countries' national anthems and then laid match commentary over a tape of football sound effects, the BBC claimed.

At the high court in London yesterday, Mr Justice Blackbourne ordered Talk to make it clear its coverage is not live, to say its commentators are watching the game on TV, and not to suggest the station has the broadcast rights.

Bob Shennan, the controller designate of Radio 5 Live, which is broadcasting coverage of Euro 2000 matches with direct sound feed and commentary, said: "Talksport's promotion and coverage over the weekend was duping listeners."

But Talk last night accused the BBC of hypocrisy. Kelvin MacKenzie, chairman and chief executive of the Wireless group which owns Talksport, claimed the BBC had only secured the rights to Euro 2000 radio coverage through its membership of the European Broadcasting Union. "The BBC belongs to a cartel of state broadcasters who are opposed to the idea of competition from the commercial sector. The idea that we would be responsible for lowering the value of sports rights is preposterous - considering they were instrumental in making sure we were unable to bid against them."

Talk has reported the European Broadcasting Union to the European commission, which is investigating the acquiring of broadcast rights.

Talk said it would continue to present its coverage, but would comply with the terms of the court order.

webTitle: Banana war may hit cashmere jobs

fields.headline: Banana war may hit cashmere jobs
fields.trailText: The government is braced for heavy job losses in the Scottish cashmere industry as the US prepares to step up retaliation against the European Union for failing after a 15 month pause to resolve the long-running EU-US banana war.
fields.body:
The government is braced for heavy job losses in the Scottish cashmere industry as the US prepares to step up retaliation against the European Union for failing after a 15 month pause to resolve the long-running EU-US banana war.

British ministers are dismayed because the Caribbean banana producers, for whom they had fought against US-owned exporters from Central America, have done a satisfactory deal with Washington, only to be let down by European importers.

As with the parallel row over imports of hormone injected beef, Britain hopes to avoid damaging US sanctions which may see cashmere knitwear, which sustains thousands of jobs in Scotland, added to the sanctions list by June 19.

Last night Whitehall continued to side with the US and Canada in their long-running trade war with the EU over the 12-year-old Europe-wide ban on the use of hormones in beef. Downing Street says that no Whitehall ministry is now blocking the compromise on bananas either.

Nick Brown, agriculture minister, said there was no scientific justification for the ban, which also applies to imports, and last year prompted tit-for-tat action, involving punitive 100% US tariffs, on selected goods from all EU countries except Britain.

The goods included French cheese and truffles, French and German mustard. The tariffs were designed to make up for trade losses totalling nearly $117m (£73m).

There is no question of Britain opting out of the EU ban but its continuing support for the US position means it is unlikely to face any retaliation for the foreseeable future.

Coincidentally, the Scottish Office minister, Brian Wilson, protested at EU lethargy about failure to meet the terms of the World Trade Organisation ruling to allow more non-Caribbean bananas into EU markets, notably Germany where bananas are popular.

"Fifteen months have now elapsed since the WTO panel once again found against the EU on this issue. To any objective observer, it is incomprehensible that these 15 months have not been sufficient to bring this whole matter to a WTO-compliant conclusion," he told Scots MPs.

webTitle: Nuclear weapons secrets vanish from Los Alamos labs

fields.headline: Nuclear weapons secrets vanish from Los Alamos labs
fields.trailText: Computer hard drives holding some of the United States' most sensitive nuclear weapons secrets have vanished from a vault at the Los Alamos research laboratory, in New Mexico, the US department of energy admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Computer hard drives holding some of the United States' most sensitive nuclear weapons secrets have vanished from a vault at the Los Alamos research laboratory, in New Mexico, the US department of energy admitted yesterday.

An official statement said the disappearance of the electronic files was "an extremely serious matter", but added that it was too early to blame their absence on espionage. A desperate search of the laboratories was under way last night, in the hope that the drives had simply been mislaid.

The hard drives had been stored in special containers in a vault in the research centre's X division, where nuclear weapons are designed.

They include data on weapons used by the Nuclear Emergency Search Team, which is deployed in the event of nuclear accidents or nuclear threats from terrorists. It therefore contains all the information necessary to render nuclear devices safe in emergencies. The drives also held information about the Russian nuclear weapons programme, and details of Russian technology.

The drives were discovered to be missing on June 1, as brush fires burnt around the Los Alamos area, threatening the laboratories themselves - the site of the first nuclear explosion in 1945. When officials went to transfer the data for safekeeping, they found only empty containers.

"This is an extremely serious matter, and we are taking swift actions to deal with it," said John Browne, the director of the federal weapons research laboratory.

An energy department press release said: "Officials are conducting an exhaustive search of computers, safes, containers and vaults and are interviewing all staff members who had access to the vault where the media were stored."

Ed Curran, the director of the energy department's counter-intelligence unit, insisted yesterday that: "At this point there is no evidence that suggests espionage is involved in this incident."

Normal work at the laboratory was suspended to allow technicians to join the search, and energy department officials said that all employees with access to the vault may have to undergo polygraph "lie-detector" tests as part of the inquiry, being pursued jointly with the FBI.

The embarrassment could not have come at a worse time for the energy secretary, Bill Richardson. The Los Alamos laboratory was already in the midst of a security review following the arrest last year of one of its scientists, Wen Ho Lee, who is awaiting trial for allegedly transferring secret information from secure to unsecure computers and computer tapes.

It is still unclear what happened to the computer tapes and Mr Lee has not been charged with espionage. The hard drives in the X division laboratory reportedly went missing after Mr Lee first came under suspicion and was dismissed.

The head of the energy department's security section, Eugene Habiger, who is leading the search for the missing information, said the chaos caused by the New Mexico wildfires might be a factor in the continued absence of the files, suggesting that perhaps a laboratory employee took them when forced to evacuate the area.

"Our inquiry has been conducted during a period in which employees are still recovering from the effects of a major emergency disaster," Mr Habiger said.

After Mr Lee was dismissed last April, the energy department was the subject of withering criticism from Republican leaders, who accused the government of letting its guard down in a matter of critical national security.

As a result of the scandal, Mr Richardson ordered a shutdown of the laboratory's computer systems and gave instructions for Los Alamos employees to undergo security training sessions.

Congress later passed measures to establish a new nuclear weapons agency within the energy department specifically to oversee the weapons laboratories.

Security officials quoted on the New York Times website late yesterday evening said the energy department had initially played down the importance of the incident, believing that the hard drives would turn up.

But the fact that the missing hard drives contained files of intelligence reports has raised suspicions of espionage.

webTitle: Hewitt tries to spread the skills and resources

fields.headline: Hewitt tries to spread the skills and resources
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Along with its opportunities, the new economy has thrown up another instance of Britain's north-south divide.
fields.body:
Along with its opportunities, the new economy has thrown up another instance of Britain's north-south divide.

Patricia Hewitt, e-commerce minister, acknowledges that the north largely remains reliant on manufacturing, battered by the strong pound, while internet investment is concentrated in the south.

The government's regional development agencies, promoting technology investment at local level, have partly offset this dichotomy, she says.

The next step has been to introduce IT training programmes, particularly in the north. "The skills shortage of information technology workers in this country has become a huge problem. We are investing in training people in this area, particularly those who have lost jobs in an industry that is contracting."

The electronic communications bill aims to alleviate the skills shortage by making it easier for British firms to hire foreign IT specialists, but this has caused disquiet at the Home Office, which argued this encourages economic migration.

The department of trade and industry is confident of victory. At stake, it argues, is the need to ensure that Britain does not drop out of the race to dominate cyberspace. At present 8m Britons are online but this is expected to explode as more consumers gain access to the internet via digital television and mobile phones.

"It's absolutely essential to our economic wellbeing and competitive position that we ensure there is mass internet access that is low cost," Ms Hewitt says. "The aim is to give people internet access without the cost and constraint of the personal computer."

The government has been pushed into coming to grips with the information age by not only getting itself online but also working with other countries to create international frameworks. One fear of technology sector has been that the British and other European governments will move to over-regulate the internet. Britain has the largest e-commerce market in the European Union and Ms Hewitt denies she will apply a regulatory dead hand to this thriving sector.

"There are a number of changes that are happening and we are looking for an effective system of co-regulation," she says, pointing to private industry bodies such as the Internet Watch Foundation. "All the way through our position has been to manage what the government can do in this field, which is quite limited. Our job is to make sure there is an efficient environment."

The government has moved towards making the internet attractive to small business by introducing in the Budget 100% tax write-offs for investment in e-commerce or new information technology.

However, the government will have to decide soon whether the fast-converging areas of telecoms and broadcasting still need separate regulators. A statement is expected later in the year.

Ms Hewitt says she wants to eliminate another British dichotomy: that between the new and old economies.

Many a "traditional" industry is a big investor in new technology, she argues. "If you are a textiles company it seems the thinking is that you must be in decline and not worth investing in. That's deeply wrong."

fields.headline: Vote for chaos
fields.standfirst:
Early elections in Kosovo are just a way for the west to cut and run

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Lesley Abdela: Early elections in Kosovo are just a way for the west to cut and run
fields.body:
The UN secretary general's special representative in Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, plans municipal elections this September or October. "When will they e-e-ever learn?" say the despairing words of the sixties anti-war song.

Early elections are likely to be a dagger at the heart of democracy in Kosovo. Picture it. Just 16 months will have passed since the bombing stopped, the Serb army and murdering/raping paramilitaries withdrew, and several hundred thousand exiles returned to burnt-out houses and broken-down power stations. Before that, decades of autocratic rule from Belgrade under Milosevic and Tito. Before that? Hundreds of years of autocratic rule under the Ottoman empire.

These elections will further democracy in Kosovo just 16 months since the bombing stopped? To quote John McEnroe - "you cannot be serious!"

"The tendency of the international community after conflict has been to cut and run," says the Ford Foundation's Michael Edwards, author of a new book Future Positive, "pushing through early elections instead of staying for the long term and consolidating conditions for an emerging democratic policy."

Dame Pauline Neville Jones, who led the British delegation at the Dayton negotiations, says bluntly: "We should have learnt from the Bosnia experience where elections were held prematurely for the same reason - the US desire to get out fast. The elections went ahead with predictable results - the return to power of nationalists. There is even less excuse to commit the same error twice."

Kosovan society is still too wounded, too riven with fresh hatreds, too economically insecure, fundamentally too unstable to sustain pluralist politics. Right now Kosovans have other priorities. Top of their list are the 4,000 missing persons plus 2,000 hostages held in Serb jails, including the women's rights campaigner Flora Brovina.

Albanian Kosovans still wait to open mass graves to find their loved ones. The province lacks the basic election infrastructure. Even King Solomon would have lifted his toga and run rather than preside over the quagmire of Kosovan voter registration. The pre-bombing population of the capital Pristina was 250,000. Now it has swollen with internal displacements to around 600,000. Many villagers cannot return home because their houses remain gutted, farms and villages in thrall to anti-personnel mines and unexploded ordnance.

Credible rumour holds that some 200,000 Albanians have crossed the border into Kosovo, faking residency. Last seen going the other way, at least 150,000 Serbian Kosovans have fled as refugees.

The ruling UN mission has decided that only citizens resident in Kosovo on January 1, 1998 will be allowed to register to vote. A Kosovan community leader says this makes a mockery of voter registration. "There were 40,000 Serb military police and paramilitaries in Kosovo on that date. Will they be registered to vote? Between 300,000 and 500,000 Kosovan Albanians had already fled to safety by then. Many will not be back in Kosovo in time to register."

UN security council resolution 1244 is committed to a multi-ethnic Kosovo. Even if the 95,000 Serbs still living in the province want to register to vote, it has become too physically dangerous for them to venture out. Just a few days ago, a car of Serbs, including small children, on their way to a market was blown up by a freshly placed mine.

Kosovan political parties are mostly no more than clans led by young warriors who fought with the UCK (Kosovan Liberation Army). These ambitious young men see politics as a route to personal fame and fortune - especially fortune. Other than wanting an independent Kosovo they have few policies.

Certain Kosovan party leaders are well-known to international police as gangsters and mafia leaders with links to organised crime throughout Europe, Asia and North America. "They are extremely dangerous," a US police officer with the international police in Kosovo told me. "It would be laughable to turn an entire country over to such a gang of thugs if it wasn't so sad for the common people who have to live here."

Almost from the moment the bombs stopped raining down from 15,000 feet last June, leaders of UN and OSCE missions endorsed these criminals by dealing with the first self-appointed Kosovan leaders they came across. They did not take the trouble to include and consult with the wider range of readily available moderate and representative Kosovan community leaders. Moderate Kosovans, both Albanian and Serb, watched in growing horror as the charade unfurled.

As another senior UN police officer quoted in the Observer admitted haplessly: "I think we all - aid workers, diplomats, journalists - made a mistake. We didn't speak to the right people."

The British journalist Ian Mather, an experienced defence correspondent, has just completed six months in Kosovo as media development coordinator with the OSCE. "The chances of an election being covered fairly by the media are virtually nil," he says. "Radio TV Kosovo, run by the OSCE, broadcasts for two hours each evening when there is electricity. Koha Ditori is the only independent newspaper. Other newspapers are owned by or beholden to political groups - a number are mafia protected. Some even border on incitement."

It has taken other European societies centuries to develop key components of democracy and inclusion - law, order, free expression, political parties with developed election manifestos, freedom to register to vote and to place your votes in safety and secrecy, without fear of intimidation.

From a US perspective, Kosovo was always likely to be a minor problem in a faraway place, a tiny province in a tiny nation tucked away in the cockpit of Europe, or a Somalia in the making. Holding elections must seem a reasonable and honourable way to restore democracy. Holding them so prematurely, as part of the not-so-hidden agenda to get the heck out, is not especially honourable. Indeed, it dishonours democracy. It dishonours the tax-payers who funded the estimated $35bn to free Kosovo for democracy and entry into the European family. It dishonours the forces that rescued Kosovo from Milosevic's maw.

The last helicopter is revving up on the roof-top.

Lesley Abdela served in Kosovo in 1993 as deputy director for democracy at the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE).

fields.headline: Corridor lined with gold
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Along the M4 corridor construction cranes fight for space against the billboard size names of trail-blazing multinationals such as Microsoft, Oracle and Motorola.
fields.body:
Along the M4 corridor construction cranes fight for space against the billboard size names of trail-blazing multinationals such as Microsoft, Oracle and Motorola.

Technology companies and internet start-ups have spread west from Slough to Swindon, sweeping up Reading, Maidenhead and Newbury to create England's silicon corridor.

The emergence of the new economy has seen US companies flock to the Berkshire countryside. More than 40% of the technology companies along the M4 have US roots and their investment in the area has given rise to an internet gold rush. The region ranks only behind London in terms of wealth in England, with a gross domestic product of £25bn for a population of just 2m.

Even diehard valley types from California have been lured here. "I lived in silicon valley in California for 22 years and watched it grow from a pretty small operation. Something similar is happening in this area, especially with the internet boom on top of the technology boom," says Jim Ambras, vice president of engineering at AltaVista's European headquarters in Maidenhead.

Silicon valley's cash culture has also arrived. The local newspaper in Reading claims that rents for a two-bedroom flat are on a par with London at between £600 and £900 a month. It appears there are as many BMWs as Ford Mondeos. Recruitment agencies litter the town centre, their windows plastered with ads begging for call centre staff, data entry employees or information managers.

Gridlock along M4

The hotels are full and at least a further three are on the drawing board to be developed to meet the demand. Peter Sullivan, director of sales and marketing at the Renaissance Hotel, said: "Ten years ago Reading was not the sort of place you would consider going to, but now all that has changed. Now they're saying Cisco, one of the largest companies in the world, is looking to move their UK headquarters here."

Mr Sullivan is one of the lucky ones. He brought his home on the Reading outskirts in the seventies for a tenth of what people are now paying to climb aboard the area's booming property market.

Progress brings it problems. The most frequently heard gripe is that the local infrastructure has failed to keep up with the explosion of people and new business.

The gridlock of traffic along the M4 and the ineffectiveness and unpredictability of public transport are the main complaints of three in four companies in the area, according to a survey by the Thames Valley Economic Partnership.

However bad the situation here - it is still better than in the US. "This area has a lot of great things going for it, especially commuting which is nothing like silicon valley where for some people it can be a two-hour journey each way," said Mr Ambras of AltaVista. The US-based search engine and internet portal employs about 50 staff in Maidenhead.

It is not just new economy companies that have benefited. Slough Estates has been developing industrial and more recently technology parks in the area since 1920. Now more than 22% of its non-retail UK rent roll comes from "new generation businesses" such as e-commerce, computers, communications and biotechnology.

John Heawood, executive director at Slough Estates, argues that the benefits of the technology boom outweigh the transport and housing issues. "There isn't anywhere in the UK or overseas where you have economic success and you don't have a problem with congestion and so forth. I would rather that, as a challenge to face, than an economic wasteland. It's the price of success."

Highly skilled information technology staff are hard to find, although companies are looking to graduates from local universities and possibly even school leavers, who would start as trainees, to fill the gap. Local unemployment has plummeted from 9% a decade ago to almost zero today.

Intel, which employs about 1,800 people in the UK, deals with its labour issues by looking to Europe, India or the US for those staff it cannot recruit locally. The area's productivity rate is an impressive 27% higher than the UK average.

Computer group Oracle says it picked Reading as its base because the M4 corridor has become a magnet for technology and computer workers. Nine out of 10 of its staff are graduates.

'Logical solution'

The huge influx of skilled people into the area has also attracted internet start-ups and small software firms who know their location is crucial in poaching from that labour pool.

Outside Reading, Intel is building a $150m European "internet-server farm" offering e-commerce support to corporate customers. The site was chosen over Amsterdam and Frankfurt and will employ 250 people.

"We wanted a site that was close to the airport; to telecommunications network access points; to the hi-tech industry and that was close to the financial community," said Rod Jackson, director of operations for Intel Europe. "It was a logical solution because of the telecommunications network and internet carriage activity that is established here."

Most companies agree that brief commuting to London is also a big advantage when trying to recruit staff from overseas; not everyone is keen to live in smaller towns.

"I don't think anyone in their right mind would live in Slough," said Peter Allen, finance director at biotechnology group Celltech. His bluntness doesn't dent his affection for the town that has been Celltech's head office for the past 10 years. He says most of the 400 staff live in London or the catchment area of the M4.

Allen's words reflect the thoughts of poet laureate John Betjeman who passed through the area just before the second world war. His famous poem invited "friendly bombs" to fall on Slough be cause industry and concrete boxes had made it unfit for humans.

Judith Anthony, chief executive of the Thames Valley Economic Partnership, says the success of the M4 corridor is a credit to the government's ability to win foreign investment against cities such as Frankfurt, Amsterdam and Paris. However, if the area is to remain a key part of the UK economy, further public funding is needed to provide improved support facilities. If this doesn't happen the private investment pouring into England's proudly proclaimed "silicon valley" may disappear as quickly as it came.
fields.bodyText: Along the M4 corridor construction cranes fight for space against the billboard size names of trail-blazing multinationals such as Microsoft, Oracle and Motorola. Technology companies and internet start-ups have spread west from Slough to Swindon, sweeping up Reading, Maidenhead and Newbury to create England's silicon corridor. The emergence of the new economy has seen US companies flock to the Berkshire countryside. More than 40% of the technology companies along the M4 have US roots and their investment in the area has given rise to an internet gold rush. The region ranks only behind London in terms of wealth in England, with a gross domestic product of £25bn for a population of just 2m. Even diehard valley types from California have been lured here. "I lived in silicon valley in California for 22 years and watched it grow from a pretty small operation. fields.headline: Indian recruits plug labour gap
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Pawan Prasad is unabashed when he says Indian software engineers and web designers are the best information technology staff you could hire.
fields.body:
Pawan Prasad is unabashed when he says Indian software engineers and web designers are the best information technology staff you could hire.

He points out that 38% of IT staff in the US are of Indian origin.

Certainly the shortage of software skills has thrown open exciting opportunities for Indian software companies such as Polaris, which Mr Prasad manages, especially in Britain.

Gordon Brown gave a helpful push when he announced in the last Budget plans to relax working restrictions on programmers, designers and other key computer staff.

They will fill some of the 100,000 vacancies in the IT sector, according to the National Computing Centre, and give a lift to Britain as it plays catch-up with America.

Polaris provides software applications to clients including Citibank, Reuters, the Nigerian Bank and NEC.

Finding qualified staff for his offices in London and Reading is one of Mr Prasad's main occupations. "It seems to be a major problem that there are not enough IT staff,"

Like California's Silicon Valley, England's technology hub has a "floating" work force from which contractors could be sourced, he says.

However, Mr Prasad does not appear to be too worried, if only because 80% of the 1,600 staff the company employs are located in India.

Polaris stresses speed, low cost and high quality in its products. However, low labour costs are where Polaris gains its edge. The company entered Britain in June 1998 and now employs 14 staff here. Much of its work is transmitted to India where its programmers design tailor-made packages.

If the program needs to be installed, consultants are flown from India to do the job.

Mr Prasad says it is cheaper than having a large workforce based in Britain, especially when staff can be seconded to clients for six months to a year.

Polaris is expanding under a plan based on organic growth that has so far seen turnover rise to £1m in Britain "This year we will be banking a profit," Mr Prasad boasts.

The firm is backed by an impressive history; it was started in 1983 by three entrepreneurs with total capital of £150. They now run a company that turns a profit of £27m.

The company is listed on the Indian stock exchange, but the determination to grab investors and customers from east and west should lead to a Nasdaq listing once volatility in net stocks has subsided.

webTitle: Accusations fly after south-east councils reject homes blueprint

fields.headline: Accusations fly after south-east councils reject homes blueprint
fields.trailText: Deputy prime minister John Prescott's housebuilding policy suffered an embarrassing setback yesterday when councils in the south-east united to reject government targets for new homes.
fields.body:
Deputy prime minister John Prescott's housebuilding policy suffered an embarrassing setback yesterday when councils in the south-east united to reject government targets for new homes.

The government faced pressure to cut back its plans for 43,000 extra homes to be built annually in the region when Conservatives on the planning authority backed a lower target of 33,000 homes a year for five years, claiming government proposals were "unachievable".

The decision, which councillors insisted was based on concern that the government plan would mean "concreting over the countryside for ever", provoked Labour accusations that the Conservative leadership was seeking to "play politics with people's homes".

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, pressurised Tory councils on the all-party south-east regional planning conference (Serplan) in advance of yesterday's vote, the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, claimed.

Labour councillors said the party-lines split on the issue meant that the authority had now become politicised and might never recover.

Meanwhile environmental and countryside groups warned ministers against clashing head-on with local authorities over housing, arguing that measures were not yet in place to make a reality of government targets for more building on recycled land.

Tony Burton, the assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England, said: "Tax breaks for urban renewal, extra funds for affordable homes and positive action to promote more even development around the regions are all needed before the government can consider raising housebuilding levels in the south-east."

In a warning that will alarm ministers who feel they have lost the confidence of middle England, Tony Bosworth of Friends of the Earth said imposing thousands of new houses on the region would store up "real electoral problems" for the government.

Serplan rejected by a majority of 39 to 30, with one abstention, government proposals to build an extra 860,000 homes across the 12 counties in the south-east outside Greater London.

An alternative proposal by Labour councillors for 39,000 new homes annually was rejected by Tory members of the authority, who argued that the need for the numbers of homes proposed by Mr Prescott had not been proven.

It also said that the government's figures would require an annual rate of housebuilding - around 47,000 new houses a year in 2006 to 2016 - which exceeded any previous level and was "therefore unachievable".

The row was provoked by an inquiry by a panel chaired by Professor Stephen Crow into Serplan's original baseline recommendation last October that 33,300 homes should be built annually.

Mr Prescott rejected this target and suggested a compromise figure of 43,000. This proposal, rejected yesterday by councillors, is out to consultation which closes on June 19.

Mr Raynsford said he regretted that the "tradition of cross-party consensus that has characterised Serplan's way of working in the past has been set aside in favour of party-political division".

The government would consider the views of both factions in the authority as well as more than 200 other submissions before reaching a decision in the autumn, he said.

Conservative opposition to plans for more affordable housing in the south-east would fuel house price inflation and force the children of local people to move away, he warned.

But Mr Norman insisted councillors in the region were "standing up for their residents".

He said: "They have every right to do so. The people in the south-east have now spoken. The government is committed to building the wrong houses in the wrong places, more than half will be built on green fields, countryside will be concreted over for ever and the vicious cycle of migration from the inner cities will continue."

Mr Prescott wants 60% of new homes on brownfield former industrial sites. But opponents argue there are fewer suitable brownfield sites in the region than in the north of England and green fields will be at risk.

But Labour councillors on Serplan accused the Tories of "breathtaking hypocrisy", saying it was a Tory minister who ruined green fields with the building boom in the 1980s.

webTitle: Heroic home secretary shoots the Tories' fox

fields.headline: Heroic home secretary shoots the Tories' fox
fields.standfirst: Special report on hunting
fields.trailText: Hunting came back to the chamber yesterday. Like the Belgian police, we were expecting a ruck. The two sides lowered angrily at each other. Metaphorical bar stools were raised above heads. Instead of St George's crosses on their faces, Tory MPs were smeared with the blood of foxes, or possibly stray Labour abolitionists   they had pursued through the tearoom.
fields.body:
Hunting came back to the chamber yesterday. Like the Belgian police, we were expecting a ruck. The two sides lowered angrily at each other. Metaphorical bar stools were raised above heads. Instead of St George's crosses on their faces, Tory MPs were smeared with the blood of foxes, or possibly stray Labour abolitionists they had pursued through the tearoom.

But in the end, there was little more fury than a few ironic jeers when Jack Straw rose to make his statement.

The pent-up rage and hatred seemed somehow to dribble away when he solemnly quoted a key passage from yesterday's Burns report on getting the government off the hook; sorry, the Burns report on hunting with dogs.

"There is a lack of firm scientific evidence about the effect on the welfare of a fox of being closely pursued, caught, and killed above ground by hounds. We are satisfied, nevertheless, that the experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox."

This po-faced assertion brought a great shout of laughter from the Labour benches. It is an example of the British, as opposed to the English, language. I suppose Lord Burns meant that the fox's welfare would be better served if it had its head shot off cleanly, though that is not the way we say it in English.

The Tories were facing two disadvantages. Back in 1997, the house voted by the enormous majority of 260 to ban fox hunting, after a belting speech by Ann Widdecombe, who now just happens to be the shadow home secretary. (She suggested loosing opponents of the bill near the lions in African game parks, to see if they too enjoyed the thrill of being hunted.)

Yesterday Miss Widdecombe was discreetly absent. Her understudy was poor David Lidington, who rose to mocking cries of "Wizzjee, wizzjee?", the colourful tribal chant that means "where is she?" "Regardless of the opinions various members of the opposition may have on this subject" he began, a little lamely, to more derisive laughter.

Tories tried to regain the moral low ground by yelling "Where's Kate?", a reference to Kate Hoey, who is against a ban. But it didn't work. She may be minister for sport, but she doesn't have to do anything with this bill. Anyhow, she comes from Ulster, where they don't waste time hunting mere foxes.

Mr Lidington flannelled around. The bill would be a "distraction" from the government's real problems. (This is true, which is one reason why everyone is looking forward to it so much.)

He wondered if Mr Straw had consulted the police to see if the ban could be enforced, and Labour MPs barracked: was he implying that people would hunt illegally?

And he demanded that Scottish MPs - the bill will not apply north of the border - should keep quiet and not vote. Fat chance. You might as well tell Tam Dalyell that he can't talk about the Belgrano because his seat isn't in Argentina.

Gordon Prentice was overcome. "I haven't said this before, but I'll say it now: the home secretary is a hero!" No one has ever said this to Mr Straw. He was covered in embarrassment, like the mousy secretary in old Hollywood films, told "Why, you look beautiful without your glasses!"

It was left to Gerald Kaufman to make the inevitable and inescapable Oscar Wilde joke. "The unspeakable in pursuit of the unbeatable," he said of the Conservatives.

But the Tories seemed wan, half-beaten, waiting for the Lords to do their work. "Chickens!" someone shouted desperately, reminding us that, yes, foxes too are guilty of specieism, by eating their comrades in the struggle against oppression.

webTitle: Peers vow to wreck hunt bill

fields.headline: Peers vow to wreck hunt bill
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers face a summer of discontent from rural Britain as thousands of passionate hunt supporters launch a "rapidly escalating, energetic and sustained protest campaign" to stop the government-backed bill, announced yesterday, that is expected to outlaw hunting with hounds by 2002.
fields.body:
Ministers face a summer of discontent from rural Britain as thousands of passionate hunt supporters launch a "rapidly escalating, energetic and sustained protest campaign" to stop the government-backed bill, announced yesterday, that is expected to outlaw hunting with hounds by 2002.

The Countryside Alliance, which has already organised a big London march in favour of bloodsports, predicted more marches, demonstrations at the Labour party conference and "spontaneous" events, one of which brought traffic to a halt in Parliament Square yesterday and led to protests outside Labour headquarters in Millbank.

The campaign will be backed up inside parliament by guerrilla tactics to wreck other government legislation in the House of Lords by pro-hunting peers led by Lord Kimball, deputy chairman of the Countryside Alliance.

Last night Lord Kimball was meeting Tory peers to draw up tactics to wreck Michael Meacher's countryside and right of way bill - in revenge for Jack Straw's announcement of a free vote in the Commons on hunting.

"The decision to withdraw an amendment banning hunting from this [countryside] bill will make no difference. I shall now be drawing up plans to delay the bill in the Lords," Lord Kimball said yesterday.

The decision to hold a free vote will be used by William Hague's supporters to argue that Labour's plan is a "distraction" from its key issues: the NHS, schools and law and order. The aim will be to build on public disquiet that Labour may not be able to deliver on the big issues that affect the majority - to claim that it is reduced to banning country pursuits enjoyed by a minority.

The Tories, who opposed Britain signing up to the European court of human rights, plan to use the court to challenge a ban.

At the same time Lord Daresbury, chairman of Aintree racecourse and a passionate supporter of hunting, indicated that "to gain public confidence" he would be prepared to discuss a series of restrictive measures to limit some of the worst aspects of bloodsports announced by the Treasury civil servant Lord Burns in his inquiry.

These include a closed season for fox hunting and hare coursing, a ban on man-made fox earths, and a ban on hunts that are too near large towns.

Mr Straw yesterday insisted that the government would be neutral on the issue, allowing MPs to choose in a free vote between a series of options.

These will include maintaining the status quo, retaining hunting with new restrictions, a partial ban, and a total ban. The home secretary made it clear that once MPs had taken a free vote - and there is a big majority for a ban - the government might guillotine the measure in the Commons and use the Parliament Act to override objections in the Lords.

Civil servants still have to draft the options and define what offences will be committed under the bill if people ignore the new law.

Both sides - the Campaign for the Protection of Hunted Animals and the Countryside Alliance - argued that the Burns report vindicated their stance.

The alliance claimed, with 6,000 to 8,000 jobs at stake, that a ban would damage rural economies and that hunting was necessary for pest control. The anti-hunting lobby said that the report made clear that hunting was cruel, quoting a line from Burns saying : "We are satisfied that this experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox."

The Labour MP Mike Foster, whose backbench bill to outlaw hunting floundered in the Commons, congratulated Mr Straw. He welcomed the "very real prospect of an end to the cruel and unnecessary practice of hunting with dogs" and urged the government to use parliamentary devices to cut short debate on its bill to ensure that it became law by the next general election.

Gordon Prentice, another Labour MP, whose decision to table an amendment to the countryside bill banning hunting put ministers on the spot, described the home secretary as a hero for promising the measure.

Anthony Bosanquet, president of the Country Landowners Association, said: "The government has allowed itself to be distracted from much more important issues such as the future of food and farming, creation of jobs, provision of suitable housing and public transport."

Lord Burns refused to say last night whether his experiences as chairman of the inquiry had led him to think that hunting should be banned, but he welcomed the government's swift publication of his report.

He told Channel 4 News: "This is a game which has got quite a long way to go. It is a very difficult issue, a complex issue and a sensitive one and there are a lot of arguments still to be exposed.

"What I hope our report will do is inform that debate and make it a better debate than it would have been if we hadn't done this work."

League Against Cruel Sports
