The anti-hunting lobby said that the report made clear that hunting was cruel, quoting a line from Burns saying : "We are satisfied that this experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox." The Labour MP Mike Foster, whose backbench bill to outlaw hunting floundered in the Commons, congratulated Mr Straw. He welcomed the "very real prospect of an end to the cruel and unnecessary practice of hunting with dogs" and urged the government to use parliamentary devices to cut short debate on its bill to ensure that it became law by the next general election. Gordon Prentice, another Labour MP, whose decision to table an amendment to the countryside bill banning hunting put ministers on the spot, described the home secretary as a hero for promising the measure. Anthony Bosanquet, president of the Country Landowners Association, said: "The government has allowed itself to be distracted from much more important issues such as the future of food and farming, creation of jobs, provision of suitable housing and public transport." Lord Burns refused to say last night whether his experiences as chairman of the inquiry had led him to think that hunting should be banned, but he welcomed the government's swift publication of his report. He told Channel 4 News: "This is a game which has got quite a long way to go. It is a very difficult issue, a complex issue and a sensitive one and there are a lot of arguments still to be exposed. "What I hope our report will do is inform that debate and make it a better debate than it would have been if we hadn't done this work." fields.headline: Case study: Saboteur
fields.standfirst:
People believe hunting is cruel, but don't know the extent of it

Burns Inquiry
Special report on hunting
Countryside Alliance
League Against Cruel Sports
fields.trailText: Kevin Williams, 31, from Newport, south Wales
fields.body:
Kevin Williams, 31, from Newport, south Wales

"I have been actively involved in the anti-hunting movement for the last five or six years and go out every weekend during the hunting season carrying out sabotage.

"I come from a rural environment and have lived on a farm.

"As I grew older and became more aware I began to oppose hunting more and more strongly. It was the barbarity of the hunt and the fact that it was unnecessary that led me to be involved.

"Hunt sabbing is not all sticks and balaclavas like a lot of people imagine. If you went out with sticks you would end up getting a beating every week. The hunters invariably outnumber us six to one so it's in your interest to keep it peaceful and within the law. You stay close to the hounds and confuse them by spraying the place where the fox has gone with lemon and garlic solution or by using a horn.

"People believe that hunting is cruel but they don't know the full extent of it. The more you get to know about it, the crueller you realise it is and the crueller you realise the hard core of hunters are. I have seen the full range of cruelty: foxes being chased all day and others being dug out after they have gone to earth. At the end of the season I have seen hounds get a vixen and pull her apart and I have seen the unborn cubs.

"I want to see a complete ban on hunting with dogs. That's not to say that people can't walk their dogs in the countryside but if they go out with shovels and lots of terriers the police should be able to arrest them for it.

"I want to see an end to hare coursing, mink hunting, deer hunting, the lot. And that includes tougher measures to stop badger digging, dog fighting and cock fighting, all of which is a lot more common than we think.

"It is good news that the Burns report has been finished and presented but it sounds as though Jack Straw is fudging the issue. Everybody knows that when a bill goes before parliament MPs will vote for an outright ban.

"The suggestion that up to 4,000 jobs would be affected by a ban is ludicrous. In Newport we have a lot of struggling hunts. A lot of people with horses will not go fox hunting but a drag hunt could actually create jobs."

fields.headline: Case study: Huntsman
fields.standfirst:
It is my job and my life. It supplies everything

Burns Inquiry
Special report on hunting
Countryside Alliance
League Against Cruel Sports
fields.trailText: Derrick Partridge, 52, huntsman with the Curre and Llangybi hunts based at Itton, near Chepstow.
fields.body:
Derrick Partridge, 52, huntsman with the Curre and Llangybi hunts based at Itton, near Chepstow.

"I was born and brought up in the Usk area and I have been involved in hunting since I was a boy. My father used to hunt and he always took me with him.

"I took it up professionally 20 years ago and it is my job and my life. My wife is also employed by the hunt as a groom, looking after the horses.

"We pick up the dead animals from the farmers, feed and exercise the hounds and have the horses to look after.

"If hunting is banned I would have no job and neither would my wife.

"The hunt supplies the house, the water, the electricity, everything. I haven't got enough money to go and buy a house so we would be out on the road with our 11 year old son.

"I'm very worried about it and I would like to ask Mr Blair how he would be if they were going to kick him out on the road. I just don't know how I'd survive. I am too old to get another job now. I don't know what I'd do, we'd be on the scrapheap.

"In the last 20 years I have bred all the pups and the hounds I have got now and it would mean I would have to shoot them. To me it's like Mr Blair having to go and shoot his new born baby. We have got 54 couple of hounds in the kennels here and I know them all by name. There are little puppies over there - who is going to shoot them? I wouldn't be in this job if I didn't love the hounds and the horses.

"I think it is ridiculous for them to stop us hunting when it has been going for thousands of years.

It would be crueller for foxes to be controlled in another way. All the farmers who have sheep will put down snares in the hedges or shoot them and they will get away half injured and just suffer and die - it's going to be barbaric.

"The way we do it they are shot humanely as soon as we are on them and that's it. I would not dispute that somtimes the hounds do catch them but it is usually the lead hound that catches the fox and breaks its neck in seconds so it's just as quick as shooting. Most of the time they are shot by me."

webTitle: Scotland Yard to train Greek police hunting British attache's killers

fields.headline: Scotland Yard to train Greek police hunting British attache's killers
fields.trailText: Greece is to enlist the help of Scotland Yard counter-terrorism experts in an attempt to unearth November 17, the elusive group behind last week's assassination of the British embassy's military attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, in Athens.
fields.body:
Greece is to enlist the help of Scotland Yard counter-terrorism experts in an attempt to unearth November 17, the elusive group behind last week's assassination of the British embassy's military attache, Brigadier Stephen Saunders, in Athens.

Senior members of Greece's 300-strong anti-terrorist squad are to fly to London next month to be trained in the sort of skills that have enabled Scotland Yard to track down IRA gunmen, it was revealed last night.

"There have been connections between our two police forces in the past but now they are going to intensify greatly," the public order minister, Michalis Chrysohoidis, said.

"The British are very, very good. They're very practical and they can show us things, give us seminars."

A senior official at the ministry said all counter-terrorism officers would attend training. "We realise we have a very serious problem and we really want to crack it, so we're going to take up the British offer," he said. "Scotland Yard knows what we need, it's got one of the best records in the world."

The decision not only ends years of viewing outside help with suspicion, but highlights official embarrassment over the diplomat's murder.

Brig Saunders, whose body will be flown home today, is the first Briton to be killed by November 17. The group said it had targeted the defence attache because of his role in Nato's "barbaric airstrikes" against Yugoslavia last year. The Ministry of Defence denied he had any role in planning the attacks.

No member of November 17, an ultra-leftist urban gang without any clear political objective, has been captured or identified in the 25 years since it emerged with the slaying of Richard Welch, the CIA station chief in Athens. Brig Saunders was its 23rd victim.

Despite almost all of Athens' 15,000-strong police force being seconded to the job, no progress has been made in tracking down the two men who fatally shot the soldier in a ride-by assault as he drove to work last Thursday.

For the first time, investigators have failed to find the assassins' motorbike, which could, they say, provide critical DNA evidence.

On the suggestion of three Scotland Yard counter-terrorist officials already in the capital, Greek police are considering an appeal for people to come forward with information.

"But," said one government insider, "that sort of thing is not so easy here because people still have very bitter memories of the dictatorship and being an informant has very strong associations even if it's for the good of the country and is very effective."

Greece said it would also discuss other ways of fighting terrorism with Britain on a European Union level at a meeting of foreign ministers in Luxembourg today.

Under renewed pressure from Washington, the ruling Socialists have also said they will improve the country's anti-terrorism legislation by introducing witness protection and doing away with juries in terrorist cases. Such steps were taken in France, Italy and Germany - countries that wiped out their own terrorist groups in the seventies and eighties.

Many Greeks are concerned by the re-emergence of November 17, four years before Athens hosts the Olympics, and fear it may affect tourism, Greece's economic mainstay.

"The Greeks understand that this murder has been very very bad for the image of the country," said Mary Bossi, a specialist in political violence. "There's been a real change of heart, from the official level downwards. Before, there may have been a silent acceptance of November 17 but now people have had enough. They have begun to see this phantom group as a very big problem that has to end."

fields.headline: US gets warning on climate
fields.standfirst:
Scientists see a land of storms and droughts battered by sea

The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Picture New York as a tropical city, as hot and sticky as Miami, with much of downtown Manhattan frequently flooded. The Alaskan ice has melted leaving temperate agricultural land, while further south, the Florida Everglades disappear below the waves, changing the very shape of the US.
fields.body:
Picture New York as a tropical city, as hot and sticky as Miami, with much of downtown Manhattan frequently flooded. The Alaskan ice has melted leaving temperate agricultural land, while further south, the Florida Everglades disappear below the waves, changing the very shape of the US.

This radical vision is no longer just a distant possibility, but a likely scenario for the coming century, according to a US government study published yesterday. Among a string of sobering predictions, it suggests that if global warming continues on its present trajectory, average US temperatures will rise by 6C (10F) by 2100 and sea-level could rise by over two feet.

The report, Climate Change Impacts on the United States, which took four years to compile, suggests the US will change more in the next century than during the past millennium. Over much of the country more rain will fall in more intense thunderstorms, but the rate of evaporation will also increase sharply. Severe floods and prolonged droughts will occur side by side.

The forecast is not entirely gloomy. Crop yields will improve dramatically as vegetation thrives on an atmosphere rich in carbon dioxide. Forests should also flourish.

However, the outlook is bleak for fragile ecosystems vulnerable to changes of temperature and sea level. Coral reefs are likely to die off, and the swamps and wetlands which dot the eastern seaboard will be overwhelmed by seawater. The Everglades, a huge expanse of swamps which are home to alligators and rare species of birds, could be wiped off the map of Florida.

Denise Reed, a climate change expert at the University of New Orleans, said: "Where ecosystems are already heavily altered and stressed by human impacts, sea-level rise could be the straw that breaks the camel's back."

Meanwhile low-lying eastern cities including Miami, Washington DC, New York and Boston, would come under pressure. New York city, with a long coastline and four out of five boroughs on islands linked with tunnels and bridges, would be particularly hard-hit.

Sea-level rises of up to 3ft 6in would be exacerbated by storm surges, submerging much of Coney and Staten islands, and the foundations of the World Trade Centre and Battery Park city on the southern tip of Manhattan would be regularly flooded. The climate through much of the year would be as hot and humid as today's Miami.

Storms like the northeaster of 1992, which shut down New York's subway system, its airports and many of its roads, would become much more common, and could even be annual occurrences by the end of the century. The rising ocean and the frequent storms would also endanger freshwater resources all along the east coast without large-scale sea defences.

Susanne Moser, of the Union of Concerned Scientists, who contributed to the report, said yesterday: "People will try to protect themselves with sea walls, and natural ecosystems will be the most likely losers. But I cannot imagine how humans will not be forced to retreat from the less heavily-populated areas."

The study was published in draft form on the internet yesterday to invite public comment, and is expected to spark furious debate over its assumptions and the computer models it employed.

Critics have pointed out that the two main computer simulations used by Britain's Hadley centre and the Canadian meteorological centre - produced startlingly different results for some regions. One forecast North Dakota would turn into a virtual desert, the other that it will become a swamp.

But Anthony Janetos, a co-chairman of the panel which wrote the report, said that the uncertainties did not undermine the study's value for contingency planning.

"There are a lot of local and regional decisions that have to be made now, not just federal policies, and people have to start thinking hard about what they might want to do."

The study's authors say its forecasts were based on "business as usual" assumptions that emission of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases continue to rise in line with 20th century trends.

Ms Moser said that to avert the sort of radical transformation in the US landscape envisaged by the report, the western industrial nations would have to make far more radical changes than they have been willing to contemplate.

"If we completely stopped emissions today we will still have some sort of the impact from the greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere. The reductions currently being negotiated are a very modest step that would not have much impact on these predictions."

fields.headline: 'A rude and incompetent botcher'
fields.standfirst:
Gynaecologist who practised in the UK after being struck off in Canada faces 14 complaints at GMC hearing

General Medical Council
fields.trailText: A gynaecologist who worked in North Yorkshire for 10 years after having his licence revoked in Canada was yesterday accused of a catalogue of botched operations, incompetence and negligence which left women bleeding and in agony during a 17-year UK career.
fields.body:
A gynaecologist who worked in North Yorkshire for 10 years after having his licence revoked in Canada was yesterday accused of a catalogue of botched operations, incompetence and negligence which left women bleeding and in agony during a 17-year UK career.

Richard Neale denied the complaints relating to 14 women patients and charges of fraudulently claiming qualifications he did not possess, at a disciplinary tribunal of the General Medical Council yesterday. Dozens of women who claim they have been damaged by him over more than a decade travelled to London to watch the start of the hearings. The GMC investigated more than 60 complaints before deciding which to pursue.

Sheila Wright-Hogeland, who founded a support group for Mr Neale's patients, said: "We have all gone through a lot of pain and suffering and we hope that the GMC will take action to make sure that no doctor can work in this country if they have been struck off in any other country."

Vivian Robinson QC, presenting the case against Mr Neale on behalf of the GMC, said there was an accumulation of evidence against him. "The council say the picture which emerges in this case is one of serious incidents of clinical incompetence and of professional negligence and in one instance appalling rudeness to a patient."

Incompetence

His incompetence showed in his surgery, said Mr Robinson. Several charges relate to hysterectomies he chose to perform by keyhole surgery (laparoscopy). When complications arose, he should have switched to the open technique - the normal method of surgery - in which he was competent. But he did not, and several women were left with perforated bladders and incontinence problems.

His negligence showed in his failure to carry out all the checks he should have made before and after surgery - the x-rays and mammograms which show up any problems. He took far too long to act when women he had operated on complained of pain and incontinence. His patients signed consent forms, but sometimes the operation he performed was not the one he had told them he would do.

Probably the worst case before the GMC is the treatment received by a woman referred to as Mrs B, to protect her anonymity and the confidentiality of medical records. She was diagnosed with endometriosis - where hormone-bearing tissue that lines the womb occurs in places it should not - by a doctor in Paris.

By 1990, it had apparently cleared up with drug treatment, but later that year, "she suffered severe pelvic and abdominal pains, causing her to collapse on to the kitchen floor," said Mr Robinson. Mr Neale, her consultant, dismissed them as ovulation pains. In May 1991, after a second collapse in New York, a doctor there told her to see a gynaecologist as soon as she got home. Mr Neale said he had seen her in March and she was fine.

"Over the next five years, acute shooting and stabbing pelvic and abdominal pains continued," said Mr Robinson. "Mr Neale dismissed them as natural ovulation and told her to stop worrying."

By December 1994, not only were the pains more frequent, but Mrs B was experiencing bleeding. In January 1995, Mr Neale noticed her swollen abdomen. An ultrasound scan confirmed that there were serious problems. On February 1, Mr Neale told the patient that it was the worst case of endometriosis he had ever seen. She had a total hysterectomy and there was no possibility of saving even a part of an ovary, as she had wanted.

"He said if he had known, he would have operated on her as an emergency case a lot sooner," said Mr Robinson. "He said, you must have been in great pain. She reminded him that she had been telling him about the pelvic pains for four years. It appears that Mr Neale then became very arrogant."

Mrs B was very unhappy with what had happened. "There was a conversation between them about the treatment she had had for her condition. There came a stage when he raised his voice considerably. She left the room and went to the waiting area. He placed himself between her and the door and said she would live to regret it if she brought a lawsuit or complaint against him," Mr Robinson said.

She consulted another gynaecologist in York and then went with her husband to try to get her medical records from Mr Neale. "Mr Neale refused to hand over copies of the notes, saying he would provide them in his own good time. Mr Neale followed her into the waiting room and proceeded to have a tantrum." He said Mrs B described him screaming petulantly and stamping his feet. "She felt he behaved appallingly."

Mrs B suffered a premature menopause as a result of Mr Neale's failure to detect her endometriosis earlier, said Mr Robinson. Had he acted sooner, some ovarian function could have been preserved.

In one of the cases against him, Mr Neale is acused of falsely telling a patient that she would have to wait five months for a hysterectomy on the NHS, when the true time was a matter of weeks, so that she would pay him to carry it out privately. In two other cases, Mr Neale is accused of leaving needles and suture materials inside women's bodies, which led to complications, pain and further operations.

Three years ago, Mr Neale answered an advert placed by the GMC for performance assessors. They were needed to assess the skills and competence of doctors who were suspected of falling below standard. Mr Neale was approved in September 1997 and was provisionally included on the GMC list of assessors.

But his CV was fraudulent, it is alleged. He claimed he was director of the North Yorkshire Women's Continence Centre between 1985 and 1996, but it never existed. He said he was an examiner in obstetrics and gynaecology at Leeds University from 1985 to 1996, though there is no record of him being employed by the university, and its rules prevent anybody holding a post for that long. He said he had a diploma in counselling and a medal from the Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians, neither of which was true.

Yesterday one witness gave evidence against Mr Neale. Referred to as Mrs D, she told of haemorrhaging when she awoke from a hysterectomy, walking doubled up with pain as she left the hospital and spending five weeks on painkillers before her GP got her readmitted to have a blood clot drained. She is the first of many: the hearings are expected to last four weeks.

Sheila Wright-Hogeland, who founded a support group for Mr Neale's patients, said: "We have all gone through a lot of pain and suffering and we hope that the GMC will take action to make sure that no doctor can work in this country if they have been struck off in any other country." Vivian Robinson QC, presenting the case against Mr Neale on behalf of the GMC, said there was an accumulation of evidence against him. "The council say the picture which emerges in this case is one of serious incidents of clinical incompetence and of professional negligence and in one instance appalling rudeness to a patient." Incompetence His incompetence showed in his surgery, said Mr Robinson. Several charges relate to hysterectomies he chose to perform by keyhole surgery (laparoscopy). When complications arose, he should have switched to the open technique - the normal method of surgery - in which he was competent. But he did not, and several women were left with perforated bladders and incontinence problems. His negligence showed in his failure to carry out all the checks he should have made before and after surgery - the x-rays and mammograms which show up any problems. He took far too long to act when women he had operated on complained of pain and incontinence. His patients signed consent forms, but sometimes the operation he performed was not the one he had told them he would do. Probably the worst case before the GMC is the treatment received by a woman referred to as Mrs B, to protect her anonymity and the confidentiality of medical records. She was diagnosed with endometriosis - where hormone-bearing tissue that lines the womb occurs in places it should not - by a doctor in Paris. By 1990, it had apparently cleared up with drug treatment, but later that year, "she suffered severe pelvic and abdominal pains, causing her to collapse on to the kitchen floor," said Mr Robinson. Mr Neale, her consultant, dismissed them as ovulation pains. In May 1991, after a second collapse in New York, a doctor there told her to see a gynaecologist as soon as she got home. Mr Neale said he had seen her in March and she was fine. "Over the next five years, acute shooting and stabbing pelvic and abdominal pains continued," said Mr Robinson. "Mr Neale dismissed them as natural ovulation and told her to stop worrying." By December 1994, not only were the pains more frequent, but Mrs B was experiencing bleeding. In January 1995, Mr Neale noticed her swollen abdomen. An ultrasound scan confirmed that there were serious problems. On February 1, Mr Neale told the patient that it was the worst case of endometriosis he had ever seen. She had a total hysterectomy and there was no possibility of saving even a part of an ovary, as she had wanted. "He said if he had known, he would have operated on her as an emergency case a lot sooner," said Mr Robinson. "He said, you must have been in great pain. She reminded him that she had been telling him about the pelvic pains for four years. It appears that Mr Neale then became very arrogant." Mrs B was very unhappy with what had happened. "There was a conversation between them about the treatment she had had for her condition. There came a stage when he raised his voice considerably. She left the room and went to the waiting area. He placed himself between her and the door and said she would live to regret it if she brought a lawsuit or complaint against him," Mr Robinson said. She consulted another gynaecologist in York and then went with her husband to try to get her medical records from Mr Neale. "Mr Neale refused to hand over copies of the notes, saying he would provide them in his own good time. Mr Neale followed her into the waiting room and proceeded to have a tantrum." He said Mrs B described him screaming petulantly and stamping his feet. "She felt he behaved appallingly." Mrs B suffered a premature menopause as a result of Mr Neale's failure to detect her endometriosis earlier, said Mr Robinson. Had he acted sooner, some ovarian function could have been preserved. In one of the cases against him, Mr Neale is acused of falsely telling a patient that she would have to wait five months for a hysterectomy on the NHS, when the true time was a matter of weeks, so that she would pay him to carry it out privately. In two other cases, Mr Neale is accused of leaving needles and suture materials inside women's bodies, which led to complications, pain and further operations. Three years ago, Mr Neale answered an advert placed by the GMC for performance assessors. They were needed to assess the skills and competence of doctors who were suspected of falling below standard. Mr Neale was approved in September 1997 and was provisionally included on the GMC list of assessors. But his CV was fraudulent, it is alleged. He claimed he was director of the North Yorkshire Women's Continence Centre between 1985 and 1996, but it never existed. He said he was an examiner in obstetrics and gynaecology at Leeds University from 1985 to 1996, though there is no record of him being employed by the university, and its rules prevent anybody holding a post for that long. He said he had a diploma in counselling and a medal from the Royal College of Gynaecologists and Obstetricians, neither of which was true. Yesterday one witness gave evidence against Mr Neale. Referred to as Mrs D, she told of haemorrhaging when she awoke from a hysterectomy, walking doubled up with pain as she left the hospital and spending five weeks on painkillers before her GP got her readmitted to have a blood clot drained. She is the first of many: the hearings are expected to last four weeks.

fields.headline: Hunt bill triumph for Straw
fields.standfirst:
As backbench pressure grew, the government was forced into action

Special report on hunting
fields.trailText: The government's decision yesterday to bring forward a bill offering the option of banning hunting with dogs is a personal triumph for the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
The government's decision yesterday to bring forward a bill offering the option of banning hunting with dogs is a personal triumph for the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Mr Straw - hailed a hero by his backbenchers yesterday - regards fox hunting as a secondary issue but as the months of delay mounted over the issue, he came increasingly to the view that the government had an obligation to meet its manifesto commitment to resolve it one way or another.

Mr Straw was aware that the Commons contained a massive majority in favour of a ban since the vote on Michael Foster's private member's bill in November 1997. Like all backbench bills, Mr Foster's was always likely to be blocked by filibustering and a lack of time on the Commons floor.

Mr Straw's advisers told Mr Foster he was wasting his time using the vehicle of a private member's bill to try to steer through such controversial legislation.

A lover of parliamentary precedent and history, Mr Straw was aware that backbench legislation to change Sunday trading law had been similarly defeated repeatedly. Reform only occurred after the Conservative government produced its own bill setting out different options.

Mr Straw also felt fox hunting was potentially an issue becoming worse for the government the longer it delayed. The stakes seemed to be ratcheted ever higher each time the government prevaricated.

Inside Downing Street, the mood was more ambiguous. Tony Blair does not have a feel for countryside issues, and had been disturbed by the countryside marches early in his government. He had no desire to stir a rural civil war on something so tangential to his central mission. The issue was big in the party and among the professional lobbyists - but did not stir "swing suburbia". On balance, the minuses seemed more numerous than the pluses.

Nevertheless, days before the Eddisbury byelection last July, Mr Blair unexpectedly told BBC TV Question Time that the government would press ahead with a vote on banning fox hunting. It looked as if he was deliberately reactivating a dormant issue.

Mr Straw had not been forewarned of Mr Blair's remarks. One Straw ally claims: "It did us a favour. It made sure that we could no longer pretend that the Foster bill meant we had discharged our responsibility as a government to deal with fox hunting. It needed some further conclusion."

Mr Straw now had to come up with a solution. It took another four months internal debate before, in November, he asked Lord Burns, the former Treasury permanent secretary, to chair an inquiry. He had been struck by the indequacy of the public debate and the absence of an agreed corpus of informed knowledge.

In an equally important move, he also made it clear in principle that the government would, following the inquiry, provide government time for a further private member's bill on the issue.

Lord Burns was given a deliberately brief timetable and narrow remit - to examine the practical aspects of different types of hunting, its impact on the rural economy, pest control, the cultural life of the countryside and animal welfare. It was also to look at the consequences of a ban and how it might be implemented.

It was not being asked to make a recommendation on the intrinsic merits of a ban.

At the time of setting up this inquiry, many said Mr Straw was simply hurling the issue into the longest of long grass. But he was determined to act and through the spring became more convinced that the government should produce its own bill with options in the manner of the Shops Act.

In discussions with key backbenchers, he accepted that a private member's bill, even with government time, was more vulnerable.

Secondly, the government can frame its own bill as it wants and ensure that all the necessary options are offered MPs - and it sends a clear signal to the semi-reformed Lords that the government is serious on the issue.

It will be easier to invoke the Parliament Act if the bill is sponsored by the government rather than backbencher. It would also provide a convenient rallying point for a clash between the Commons and unelected peers in the run-up to the election.

Mr Blair was quite happy to accept this course so long as the government could be seen to remain formally neutral on the issue.

There was one final consideration. Downing Street was under increasing attack from its own backbenchers for delay. Gordon Prentice was preparing to publish the names of 150 backbenchers willing to delay other government legislation - notably the Countryside Bill - if no clear signal emerged from government.

"It would have been armageddon," said Prentice yesterday. Mr Staw's solution of a government bill, he said, was "always the best way out, but it has taken them a long time to get here".

fields.headline: New Father Thames
fields.standfirst: London's river used to be a giant sewer system, walled off from a city that didn't want to know. Now, as a string of shiny (if wobbly) attractions spring up along its banks, we are flocking to the Thames again.
fields.trailText: London's river used to be a giant sewer system, walled off from a city that didn't want to know. Now, as a string of shiny (if wobbly) attractions spring up along its banks, we are flocking to the Thames again.
fields.body:
Until it developed an 8in "wobble" that terrified its first users and caused its temporary closure, London's new Millennium Bridge had been floating on a tide of enraptured praise. The "blade of light" that Lord Foster of Thameside has suspended between St Paul's and Tate Modern is actually of wider significance than its architectural merits - or otherwise - necessarily suggest. A thing of pedestrian pleasure rather than motorised utility, it testifies to the fact that Londoners are rediscovering the Thames as something quite other than the "dirty old river" of habitual description, and finding newly genial forms of public life in places that were once more or less abandoned to the homeless and outcast.

Encouraged by the surging property market and a new planning framework that demands ambitious "landmark" buildings as well as the conservation of historic buildings and views, developers are pressing in on the river with big residential propositions. However, in London as in Tyneside and Belfast, the transformation is being led by large-scale cultural projects.

That imposing palace of state bureaucracy, Somerset House, is being opened on the north bank. Out go the clerks and in comes the Gilbert Collection: a riot of gaudy jewel-encrusted snuff-boxes and a splendid waxwork model of the recently knighted donor: an elderly Californian property developer who will be forever lounging at his desk in tennis shoes.

Yet it is on the south bank of the Thames that the real breakthrough is taking place. There are still dead stretches opposite and upriver from the Houses of Parliament where the stroller has to negotiate a forest of security cameras. And County Hall can hardly be said to have come together since 1992, when it was acquired by a Japanese corporation. The recarved and multiply tenanted former seat of the Greater London Council now looks like a corporate squat. Yet it also forms the land-base for the huge wheel of the London Eye, a brilliant innovation that enables the citizen to look down on the Houses of Parliament and assorted ministries of state from a great and belittling height.

From this crowded democratic spot, you can wander past public sculptures and through the soon to be refurbished South Bank Centre, a famously brutalist concrete warren which, despite habitual moaning, has actually been embraced by a richly varied London public. Next comes the National Theatre, and from there it is possible to follow the river through to the massive edifice of Tate Modern, which has been clocking in 3,000 visitors per hour, and the Globe Theatre in Southwark, where tourists jostle with the members of a more indigenous New Elizabethan subculture. With the new Millennium Bridge, this teeming, convivial, and largely car-free stretch of the river is now surely remarkable enough to convince even the most loyal of countrydwellers that the city may be the place to go if you want a really interesting riverside walk.

Just as intolerant rural incomers resent the crowing cocks that wake them up in the morning, people who now live in the converted warehouses near Tower Bridge complain of being disturbed by the amplified warnings directed at motorists and pedestrians whenever the bridge is raised or lowered. Yet these minor irritations only serve to illustrate one of the preconditions of the new Thames: namely that the working river of old is almost completely dead. Indeed, the once industrious Pool of London is now so quiet that David Mellor, who lives in the Harbour Master's house at St Katharine's Dock, can record his Sunday morning Classic FM programme without leaving his house.

That would not have been possible in 1965, when the world watched as Churchill's draped coffin was ceremoniously taken up the London Thames to the accompaniment of a 19-gun salute. In those grainy, black and white days there were still waterside cranes to dip ceremoniously in tribute. Perhaps that was the last great sighting of the London river as a working entity, with its own population, culture and political traditions. Its waters had already been dubbed "liquid history", but the man who coined that phrase, the Scottish Londoner John Burns, was not trying to lure tourists into riverside restaurants. A Liberal activist and politician, he had been among the radical leaders of the first Great Dock Strike of 1889.

By the early 1980s, the London docks had been killed off by containerisation. For years, walking through the old dockland areas was a bleak and lonely business. Yet sharp-eyed property developers were already alchemizing the redundant London river into a lucrative view. It seemed an unlikely ploy to begin with, but you only have to walk down Wapping High Street now to realise that the whole history of the Port of London was just a roundabout way of bringing Manhattan-style loft-living to the Thames.

Anyone interested in contemplating this recent conversion of the river would do well to visit Oxo Tower Wharf, between the London Eye and Tate Modern on the south bank. In the old London this was a meat warehouse dedicated to producing not just Oxo cubes but also the curiously extended tubular eggs that still run through some pork pies. No such item appears on the menu of the restaurant that Harvey Nichols now operate on the top floor.

From this smart and highly successful institution you can look out from your balcony seat and let your eye drift across the river to the City and the great dome of St Paul's. You may feel pretty good about yourself as all that money and tradition come together in your eye, but to look across the river from this new vantage point is to recognise that London has arrived too.

Oxo Tower is by no means the first restaurant to set out to alchemize the dirty old river into a radiant and dreamy prospect. Before it came the BluePrint Café at the Design Museum - which once seemed dangerously downstream at Butler's Wharf - the River Café and the ever more ironically named People's Palace at the Royal Festival Hall. It wasn't that many restaurants ago that an ordinary green pepper seemed like an exotic item in England.

Take the lift downwards and Oxo Tower Wharf turns into a building that proves you don't always have to be a millionaire to live in a riverside loft. There are workshops and several floors of social housing, run by staff who draw a certain satisfaction from telling prosperous inquirers that they earn far too much to be allowed anywhere near the waiting list for a flat. Oxo Tower Wharf is part of the Coin Street development, and the story of its conversion reveals something of the cost of reconfiguring the Thames as a view.

It was in the early 80s that the Coin Street Action Group fought off the developers, who planned to demolish Oxo Tower Wharf and other industrial buildings in the area and replace them with a 20-storey office block designed by Richard Rogers, at that time known as The Cossack of Coin Street rather than Lord Rogers of Riverside. As had happened earlier at Covent Garden, the site was saved by local community action. Eventually assisted by the GLC, the residents, threatened with displacement, acquired the various industrial properties and set about building low-cost housing. They also opened access to a stretch of the riverfront that had been closed for some two centuries. Writing in the New Statesman, the architecture critic Jules Lubbock commended the Coin Street Action Group for opening a new view across the river to St Paul's, the cathedral that had been the "very symbol of the British people in the face of Nazism" but which had since been "shamefully mutilated" by post-war developers.

At that time Lubbock was among Prince Charles's architectural advisers, and a few weeks later, that same argument about St Paul's turned up in Prince Charles's Mansion House speech, in which the traditional look of St Paul's cathedral was used to redeclare the memory of the second world war against the peace that had followed it. Prince Charles chose to launch his revivalist "Vision of Britain" with the help of Turner's view of St Paul's, looking up the Thames from Greenwich, and also Canaletto's earlier downriver view from the terrace of Somerset House. By the time Charles and his advisers had finished with the dome of St Paul's, the whole question of the city and its future was lost in a barren argument about architectural styles, with modernism being bad and undue praise falling on classical revivalism.

To look out from Oxo Tower Wharf now is to realise how far we've have come since that chaotic, largely ghost-written argument. St Paul's looks fine, and the architects have recovered too. The same cannot be said for the tradition of state-led social reform, which got written off as so many infernal council tower blocks. As for the "public access" that is now routinely demanded in riverside planning, that has already come to mean considerably more than the right to squeeze past private residential fortresses and their security systems. The south bank especially has become a new public amenity, which is already changing the feel of London: it's an energetically mixed-up place, where Londoners encounter one another in their flamboyant post-colonial diversity while tourists from more monocultural places boggle enviously at the result.

Meanwhile, the river itself is becoming something more than just a moneyed view. Mark Rylance, the artistic director at the Globe Theatre, describes it as both sinister and inspiring, a brown deity that brings nature and myth into the midst of an over-controlled city. The London Rivers Association has also been working to intensify the meaning of the resurgent and successfully cleaned-up river, insisting that it should be seen as an "ecological super-highway" and "reservoir of memory", and disconcerting some architects by describing it as a potential "blue-belt" and nature reserve.

As ever, the money will look after itself. But Ken Livingstone is plainly the man to take the public aspect of the new river further. As the figure responsible for "promoting the wellbeing of London and Londoners", the new mayor doesn't have to confine his attention entirely to London's irksome transport problems. His real job is to be the patron of London's new public domain, and the river should be among his focal points.

It can be assumed that Livingstone will do everything he can to establish that cosmopolitanism is one of the great qualities of London's people rather than just its most exotic cuisine. Since wandering about, whether in a spirit of curiosity or of mutual exhibitionism, is to play such a considerable part in new London life, he should preside over a general increase in public litter bins - early casualties of the IRA, who seem to have provided every cost-cutting bureaucrat in the country with the excuse to get rid of them. He might also encourage the return of herbaceous borders: traditional but labour-intensive features of municipal parks that were among the first victims of council job cuts in the 80s.

If further measures are needed to dispel any hint of smugness that may already be arising in this perfect new metropolitan world, Livingstone might consider reviving an ancient river custom that was unaccountably missing from the watery scenes of Shakespeare in Love. In the days when watermen propelled wherries and other such floating taxis up and down the London river, their passengers used to enjoy hurling insults at one another. Samuel Johnson was proud of the killer line with which he put an end to one such virtuoso contest: "Sir, your wife, under pretence of keeping a bawdy house, is a receiver of stolen goods." That particular example would only cause perplexity if called out from the wind-buffeted Millennium Bridge today, but more appropriate versions would surely be forthcoming with a little encouragement.

Battersea Power Station

Design Museum

County Hall/London Aquarium

Canary Wharf

London Eye

Millennium Dome

South Bank Centre

Somerset House

Oxo Tower Wharf/Coin Street

Tate Modern

To look out from Oxo Tower Wharf now is to realise how far we've have come since that chaotic, largely ghost-written argument. St Paul's looks fine, and the architects have recovered too. The same cannot be said for the tradition of state-led social reform, which got written off as so many infernal council tower blocks. As for the "public access" that is now routinely demanded in riverside planning, that has already come to mean considerably more than the right to squeeze past private residential fortresses and their security systems. The south bank especially has become a new public amenity, which is already changing the feel of London: it's an energetically mixed-up place, where Londoners encounter one another in their flamboyant post-colonial diversity while tourists from more monocultural places boggle enviously at the result. Meanwhile, the river itself is becoming something more than just a moneyed view. Mark Rylance, the artistic director at the Globe Theatre, describes it as both sinister and inspiring, a brown deity that brings nature and myth into the midst of an over-controlled city. The London Rivers Association has also been working to intensify the meaning of the resurgent and successfully cleaned-up river, insisting that it should be seen as an "ecological super-highway" and "reservoir of memory", and disconcerting some architects by describing it as a potential "blue-belt" and nature reserve. As ever, the money will look after itself. But Ken Livingstone is plainly the man to take the public aspect of the new river further. As the figure responsible for "promoting the wellbeing of London and Londoners", the new mayor doesn't have to confine his attention entirely to London's irksome transport problems. His real job is to be the patron of London's new public domain, and the river should be among his focal points. It can be assumed that Livingstone will do everything he can to establish that cosmopolitanism is one of the great qualities of London's people rather than just its most exotic cuisine. Since wandering about, whether in a spirit of curiosity or of mutual exhibitionism, is to play such a considerable part in new London life, he should preside over a general increase in public litter bins - early casualties of the IRA, who seem to have provided every cost-cutting bureaucrat in the country with the excuse to get rid of them. He might also encourage the return of herbaceous borders: traditional but labour-intensive features of municipal parks that were among the first victims of council job cuts in the 80s. If further measures are needed to dispel any hint of smugness that may already be arising in this perfect new metropolitan world, Livingstone might consider reviving an ancient river custom that was unaccountably missing from the watery scenes of Shakespeare in Love. In the days when watermen propelled wherries and other such floating taxis up and down the London river, their passengers used to enjoy hurling insults at one another. Samuel Johnson was proud of the killer line with which he put an end to one such virtuoso contest: "Sir, your wife, under pretence of keeping a bawdy house, is a receiver of stolen goods." That particular example would only cause perplexity if called out from the wind-buffeted Millennium Bridge today, but more appropriate versions would surely be forthcoming with a little encouragement. webTitle: Fine foundation for a nest-egg stock

fields.headline: Fine foundation for a nest-egg stock
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A quick glance at trading screens yesterday indicated that the flotation of Prudential's internet bank, Egg, had proved a success. Here was a big new issue calmly joining a volatile and unpredictable market.
fields.body:
A quick glance at trading screens yesterday indicated that the flotation of Prudential's internet bank, Egg, had proved a success. Here was a big new issue calmly joining a volatile and unpredictable market.

At 160p, capitalising this 21-month-old company at £1.3bn, the issue was priced towards the top end of Goldman Sachs' pre-float pricing range. And by the close of play yesterday, the stock was sitting at 177.5p.

This modest but respectable first-day premium had been achieved in a market that has gone from a delirious love-in with all forms of dot.commery to one where pundits routinely speculate when so-and-so internet start-up will run out of money.

Goldman, as book runner, established good retail and institutional demand for the stock, but at the same time avoided the screaming first-day premium syndrome which, for example, infected Lastminute.com.

But the new market in Egg was calm to the point of being unnatural. The price spent the entire day within a narrow band of 165p-185p and yet 84m shares changed hands - more than half the shares now in free hands.

Now, in modern flotations, investment banks use a thing called a "green shoe" to help ensure things go smoothly during the early days of a new issue. This involves the bank (Goldman) having an artificial "short" position in the new stock (amounting to 3m shares, in Egg's case), which allows it to go out and mop up short-term sellers without being out of pocket. But there is no indication that it has yet had to use this mechanism.

Instead, Goldman was aggressively buying up every loose piece of Egg paper whenever the price touched 165p, presumably on behalf of institutional clients. It was giving a strong signal to the market that it will support this issue - exactly the sort of support which its rival, Morgan Stanley failed to provide when the latter botched the flotation of Lastminute.com.

Whatever the discounted cash flow or market capitalisation per customer, valuation models suggest, assessing the longer-term viability of a business like Egg and deciding whether there is a fundamental investment case for buying the shares is as much a gut feeling thing as anything else.

Yes, Egg is haemorrhaging cash. Yes, all its customers may leave when the bank moves to commercial interest rates for borrowers and savers. Yes, branch bank managers, sitting behind leather-topped desks, might crash back into fashion.

But, in short order, Egg has established itself as a premium online financial brand. The challenge now is to get its service reputation up and stop its computers going down. If it can meet this, the shares are probably a snip at current levels.

webTitle: After the dome and the wheel, millennium bug strikes again as bridge is suspended

fields.headline: After the dome and the wheel, millennium bug strikes again as bridge is suspended
fields.trailText: London's £18.2m Millennium Bridge closed last night for engineering tests that will probably last weeks, a victim of its own overwhelming popularity.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
London's £18.2m Millennium Bridge closed last night for engineering tests that will probably last weeks, a victim of its own overwhelming popularity.

The engineers Ove Arup and the Millennium Bridge Trust, although confident that the footbridge is safe, took the decision to close it after another day in which thrilled and terrified crowds reported bouncing, swaying and rippling movements in the "blade of light" across the Thames.

Barriers went up on Sunday as crowds flocked, eager to try what had been dubbed "the bouncing bridge" and billed as London's latest white-knuckle ride. Yesterday people were queueing for more than half an hour for a chance to make the two-minute crossing of the 320-metre aluminium and steel bridge. Only 60 people were allowed across at a time. An estimated 150,000 people had crossed on the first day, 15 times the number expected. The closure of the bridge follows the difficulties of the Millennium Dome and the failure of the London Eye ferris wheel to open in time after technical problems.

Lord Foster, joint designer of the bridge with the sculptor Sir Antony Caro and Ove Arup, delicately disowned responsibility for the problem. "Although the issues are engineering-led, we are fully supportive of Arup who are undertaking their investigation into the events of last weekend," he said.

"Until they have reported to the client, we are not in a position to comment further. Everyone is working together to resolve the problems."

Earlier he had described the future of the bridge as "an act of faith in engineering". He predicted confidently that the problem would be solved. "There's going to be a point when everyone will look back on this as a hiccup."

The closure is a severe embarassment to the Millennium Bridge Trust. The Queen formally opened the bridge last month when it was only partly completed.

David Bell, chairman of the trust, issued a statement apologising to people who might have felt "unease" crossing the bridge. "The current problem, which involves excessive movement on the bridge in certain conditions, is something we will overcome," he said. "We are in discussions with the engineers to find out the exact cause of the problem. It is something we will put right."

The Ove Arup engineer Tony Fitzpatrick said there was no question of the bridge being dangerous. "The bridge is never going to fall down. No bits are going to come off it. But there is a movement that is very uncomfortable."

After tests over the weekend Ove Arup decided yesterday to close the bridge for comprehensive tests to determine how much of the movement is a real problem - all suspension bridges must flex slightly - and how to solve it. The spokesman said the answer might be to use dampers, similar to shock absorbers.

The problems of vibration in bridges, created by large crowds marching in step, has been well known for centuries. The iron Albert Bridge on the Thames, like several other Victorian bridges around the country, still has a small notice commanding "All Ranks Break Step" dating from the days of soldiers marching across.

Denis Smith, past president of the civil engineering Newcomen Society and an expert on the history of bridge design, said civil engineers had been wrestling for centuries with the twin problems of strength and stiffness. The most notorious example was a 19th-century railway bridge over the Tees designed by Samuel Brown. "When they drove a locomotive across it, it started a ripple that ran on through the bridge ahead of the locomotive, until it was running uphill with the side rails rearing up two metres in front of it."

fields.headline: Granada chief's £10m merger bonus
fields.trailText: Granada chairman Gerry Robinson will bank £10.6m on completion of the company's merger with Compass Hospitality, it emerged yesterday, and will enjoy an additional £1m consultancy fee a year for the next three years.
fields.body:
Granada chairman Gerry Robinson will bank £10.6m on completion of the company's merger with Compass Hospitality, it emerged yesterday, and will enjoy an additional £1m consultancy fee a year for the next three years.

The details of Mr Robinson's retirement stipend were carried in the shares prospectus for the newly merged group.

Under the merger's terms share options granted to all Granada directors will turn into cash when the deal goes through.

Charles Allen, the 43-year-old Granada chief executive, will see his options realised with a value of around £8.1m.

The Granada-Compass deal has been agreed ahead of the demerger of Granada's media business later this year into a separately quoted company.

Mr Robsinon, who is 51, will continue to receive his £1m a year salary from the hospitality rump group until his retirement at 55.

A company insider said it was difficult to say how many days a week he might be working as a consultant. "It's not about how long you spend at the crease, it is about how many runs you score," he said.

The re-engineering has been driven by Granada's ambition to play a part in the forthcoming tussle for control of ITV, and gives the media division clearer currency in the form of separately listed shares.

Directors joining the media division will be expected to buy shares in the business as a demonstration of their commitment to the company. They will reinvest between 100% and 300% of their basic salary.

Sources close to the group said Mr Allen would plough a large part of money made on his options back into the separately listed media business.

Further free shares and options matching the individual's investment in the new company will be granted at the discretion of the remuneration committee.

Granada directors joining the media business will be given two-year contracts.

The £17.5bn agreement announced last month initially met with a hostile reception from the City but shares in both firms have crept back up.

Compass directors will not see their options packages realised but instead converted to Granada-Compass shares.

Compass directors, how ever, will also be awarded an unspecified amount of free shares and options as part of the deal.

A spokesman for the two firms said: "Both Compass and Granada are setting up share commitment plans that are appropriate to their business environments.

"The message to shareholders is clear. Executives are aligning their interests with the future success of Compass-Granada Hospitality and Granada Media."

Around 20% of Granada Media will be floated on the stock market by the middle of next month, placing a value on the company of between £6bn and £7bn.

Mr Allen will be executive chair of Granada Media while the Compass boss, Francis Mackay, will run the hospitality company.

The deal satisfied the ambitions of Mr Robinson, who had long suggested that he hoped to do one more significant deal before retiring.

Granada was caught flatfooted by plans of its two rival ITV groups, United News & Media and Carlton Communications, to merge and has said it is minded to bid for one or the other.

The competition commission is expected to make its submission to the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, some time later this week.

The share prospectus also disclosed that the deal has earned the investment bank, Lazards, around £55m.

webTitle: Smith warns C5 over nude shows

fields.headline: Smith warns C5 over nude shows
fields.trailText: Channel 5 has been warned by the government to clean up its act after viewers were outraged by the growing levels of sex and nudity in its programmes.
fields.body:
Channel 5 has been warned by the government to clean up its act after viewers were outraged by the growing levels of sex and nudity in its programmes.

The culture secretary, Chris Smith, said that broadcasters had a commercial and moral duty to take account of the views of the public over the content and quality of televi sion - and he urged them to do so.

He told MPs at Commons question time: "We have noted in recent days very considerable concern about some of the content on television, particularly in relation to Channel 5."

The move came as pressure grows for the Independent Television Commission to crack down on programmes such as Naked Jungle, the game show in which host Keith Chegwin and contestants participated naked.

A former ITC chairman, Sir George Russell, said the channel would never have won its licence if it had hinted that it intended to show such programmes.

Mr Smith's comments followed press criticism of Naked Jungle, one of several programmes screened to mark the anniversary of British naturism.

Channel 5 originally won its licence by promising the ITC a mix of "high quality drama, entertainment, news and factual programmes" with an "emphasis on learning and leisure". But two years ago, late night erotica started to creep in and in March last year, the ITC issued a report condemning the station for its preoccupation with nudity and sex, particularly for its Sex and Shopping series.

webTitle: Jubilee Line celebrates after troubled start

fields.headline: Jubilee Line celebrates after troubled start
fields.standfirst: Royal Fine Art Commission chief takes personal swipe at dome and London Eye but congratulates 'enduring monument to millennium'
fields.trailText: It cost seven times more than the dome, was finished a year and a half late, and its teething problems have driven thousands of commuters round the twist. But all was forgiven yesterday when the sleek Jubilee Line extension won the title of millennium building of the year.
fields.body:
It cost seven times more than the dome, was finished a year and a half late, and its teething problems have driven thousands of commuters round the twist. But all was forgiven yesterday when the sleek Jubilee Line extension won the title of millennium building of the year.

While the poor dome flattered to deceive, the judges pointedly went for a "useful construction" they said will be enjoyed by Londoners for generations to come.

"It has brought the highest standards of architecture to the public transport services of London," said Lord St John of Fawsley, chairman of the Royal Fine Art Commission Trust. "At last we have something worthy of the millennium as opposed to the somewhat second rate controversial contributions we have had to put up with until now."

The flamboyant former Tory minister, who chaired the judges, could not resist another dig at the millennium wheel, which he loathes. "The London Transport Executive is to be congratulated on commemorating the millennium in such a brilliant and socially useful way, which will be an enduring monument to the millennium as opposed to follies like the millennium wheel, which I hope will be moved to a more suitable site at the earliest possible moment."

The win is a personal triumph for its Anglo-Italian architect Roland Paoletti, who has dedicated a large chunk of his life to a £3.5bn project so byzantine and troublesome it might have killed lesser men.

He commissioned different architects to create each of the 11 stations from Westminster to Stratford, east London. The spectacular Will Alsop designed station at North Greenwich, which serves the dome, and those at Southwark and Canary Wharf (Norman Foster) came in for special praise. For many however, Westminster station is the most beautiful.

The Royal Opera House restoration and the dome - as well as its mind zone - were among those shortlisted. They may have better luck in the £20,000 Stirling prize, the main architecture award organised by the Royal Institute of British Architects which also published its long list of 50 buildings yesterday.

All the buildings, which included the much-praised Walsall art gallery in the West Midlands and the great greenhouse of the National Botanic Gardens of Wales, will get Riba awards. The new Tate Modern did not qualify because it was not finished before the April 1 deadline.

The list includes other obvious contenders such as the London Eye, the Royal Opera House, two of the Jubilee Line extension stations, the dome, and the restored Royal Court theatre.

Not all of the nominees are on a monumental scale. Telford crematorium is said to stand a good outside chance while a new "green' Sainsbury's store in Greenwich is a stronger contender in the environmentally friendly section. The winners will be announced on November 4.

A girl guides' building in south London and a stainless steel shelter for walkers in Northumberland described as "little gems" by Riba president Marco Goldschmied will be competing for the Stephen Lawrence prize - named after the murdered black teenager who was training to be an architect - which celebrates smaller projects.

 A 35-member Metropolitan police squad based around the dome is being redeployed due to lower than expected visitor numbers. "The anticipated increase in traffic, crime and public disorder has not materialised," a spokesman said.

The win is a personal triumph for its Anglo-Italian architect Roland Paoletti, who has dedicated a large chunk of his life to a £3.5bn project so byzantine and troublesome it might have killed lesser men. Not all of the nominees are on a monumental scale. Telford crematorium is said to stand a good outside chance while a new "green' Sainsbury's store in Greenwich is a stronger contender in the environmentally friendly section. The winners will be announced on November 4. A girl guides' building in south London and a stainless steel shelter for walkers in Northumberland described as "little gems" by Riba president Marco Goldschmied will be competing for the Stephen Lawrence prize - named after the murdered black teenager who was training to be an architect - which celebrates smaller projects.  A 35-member Metropolitan police squad based around the dome is being redeployed due to lower than expected visitor numbers. "The anticipated increase in traffic, crime and public disorder has not materialised," a spokesman said. webTitle: Gallaghers' row makes Oasis look like a mirage

fields.headline: Gallaghers' row makes Oasis look like a mirage
fields.trailText: The future of Oasis looked increasingly shaky last night after Noel Gallagher claimed his brother Liam was "losing it".
fields.body:
The future of Oasis looked increasingly shaky last night after Noel Gallagher claimed his brother Liam was "losing it".

Speaking about his departure from the band's world tour, guitarist Noel said relations with his lead singer brother had reached such a low ebb he could no longer stand to be in the same room.

"What's going on is that I've had a major disagreement with monkey boy, the singer," Noel said.

Speaking on Chris Moyles's Radio 1 show, Noel, who quit the overseas dates last month, said it was a "major disagreement" but refused to go into details.

His outburst followed an interview with Liam in yesterday's Sun newspaper, where he branded Noel a "loser" for wanting to go solo, saying it would destroy the band.

But last night Noel hit back, saying: "It's me that's kept the band together for six, seven years. It's not something that I've done lightly, but it's just been made impossible for me to let alone be on the same stage, but be in the same room as him."

Noel is to rejoin the band for their British shows next month, but performed solo numbers during the Radio 1 broadcast from Eindhoven.

"It's been virtually impossible for me to tour at the moment because he's been a bit of an idiot," he said. "I'll be doing the British dates and then we've all got to have a chat, but at the moment he's losing it."

webTitle: BBC must reinvent itself, says Dyke aide

fields.headline: BBC must reinvent itself, says Dyke aide
fields.standfirst:
Ratings-driven BBC1 advocated in complete overhaul of output

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: One of Greg Dyke's most senior lieutenants last night published a vision for a complete overhaul of the corporation's television channels, proposing the relaunch of BBC1 as a ratings-driven entertainment channel with more serious programmes airing on other networks.
fields.body:
One of Greg Dyke's most senior lieutenants last night published a vision for a complete overhaul of the corporation's television channels, proposing the relaunch of BBC1 as a ratings-driven entertainment channel with more serious programmes airing on other networks.

Mark Thompson, who was appointed earlier this year as director of television by Mr Dyke, the BBC's director general, risked accusations of "dumbing down" by saying that the corporation had to reinvent itself to survive the digital television age.

The presnt "mixed schedule" channels such as BBC1 and BBC2 should be transformed into "genre-based" networks, and a review was already under way.

"There can be no sacred cows," said Mr Thompson.

It is understood that, under the plans being drawn up for Mr Dyke, BBC1 would become a general entertainment channel, while BBC2 would air more demanding shows for discerning viewers.

A new BBC3 would show comedy and edgier entertainment, in competition with Channel 4, while a fourth channel would be devoted to "serious music and the arts, and to the world of ideas, in science, politics and philosophy," Mr Thompson said. The process must start soon, he urged.

The BBC is already actively considering a move for its main evening news bulletin from 9pm to 10pm.

The plan, which is supported by presenters Peter Sissons and Michael Burke, and by the BBC1 controller Peter Salmon, would free the peak time schedule for popular entertainment and drama - a key battleground in the audience war with ITV.

BBC2 has promoted "theme nights" such as the History Zone which have proved popular with viewers.

Such moves are a response to research which shows that in digital satellite homes, ratings for the traditional channels are plummeting.

Electronic programme guides enable viewers to seek out easily the programmes they want to watch among the plethora of available channels, and channel loyalty has all but disappeared.

Many at the BBC believe that by creating genre-based channels instead of the mixed schedules of BBC1 and BBC2, viewers will know where to come for the kinds of programmes they enjoy.

Already, specialist channels such as Discovery, National Geographic and the Cartoon Network, are building up considerable followings among viewers.

Speaking at a Canadian television festival in Banff last night, Mr Thompson said that it was important for BBC1 and 2 to be able to cover big cultural events.

But broad-spectrum channels inevitably led to compromises in, for example, the range of arts documentaries and the coverage of classical concerts.

New "genre-based" channels would give the BBC an opportunity to show far more of those sorts of programmes and would extend, rather than dilute, the BBC's public service remit.

"The object is to create a suite of channels which will live up to the ideals the BBC was created to promote."

Mr Thompson, who knows his plans will meet with opposition from within the BBC as well as outside, said that public service television had to change radically to remain relevant and viable.

"I don't think it would be right or possible to move overnight from our traditional mixed schedules into fully genre-based channels, but I believe that unless we start the journey soon, we risk becoming irrelevant."

He said that the recent seven year licence fee settlement gives the BBC a chance to put more money into key areas such as education, BBC1 and the new digital channels.

"This investment is a unique chance - probably the last chance - for the BBC to reinvent itself and prepare its services for the digital future. If we disappoint the public we will not be forgiven."

One senior BBC executive said last night that the plans represented the only way by which the corporation could survive.

He said: "Since Greg Dyke arrived, there has been this new atmosphere that we can think the unthinkable, and this is just what Mark is doing."

There would be opposition, but the executive added: "The prospect of more money inevitably makes this process easier."

 The BBC last night underlined its determination to be at the heart of the classroom of the future by announcing plans to double its spending on developing online digital education material in a multi-million pound investment programme.

Mr Dyke revealed in a keynote speech that the BBC's spending on the sector would increase from nearly £10m this year to £20m next year - virtually all of it at this stage going on creating an online GCSE curriculum for free use by all schools.

The idea is that "digital desktops" using interactive material will be up and running in schools within three to five years.

fields.headline: Cancer fears after blunders
fields.trailText: Cancer tests on more than 10,000 patients carried out by a single specialist are being reviewed after more than 200 patients were found to have been wrongly diagnosed.
fields.body:
Cancer tests on more than 10,000 patients carried out by a single specialist are being reviewed after more than 200 patients were found to have been wrongly diagnosed.

The tests were carried out by a 78-year-old pathologist named by the BBC Newsnight programme as Dr James Elwood. He was employed by the NHS as a locum for several years until last year.

Most of the tests were carried out at the Princess Margaret hospital in Swindon, Wiltshire. One woman reportedly had a breast removed unnecessarily. The review found that among the 200 patients, some were told they had cancer when they did not and others were given the all clear when they had cancer.

The government is expected to announce an inquiry today and the setting up of an early warning system to spot medical errors at an earlier stage.

Dr Elwood also worked at the Mid Sussex hospital, Frimley Park hospital in Surrey, and the Royal United hospital in Bath.

He removed himself from the medical register 10 months ago when the General Medical Council became aware of the problem. The move means he will not face any disciplinary action or an inquiry.

Sonia Mills, chief executive of the Princess Margaret hospital, which is part of the Swindon and Marlborough NHS Trust, said: "We are deeply sorry. Out of the 7,000 slides we have examined, a very small number have had serious consequences... There are 215 other patients we have contacted for whom the consequences are less serious but for them as individuals it is extremely worrying and as a trust we deeply regret that situation."

The Department of Health would not reveal how many patients were affected but said the review would show the locum had carried out "incorrect" diagnoses. The histologist was employed by the four trusts on a temporary basis between July 1994 and July 1999.

Last night Rosalind Clarkson, who was told her breast cancer had been cured, said she was told a week ago that Dr Elwood had made a mistake. "I felt completely numb really. I was in total shock. Now it's all come back and it's very painful."

As a locum, Dr Elwood used to fill in when full-time staff were on holiday and his work was not routinely checked.

Unions representing hospital workers blamed errors on under-staffing and the use of under-qualified staff.

Becky Miles, of the National Cancer Alliance, said: "We have been shouting about the shortage of nurses, oncologists, special surgeons, pathologists and radiologists for five years now, and it takes five years to train them.

"We cannot underestimate the impact on a personal level it has on patients and their families."

The shadow health secretary, Dr Liam Fox, told Newsnight that the GMC should be given the power to investigate former doctors such as Dr Elwood who are no longer on the medical register.
