fields.headline: Hunting - the wider social context
fields.standfirst:
The report: Long-term effects of a ban on estimated 6,000-8,000 full-time jobs likely to be offset as rural economy adjusts

The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Edited extracts from the Burns report into hunting with dogs in England and Wales.
fields.body:
Edited extracts from the Burns report into hunting with dogs in England and Wales.

Committee members: Lord Burns (chairman), Victoria Edwards, Sir John Marsh, Lord Soulsby, Michael Winter.

The committee was appointed to inquire into:

 The practical aspects of different types of hunting with dogs and its impact on the rural economy, agriculture and pest control, the social and cultural life of the countryside, the management and conservation of wildlife, and animal welfare in particular areas of England and Wales;

 The consequences of these issues of any ban on hunting with dogs;

 How any ban might be implemented.

The committee was not asked to recommend whether hunting should be banned nor to consider moral or ethical issues.

Main points

Between 6,000 and 8,000 jobs depend on hunting. Not possible to give precise figure for job losses in event of a ban

Hunting and killing of foxes above ground "seriously compromises welfare" of foxes

Hunting a "significant cohesive force" in some isolated rural areas

Independently appointed monitors of hunts taking video/photographic evidence proposed in absence of full ban

Hunting

There are about 200 registered packs of hounds in England and Wales which hunt foxes. The packs are estimated to kill 21,000-25,000 foxes a year.

There are three registered staghound packs in the Devon and Somerset area [which] kill about 160 red deer a year in total ... 15% of the number required to be culled to maintain a stable population.

There are about 100 registered packs of hounds which hunt hares. They kill about 1,650 hares a season, a very small percentage of the number killed by shooting.

There are some 24 registered hare coursing clubs which kill about 250 hares a year; the 20 minkhound packs kill somewhere between 400-1,400 mink a season, considerably less than are killed by trapping and shooting.

Hunting and the rural economy

Hunting needs to be seen in a wider economic and social context. There is a complex set of relationships and economic activities that serve hunting or are dependent on it.

Jobs

We estimate that 6,000-8,000 full-time jobs depend on hunting, although the number of people involved may be significantly higher. About 700 jobs result from direct employment by hunts. Between 1,500-3,000 full-time equivalent jobs (involving 2,500-5,000 people) result from employment on hunting-related activities.

It is not possible to give a precise figure for the number of jobs which would be lost. In terms of national employment statistics the short term loss would be limited. In the medium term, three-five years, losses would arise in the wider rural economy, particularly the horse economy. In the long term, seven-10 years, most effects would be offset as the rural economy adjusted.

Some of those affected have specialised skills and they would find it hard to find alternative employment. For a small number of local communities the effects could be more serious.

Social and cultural aspects

For a significant minority, notably hunt participants and farmers in more isolated rural communities, the hunt plays a dominant role.

Even those who do not feel greatly the loss of the hunt's social activities consider that it would have a detrimental effect on community in general. A number feel it would mean the end of an important living, cultural tradition.

It is clear that, especially in isolated communities, hunting acts as a significant cohesive force. Farmers and landowners ... would resent what they would see as an unnecessary and ill-informed interference.

For another group the hunt itself seems divisive, intrusive and disruptive.

Population management and control

Foxes: Landowners and gamekeepers consider it necessary to manage fox populations in view of the damage to farming and game management.

Methods involving guns probably account for the greater part of foxes killed. In lowland areas hunting makes only a minor contribution ... terrier work may be more important. In upland areas there are fewer alternatives to the use of dogs.

Deer: There are 4,000-6,000 red deer in Devon and Somerset ... 1,000 need to be culled annually for a stable population.

Hares: There are about 630,000 brown hares in England and Wales. About 1,650 are killed by packs. Hare hunting and coursing are essentially carried out for recreational purposes and have a small direct impact on numbers.

Mink: There are an estimated 18,000 mink in England and Wales. Because of fecundicity and high level of dispersal hunting does not have any significant effect on the mink population.

Animal welfare

The issues of cruelty and animal welfare are central to the debate about hunting. Animal welfare is concerned with assessing the ability of an animal to cope with its environment. This judgment is distinct from any ethical or moral judgments.

Deer: Most scientists agree that deer are likely to suffer in the final stages of hunting. The available evidence does not enable us to resolve at what point in the hunt the welfare of the deer becomes seriously compromised. Stalking ... is in principle the better method of culling deer from an animal welfare perspective.

Foxes: There are three main aspects of foxhunting that effect welfare: the chase; the kill by hounds above ground; and digging out /terrier work.

In the case of killing, death is not always effected by a single bite to the neck by the lead hound. In a proportion of cases it results from massive injuries to the chest and vital organs. There is a lack of firm scientific evidence on the welfare of a fox pursued, caught and killed above ground by hounds. We are satisfied that this experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox.

We are satisifed that the activity of digging out and shooting a fox involves a serious compromise of its welfare.

Drag and bloodhound hunting

It is unlikely that drag and bloodhound hunting or drag coursing would mitigate any adverse effects on the rural economy or the social life of the countryside arising from a ban on hunting.

Practical aspects of hunting: the concerns

Trespass: There are too many cases of trespass, disruption and disturbance [that] can cause distress.

Openness: In the absence of a ban, organised hunting should be conducted on a more open basis than at present. One option would be the appointment of individuals as independent monitors who would have the freedom to take photographs and video evidence.

Digging out/terrier work: In the absence of a ban serious consideration could be given as to whether this practice should be allowed to continue.

Artificial earths: In the absence of a ban hunts could be required or encouraged to end this practice.

Implementing a ban

Legislation to ban hunting might be open to challenge under article 1 of Protocol (property rights) and article 8 (respect for private life) of the European convention on human rights. An important point would be whether legislators could point to unnecessary suffering or some other point beyond mere disapproval.

Unless there was a good reason on objective grounds, we do not think it would be satisfactory to have different legislative provisions in different regions.

It would be possible to implement a ban quickly. There are stronger arguments for allowing a reasonable period of adjustment. This would enable more time ... to mitigate social and economic consequences.

Because of fecundicity and high level of dispersal hunting does not have any significant effect on the mink population. Animal welfare The issues of cruelty and animal welfare are central to the debate about hunting. Animal welfare is concerned with assessing the ability of an animal to cope with its environment. This judgment is distinct from any ethical or moral judgments. Deer: Most scientists agree that deer are likely to suffer in the final stages of hunting. The available evidence does not enable us to resolve at what point in the hunt the welfare of the deer becomes seriously compromised. Stalking ... is in principle the better method of culling deer from an animal welfare perspective. Foxes: There are three main aspects of foxhunting that effect welfare: the chase; the kill by hounds above ground; and digging out /terrier work. In the case of killing, death is not always effected by a single bite to the neck by the lead hound. In a proportion of cases it results from massive injuries to the chest and vital organs. There is a lack of firm scientific evidence on the welfare of a fox pursued, caught and killed above ground by hounds. We are satisfied that this experience seriously compromises the welfare of the fox. We are satisifed that the activity of digging out and shooting a fox involves a serious compromise of its welfare. Drag and bloodhound hunting It is unlikely that drag and bloodhound hunting or drag coursing would mitigate any adverse effects on the rural economy or the social life of the countryside arising from a ban on hunting. Practical aspects of hunting: the concerns Trespass: There are too many cases of trespass, disruption and disturbance [that] can cause distress. Openness: In the absence of a ban, organised hunting should be conducted on a more open basis than at present. One option would be the appointment of individuals as independent monitors who would have the freedom to take photographs and video evidence. Digging out/terrier work: In the absence of a ban serious consideration could be given as to whether this practice should be allowed to continue. Artificial earths: In the absence of a ban hunts could be required or encouraged to end this practice. Implementing a ban Legislation to ban hunting might be open to challenge under article 1 of Protocol (property rights) and article 8 (respect for private life) of the European convention on human rights. An important point would be whether legislators could point to unnecessary suffering or some other point beyond mere disapproval. Unless there was a good reason on objective grounds, we do not think it would be satisfactory to have different legislative provisions in different regions. It would be possible to implement a ban quickly. There are stronger arguments for allowing a reasonable period of adjustment. This would enable more time ... to mitigate social and economic consequences. Useful links Burns inquiry homepage Countryside Alliance League Against Cruel Sports

fields.headline: Another Birt appointee quits BBC
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday lost another of Sir John Birt's former apparatchiks when Patricia Hodgson, director of public policy, accepted the job of chief executive at the Independent Television Commission.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday lost another of Sir John Birt's former apparatchiks when Patricia Hodgson, director of public policy, accepted the job of chief executive at the Independent Television Commission.

Mrs Hodgson, who had been on the main board of the BBC for seven years, was viewed as a strong contender for the corporation's top job before it went to the present director general, Greg Dyke. She led the campaign for charter renewal in 1996 and the negotiations for the current licence fee settlement which resulted in an above inflation increase.

Her departure had been widely anticipated after Mr Dyke's restructuring of the BBC left her with fewer responsibilities.

She follows former director of corporate affairs Colin Browne out the door while Sue Farr, former director of marketing, has also resigned in the wake of restructuring.

Mrs Hodgson said: "Leaving the BBC will not be easy; but the post of chief executive at the ITC is extremely attractive. It will give me the opportunity of playing a broader role - taking commercial broadcasting into the digital age - which I will relish."

Her appointment at the ITC, which regulates commercial television, was viewed as a coup ahead of the upcoming communications white paper. There is a powerful lobby to create a single regulator covering broadcasting and telecommunications and Mrs Hodgson will be expected to use her government contacts to argue for the ITC's pre-eminance. The job carries a £200,000 salary.

Her appointment will also be welcomed by the ITV companies which are trying to force through further consolidation in the industry. Mrs Hodgson is understood to favour less stringent regulation. She replaces Peter Rogers who will retire in September.

Mr Dyke said: "Patricia has done a fantastic job for the BBC over many years. She is the ideal person to think through how the commercial sector should be regulated in the digital age."

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.body:
Gulf News
Hafez al-Assad has passed away leaving Syria in as strong a position as it ever has been... His firm negotiating with Israel and the United States has meant that Syria has not been led down the dangerous path of making an agreement with Israel which leaves loose ends.

Yedioth Ahronoth (Israel)
In the age of political correctness, we must "understand the sorrow of the Syrian people" and even "participate in their profound grief". Leaders and governments - even those of the enemy - must choose their words. To be careful to honour the dead. To pretend to be respectful.

We don't have to be like that, so therefore let us say that we are not too sorry over Assad's death, and deep in our hearts - despite the enjoinment "Do not rejoice over your enemy's downfall" - we are even a bit happy. From the Israeli point of view, he was a bitter enemy.

Ha'aretz (Israel)
If the change of government in Syria indeed offers a new opportunity for peace, it should be exploited as early as possible.

Iran News
The question after his passing is whether or not his son and heir, Bashar, will be able to fulfil Assad's fondest wish of liberating all the Syrian territory occupied by the Zionist entity.

Jordan Times
Hafez al-Assad's successor will inherit a country with the diseases that are almost typical in this region: corruption, a struggling economy in need of modernisation and liberalisation, and the challenges of democratisation lying ahead.

Al-Thawra, Syria
Great leaders do not die and the great do not die. They are eternal. Such great symbols do not die but are a part of a nation's memory and a part of its people's history... Peace on you, oh great leader.

fields.headline: Hunters at bay
fields.standfirst:
We thought the Burns inquiry might save us. Instead, it is a nightmare come true

Special report on hunting
fields.trailText: We thought the Burns inquiry might save us. Instead, it is a nightmare come true
fields.body:
I hate people telephoning in the evenings. However, there is no peace for the wicked. As the wife of a Master of Foxhounds my home number is on the bush telegraph. "Sky television are doing a survey on a hunting ban," a neighbour tells me. "Ring in and pass the message on."

Saturday evening, and the phone rings again. "Jack Straw is announcing a bill on Monday. A few of us are going to join a silent protest in Parliament Square."

Good organisation enables the hunting community to punch above its weight. But there are no illusions about the odds against us.

People are afraid. Not people like me who work for urban employers and can afford to ski if they don't hunt. I feel more jaded than fearful. No, it's the postman, the small farmer, the rural GP, the people who are always done over by governments who are afraid - and have been for a long time now.

The strain of the phoney war of the past three years has been almost unbearable. The higher morale has risen after one of the great countryside rallies, the harder it has been dashed by newspaper gossip on what the prime minister and his "overwhelming majority" have in store for their way of life.

I've seen a hunt secretary break down in tears as she introduced the hounds to a crowd at an agricultural show. I've heard murmurs of rebellion. Some, tiring of the sniping and the weight of other people's disapproval have drifted away from the sport. The remainder have often had to be reminded that they are supposed to enjoy it.

But for all this, hunting people had at least half convinced themselves that the Burns inquiry would save them. All would be well when the facts were known. It was unthinkable that things should be otherwise. Yesterday's publication of the report, then, was a nightmare come true.

Barry Todhunter, huntsman with the Blencathra Foxhounds in Cumbria, tells me that, in his village, when the news came in, "We felt the sinking feeling that now we are finally going to be put up against that wall and shot."

I told some of the local hunt people here in the Midlands that the Burns inquiry apparently thought shooting foxes was less cruel than hunting them. They couldn't accept I'd heard right and I don't blame them. Every country person knows that a fox wounded with a bullet can take hours to die.

Even if a pack of hounds chose to eat a fox from theballs first, he's going to be dead in seconds - a quicker end than a wild bird at the paws of a domestic cat.

Mr Todhunter spent two days hunting with people from the Burns inquiry. "I struggle to understand why they have made these announcements before anyone has had a chance to study the report," he says. He couldn't believe the government could announce a bill on the same day the Burns report was published.

He recognises the same arrogance and contempt for debate that earned Tony Blair the jeers of the Women's Institute.

"People who have nothing to do with hunting come up to me and say, 'I hope they don't stop you'. The govern ment will rue the day they picked this fight."

However this surely isn't quite the way the government sees it. Tony Blair has not made some brave and bold decision. He is incapable of such a thing. He is presenting MPs with a range of options from a full ban through keeping some packs and banning others. Why? Because like Pilate he wants others to bear the guilt for the hard decisions.

A full ban may be the predicted result of his government's bill, but it will be the individual men and women of the House of Commons who will send the foot followers of the Ystrad and Taf Fechan hunt the way of the scarlet-coated gentlemen of the Quorn.

P erhaps the bairns on the backbenches don't care if they ruin workingmen's lives along with a prince's breakfast. Perhaps they share the opinion, all too often expressed in the Guardian, that "we shouldn't care about hunting people, because they didn't care about the miners". If so, it's a pity they didn't go into Parliament Square yesterday and talk to Brian and Mair Hughes from Gilfach Goch in South Wales.

Their four grandfathers died of emphysema after a lifetime in the pits. Brian's father and elder brother were miners too, but had advised him to look for different work. He became a farrier and his elder son makes a living selling horse food. For the hunt.

In Mair's words, they get "very, very angry" to have what happened to the miners flung in their faces, as it so often is.

The way she sees it, "Margaret Thatcher took away my father-in-law's job and now Tony Blair wants to take away his son's". Will the family feel it less because the Burns inquiry predicts it will be one of 6,000 jobs to go and not the 16,000 mentioned by the Countryside Alliance? Will it comfort them to know that they are saying that in 10 years the hunting community will be forgotten?

How long until the silent protests turn to howls of rage?

League Against Cruel Sports

webTitle: Syrian heir disputed by uncle in exile

fields.headline: Syrian heir disputed by uncle in exile
fields.standfirst:
Bashar al-Assad's succession to presidency called 'unconstitutional' as former coup leader signals power struggle

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The first signs of a power struggle in Syria emerged yesterday when the late president's disgraced brother challenged the succession to power of his 34-year-old nephew, Bashar al-Assad.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker  in London, Paul Webster  in Paris and  Adela Gooch in Madrid
fields.body:
The first signs of a power struggle in Syria emerged yesterday when the late president's disgraced brother challenged the succession to power of his 34-year-old nephew, Bashar al-Assad.

Rifaat al-Assad, who in 1983 attempted a coup d'etat , threatened to return from exile in France to Damascus "at the appropriate time". He claims that his dismissal as vice-president in 1998 was "an illegal act" and that he - rather than Bashar - should have succeeded to power.

"What is happening in Syria is a real farce and an unconstitutional piece of theatre which is a real violation of the law and the constitution," Rifaat said through his spokesman in Marbella, Spain.

The spokesman, al-Hareth al-Khair, added: "Rifaat Assad is a leader of the Syrian people, [he] loves his people as his people love him. He will go to his people and take up his responsibilities to fulfil the will of the people.

"He represents legitimacy in Syria," Mr Khair said, adding that Rifaat is therefore capable of removing the restrictions against him "through the force of legitimacy, the people and the army who are with him".

He added: "Dr Rifaat stresses peaceful action and refraining from spilling blood and does not want Syria to drown in blood. But he believes that legitimacy will prevail in a rightful way."

The Syrian military, however, appears to have rallied around Bashar.

The pan-Arab newspaper, al-Hayat, yesterday quoted a senior official as saying orders had been issued to arrest Rifaat if he tried to attend his brother's funeral. The army and the security services were granted "full powers to carry out anything to stop him from entering the country", the official said.

Security has been stepped up at Beirut airport and at Lebanese seaports; security officials there said Syrian agents were on the lookout for Rifaat in case he tried to sneak home through the porous Lebanese border.

Commenting on the threat of arrest, Rifaat's spokesman said: "This is natural to come from a leadership that has no confidence in itself. We expect more."

After his sacking as vice-president, Rifaat, 63, took refuge in France, where surveillance has been sharply stepped up, according to French secret service sources.

Rifaat has been told formally that he will be expelled from the country if he starts moves to return to Damascus and challenge Bashar. "If he is told to leave the country, he will probably seek refuge in London where his son, Soumar, runs the television station, ANN, which is linked with studios in Paris," an agent in the surveillance team said.

The decision by the French president, Jacques Chirac, to attend Hafez's funeral as the only western head of state was seen by diplomats here as proof that France was committed to Bashar's succession as part of a long-running attempt to re-establish French influence in the Middle East.

Mr Chirac's preference for a Syrian successor was signalled in November when he publicly shook hands with Bashar on the steps of the French presidential palace, a gesture which angered Rifaat.

France's sudden chill treatment of Rifaat is in strong contrast to the welcome he received when he quit Syria in August 1998 and was considered as a potential successor as head of state.

With a fortune estimated at between $2bn and $4bn (£1.33bn-£2.7bn), he has allegedly helped many French politicians with their election funds and received favoured treatment in return.

Permanently escorted by about 30 bodyguards, he continues to manage at least 100 companies and control funds salted away in Panama and other tax havens. He is also allowed to publish two daily papers and to attend official receptions on a quasi-diplomatic level.

An Arab diplomat said he was not sure that France had ruled out Rifaat's succession altogether and he would maintain some privileges, including official protection, until the changeover became more clear. "Bashar is faced with one overwhelming question: Can he last?" the official said. "Rifaat might have everything to gain from a policy of wait-and-see."

webTitle: MI5 faces censure over handling of spy cases

fields.headline: MI5 faces censure over handling of spy cases
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: The domestic intelligence service MI5 is bracing itself for a fiercely critical parliamentary report today condemning senior officers for failing to keep ministers informed about their decisions not to prosecute senior spies.
fields.body:
The domestic intelligence service MI5 is bracing itself for a fiercely critical parliamentary report today condemning senior officers for failing to keep ministers informed about their decisions not to prosecute senior spies.

The intelligence and security committee of MPs, chaired by the former Conservative cabinet minister Tom King, will accept that the home secretary Jack Straw and law officers - the attorney general and the solicitor general - should have been informed that MI5 had decided not to prosecute Melita Norwood, a British-based Russian agent. The report will raise serious issues of accountability and will reassert the principle that law officers must take decisions on prosecuting spies.

The intelligence and security committee has been told the government will accept all but one of its recommendations.

The current MI5 director general Stephen Lander conceded to the committee that the service had been mistaken in not telling law officers that they had decided not to prosecute Ms Norwood after she was revealed to have been a Russian spy. The revelation of her status as an agent was made in the Mitrokhin archive smuggled out of Russia by MI6.

The decision not to prosecute was in effect made by MI5 in 1992, but Mr Straw was not informed until 1998 when a book on the subject was about to be published. The intelligence committee report will call for a more effective system of information flow across Whitehall following findings that some information is passed to the home secretary's office, but is not then passed to the home secretary himself.

MI5 judged that the evidence gleaned from the archive would not have been admissible in court, partly because it was not based on primary documents.

The committee will not challenge the decision to give a single trusted academic exclusive access to the documents, pointing out that the Mitrokhin archive had never been the property of the British intelligence services. MI5 also insisted that there was evidence in the archive about agents still active or uncovered.

During its inquiry, the intelligence and security committee fought, and won, a series of battles with MI5 over access to primary documents, rather than precis of reports. One member said: "Mr Straw was extremely helpful in making sure we saw what we wanted".

Apart from the committee report and the formal government response today, MPs will be given a wider chance to debate the security services in a debate next week.

webTitle: Israel knew of president's death hours before Syrians were told

fields.headline: Israel knew of president's death hours before Syrians were told
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli spies knew of President Assad's death within an hour, and got the news to the defence ministry in Tel Aviv five hours before it was announced in Syria, an Israeli newspaper reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Israeli spies knew of President Assad's death within an hour, and got the news to the defence ministry in Tel Aviv five hours before it was announced in Syria, an Israeli newspaper reported yesterday.

According to Yedioth Aharonoth , Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, was informed of Assad's death on Saturday morning, allowing him to be first in the line of world leaders offering condolences, with a conciliatory message for the leader of a state with which Israel is still at war.

"We were not surprised by Assad's death," the paper quotes a senior security source as saying. "The time of our knowledge of his death will not be revealed at the moment to protect the safety of our source, but we had close tabs on Assad."

The exact time of Assad's death has not been revealed. But an Arab diplomat said that Assad may have suffered his fatal heart attack on Tuesday or Wednesday, slipping into unconsciousness before dying on Saturday. The delay afforded his son and heir, Bashar al-Assad, precious time to ensure his transition.

It also explains the speed with which parliament was convened later on Saturday to amend the constitutional age bar on the Syrian presidency so that Bashar would be eligible to succeed.

Intelligence experts accepted the Yediot Aharonoth report as credible. Although Israeli intelligence on its most powerful foe suffered a disaster in 1961 when spy Eli Cohen was caught in Damascus and later hanged, it has closely monitored events in Syria.

"I assume that Israeli intelligence monitoring and bugging communications lines in Syria probably heard the news when it was transmitted by the Syrian tom-tom drums," said Yossi Melman, a leading writer on intelligence matters.

"Someone had to inform Bashar Assad and Bashar had to call his family, and the circle of people who knew within an hour or so must have been very big."

Yesterday, Cohen's brother, Maurice, offered his condolences to Assad's family, including his email address and an appeal that the Syrian leadership return the spy's remains so that they could be buried in Israeli. His widow, Nadia, also sent a polite message, but she told an Israeli newspaper: "I see on television the tears and pain of the Syrians, and I and my family feel relief and happiness."

The demand for Cohen's remains is one of the issues in the Israeli-Syrian peace talks, and the family had sent emissaries to Assad to press their case. Yesterday, Maurice Cohen revealed that Assad had assured them through an intermediary a few months ago that he did not oppose the return of the body "at the right time".

Israelis had been speculating about the death of the ailing Assad for years. In recent weeks, Israeli officials were leaking dramatic accounts of his ailments, which they said included "intermittent dementia". On five or six occasions they even reported that the Syrian leader was dead.

The scrutiny of the Syrian leadership is not about to let up now he has gone, although intelligence officials say they have detected no worrying troop movements across the occupied Golan Heights.

webTitle: City in black as leaders arrive

fields.headline: City in black as leaders arrive
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Syria - normally wary of foreigners - yesterday braced itself for the arrival of at least 10 heads of state, a score of prime ministers or foreign ministers, and hundreds of journalists.
fields.byline: Mona Eltahawy  in Damascus, Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem and Brian Whitaker  in London
fields.body:
Syria - normally wary of foreigners - yesterday braced itself for the arrival of at least 10 heads of state, a score of prime ministers or foreign ministers, and hundreds of journalists.

"I didn't sleep for a minute last night," said one official as he discussed the timetable for the late president's funeral today.

In the streets of Damascus, the hundreds of photographs of Hafez al-Assad that normally decorate bus stops, buildings and vehicles were adorned with a black sash.

The city was swamped with huge black banners mourning Assad's death and proclaiming allegiance to his son, Bashar: "Our grief is great but our hope is great too," said one.

Jacques Chirac of France will be the only European head of state attending the funeral. The King of Jordan, the Emir of Kuwait and the Crown Prince of Saudi Arabia will be there, along with the presidents of Egypt, Iran, Lebanon, Sudan, Turkey and Yemen.

Britain will be represented by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the US by the secretary of state, Madeleine Albright. The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, will be absent.

But the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, was on his way to Damascus for the funeral yesterday, burying grudges that had lasted more than 30 years. According to Palestinian press reports, Bashar intervened to invite Mr Arafat, who reacted with alacrity, taking the chance to be seen mingling with other leaders.

Israel opened the border crossing on the Golan Heights to its own citizens for the first time yesterday for an Israeli Arab delegation travelling to Syria for Assad's funeral.

Six Arab members of the Israeli parliament, and seven other community leaders, were yesterday expected to cross the border. Knesset member Mohammad Barakeh said: "We will be there to express our participation with the Syrian people. We have no message from Israel, but I hope that at least it will serve the peace process."

An Israeli spokesman said members of the group were travelling as private citizens.

Hundreds of Druze Arabs wanting to attend the funeral tried to cross from the Golan Heights into Syria, waving pictures of Assad in the faces of Israeli soldiers, who pushed them back. One hundred had Israeli permission to cross, but when Syria said it would only allow 59 in, the whole group turned back.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Trading was described as thin and directionless on the London market yesterday - and it certainly showed through in the volume figures. Fewer than 1bn shares changed hands, the sort of figure usually reserved for the period between Christmas and new year, or maybe before the August bank holiday weekend.
fields.body:
Trading was described as thin and directionless on the London market yesterday - and it certainly showed through in the volume figures. Fewer than 1bn shares changed hands, the sort of figure usually reserved for the period between Christmas and new year, or maybe before the August bank holiday weekend.

Dealers pointed to the fact that London is more "European" than it was, and most big continental exchanges were closed yesterday.

It would have been even more embarrassing but for the arrival of Egg, which accounted for close to 10% of the day's business as the shares moved from a sale price of 160p to 177.5p on their first day out.

Of course, Egg (with a value of around £1.4bn) is still a long way from being in a position to help the FTSE 100, which drifted 12.9 points to a close of 6,430.9.

A 5p up-tick in the price of Vodafone to 317p helped limit the damage, the mood surrounding the company helped by the long-awaited news that it has won a majority stake in Spain's Airtel. British Telecom, which seems to have lost out in the battle for control of Spain's second largest mobile group, slipped 11p to 973p.

Meanwhile, Egg's 80% parent, Prudential, managed to lose 36p to 965p in a financials sector that was under some serious selling pressure. Lloyds TSB stood out, with the recent rally in the stock attracting profit takers and bringing the quote back from 693p to 672.5p.

Bid hopes returned to support Freeserve, where Dixon's is looking to sell part or all of its 80% holding. The shares rose 20p to 519p. Psion, despite its imminent move out of the Footsie, clicked 22p higher to 658p after buying a small stake in Widcomm, a private American firm which specialises in Bluetooth wireless technology.

Tesco gave up 7p to 206.5p as analysts at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson trimmed their profit forecast and reiterated a "reduce" rating on the stock. The investment bank has slapped a 195p price target on the shares ahead of this week's AGM. Its smaller (troubled) rival Somerfield surged from 50p to 57p after a weekend report (later denied) that the company is looking to be taken private.

Compco Holdings, a small property company, rallied with chairman Ken Rubens using yesterday's year-end figures to declare that contrary to what the City says, "the interests of shareholders can at present best be served without the need for share buy-backs, discounted privatisations or liquidations". The shares jumped 19p to 278.5p.

fields.headline: Leaked memo worries Millbank
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair does "not regret a word" of last week's speech to the Women's Institute, Downing Street insisted yesterday as ministers paraded a business-as-usual resilience in the face of electoral woes.
fields.body:
Tony Blair does "not regret a word" of last week's speech to the Women's Institute, Downing Street insisted yesterday as ministers paraded a business-as-usual resilience in the face of electoral woes.

But official optimism was tempered by the knowledge that a highly-sensitive memo about Labour's internal analysis of its problems - written by polling guru, Philip Gould - has surfaced in the Sunday Times for the second times in three weeks.

With Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, locked in meetings all day, his civil service deputy dismissed talk of a leaks investigation although a maximum of six people had Mr Gould's memo faxed to their homes the night before last Monday's strategy meeting.

The latest memo shows Mr Gould, in a note to Mr Campbell, criticising the prime minister's WI speech before it was delivered. "It makes you feel less of him, not more. Partly it is tone which tries to be conversational, but instead feels condescending; partly it is voice, because this is not the TB we know," Mr Gould wrote.

Some MPs and officials were saying that the most likely source of such a leak was Mr Gould himself, keen to get across concerns. Some of those who know him best say he is too loyal to the Blair project to act in that way.

As a manager of polling data and focus groups, Mr Gould sometimes expresses the views of people he and his team interview rather than his own.

But the latest memo seems to reflect his feeling that the WI speech, which prompted slow-handclaps and anger, later reflected in poor opinion poll results, was "out of touch, reacting not to the wider concerns of real people".

One Blairite analyst, Sion Simon, yesterday translated that phrase as expressing Mr Gould's concern about issues such as asylum.

fields.headline: Rentokil Initial
fields.trailText: The only thing that will rescue the share price at Rentokil Initial will be the exit of chief executive Sir Clive Thompson.
fields.body:
The only thing that will rescue the share price at Rentokil Initial will be the exit of chief executive Sir Clive Thompson.

That was the view of some in the City yesterday as the company offloaded another batch of businesses worth £118m but the stock price moved only 0.25p to 151.25p.

Its a shocking thought that Sir Clive, president of the Confederation of British Industry and architect of the company's past success, has become a millstone. Shares in Rentokil in March hit a five-year low. A huge buy-back scheme and a refocusing of the business have done little to bring them out of the doldrums.

Yesterday the company took the latest step down the restructuring road. It disposed of its international container business for £75m and its US personnel services division for £43m.

Total sale proceeds of £488m have been brought in as part of a target announced last August of reaching £600m by the end of 2000.

Disposing of the British plant hire company and the European distribution business will make up the rest. Talks are under way with potential buyers. Completion of this will trigger the second tranche of a planned £1.5bn buy-back scheme but borrowings will be increased for more acquisitions.

The City remains jaundiced. Some analysts argue that Sir Clive, around 18 months away from his 60th birthday, should pave the way for a successor.

Sir Clive first was knocked off his pedestal at the end of 1998. His ability to churn out market-beating earnings per share growth had given him the nickname of Mr 20%, but he became a victim of his own success. Mature markets and high asset prices have made it impossible for him to improve profits through the kind of daring acquisitions he was famed for. The position is the same today.

On forecast December 2000 profits of £585m, Rentokil is marooned on a forward multiple of around 10.5, extraordinarily low for what is still a well managed company.

But one still might not want to buy shares in the Royal Ratcatcher until a new crown prince is named.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: At moments of crisis such as these, when the authority of the government is openly mocked by members of the Women's Institute, it takes a politician of stature to step forward and capture the mood of the nation.
fields.body:
At moments of crisis such as these, when the authority of the government is openly mocked by members of the Women's Institute, it takes a politician of stature to step forward and capture the mood of the nation.

Such a latter-day Churchill is the Conservative peer Lord Kimball of Easton. "Dear Margaret," he begins in a memo to Baroness Jay, "I am increasingly concerned about the failure of good manners by many of the newer Civil Servants who work for the government." (And let's face it - who isn't concerned?) "The worst example is that Ministers' Private Secretaries write fewer and fewer bread and butter letters when Ministers attend a Luncheon, or another function." (That's nothing my lord, you should try ringing the Downing Street press office) "I also feel that if people are to be asked to something the invitations should be sent out at least one month in advance," writes his lordship. "Perhaps we could have a word about this." Hear, hear, my lord. The government may have pressing issues on its plate, but that's really no excuse for letting the common decencies of politeness go by the board, is it?

Being a member of the upper house makes Lord Kimball ineligible for the Diary's prestigious Stupidest MP 2000 competition. But even Lord Kimball would have little chance of stopping runaway favourite David Wilshire, a man who is becoming synonymous with the title "Stupidest MP". One of Mr Wilshire's local papers, the Staines Informer, is so confident he will win (thanks to his threat to sue for libel a local Labour member who defended the local hospital where he was treated for cancer) that it carried the headline "MP branded as stupidest" on page 19 of last week's issue.

Apologies to those who rang trying to nominate Kate Hoey for the Stupidest MP title. Sadly (for her as well as for us) the member for Lambeth South is also ineligible on the grounds that she is a minister (and ministers are required to say any number of stupid things, so it's not fair on the others). But Kate did have a damned good crack at it, being quoted in the Daily Mail: "A ban is not going to help us save a fox. In fact, there will be very few foxes left in the country if hunting is abolished." Brilliant. We may have to establish a special "non sequitur" category, to be judged by the Regius Professor of Logic at Oxford University.

While foxes are under threat from not being hunted, the Women's Institute is going from strength to strength after its hounding of Mr Blair. My colleague Esther Galan rang the WI's HQ to find out how a Blair-hating, jam-loving woman goes about joining, to be told there has been such a surge in membership applications since last Wednesday that the WI's office has had to draft in extra staff.

It's Mary Whitehouse's 90th birthday today, but I should warn her and any other readers of a delicate disposition not to read the following item. In what must be a seminal moment in the history of British daily newspapers, yesterday's Sun carried its first ever photograph of - ah, how can I put this? - a tumescent male member. It's true that the member in question (in the final frame of Deidre's Photo Casebook, page 39) is masked by a pair of black briefs, but there's no mistaking what economists would call the - er - underlying trend. Thank goodness editor David Yelland is now back from holiday and can get a firm grip. On the paper.

There must be something in the water at Wapping that's causing an outbreak of photo-lewdness, because the cover of the Times's second section yesterday carried a picture of Alastair Campbell making the internationally recognised "tosser" hand gesture. We know Alastair hasn't got a high regard for the media, but should he be allowed to make it so graphically obvious?

webTitle: Brown backs US on hormone beef

fields.headline: Brown backs US on hormone beef
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Britain last night continued to side with the US and Canada in their long-running trade war with the EU over the 12-year-old Europe-wide ban on the use of hormones in beef.
fields.body:
Britain last night continued to side with the US and Canada in their long-running trade war with the EU over the 12-year-old Europe-wide ban on the use of hormones in beef.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said there was no scientific justification for the ban, which also applies to imports and last year prompted tit-for-tat action, involving punitive 100% US tariffs, on selected goods from all EU countries except Britain.

The goods included French cheese and truffles, French and German mustard and chocolate and soups. The tariffs were designed to make up for trade losses totalling nearly $117m (£73m).

There is no question of Britain opting out of the EU ban but its continuing support for the US position means it is unlikely to face any retaliation for the foreseeable future.

Scientists working for the European commission have reaffirmed their view that the use of hormones in speeding up the growth of cattle and in treating their diseases does pose a threat to human health, particularly to children who have yet to reach puberty. Po tential risks include encouraging cancers and undermining the body's immune systems, they warn.

The scientists were compelled to provide new evidence by the World Trade Organisation, which said the ban had been imposed without proper risk assessments. The commission now proposes a continuing ban on six hormones to maintain a "high level of protection of public health" but says it will keep the position under "regular review".

However, government advisers on the veterinary products committee continue to dispute the verdict of their EC colleagues, who include two Britons, Richard Gilbert, the former deputy director of the public health laboratory service, and Mac Johnston, of London University's department of farm animal and equine medicine and surgery.

Mr Brown said: "Unless new scientific evidence is made available for a full evaluation by independent UK experts, the position of the government is unchanged. We do not accept that the scientific case for a ban has been made. We will, however, continue to fulfil our European obligations by enforcing the ban in the UK."

There is no question of Britain opting out of the EU ban but its continuing support for the US position means it is unlikely to face any retaliation for the foreseeable future. Scientists working for the European commission have reaffirmed their view that the use of hormones in speeding up the growth of cattle and in treating their diseases does pose a threat to human health, particularly to children who have yet to reach puberty. Po tential risks include encouraging cancers and undermining the body's immune systems, they warn. The scientists were compelled to provide new evidence by the World Trade Organisation, which said the ban had been imposed without proper risk assessments. The commission now proposes a continuing ban on six hormones to maintain a "high level of protection of public health" but says it will keep the position under "regular review". However, government advisers on the veterinary products committee continue to dispute the verdict of their EC colleagues, who include two Britons, Richard Gilbert, the former deputy director of the public health laboratory service, and Mac Johnston, of London University's department of farm animal and equine medicine and surgery. Mr Brown said: "Unless new scientific evidence is made available for a full evaluation by independent UK experts, the position of the government is unchanged. We do not accept that the scientific case for a ban has been made. We will, however, continue to fulfil our European obligations by enforcing the ban in the UK."

webTitle: Women assaulted by New York gang

fields.headline: Women assaulted by New York gang
fields.trailText: A gang of young men rampaged through central park on Sunday, sexually abusing four young women in three separate incidents.
fields.body:
A gang of young men rampaged through central park on Sunday, sexually abusing four young women in three separate incidents.

The New York police department refused to confirm that among the injured women were French and English tourists. However, the department released details of three incidents, all of which took place in 30 minutes just after 6pm, when it was still light and humid, and just hours after major roads through Manhattan were closed for a day of Puerto Rican celebrations.

The police department said two black men had been arrested in connection with the incident but said they were seeking about 15 suspects. Before abusing the women, aged between 16 and 28, the gang threw water over them. According to one report, the assailants restrained the husband of one of the women while she was subjected to the attack.

The incident, which the police department described as "unusual", evoked memories of the 1989 "wilding" rape of an investment banker jogging in the park.

The police acknowledged that these new attacks would receive a lot of publicity because of the popular location in which they took place.

The first incident involved 16- and 18-year-old women, both white, the second involved a 28-year-old white woman, while the third victim was an 18-year-old black woman. A spokeswoman for the police department said all four women had now been discharged from local hospitals.

The New York city police commissioner, Howard Safir, reacting to concerns about patrols in the 340-hectare (840-acre) park said crime was down and he believed the current police presence was sufficient. "The truth is that if I put 10,000 cops in Central Park, we couldn't cover every single area," he said.

Police named two of those arrested as David Rowe of Hempstead, New York, and Tremayne Bane of Miami. "They have been charged with robbery and sexual abuse," the police department said.

fields.headline: Drunken gambler who lost $1m
fields.trailText: Two Las Vegas casinos have settled out of court with a man who claimed he was plied with drinks while he gambled away more than a million dollars.
fields.body:
Two Las Vegas casinos have settled out of court with a man who claimed he was plied with drinks while he gambled away more than a million dollars.

Nevada prohibits serving alcohol to anyone who is visibly drunk and allowing such a person to gamble.

Stephen Roel, 54, had sued the Las Vegas Hilton and the Mandalay Bay Resort in January, accusing them of capitalising on his alcoholism. One month earlier, the Hilton had sued Roel, seeking $300,000 he borrowed and lost during a three-day binge.

The construction company executive said in court documents that the Hilton had sent its private aircraft to pick him up last September. He had been gambling there regularly for 15 years and had a $50,000 credit line.

Roel was visibly drunk when he arrived at the Hilton and promptly lost $117,000 in cash at blackjack, his lawyers said. He continued drinking and signed IOUs for $839,000.

A Mandalay Bay representative encouraged him to switch casinos. Roel's lawyers said he lost several hundred thousand dollars there and had$100,000 inIOUs. Mandalay Bay did not file suit seeking repayment.

Roel said that he had entered a treatment programme for alcoholism.

AP, Las Vegas

webTitle: New York police want to boycott 'the Boss'

fields.headline: New York police want to boycott 'the Boss'
fields.trailText: His New York concerts have sold out - but Bruce Springsteen certainly hasn't. So much so that the police officers' union wants members to boycott the Boss because of his new song about a police killing.
fields.body:
His New York concerts have sold out - but Bruce Springsteen certainly hasn't. So much so that the police officers' union wants members to boycott the Boss because of his new song about a police killing.

The song, American Skin, does not mention Amadou Diallo by name. But the repeated line "41 shots" leaves no room for doubt that its subject is the killing of the unarmed West African immigrant by New York police officers in February 1999.

Four white NYPD officers fired 41 shots at Diallo in the entrance to his Bronx block of flats. The four were acquitted earlier this year, after claiming they thought that a wallet the dead man was reaching for was a gun.

As Springsteen and the E-Street Band began a 10-night run in New York last night, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the main NYPD union, has urged members to boycott any duties during the concerts and not to attend as paying guests. The president of the Fraternal Order of Police called the singer "a dirtbag".

Springsteen's song, not yet recorded, opens with eight repetitions of the line "41 shots". The chorus runs: "Is it a gun? Is it a knife? Is it a wallet? This is your life. It ain't no secret. The secret my friend, you can get killed just for living in your American skin."

"I happen to like Springsteen," New York police officer Orlando Vega told the New York Daily News yesterday, "but we're trying to work in the community, and him opening up old wounds just makes our jobs more difficult".

Diallo's mother has said she wants to meet Springsteen to thank him for keeping her son's case in the public eye. Since the acquittal, the Diallo killing has largely disappeared from the front pages and has barely figured in the Senate election battle between Hillary Clinton and Rick Lazio.

"The anger is nowhere and nothing is happening," the veteran New York columnist Jimmy Breslin wrote on Sunday. "At the last hour, only Bruce Springsteen comes in to remind this city of its duty never to forget a horror."

fields.headline: US snubs world court treaty
fields.standfirst: America fears its soldiers may face war crimes trials
fields.trailText: The United States may be the world's only superpower, and its values may be sweeping many of the world's cultural and economic borders aside, but Washington is once again preparing to mount a rearguard action against moves to establish an International Criminal Court which would try the perpetrators of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
The United States may be the world's only superpower, and its values may be sweeping many of the world's cultural and economic borders aside, but Washington is once again preparing to mount a rearguard action against moves to establish an International Criminal Court which would try the perpetrators of war crimes and crimes against humanity.

Yesterday, as the latest session of the preparatory commission for the International Criminal Court (ICC) got under way in New York, the US delegation put forward new proposals to ensure that citizens of countries which have refused to sign the treaty establishing the court - of which the US is the most prominent - should not be covered by its jurisdiction.

The United States is one of seven nations which have not signed the ICC treaty, which was drafted in Rome in 1998. Others include China and Iraq.

The court will come into existence when 60 nations have ratified the treaty. So far, 12 have done so, though 97 have signed the treaty and are committed to ratification in due course.

The official US position is that it is opposed to any court that might possibly seek to put US soldiers and officials on trial under an international jurisdiction. This is a highly sensitive issue for the Pentagon and for a nation which has always been reluctant to allow its domestic law to be overridden by international agreements of any kind.

Washington says that the dispute is a crucial sovereignty issue. But there is increasing evidence that the US position is being formulated in response to domestic party political considerations as much as to principles of international law.

Republican leaders in Congress have chosen this week to turn up the heat on the issue, a move which is widely seen as an attempt to prevent any compromise on the issue by the Clinton administration.

The Senate foreign relations committee, whose chairman Senator Jesse Helms has already said that any treaty to establish the court would be "dead on arrival" if submitted to his committee, has summoned several opponents of the court to give evidence on Capitol Hill tomorrow. Witnesses include the former defence secretary Caspar Weinberger and the conservative jurist Jeremy Rabkin.

In the absence of any great enthusiasm for the treaty on the part of the Democrats, especially in election year, it is becoming increasingly probable that the court will come into existence without the participation of a nation which has repeatedly been in the forefront of international calls for leaders such as Pol Pot or Saddam Hussein to be put on trial for crimes against humanity.

The ICC is currently on course to come into existence in 2002, with jurisdiction to bring prosecutions of perpe trators of crimes such as genocide and torture.

The current session of the preparatory commission for the ICC opened in New York yesterday and is focusing on rules of procedure and evidence. The session, the fifth in a process set up under the Rome treaty, is expected to continue for the rest of this month, with a sixth session scheduled for the autumn.

The latest nation to ratify the treaty is France, which did so last week. Britain is a signatory to the 1998 treaty but has not yet ratified it.

France's decision was "a clear signal to the United States that major nations and allies are continuing to progress towards completing the ratification, and they are not willing to reopen the treaty," said William Pace, the convenor of the US-based Coalition for an International Criminal Court, an umbrella group of pro-treaty bodies. The latest US attempt to change the terms of the treaty was an "ill-timed and misguided effort," Mr Pace said.

Supporters of the treaty are suspicious of the timing of the latest moves, not least because the court gives countries whose citizens are charged with international crimes the right to have their cases tried in their own home country. "Why they seem to be driving this thing over the edge to get something they don't need is an intriguing question," said Richard Dicker of Human Rights Watch. "The treaty has more than enough assurances to meet their concerns."

webTitle: Southern Baptists clash over banning of women pastors

fields.headline: Southern Baptists clash over banning of women pastors
fields.trailText: The Southern Baptists are debating a proposal dividing America's largest Protestant denomination: A measure that says women should no longer serve as pastors.
fields.body:
The Southern Baptists are debating a proposal dividing America's largest Protestant denomination: A measure that says women should no longer serve as pastors.

The group will vote on the revised statement of belief at its annual convention, which begins in Orlando, Florida today.

"I think you'll see a lot of women leaving the denomination if the proposal passes," said the Rev Martha Phillips, interim pastor of the Mount Vernon Baptist Church in Arlington, Virginia, which is attended by Vice-President, Al Gore. "For me it's the last straw."

The chairman of the drafting committee, the Rev Adrian Rogers of Memphis, Tennessee, said the panel's stand is based on "doctrines revealed in the Bible".

The Rev David Key, director of Baptist Studies at Emory University's Candler School of Theology, called the statement a litmus test of who's in and out of conservative circles.

"Instead of building a con sensus statement, [Baptist leaders] are using it as a club to drive out people they disagree with," he said. "After they pass this, every denominational bureaucrat, every missionary, every seminary professor is going to have to adhere to the statement."

The statement of belief reads: "While both men and women are gifted for service in the church, the office of pastor is limited to men as qualified by scripture."

While it opposes the future ordination of women, the 1,600 or so current Southern Baptist clergywomen, about 100 of whom are pastors leading congregations, would not lose their credentials.

The statement is not binding on individual Southern Baptists, and the 41,000 local congregations would remain free to ordain women. But the statement could affect the denomination's hiring decisions.

In 1998, the Southern Baptists declared a wife should "submit herself graciously to the servant leadership of her husband". About a dozen congregations left the denomination.

fields.headline: Wider rules on 'family friendly' working
fields.trailText: Millions more parents will get new rights on family friendly working after ministers opted to extend proposed improvements to include mothers of all children up to 16, rather than just under-fives.
fields.body:
Millions more parents will get new rights on family friendly working after ministers opted to extend proposed improvements to include mothers of all children up to 16, rather than just under-fives.

Ministers have accepted that the difficulties of balancing work and home life are as great or greater once children go to school, and so will widen the application of proposed new rights, such as an entitlement to work part-time, to parents of pre-school and school-age youngsters.

The decision, made at the first meeting of a ministerial review group on maternity rights and flexible working, will be warmly welcomed by campaigners for a better deal for working parents. However, the extension is certain to anger business, which already argues that government regulation increasing workers' rights is excessive and burdensome.

If the review opts to take a tough line and enshrine new rights in legislation, firms could be forced to allow all mothers of school age and pre-school children to switch to part-time working. Companies are unlikely to be appeased by government pledges to make a powerful business case for more workplace flexibility.

The review group, which is chaired by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, and includes women's ministers Lady Jay and Tessa Jowell and equal opportunities minister Margaret Hodge, is charged with finding ways to help parents, particularly women, to combine work and family life.

So far, the government has launched a work-life balance campaign to urge companies to introduce flexible work policies, but is relying on coercion rather than legislation. Ministers have already privately indicated that the right to return to a job part-time after having a baby is being considered as a manifesto proposal for Labour's second term.

However, the review group's implications now go even further by dramatically increasing the proportion of parents affected.

The group, which is due to report in the autumn, will decide whether to make the option of returning to work part-time or on a flexible basis - perhaps including home working - a legal right, or whether to offer weaker options such as a strong presumption of flexible working unless a company can prove it would be difficult to offer it.

Alternatively, companies could be offered incentives to introduce better family-friendly policies.

A primary reason for change, ministers believe, is that women at present leave work altogether after having children, or go back too soon because of inadequate maternity pay and then swiftly leave their jobs anyway.

However, campaigners for new family-friendly rights are wary of the move to apply any changes to a wider group of parents.

The former social security secretary Harriet Harman, campaigning from the backbenches on family policy, said: "What would be totally unacceptable would be to do too little to improve maternity pay and leave, which were the initial focus of this review.

"The government must also be wary of talking up issues such as family-friendly working and then failing to back that up with legislation."

She added: "Working groups, accreditation schemes and management handbooks will make absolutely no difference for the vast majority of Britain's women."

fields.headline: The declining monarchy
fields.standfirst:
Support for it may simply be dying out

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: In that heady week of nearly three years ago, there were plenty who saw the monarchy teeter on the verge of oblivion. The beloved Diana was dead and the people were massing at the gates of the palace, like a mob in a French or Russian revolution.
fields.body:
In that heady week of nearly three years ago, there were plenty who saw the monarchy teeter on the verge of oblivion. The beloved Diana was dead and the people were massing at the gates of the palace, like a mob in a French or Russian revolution. "Where is our Queen? Where is her flag?" taunted the usually loyal tabloid press. There was even a champion to take on the Windsors, in the time-honoured form of a fellow aristocrat, Charles Spencer. The whiff of upheaval was in the air. Even the less melodramatic imagined that, with the royal soap opera's most charismatic star gone, the Windsor story was reaching its final act.

But those strange September days passed and the memory of Diana began to fade. Charles started to rehabilitate himself. No longer the adulterous hate-figure, he was allowed to be himself at last, without the upstaging presence of his dazzling, volatile former wife. Princes William and Harry did not become defiant reminders of their mother, but rather helpful assistants in the makeover of their dad. The polls moved, so that the very same papers which had once reviled Camilla Parker-Bowles now demanded the prince do the decent thing and marry. The "firm" seemed to be safely back in business. Until yesterday.

For the Guardian/ICM poll has suddenly and unexpectedly burst that bubble. Its central finding, that only 44% of Britons believe the country would be worse off without the royal family, is an enormous setback. It is even lower than the 48% figure which sent such shockwaves when it was recorded, with eerie timing, a matter of days before the death of Diana in 1997.

What the poll numbers suggest is that the monarchy's unpopularity in the 1990s was not simply the result of the consistently bad publicity of those years. Until now, the royal family could tell themselves that two divorces and the row over tax caused the slide in their fortunes.

But yesterday's survey offers no such easy explanation. There has not been a publicity disaster to hurt the family's image. On the contrary, the papers have been full of pictures of the photogenic Prince William in the run up to his 18th birthday next week, jockeying for space with his still-liked great-grandmother, who is about to turn 100. The rows over genetically-modified food, with Charles and Philip taking opposite views, have hardly damaged the family: they have probably made them seem current.

And yet none of this has helped. An absence of PR catastrophes and a series of media boosts have done nothing to persuade Britons that we need this family as the exclusive, genetic producers of our head of state. Instead, an ever- declining number believe they add anything to our national life whatsoever.

The simple explanation may be that, while the disenchantment of the last decade was fuelled by scandal, the current sentiment is something deeper - and surely more alarming for the palace: plain indifference. It seems that, for large sections of the country, the royals no longer have any relevance. Our survey found that some 40% of 18- to 24-year-olds think Britain would be positively better off without them; the over-55s were the only age group to speak up for the royals. That finding suggests monarchism could quite literally die out in the coming years, with a kind of republicanism taking its place. It seems the new generation has taken the politicians' talk of modernisation to heart - and that they see little place in a modern country for so archaic an institution.

Princes William and Harry did not become defiant reminders of their mother, but rather helpful assistants in the makeover of their dad. The polls moved, so that the very same papers which had once reviled Camilla Parker-Bowles now demanded the prince do the decent thing and marry. The "firm" seemed to be safely back in business. Until yesterday. For the Guardian/ICM poll has suddenly and unexpectedly burst that bubble. Its central finding, that only 44% of Britons believe the country would be worse off without the royal family, is an enormous setback. It is even lower than the 48% figure which sent such shockwaves when it was recorded, with eerie timing, a matter of days before the death of Diana in 1997. What the poll numbers suggest is that the monarchy's unpopularity in the 1990s was not simply the result of the consistently bad publicity of those years. Until now, the royal family could tell themselves that two divorces and the row over tax caused the slide in their fortunes. But yesterday's survey offers no such easy explanation. There has not been a publicity disaster to hurt the family's image. On the contrary, the papers have been full of pictures of the photogenic Prince William in the run up to his 18th birthday next week, jockeying for space with his still-liked great-grandmother, who is about to turn 100. The rows over genetically-modified food, with Charles and Philip taking opposite views, have hardly damaged the family: they have probably made them seem current. And yet none of this has helped. An absence of PR catastrophes and a series of media boosts have done nothing to persuade Britons that we need this family as the exclusive, genetic producers of our head of state. Instead, an ever- declining number believe they add anything to our national life whatsoever. The simple explanation may be that, while the disenchantment of the last decade was fuelled by scandal, the current sentiment is something deeper - and surely more alarming for the palace: plain indifference. It seems that, for large sections of the country, the royals no longer have any relevance. Our survey found that some 40% of 18- to 24-year-olds think Britain would be positively better off without them; the over-55s were the only age group to speak up for the royals. That finding suggests monarchism could quite literally die out in the coming years, with a kind of republicanism taking its place. It seems the new generation has taken the politicians' talk of modernisation to heart - and that they see little place in a modern country for so archaic an institution.

webTitle: Twin born a month after her brother

fields.headline: Twin born a month after her brother
fields.trailText: A mother was yesterday celebrating the birth of her second twin almost a month after the first was born 14 weeks prematurely.
fields.body:
A mother was yesterday celebrating the birth of her second twin almost a month after the first was born 14 weeks prematurely.

In what is believed to be the biggest delivery time gap between twins in British history, Sandra Beveridge gave birth to her daughter, Chloe, on Sunday afternoon. The girl was some way behind her brother, Edward, who was born on May 14, weighing just 1lb 12oz.

Although twins being born so far apart is not unprecedented, a spokeswoman for the Royal College of Midwives said she had no experience of a case with such a time gap between delivery.

Generally when a woman begins delivering twins, the uterus contracts and expels both babies. But, because of Edward's tiny size,the uterus did not close fully and Chloe was left in the womb.

The biggest delay recorded by the Royal College of Midwives between the birth of twins in Britain is 10 days and doctors at Edinburgh's Simpson memorial maternity pavilion expected Ms Beveridge to give birth to her daughter within a few days. They sent her home to Livingston, West Lothian, to rest, and on Sunday doctors - fearing infection from Edward's placenta, which was still in the womb - performed a caesarean section. A hospital spokeswoman said Chloe and her mother were "stable".

The world record for difference in twins' birth dates lies with US mother Peggy Lynn who had her babies 84 days apart in 1995 and 1996.

fields.headline: March of superbugs 'must be halted'
fields.standfirst: WHO report warns that basic operations could be put at risk
fields.trailText: Commonplace hospital and dental operations could become too medically risky because of the rapid march of superbugs resistant to antibiotics, the World Health Organisation said yesterday.
fields.body:
Commonplace hospital and dental operations could become too medically risky because of the rapid march of superbugs resistant to antibiotics, the World Health Organisation said yesterday.

It warned of the "almost unimaginable repercussions" of a failure to curb the misuse of drugs that threatened procedures such as hip replacements and cyst removals because infection controls were proving so inadequate.

The WHO's report points to the danger that increasing drug resistance among infectious bacteria posed to programmes to reduce the victims of killer diseases, such as pneumonia, TB, malaria and Aids. The report calls on governments and drug companies to devise new ways of curbing overuse in industrialised countries and of encouraging "wider but wiser" prescriptions in developing countries.

The report's publication coincided with the government's announcement of a new action plan for Britain.

This takes in new checks on hospital procedures to prevent cross-infection; fresh guidelines on drugs, dosage and duration of treatments to stop routine overuse of medicines; public education programmes to reduce patients' demands for antibiotics; and monitoring of use of antibiotics in humans, pets and livestock.

In UK hospitals, resistance to penicillin treatments for the staphylococcus infection, whose symptoms include severe vomiting and abdominal pain - potentially disastrous among patients whose immune systems are already compromised - now occurs among about a third of cases. Resistance to an alternative antibiotic, methicillin, is nearing similar levels in England and Wales.

About 50m prescriptions for antibiotics are handed out by GPs in England alone and many of those are given for complaints such as viral sore throats, for which they are not appropriate.

The report was published as the WHO warned that a small but growing number of patients was already developing resistance to the anti-HIV drug AZT, and that penicillin had become "virtually useless" for treating the venereal disase gonorrhoea. Further, strains of TB resistant to a whole range of drugs, which had emerged in eastern Europe, Asia and Africa, were now reappearing in patients in western Europe and north America. Resistance to the old first treatment of choice for malaria, chloroquine , was widespread in most countries where the disase was still a major killer.

In the US alone, some 14,000 people were infected and died each year from drug-resistant microbes being picked up in hospitals. But some problems in the developing world were caused by underuse not overuse, with many governments being unable to afford programmes which allowed patients to follow complete courses of antibiotics. The use of counterfeit drugs was making matters worse.

The WHO report criticised the way some drug companies rewarded poorly paid health workers in developing countries with commissions that effectively encouraged them to avoid treatments aimed at specific complaints in favour of broad-spectrum antibiotics that had wide applications.

The WHO is in talks with drug companies and governments over introduction of incentives to develop a new generation of drugs, including tax breaks, extension of patents, and fast-track approvals for some new treatments.

It is also expected that the G8 summit of industrialised nations in Japan next month will announce new funds to boost research into AIDS, malaria, acute respiratory infections such as pneumonia, diarrhoeal diseases and TB.

At the moment, treatments for these afflictions only account for 2% of global research and development health budgets.

David Heymann, executive director of the WHO's programme on communicable diseases, said: "We are in a race against time to bring levels of infectious disease down worldwide before the diseases wear the drugs down first."

Rosamund Williams, who heads the WHO team on drug resistance, said that the organisation and governments were asking pharmaceutical companies to develop new drugs "because the pipeline is running dry ... but we don't want them to overpromote them and oversell them.

"It is a challenge. How do we provide the incentives that are necessary so that the profits do not have to be recouped through sales?"

fields.headline: Policeman 'had drink with jurors'
fields.trailText: Police chiefs were last night considering disciplinary action against a detective for allegedly making improper contact with a jury after a fraud trial.
fields.body:
Police chiefs were last night considering disciplinary action against a detective for allegedly making improper contact with a jury after a fraud trial.

Detective Constable Keith Hughes went for drinks with members of the jury at his local pub after the trial finished, the crown prosecution service said.

The court of appeal quashed the convictions against the three defendants on Friday after Lord Justice Roach ruled there was a real danger of bias.

The seven-month trial last year cost taxpayers £10m.

A Metropolitan police spokeswoman said: "We will be considering whether or not any disciplinary proceedings are appropriate." She would not go into further details about the collapse of the case or comment on the release of the defendants, two Italians and a Swiss.

But a spokeswoman for the CPS said that it had first brought the matter up with the defendants' lawyers.

"We were concerned that this police officer had apparently had contact with the jury," she said.

"He had allegedly gone out for a drink with a number of the jury members. It was thought that what he had done was not proper conduct. That is why we brought it to the attention of the defence."

It is also alleged the jury members received a business card from DC Hughes via a court usher.

The defendants, Gian Lombardi, his wife, Veronica, and Gianfranco Udovicich were jailed for between three and five years for conspiracy to defraud.

They had all served eight months in prison after Southwark crown court heard they cheated clients around the world with promises of cheap finance.

The case had already made history when Judge Valerie Pearlman concluded the trial over an internet link from her hospital bed after she had broken her leg.

Press Association
