fields.headline: Scoot buys Loot for £190m
fields.trailText: Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, has won the backing of its French partner Vivendi to snap up the free advertising newspaper group Loot for £190m.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, has won the backing of its French partner Vivendi to snap up the free advertising newspaper group Loot for £190m.

Chief executive Robert Bonnier believes he can turn the business into an internet auction platform, competing with the likes of QXL and eBay.

He said much of the technology was already in place and forecast that the Loot acquisi tion, which crystalises a £40m windfall for Loot's founder, David Landau, would boost Scoot's revenues by £20m within three years.

Scoot.com also intends to look at cross-advertising opportunities with Loot. However, a disappointing set of interim results saw Scoot.com shares fall 5p yesterday to 190p.

The company said revenues for the half-year to March 31 slumped 34% to £6.2m, blaming the fall on its decisions to cut its listing charges to attract more businesses. A decision to adopt a more conservative revenue policy by using US accounting standards also contributed to the fall.

Group operating losses, on the other hand, were cut by 11% to £9.9m as Scoot.com's cost base improved and its customer churn rate reduced.

Mr Bonnier said the narrowing of losses was "pleasing, as I don't think many people expected it".

He forecast this was the last quarter of declining revenue. "Towards the autumn, you will see a significant acceleration in revenue because our subscriber numbers are starting to accelerate."

Mr Bonnier said the group's target of 60,000 merchant subscribers by year-end remained, despite the present total standing at just 20,000.

Scoot.com's £190m purchase of Loot is in cash and stock, including the assumption of £2m debt. Mr Landau said the volatility in Scoot.com's share price had meant the offer had to be mainly in cash, with only 5m shares issued to Loot investors.

"We wanted more shares," Mr Landau said. "And I probably will buy more Scoot shares."

French media and utilities group Vivendi, which holds an 11.5% stake in Scoot.com, has funded the deal, paying just under £200m for new shares which will potentially take the French conglomerate's stake up to 23.6%.

Nick Bubb, head of European retail research at SG Global Equities, said Scoot.com had the potential to make a £40m profit within three years, rather than losses of that order.

"It has the right model and the right partners to be a very substantial company in two to three years' time," he said. "If it delivers, then our long term price target of 575p should be easily achievable, and Vivendi share our view."

Scoot is also expected to review the opportunities presented by the acquisition of Loot's assets in the US, India and Pakistan.

webTitle: More heckling for the prime minister

fields.headline: More heckling for the prime minister
fields.trailText: The problem for Tony Blair (Wounded Blair orders attack, June 12) is that the messages sent out by New Labour are listened to - even by those for whom they are not intended.
fields.body:
The problem for Tony Blair (Wounded Blair orders attack, June 12) is that the messages sent out by New Labour are listened to - even by those for whom they are not intended.

When he makes placating noises to big business and assures them that the parts of the European social chapter that will provide more worker security might not be implemented, those noises are heard by people who are growing more insecure and dissatisfied at work.

When Blair assumed leadership of the Labour party he started off by telling us what he believed in. Even if the message wasn't to the taste of everyone people believed that he meant what he said. That sincerity seems to have disappeared.

Alan Pearman
Rotherham

 We old Labour parliamentary candidates of the Wilson and Callaghan years accepted opposition to our views as a fact of life and learned to deal with heckling.

How different from exponents of New Labour who assume that everyone will agree with what they say and just mumble "Thank you" to critical shouts from the floor.

Derek Forwood
Atherstone, Warwickshire

webTitle: Nato's war: the dust still hasn't settled

fields.headline: Nato's war: the dust still hasn't settled
fields.trailText: George Robertson (Letters, June 12), like some of his critics, confuses the legal, the moral and the criminal in his defence of Nato action in Kosovo and Serbia. That the war itself was illegal no competent scholar denies; this was confirmed by the recent parliamentary committee. Whether it involved war crimes is a narrower question.
fields.body:
George Robertson (Letters, June 12), like some of his critics, confuses the legal, the moral and the criminal in his defence of Nato action in Kosovo and Serbia. That the war itself was illegal no competent scholar denies; this was confirmed by the recent parliamentary committee. Whether it involved war crimes is a narrower question.

It may be that no aerial attacks, however misguided or cruel, including even nuclear explosions, can count as indictable war crimes. The TV station, the far-away bridges, the power stations, civilian attacks, all designed to punish Serbia, were probably illegal in the broad sense. They may still not be crimes like the cutting of an individual throat upon the ground. Moral justification is clearly a matter of opinion. But there is still no law in Kosovo, as the weekend attack by UK forces upon the civilian hospital shows (MoD denies abducting injured Kosovo gunman, June 12).

Peter Nicholls
Colchester pnicholl@essex.ac.uk

 No, George Robertson, Nato's actions were not "within the confines" of international law - see the Corrections column on the same page of the Guardian as your letter.

Nor has the question been addressed of other violations of the law during the Nato attack on the Balkans, for example, use of weapons of "indiscriminate effect", including cluster bombs and depleted uranium weapons, which violate Article 51 Protocol 1 of the Geneva Convention. The rapporteurs to the Nato parliamentary assembly itself (November, 1999) conceded just this point.

Rae Street
Littleborough, Lancs raecnd@gn.apc.org

 Unlike the UN and the EU, Nato is the only organisation to have intervened effectively in the former Yugoslavia. An ethical foreign policy would expand Nato, not call for its abolition (Time for truly ethical policies, June 12).

Dr Angus Bancroft
Edinburgh

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Time for truly ethical policies, page 10, yesterday, we said that both Russia and the US were members of the OSCE, the organisation for security and cooperation in Europe. We meant to say that Russia is a member but the US is not.
fields.body:
In a report headed Time for truly ethical policies, page 10, yesterday, we said that both Russia and the US were members of the OSCE, the organisation for security and cooperation in Europe. We meant to say that Russia is a member but the US is not.

In a report on page 8 yesterday about the decision of the management of the Millennium Dome to decline to show a wax sculpture of Che Guevara we described "BAe/Marconi", the sponsors of the Mind zone, as "the UK's largest manufacturer of military hardware". We then quoted the artist responsible for the work as saying, "They thought it would not go down well with Marconi as they make missiles." Marconi is a telecommunications company and does not make missiles. It has not made arms since November of last year, before the dome opened, when that part of its activities went to BAe Systems.

The Newcomen Society, mentioned in our survey of famous bridges, Spanning the centuries, page 11, June 10, exists for the study of the history of engineering and technology and is, "emphatically", the present president of the society says, not "dedicated to civil engineering and industrial archaeology". The society is interested in the history of all kinds of engineering. There is a quite separate Association for Industrial Archaeology. In the map on the same page we switched the positions of Westminster and Waterloo bridges.

The photograph on page 1, June 10, captioned, "An Israeli soldier on lookout during the six-day war" actually related to an event several months after the war. The Israelis had bombed an oil refinery at the southern end of the Suez Canal, in retaliation for the sinking of an Israeli warship.

The Japanese poet to whom we meant to refer in a report pondering the question, whither the haiku? page 6, yesterday, was Matsuo Basho (not Mensuo Basho). He was a master, rather than the father of the genre which came to prominence somewhat earlier.

Little errors: The 1811 bottle of Chateau Lafitte [sic] sold for £24,200 at Christie's, page 9, June 9, was Chateau Lafite.

On page 2, Sport, June 10, we referred to "...a large strawberry gateaux".

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. fields.headline: Kosovo: one year on
fields.standfirst:
Morality can sometimes be ahead of law

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: One year into their rule over Kosovo, the United Nations and Nato have been having an uncomfortable anniversary. For the UN there is a litany of bad news with a rise in attacks on the Serb minority, a walk-out by Serb moderates from the interim government, and the prospect of a Serb boycott of this autumn's elections. For Nato the grim tidings are a series of retrospective reports which criticise its air strikes as well as the mistakes made before the first bomb-button was pressed.
fields.body:
One year into their rule over Kosovo, the United Nations and Nato have been having an uncomfortable anniversary. For the UN there is a litany of bad news with a rise in attacks on the Serb minority, a walk-out by Serb moderates from the interim government, and the prospect of a Serb boycott of this autumn's elections. For Nato the grim tidings are a series of retrospective reports which criticise its air strikes as well as the mistakes made before the first bomb-button was pressed.

The two issues should not be confused. Bungling in the post-war running of Kosovo cannot be used to argue that the military campaign was wrong, any more than the damaging division of Germany after 1945 undermines the validity of the fight against German fascism. If the attack on Yugoslavia was wrong, it was not because of what happened after President Milosevic surrendered but before it. The first charge is that Nato committed war crimes by hitting targets like bridges, power stations, and the Serbian government's TV station, and failing to take sufficient care to avoid civilian casualties. Nato has been exonerated by the chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Tribunal in the Hague as well as by Human Rights Watch. Amnesty International disagrees. International law is vague on the circumstances in which targets which have both military and civilian uses may be hit by bombing, and what precautions have to be taken. It is not so vague on the kind of face-to-face crimes against civilians - rape, murder, and forced deportation - for which Serb commanders have been indicted.

The fullest of the recent reports comes from the House of Commons foreign affairs committee. It takes up the important issue of whether the attack on Yugoslavia was legal, and concludes that it was not - though it was morally justified. This is a conclusion that can easily be parodied as a wonderful plea for any defendant, from Robin Hood to Jack the Ripper. The real arguments are dense and complex, but the evidence given to the committee by a series of distinguished jurists is probably the fullest there has been on this subject. With "humanitarian intervention" increasingly under challenge, the committee highlights the need for greater clarity in defining the occasions where international law may overrule national sovereignty even when the United Nations security council has not taken a position.

fields.headline: Swayed by the bridge
fields.trailText: We went to the riverside, to cross the new bridge (Bridge in troubled waters, June 12) A jazz band playing, balloons flying into the sky, the Tate Modern looming on the opposite shore, a good day for a new bridge.
fields.body:
We went to the riverside, to cross the new bridge (Bridge in troubled waters, June 12) A jazz band playing, balloons flying into the sky, the Tate Modern looming on the opposite shore, a good day for a new bridge.

As we began to cross it became apparent that the bridge was swaying, several inches, from side to side. It was a wonderful moment. The bridge's transient population swayed drunkenly as they walked, in synchrony, as if choreographed. We were made to dance, by some master hand. Now engineers are trying to solve the swaying. I hope and pray that they will fail. The swaying bridge is one of the best experiences that London has to offer.

Ed Emery
Teignmouth, Devon ed.emery@cwcom.net

 I watched with amazement the people struggling across the new millennium bridge this weekend - up there in the air on an insubstantial but vastly expensive pathway, stuck uncertainly somewhere between left and right, wobbling dangerously over very deep water, unsure which way to go: is this what Mr Blair means by his third way, perhaps?

Anne Sweeney
Lancaster anne.sweeney@tinyworld.co.uk

 Could we have a comment from a feng sway expert?

David Goldsmith
London

 Bridge troubled waters:

suspend 18 million

haiku rules wobble

John Hamlett
Manchester johnhamlett@mac.com

 You are premature in talking of delays to the new bridge. With six and half months available, I am sure that the engineers will have fixed any minor problems in good time for the millennium.

Brian P Moss
Tamworth, Staffs BrianMoss@NorthWarks.gov.uk

 The news from the Forth Bridge is not good either. You report (Bridging the centuries, June 10) that when some years ago painting was stopped in a cost-saving exercise "there was a public outcry and the painting resumed". It recently stopped again. Half way through a "£40m" refurbishment Railtrack have called a halt.

This time, thanks to improved news management techniques, there has been no public outcry. It looks as though Railtrack are going to get away with allowing this miracle of 19th century engineering to rust away, thereby getting themselves out of a very costly long-term commitment.

Bill Williams
Ellon, Aberdeenshire bill@forthebridge.com

webTitle: Dell preaches old values in the new economy

fields.headline: Dell preaches old values in the new economy
fields.trailText:
Michael Dell, chairman of Dell Computer, last night warned British business leaders not to ignore old-economy fundamentals of profitability and growth when taking their companies online.

E-finance: special report
fields.body:
Michael Dell, chairman of Dell Computer, last night warned British business leaders not to ignore old-economy fundamentals of profitability and growth when taking their companies online.

Mr Dell, one of the US's pre-eminent new-technology entrepreneurs, said that, while the internet was a powerful tool, simply adding a bit of dot.com spice to a company should not be viewed as an instant business fix.

"The key lesson we've learned from our success with internet business is that basic business fundamentals don't change," he said in an address at London Business School.

"Business leaders must still focus on liquidity, profitability and growth. There is little doubt the internet has expanded and radically changed business ... [but] ... if you take a business that is a bad business and put it online it's still a bad business, it just becomes a bad online business."

The main benefits the internet could bring were velocity, efficiency and improved customer experience. Businesses using the internet to speed up their value chain and break down barriers had achieved millions of dollars in savings.

"Velocity of information is the hallmark of the internet and efficiency is a measurement of how well you exploit velocity. The culmination... is improved customer experience which leads to new relationships, loyalty, profitability and growth."

fields.headline: Don't hack the haiku
fields.standfirst: It needs rules to preserve its art
fields.trailText:
Avid teacher says
"it's that haiku stuff again".
class IV beats her up
fields.body:
Avid teacher says
"it's that haiku stuff again".
class IV beats her up

For purists, this falls far short of being a classical Japanese haiku. True, it has 17 syllables broken 5-7-5 into three lines in the acceptable westernised style. It has kireji (punctuation). But it lacks a kigo , a "season word". It also lacks - as class IVs all over the world unhappily tend to do - all sense of rapt communion with nature.

It does, however, tell the story. As an export, the haiku has proved almost as successful as the Honda. A shake-up in this medieval form, the purest and once the strictest in the world, will have repercussions not only among serious poets, amateur versifiers and followers of haiku websites, but among children doing keystage three of the British national curriculum. Already, as we reported yesterday, the British Haiku Society has started revising the guidance pack it issues to teachers. Pressure for a relaxation in the old rules comes from last September's Matsuyama Declaration in Japan. This summer the World Haiku Festival 2000 in London and Oxford will try to agree changes in more detail.

Formal internationalisation of the haiku can only be good news in Britain, which teems with crossword solvers, Scrabble addicts, limerick fabricators and other breeds of word fancier. Everything is up for grabs in the rule changes: the number of syllables (renamed "beats" to please younger artists), line arrangements and even the kigo , which can be hard to fit into a limerick.

But please don't let's throw the baby out with the bathwater. The exquisite challenge of the "haiku moment", for those of us with insufficient stamina for sonnets, is the test of fixing a momentary insight or perception in the amber of a (fairly) rigorous but mercifully short form. Without a few rules, it would cease to be fun - or art.

fields.headline: Guatemala babies 'sold to highest bidders'
fields.standfirst: A UN report says that the trafficking of children for adoption is widespread but many reject its claims
fields.trailText: Gabriela de Leon is a self-assured young woman who works for a real estate firm in Mixco, a small town half an hour's drive from the capital of Guatemala. The drive to Mixco takes you past a ramshackle shanty-town that encapsulates the poverty of the country, where the richest 10% of the population have 70 times the annual incomes of the poorest 10%.
fields.body:
Gabriela de Leon is a self-assured young woman who works for a real estate firm in Mixco, a small town half an hour's drive from the capital of Guatemala. The drive to Mixco takes you past a ramshackle shanty-town that encapsulates the poverty of the country, where the richest 10% of the population have 70 times the annual incomes of the poorest 10%.

Four years ago, Ms de Leon, now 26, was pregnant with her third child. Her husband told her the family could not afford another baby and he did not want to go into debt. An abortion was suggested. When she refused, she recounted over lunch at Campero, the local equivalent of Kentucky Fried Chicken, another plan was put into operation. The child would be sold for adoption to the US for 4,000 quetzales (about £360), and in doing so would become one of the growing number of babies who have helped to make this Central American country of 11m people the fourth largest provider of children for adoption after Russia, China and South Korea.

"He had never been violent before but he threatened to kill the children if I did not agree," said Ms de Leon. "We went to see a lawyer and I was told just to listen and not to talk. He was very aggressive. I was very nervous with all the pressure."

With the cooperation of her husband's family, she was moved out of the city and into a house in a nearby town where she was kept in seclusion until just before the baby was due. She was taken to a gynaecologist who gave her a stronger anaesthetic than she had had for her first two children. When she came round, she said, the baby was gone. This was December 3, 1996. It was not until December 23 1998 that they were reunited.

With the help of several organisations and lawyers, Ms de Leon and her mother fought to find the child and have her returned. Ms de Leon's husband, from whom she is now separated, argued that she had willingly consented to the adoption and had only later changed her mind.

After two years of legal action, she won custody of the child, Melissa. "She was afraid of me at first," she said. "She had never left the house before and she started to cry."

In a cafe in Zone One of Guatemala City, an area so crime-ridden that security guards with shotguns and pistols seem to hover on every street corner, Gustavo Tobar sits with a folder of papers. They contain the address in the east of the US where his son is now living with adoptive American parents. He, too, said the child was taken against his will and for money.

Mr Tobar said his son and stepchild were both taken into an institution after a neighbour who looked after them had claimed they were being maltreated. He later discovered that the neighbour had links with a lawyer who assisted in the adoption process. He and his former partner are fighting to regain the children by proving that the adoption was illegal. He believes he has a good chance of success.

"I would love to talk to the children but I am afraid that if I make contact, they [adoptive parents] would move," he said.

Last month, the UN published a report on the sale of children by a special rapporteur, Ofelia Calcetas-Santos. It concluded that legal adoption appears to be the exception rather than the rule in Guatemala. "Since huge profits can be made, the child has become an object of commerce rather than the focus of the law."

Ms Calcetas-Santos suggested that "trafficking of babies and young children for inter-country adoption exists on a large scale. The system lends itself to the nefarious practice of reducing children to commercial objects to be offered to the highest bidders."

The report claimed there are casas de engordeza - "fattening houses" - where babies are kept while the adoption process goes through and suggested that falsification of documentation was common.

This message is simple and shocking. However, the sweeping nature of the UN report has been attacked and Ms Calcetas-Santos herself admits it had to be researched in great haste. Under the surface the story becomes much more complex. It has to do with with the relationship between rich and poor countries, national sentiment and xenophobia, the power of the church, cross-cultural adoption and the ideology of child-rearing. It is a debate that crosses political lines and creates odd allies as two sides, both inside Guatemala and in the countries where adopted Guatemalan children live, fight to have their side told.

The first time that Guatemalan children were adopted by foreigners in substantial numbers was in the early 1980s at the height of the 36-year civil war when thousands of children had been orphaned and displaced as the military carried out a scorched earth policy of wiping out the Mayan villages which had harboured leftwing guerrillas. In 1996, the year of the peace agreement that has brought a degree of normalcy to the country, there were 731 international adoptions. By 1999, the figure had more than doubled to 1,645 and there are likely to be 2,000 this year, according to Unicef.

In contrast, the total of international adoptions in all other Latin American countries combined now runs at fewer than 100 annually.

Business is booming

The reasons for the increase are many but with the acceptance within North America and Europe of abortion, the decreased stigma of single motherhood and the increase in infertility, would-be adoptive parents started looking abroad. Countries such as Peru, Bolivia and Honduras which used to allow international adoptions have all made it much harder, hence the drift to Guatemala where the Roman Catholic church still campaigns vigorously against contraception.

International adoptions in Guatemala are almost all "privatised", which is to say that they are not organised through the government but by foreign adoption agencies dealing with Guatemalan lawyers. Would-be parents, who are mainly from the US but include a number from Britain and elsewhere in Europe, have to be approved by their own social services in the same way as if they were adopting locally.

The total cost of adoption to a would-be parent ranges from around $12,000 (£8,000) to $30,000. Of this, the agency might take a fee of around $3,000, the Guatemalan lawyers between $10,000 and $15,000 and the mother will receive, in some cases, "expenses" of between $500 and $1,000.

The stories of malpractice have already led embassies including those of the US - where 62% of the adoptions take place - Britain and Canada to introduce DNA tests to ensure that the woman signing over the child is the real mother. The British embassy which oversees a much smaller, albeit increasing, number of cases said there have as yet been no failures of the DNA tests. Frank Neville, the press attache at the US embassy, said that from November 1998 to March 2000 there had been 15 cases out of around 2,500 adoption procedures where the children were shown by DNA tests not to be those of the supposed mother.

Casa Alianza, an organisation that rehabilitates street children and has also taken up the cases of parents seeking the return of adopted children, say that they know of at least 27 cases where a child has been taken for adoption against the parent's will. The Casa Alianza lawyer dealing with cases of alleged abduction for adoption, Amalia Eraso, said: "The most common situation is where the mother is pressured by her husband or a lawyer to give up a child for the money."

Elizabeth Gibbons of Unicef believes that such cases are not isolated. Unicef will be bringing out its own report later this year which she indicated will show that there are many abuses of the process. One of the anomalies, she said, was that there are around 20,000 abandoned or orphaned children in orphanages who were not being adopted partly because the gov ernment process is lengthy and complex, and also because most adoptive parents seek babies rather than older children.

"The lawyers claim that mothers come to them but we believe that the lawyers go looking for them," said Ms Gibbons. She said that one lawyer had explained his fee of $6,000 in terms of the costs of nappies, vaccinations, nannies and milk, a rate vastly beyond the likely costs.

"We are concerned for the best interests of the child. At the moment, the adoptions are being carried out for the best interests of the lawyers and the adoptive parents."

But Rachel Garst, a policy analyst and human rights advocate who has been living in Guatemala for more than 15 years and has two adopted Guatemalan children, believes the adopters' side of the story is rarely heard.

"There is a very sensationalist and disturbing debate going on here," said Ms Garst, who is from Iowa. "People believe that gringos are just waltzing in to purchase children - who knows for what evil ends - and that hundreds of children are being stolen for adoption. All this has been inflamed by sensationalist press coverage."

Ms Garst said the likely result was Guatemalan legislation that would obstruct or delay all international adoptions. "If that happens, the real losers will be the children."

The passion that permeates the adoption debate has had some extreme consequences. Here the story must take a detour to Todos Santos Cuchumatan, a village of 2,000 people 200 miles north west of the capital in the western highlands.

Lying in a valley at the end of winding, unpaved road, Todos Santos has been a place on the backpackers' map for more than two decades. More recently, conventional tour parties have started to visit. The village is accustomed to foreigners; signs in English offer weaving lessons, local restaurants cater to vegetarians.

Almost exactly a year ago, a 15-year-old girl was murdered in Huehuetenango, the nearby capital of the region. The girl's body, which had been mutilated and disembowelled, was left in the local cemetery. A rumour that she had been the victim of a foreign satanic sect circulated. At the end of last month, another rumour or bola (literally a ball) was rolling dangerously down the hills of the western highlands: a satanic sect was supposedly having a meeting in the area and was looking for local children to use in a sacrifice. Such was the strength of the rumour that schools closed throughout the area, including Todos Santos, on Friday 28 April.

The following day, a tour party of 23 Japanese arrived in the village in a bus with darkened windows. They started to mingle in the square. One tourist, 40-year-old Tetsuo Yamahiro, patted a child on the head. A local woman screamed that she had seen a knife and that her child was being stolen. Hysteria spread through the crowd of around 500 and people attacked the tourists with stones and machetes. Yamahiro was killed.

The bus driver, Edgar Castellanos, tried to escape and was attacked so violently that, according to Guido Galli, the local UN monitoring representative, his brains had spilled out of his head. Then he was doused in petrol and set on fire. Within 10 minutes the crowd's rage was spent and two dead bodies lay in the street. Nine people, including a local teacher, have been arrested and are being held in Huehuetenango.

"Have any children ever been stolen from here? No," said the village's mayor, Julian Mendoza. "Have there ever been any satanic sects here? No. Have any children from here been taken from here for adoption abroad? No. We were waiting for Satan to arrive and he never did - but what happened? Satan rose up through us."

Rachel Garst believes that what happened in Todos Santos is an extreme product of a debate that has become too anecdotal and rumour-fuelled; some rumours even suggest that children are kidnapped for their body parts. She is critical of the UN report for adding to the fears although it is not suggested in any way that it led to the lynchings. "Trafficking," she believed, was a loaded term which referred merely to the fact that lawyers were charging high but perfectly legal fees.

Abandoned children

Martha Wallace, who runs an adoption agency in Pennsylvania and is the chair of the Guatemalan caucus of the Joint Council on International Children's Services (JCICS), is also critical of the UN report and described some of the conclusions as "outrageous". She said many of the claims made were anecdotal and without any statistical basis. The effect of stopping international adoption in other Latin American countries has meant that "the orphanages are filled and more and more children are abandoned anonymously."

In response to these criticisms, Ofelia Calcetas-Santos, the lawyer who compiled the UN report, said from her home in Manila that because of time and money constraints she had only been able to spend 10 working days in Guatemala for her research and that her task included investigating not only the sale of children but also child prostitution and pornography. She said that for this reason she could give no statistical evidence to back up her suggestion that legal adoptions were "the exception rather than the rule." She said that "many of the adoptions are legal under certain circumstances ... I am not trying to knock down adoptions if all things are observed."

Adriana Portillo was the daughter and sister of guerrillas who were part of the Revolutionary Organisation of the People in Arms. On September 11, 1981 her two daughters, aged 10 and nine, were staying with her father in the 11th Zone of the Guatemalan capital when members of the military broke into the house and took the girls. She has not seen them since. She has since married and settled in Chicago but has returned to Guatemala once more in the search for her missing daughters by helping to set up the organisation Where Are the Children? In June, it will open its office, hoping that the reconciliation process might throw light on the fate of her girls and the countless others who have vanished and who could be long dead or adopted in Guatemala or abroad.

"I would ride the buses all over Guatemala City staring through the windows, just looking for them," said Adriana Portillo. "I went to the orphanages and to the women's prisons asking if anyone had seen them. But we never found them. They were old enough to remember where they came from and I still think that they might have been adopted."

Guatemala has changed since Adriana Portillo's children were seized but clearly mothers are still being forcibly separated from their children to profit from sale of babies for adoption. The sums that lawyers can make from adoptions may act for some as an incentive. Pressure is building on the authorities to impose a cap on legal fees to send a message that large profits should not be made from children.

What no one, including the UN, yet knows is how widespread forced adoption really is. There are many good-hearted people involved on both sides of the debate. Both those who want to protect vulnerable mothers from exploitation, and those who want to take children out of grim institutions and put them into caring homes.

The report claimed there are casas de engordeza - "fattening houses" - where babies are kept while the adoption process goes through and suggested that falsification of documentation was common. This message is simple and shocking. However, the sweeping nature of the UN report has been attacked and Ms Calcetas-Santos herself admits it had to be researched in great haste. Under the surface the story becomes much more complex. It has to do with with the relationship between rich and poor countries, national sentiment and xenophobia, the power of the church, cross-cultural adoption and the ideology of child-rearing. It is a debate that crosses political lines and creates odd allies as two sides, both inside Guatemala and in the countries where adopted Guatemalan children live, fight to have their side told. The first time that Guatemalan children were adopted by foreigners in substantial numbers was in the early 1980s at the height of the 36-year civil war when thousands of children had been orphaned and displaced as the military carried out a scorched earth policy of wiping out the Mayan villages which had harboured leftwing guerrillas. In 1996, the year of the peace agreement that has brought a degree of normalcy to the country, there were 731 international adoptions. By 1999, the figure had more than doubled to 1,645 and there are likely to be 2,000 this year, according to Unicef. In contrast, the total of international adoptions in all other Latin American countries combined now runs at fewer than 100 annually. Business is booming The reasons for the increase are many but with the acceptance within North America and Europe of abortion, the decreased stigma of single motherhood and the increase in infertility, would-be adoptive parents started looking abroad. Countries such as Peru, Bolivia and Honduras which used to allow international adoptions have all made it much harder, hence the drift to Guatemala where the Roman Catholic church still campaigns vigorously against contraception. International adoptions in Guatemala are almost all "privatised", which is to say that they are not organised through the government but by foreign adoption agencies dealing with Guatemalan lawyers. Would-be parents, who are mainly from the US but include a number from Britain and elsewhere in Europe, have to be approved by their own social services in the same way as if they were adopting locally. The total cost of adoption to a would-be parent ranges from around $12,000 (£8,000) to $30,000. Of this, the agency might take a fee of around $3,000, the Guatemalan lawyers between $10,000 and $15,000 and the mother will receive, in some cases, "expenses" of between $500 and $1,000. The stories of malpractice have already led embassies including those of the US - where 62% of the adoptions take place - Britain and Canada to introduce DNA tests to ensure that the woman signing over the child is the real mother. The British embassy which oversees a much smaller, albeit increasing, number of cases said there have as yet been no failures of the DNA tests. Frank Neville, the press attache at the US embassy, said that from November 1998 to March 2000 there had been 15 cases out of around 2,500 adoption procedures where the children were shown by DNA tests not to be those of the supposed mother. Casa Alianza, an organisation that rehabilitates street children and has also taken up the cases of parents seeking the return of adopted children, say that they know of at least 27 cases where a child has been taken for adoption against the parent's will. The Casa Alianza lawyer dealing with cases of alleged abduction for adoption, Amalia Eraso, said: "The most common situation is where the mother is pressured by her husband or a lawyer to give up a child for the money." Elizabeth Gibbons of Unicef believes that such cases are not isolated. Unicef will be bringing out its own report later this year which she indicated will show that there are many abuses of the process. One of the anomalies, she said, was that there are around 20,000 abandoned or orphaned children in orphanages who were not being adopted partly because the gov ernment process is lengthy and complex, and also because most adoptive parents seek babies rather than older children. "The lawyers claim that mothers come to them but we believe that the lawyers go looking for them," said Ms Gibbons. She said that one lawyer had explained his fee of $6,000 in terms of the costs of nappies, vaccinations, nannies and milk, a rate vastly beyond the likely costs. "We are concerned for the best interests of the child. At the moment, the adoptions are being carried out for the best interests of the lawyers and the adoptive parents." But Rachel Garst, a policy analyst and human rights advocate who has been living in Guatemala for more than 15 years and has two adopted Guatemalan children, believes the adopters' side of the story is rarely heard. "There is a very sensationalist and disturbing debate going on here," said Ms Garst, who is from Iowa. "People believe that gringos are just waltzing in to purchase children - who knows for what evil ends - and that hundreds of children are being stolen for adoption. All this has been inflamed by sensationalist press coverage." Ms Garst said the likely result was Guatemalan legislation that would obstruct or delay all international adoptions. "If that happens, the real losers will be the children." The passion that permeates the adoption debate has had some extreme consequences. Here the story must take a detour to Todos Santos Cuchumatan, a village of 2,000 people 200 miles north west of the capital in the western highlands. Lying in a valley at the end of winding, unpaved road, Todos Santos has been a place on the backpackers' map for more than two decades. More recently, conventional tour parties have started to visit. The village is accustomed to foreigners; signs in English offer weaving lessons, local restaurants cater to vegetarians. Almost exactly a year ago, a 15-year-old girl was murdered in Huehuetenango, the nearby capital of the region. The girl's body, which had been mutilated and disembowelled, was left in the local cemetery. A rumour that she had been the victim of a foreign satanic sect circulated. At the end of last month, another rumour or bola (literally a ball) was rolling dangerously down the hills of the western highlands: a satanic sect was supposedly having a meeting in the area and was looking for local children to use in a sacrifice. Such was the strength of the rumour that schools closed throughout the area, including Todos Santos, on Friday 28 April. The following day, a tour party of 23 Japanese arrived in the village in a bus with darkened windows. They started to mingle in the square. One tourist, 40-year-old Tetsuo Yamahiro, patted a child on the head. A local woman screamed that she had seen a knife and that her child was being stolen. Hysteria spread through the crowd of around 500 and people attacked the tourists with stones and machetes. Yamahiro was killed. The bus driver, Edgar Castellanos, tried to escape and was attacked so violently that, according to Guido Galli, the local UN monitoring representative, his brains had spilled out of his head. Then he was doused in petrol and set on fire. Within 10 minutes the crowd's rage was spent and two dead bodies lay in the street. Nine people, including a local teacher, have been arrested and are being held in Huehuetenango. "Have any children ever been stolen from here? No," said the village's mayor, Julian Mendoza. "Have there ever been any satanic sects here? No. Have any children from here been taken from here for adoption abroad? No. We were waiting for Satan to arrive and he never did - but what happened? Satan rose up through us." Rachel Garst believes that what happened in Todos Santos is an extreme product of a debate that has become too anecdotal and rumour-fuelled; some rumours even suggest that children are kidnapped for their body parts. She is critical of the UN report for adding to the fears although it is not suggested in any way that it led to the lynchings. "Trafficking," she believed, was a loaded term which referred merely to the fact that lawyers were charging high but perfectly legal fees. Abandoned children Martha Wallace, who runs an adoption agency in Pennsylvania and is the chair of the Guatemalan caucus of the Joint Council on International Children's Services (JCICS), is also critical of the UN report and described some of the conclusions as "outrageous". She said many of the claims made were anecdotal and without any statistical basis. The effect of stopping international adoption in other Latin American countries has meant that "the orphanages are filled and more and more children are abandoned anonymously." In response to these criticisms, Ofelia Calcetas-Santos, the lawyer who compiled the UN report, said from her home in Manila that because of time and money constraints she had only been able to spend 10 working days in Guatemala for her research and that her task included investigating not only the sale of children but also child prostitution and pornography. She said that for this reason she could give no statistical evidence to back up her suggestion that legal adoptions were "the exception rather than the rule." She said that "many of the adoptions are legal under certain circumstances ... I am not trying to knock down adoptions if all things are observed." Adriana Portillo was the daughter and sister of guerrillas who were part of the Revolutionary Organisation of the People in Arms. On September 11, 1981 her two daughters, aged 10 and nine, were staying with her father in the 11th Zone of the Guatemalan capital when members of the military broke into the house and took the girls. She has not seen them since. She has since married and settled in Chicago but has returned to Guatemala once more in the search for her missing daughters by helping to set up the organisation Where Are the Children? In June, it will open its office, hoping that the reconciliation process might throw light on the fate of her girls and the countless others who have vanished and who could be long dead or adopted in Guatemala or abroad. "I would ride the buses all over Guatemala City staring through the windows, just looking for them," said Adriana Portillo. "I went to the orphanages and to the women's prisons asking if anyone had seen them. But we never found them. They were old enough to remember where they came from and I still think that they might have been adopted." Guatemala has changed since Adriana Portillo's children were seized but clearly mothers are still being forcibly separated from their children to profit from sale of babies for adoption. The sums that lawyers can make from adoptions may act for some as an incentive. Pressure is building on the authorities to impose a cap on legal fees to send a message that large profits should not be made from children. What no one, including the UN, yet knows is how widespread forced adoption really is. There are many good-hearted people involved on both sides of the debate. Both those who want to protect vulnerable mothers from exploitation, and those who want to take children out of grim institutions and put them into caring homes.

fields.headline: Rock around the shop
fields.standfirst: Elton's big new image
fields.trailText: There are scarier sights than a 60ft tall Elton John towering over Oxford Street - but not many. The shopaholic rocker was last night revealed as the centrepiece of a 900ft long frieze which wraps the entire Selfridges department store in central London.
fields.body:
There are scarier sights than a 60ft tall Elton John towering over Oxford Street - but not many. The shopaholic rocker was last night revealed as the centrepiece of a 900ft long frieze which wraps the entire Selfridges department store in central London.

Sam Taylor-Wood's XV Seconds is a tongue-in-cheek take on the Elgin marbles frieze, with 21 pop cultural icons from actors to pop stars and supermodels adorning the temple of consumerism.

Sir Elton was there to support Taylor-Wood, 33, who has recently received treatment for breast cancer.

She said she conceived the work as a contemporary version of the Elgin marbles with modern day 'gods'.

Nick Cross, of Selfridges, said they were "chuffed" with the work. "We had to clean the building and this is brilliant way of covering an eyesore and doing something really interesting."

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText:
Good day
The Making Hay While The Sun Shines Award goes to William Hague for starting a slow handclap among the ladies of Great Ayton Women's Institute, in North Yorkshire, when he boarded their float at a fete.
fields.body:
Good day
The Making Hay While The Sun Shines Award goes to William Hague for starting a slow handclap among the ladies of Great Ayton Women's Institute, in North Yorkshire, when he boarded their float at a fete.

The impish comic cum Tory leader said: "The WI took our joke in great spirits. It was wonderful to meet them." Unfortunately, many slow-clapped without irony, said onlookers.

Nude of the day
Keith Chegwin whose appearance naked on Channel 5's homage to naturism, the all-nude game show The Naked Jungle, prompted much soul-searching among MPs.

A stern-faced culture secretary Chris Smith warned the nation: "We have noted in recent days very considerable concern about some of the content on television, particularly in relation to Channel 5."

Quote of the day
The latest addition to maligning the struggling Millennium Dome and its government backers comes from the shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, who announced: "The truth is that in its contempt for history, its cheap gimmickry and botched execution, the dome is a perfect symbol of New Labour."

Today
Commons: environment questions; countryside and rights of way bill; short debate on government codes of practice on taxation.
Westminster Hall: backbench debates on derelict and contaminated land in the north-west of England; government response to the sixth report of the committee on standards in public life, opened by Teresa Gorman MP; debate on Cleveland police.
Lords: utilities bill, committee stage.

webTitle: Ethiopia holds up deal to end war

fields.headline: Ethiopia holds up deal to end war
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: Ethiopia and Eritrea appeared close to a ceasefire in their two-year war yesterday after Ethiopia agreed in principle to a peace plan that would put a UN military force along their disputed border.
fields.body:
Ethiopia and Eritrea appeared close to a ceasefire in their two-year war yesterday after Ethiopia agreed in principle to a peace plan that would put a UN military force along their disputed border.

Eritrea, whose negotiating position was hit by recent battlefield losses, had already agreed to the peace plan so Ethiopia's acceptance could lead to a quick ceasefire in a war that has killed tens of thousands of soldiers.

Eritrea, however, said it did not believe its southern neighbour was serious about peace and accused it of "buying time" to prepare new attacks.

The peace proposal calls for both sides to withdraw to positions held before hostilities began in May 1998 and for a UN force to be deployed in a 12.5 mile buffer zone until international arbitrators demarcate their 600 mile border.

The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) mediators said they expected a formal peace agreement would be signed at the end of this week but conceded that differences remain over the definition of the "security zone" and on the role of the UN military force.

After Eritrea agreed to the peace plan on Friday, Ethiopia launched new attacks along the border, raising fears that it was intent on moving even deeper into Eritrea. On Sunday, it gave cautious backing to the peace plan mediated by the OAU.

"Ethiopia remains committed to ensuring a lasting and sustainable solution to the conflict and has agreed in principle to the proposals put forward in Algiers," the government said in a statement.

It said a formal decision would be made by parliament and cabinet after consultations, but it was unclear when Ethiopia's parliament would consider the peace proposal.

Fighting continued early yesterday around the western Eritrean town of Guluj but the rest of the border was quiet.

The Eritrean presidential adviser Yemane Gebremesekel pointed to recent attacks near Eritrea's Red Sea port of Assab and around the town of Senafe on the central front as evidence that Ethiopia wanted to drive deeper into Eritrean territory.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: The drive to introduce competition into the water industry could backfire on domestic consumers, the Consumers' Association warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Association warns on water
The drive to introduce competition into the water industry could backfire on domestic consumers, the Consumers' Association warned yesterday.

The group said competition could lead to higher domestic water bills, especially for households in rural areas, and more customers having to use meters. It said the government was eager to become the first in the world to liberalise water services, but suggested that the expected benefits for consumers might be a pipe dream.

Stanley profits from dot.coms
Charles Stanley, the private client stockbroker, more than doubled its profits last year as small investors flocked to buy shares in dot.com start-ups. The broker's pre-tax profits jumped 103% to £15.2m before tax, largely due to an explosion in demand from November onwards. Charles Stanley has more than 50,000 regular customers, including several Oxbridge colleges. Charles Stanley's shares slipped 12.5p to 650p, having increased sharply last week ahead of the results.

Vodafone takes control of Airtel
Vodafone AirTouch said yesterday it was set to take control of Spain's number two mobile phone company after striking a long-awaited deal with domestic rival BT.

Ending more than a year of wrangling over who should wield power over Airtel, BT said it would allow Vodafone to raise its Airtel stake to 55% from 21.8% if BT could raise its own stake to 45% from 17.8%. BT has managed to swing a deal under which both British companies will have equal board representation in a company that has been valued at around €24bn (£15.2bn).

Equitable fires opening shot
Equitable Life yesterday opened a three-day Law Lords hearing with a warning that hundreds of thousands of policyholders will lose out if the Lords uphold an earlier appeal court ruling.

The insurer, the second largest mutual in Britain, is battling to reverse a ruling in favour of 90,000 pensioners with "guaranteed annuities", which some analysts say could cost the company £1.5bn and throw its future into doubt.

SFA fines WH Ireland
The securities & futures authority said it reprimanded WH Ireland and fined the company £3,000 for failing to maintain adequate financial resources and to notify SFA promptly when resources fell below specified levels.

Government cuts gilt sales
The government will cut back on gilt sales this year, including the cancellation of one of the scheduled auctions, as a result of the bumper proceeds from the sale of third generation mobile phone licences. But it has promised to maintain the planned level of sales on long-dated and index linked stocks after representations from pension funds.

webTitle: Powderject chief's plea fails to impress

fields.headline: Powderject chief's plea fails to impress
fields.trailText: An impassioned plea for patience by Powderject Pharmaceuticals' chief executive, Paul Drayson, backfired yesterday as the group's shares slumped 15% on growing doubts about its needle-free injection technology.
fields.body:
An impassioned plea for patience by Powderject Pharmaceuticals' chief executive, Paul Drayson, backfired yesterday as the group's shares slumped 15% on growing doubts about its needle-free injection technology.

Powderject has developed a method of reformulating drugs into powder, then blasting them through the skin at supersonic speeds. However, a series of setbacks has led to criticism that the process is taking too long to perfect.

In the company's annual results statement, Mr Drayson included a long passage about his experience as a childhood asthma sufferer to plead for patience.

He said that when he was young the only treatments for sudden asthma attacks were tablets, which took too long to work, or unpleasant liquid injections. When inhalers arrived on the market "it was, quite literally, a life saver".

Mr Drayson said Powderject's system could have a similar impact. He admitted some products were taking longer than expected but stressed his "personal commitment" to bringing them to the market.

However, analysts described his comments as "bizarre". Bill Blair of Nomura said: "It's just ridiculous. I've never seen an annual results statement like this."

Powderject's losses almost doubled to £18.4m, due to a 53% fall in revenue to £2.75m. Analysts said the company's income from development partners was much lower than expected, which raised doubts about the progress of some of its drugs.

The company announced several new development programmes yesterday including a link with Swiss drugs group Serono to make Gonal-F, the world's best-selling female infertility treatment, in powder form.

Powderject has been testing this idea on pigs, which have similar skin structure to humans, and clinical trials on humans are due to begin soon.

The group also said it was working on powder-based vaccines against hepatitis B and genital herpes.

But there was little news on the progress of two lead products, a local anaesthetic, Lidocaine, and a treatment for erectile disfunction, alprostadil.

The shares, which touched £10 late last year, fell 60p to 382.5p.

fields.headline: Exchanges in diamond row
fields.standfirst: Petra seeks judicial review of its scuppered takeover of African trader Oryx
fields.trailText: Petra, the diamond exploration company, may seek judicial review of the last-minute about-turn that yesterday scuppered its planned acquisition of controversial gemstone group Oryx, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
Petra, the diamond exploration company, may seek judicial review of the last-minute about-turn that yesterday scuppered its planned acquisition of controversial gemstone group Oryx, it emerged last night.

Hours after it pulled the plans, under threat of losing its listing on the Aim equity market, Petra was locked in meetings with lawyers to decide what to do next.

Petra's advisers, Grant Thornton, told the company on Friday they would resign were the takeover to proceed, which would have had the effect of de-listing Petra's shares. The ultimatum came immediately after a meeting with the London stock exchange.

Yesterday the exchange denied having put pressure on Grant Thornton and the Foreign Office - reported to have been against the deal because of Oryx's links with the governments of Zimbabwe and the Democratic Republic of Congo - denied having put pressure on the exchange.

But a source close to Petra said: "Someone's got to be made accountable for this", adding, when asked if Petra's directors were considering a judicial review of the exchange's behaviour, "clearly they're thinking about it".

At a special meeting of shareholders in London yesterday, chairman Adonis Pouroulis said that in view of the "exceptional circumstances" he had no alternative but to postpone indefinitely the merger proposal.

Mr Pouroulis said he had been unable over the weekend to obtain a full explanation as to Grant Thornton's actions on Friday night.

He said Grant Thornton had conducted extensive due diligence of Oryx and this had disclosed nothing untoward.

Mr Pouroulis added: "Grant Thornton have announced publicly that they concluded their due diligence process satisfactorily ... [and] that this process has cast no doubt on the probity of Petra, Oryx, its directors, any of its main shareholders or the proposed acquisition of Oryx."

Grant Thornton officials yesterday confirmed the company had threatened to resign should the deal go ahead.

"As nominated adviser our primary responsibility is to the London stock exchange. As such we have a responsibility to maintain the reputation and integrity of the market," they said.

They added they had noted recent statements attributed to government ministers and had taken part in discussions with the "regulatory authorities" - which they declined to define - during the last few weeks, "the most recent of which took place late on the evening of Friday June 9 ... these discussions led us to conclude that ... [we] could no longer act [as Petra's adviser] if the acquisition of Oryx Natural Resources were to proceed".

The Foreign Office said it had held no discussions specifically about Oryx with either the exchange or the City regulator, the Financial Services Authority, but said so frequent were general discussions with the FSA that it was impossible to say whether or not the topic had ever arisen.

Oryx is based in the Cayman Islands and managed from Oman. It denies that its Congo diamond concession makes it a producer of the type of "conflict" gems - precious stones the profits from which are used to fuel wars in Africa - despite the revenue sharing arrangements it has in place with companies connected to both the DRC government and the government of Zimbabwe, allies in the Congo's continuing civil struggle.

He said Grant Thornton had conducted extensive due diligence of Oryx and this had disclosed nothing untoward. Mr Pouroulis added: "Grant Thornton have announced publicly that they concluded their due diligence process satisfactorily ... [and] that this process has cast no doubt on the probity of Petra, Oryx, its directors, any of its main shareholders or the proposed acquisition of Oryx." Grant Thornton officials yesterday confirmed the company had threatened to resign should the deal go ahead. "As nominated adviser our primary responsibility is to the London stock exchange. As such we have a responsibility to maintain the reputation and integrity of the market," they said. They added they had noted recent statements attributed to government ministers and had taken part in discussions with the "regulatory authorities" - which they declined to define - during the last few weeks, "the most recent of which took place late on the evening of Friday June 9 ... these discussions led us to conclude that ... [we] could no longer act [as Petra's adviser] if the acquisition of Oryx Natural Resources were to proceed". The Foreign Office said it had held no discussions specifically about Oryx with either the exchange or the City regulator, the Financial Services Authority, but said so frequent were general discussions with the FSA that it was impossible to say whether or not the topic had ever arisen. Oryx is based in the Cayman Islands and managed from Oman. It denies that its Congo diamond concession makes it a producer of the type of "conflict" gems - precious stones the profits from which are used to fuel wars in Africa - despite the revenue sharing arrangements it has in place with companies connected to both the DRC government and the government of Zimbabwe, allies in the Congo's continuing civil struggle.

webTitle: Output prices stay flat despite fuel costs

fields.headline: Output prices stay flat despite fuel costs
fields.trailText: The strength of the competitive pressures facing manufacturing was exposed yesterday when official figures showed that firms absorbed the largest ever increase in fuel and raw material costs on their margins last month, keeping output prices almost flat.
fields.body:
The strength of the competitive pressures facing manufacturing was exposed yesterday when official figures showed that firms absorbed the largest ever increase in fuel and raw material costs on their margins last month, keeping output prices almost flat.

The prices of goods leaving the factory gates rose by just 0.1% in May, despite a 3.6% jump in input costs, the highest monthly rise since the series began in the 1980s, according to the office for national statistics. Most of the increase was due to oil costs.

Brent crude prices have risen from below $12 a barrel 18 months ago to more $30 this week, despite an informal agreement among Opec countries to open the taps and increase output if prices rose above $28.

"The recent rebound in the oil price was the culprit behind today's surge in input price inflation," said James Carrick of ABN-AMRO. "However, even if the oil price remains at its current levels, producer input price inflation should ease as last year's sharp monthly increase in the oil price drop out of the comparison."

Subdued factory gate inflation will be a relief the Bank of England's monetary policy committee as producer prices are seen as a warning signal for inflationary pressures.

"Today's data underscore the benign inflation outlook," said Mr Carrick. "Even when faced with double-digit input price inflation, manufacturers' output prices have remained relatively subdued."

webTitle: Election boost for Milosevic divides Montenegro

fields.headline: Election boost for Milosevic divides Montenegro
fields.standfirst: Serbia: special report
fields.trailText: Yugoslavia's president Slobodan Milosevic has won an important political victory in Serbia's sister republic of Montenegro after voters strongly backed his supporters in a key local election and rebuffed proponents of independence.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's president Slobodan Milosevic has won an important political victory in Serbia's sister republic of Montenegro after voters strongly backed his supporters in a key local election and rebuffed proponents of independence.

In a poll seen as a partial referendum on the republic's future the 'Yugoslavia Coalition' took control of the coastal town of Herceg Novi from the pro-western government of President Milo Djukanovic, gaining 19 seats compared with the 13 they had before.

Since becoming the republic's leader three years ago Mr Djukanovic has broken with Belgrade, introduced the German mark as an official currency and no longer recognises the federal government.

He has won strong backing from the United States and European Union, although they do not support outright independence and have urged him to be cautious in not going so far as to risk civil war.

The Yugoslav army has a powerful garrison in Montenengro which has regularly flexed its muscles by taking control of border points and issuing conscription notices to prominent anti-Belgrade journalists and politicians.

Mr Djukanovic has created a paramilitary police as a counterweight and both sides accuse each other of preparing for civil war.

The preliminary results from Sunday's poll show the polarisation of society but will reinforce Mr Djukanovic's cautious approach. His party did well in elections in the capital Podgorica and gained an extra seat - to give it a total of 28 in the 54-seat council - while the pro-Belgrade SNP lost one.

The big losers in both places were the pro-independence Liberals who provoked the elections by walking out of coalitions with Mr Djukanovic. They expected the tensions of the last two years would have strengthened the case for immediate secession. But they lost ground.

The pro-Serb forces tend to be concentrated in inland cities closer to the Serbian border but Herceg Novi has always had a high proportion of Serb migrants from Bosnia and Hercegovina. Since the collapse of Tito's Yugoslavia, the new headquarters of the Yugolav navy are nearby.

Mr Djukanovic, who had earlier predicted victory in both towns, put a brave face on the result. "Today we can say for sure that Montenegro is marching on a stable, democratic, reformist path and that no one can distract it from that path," he said. "Our victory in Podgorica is much better and greater than our defeat in Herceg Novi," he added.

Predrag Bulatovic, a leader of the pro-Belgrade block, said afterwards the vote proved that the people of Montenegro, who are mainly Orthodox Slavs, wanted to live with fellow-Slav Serbia.

"In this election the citizens showed they were for the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia," Mr Bulatovic said, adding that the victory in Herceg Novi meant his party, already strong in the north, now held one-third of Montenegro's 21 municipalities.

The next dilemma for Mr Djukanovic's government is whether to take part in the federal elections which President Milosevic is likely to call later this year. To his chagrin, Western governments have been urging the Montenegrin leader not to boycott them.

"The international community should conduct a more careful analysis", Miodrag Vukovic, the President's legal adviser, complained recently. "The federal elections are just another of Milosevic's manipulations. If we reject them, he will accuse us of being separatists. If we take part, we will be repudiating all our previous statements."

After Sunday's poll results the dilemma has become more acute.

webTitle: Now Scoot cashes in on French connection

fields.headline: Now Scoot cashes in on French connection
fields.trailText: The creeping takeover of Britain plc by Vivendi, the French conglomerate, continued yesterday with its agreement to fund the purchase of Loot, the free ad newspaper, by Scoot.com.
fields.body:
The creeping takeover of Britain plc by Vivendi, the French conglomerate, continued yesterday with its agreement to fund the purchase of Loot, the free ad newspaper, by Scoot.com. Presumably there is synergy somewhere among all that water, electricity, trains, telecoms, internet portals and pay TV.

But with Scoot (which added the dot.com suffix at the height of net mania), Vivendi's unflinching backing seems particularly strange - if only because this company reinvents itself with such regularity that the French cannot, by definition, know what they are buying.

First it was called Freepages, and everyone called it a "talking yellow pages" until BT started complaining. As part of a plan for continental domination the name changed to Scoot, then the idea was to have a membership-only online directory service, pitched at an executive club of high-worth customers. Next came the dot.com and now along comes the online auctioneer idea - about two years too late.

Along the way, just about every figure on subscriber levels and revenue has either disappointed or been challenged. Meanwhile, at board level, the young chief executive Robert Bonnier has still to explain his strange record on personal share dealings and his relationship with a man, Ronald Zimet, who allegedly routed £2m in bribes to former officials at the Co-op and who is now primed as a witness for the serious fraud office. Vivendi must know something that eludes the rest of us.

Powder blues
Sentimentality plays poorly among hard-nosed City analysts, as Powderject Pharmaceuticals' boss, Paul Drayson, found out to his cost yesterday. After a difficult year for the powder-based medicines company, he tried to win some sympathy by recount ing his harrowing years as an asthmatic child.

His "I feel your pain" approach is sincere and he believes the firm's technology can be of great help to patients. But he glossed over the small matter of a 96% leap in year-end losses and the market was distinctly unsympathetic, marking the shares down 15%.

The idea behind Powderject is promising. The company's technology blasts tiny amounts of powder through the skin at 1,400 miles per hour - roughly the speed of Concorde. The process is painless, avoids needlestick injuries and is much more accurate than liquid injections. But progress has been stilted, to say the least. One of the biggest initial hopes was alprostadil, a product for erectile dysfunction which has to be blasted into the penis. Unfortunately, Viagra has popped up to corner the market, as have various creams - which have obvious advantages in their application.

The other lead product is Lidocaine, an anaesthetic. In a sudden about-turn last year, the group doubled its target market by including children, which meant extra trials and a two-year delay in profits.

The problem for Powderject is that medicines need completely reformulating in order to turn them into powders - which means a full set of clinical trials even for well-worn treatments, taking many years. Other companies using needle-free liquid "guns" can get to the market much more quickly, albeit with a less accurate product.

A curious deal yesterday involved PA Consulting taking a £1.1m equity stake in Powderject and some observers wonder whether the management consultants are providing services needed because of an exodus of key staff. All this is curious because in Drayson Powderject has a seasoned businessman at the helm. Far from being a wild-haired scientific entrepreneur, he is a veteran of Austin Rover and Cadbury-Schweppes. Unfortunately for him, people are beginning to wonder whether Powderject is going down the well-trodden path of drugs firms promising too much and finding it painful to deliver.

fields.headline: Bomber 'exhilarated' by media spotlight
fields.trailText: David Copeland, the nail bomber, dreamed of his day in court - and believed it was his destiny, a police doctor told the Old Bailey yesterday.
fields.body:
David Copeland, the nail bomber, dreamed of his day in court - and believed it was his destiny, a police doctor told the Old Bailey yesterday.

The Nazi sympathiser, who killed three people and injured 129 during his bomb campaign last spring, said he felt "exhilarated" by the media coverage of his devastation and "cheated" when other groups began to claim responsibility, said the doctor, Peter Dean.

Copeland, 24, whom he examined four times after his arrest in May last year, told him: "I planned this. I have been dreaming about it for ages - doing what I did, getting caught, going to court - it is my destiny."

Dr Dean said: "He said he felt exhilarated by the newspapers when he saw the photograph of where he lived.

"He was looking forward to going to court. There was no suggestion of any concern or stress. He was exceptionally calm."

The surgeon added that he could find no evidence that Copeland, who has admitted causing explosions in Soho, Brick Lane, and Brixton, had delusions, hallucinations or thought disorders. "There was no sign at the time that he was suffering from a mental illness," he added.

But he had recommended that Copeland, who told him he had stopped taking his medication for panic attacks a month earlier, be kept under observation while in police custody.

"There was no suggestion of any suicide intent. He maintained an exceptional degree of calmness ... It was almost surprising, the matter-of-factness with which he approached the whole thing."

The jury also heard from Paul Mifsud, a colleague of Copeland on the Jubilee Line extension, and the man who identified him to police.

Mr Mifsud, who described working with Copeland as "five months of total anger about everything", spoke of his disbelief when someone in a cafe showed him a newspaper photograph of the Brixton bomber and asked if it was Mungo - the name by which he called Copeland.

The engineer took the paper to Copeland's father, Stephen Copeland. "I said, 'Doesn't it look like David?' He replied: 'Yes, it does look a bit like him, but he has not got a white hat.' I just let it go."

But after work he felt compelled to look at the newspaper pictures once more. When he got in, he told his wife, and she told him to ring the police.

Mr Mifsud also spoke of his colleague's anger with his parents, whom the nailbomber claimed were convinced he was gay, and his fascination with serial killing.

Under cross-examination, he said they had talked about Brixton, Brick Lane, the killing of Jill Dando, and a high school shooting in the US.

"I think I said how terrible it was, what was going on in the world - shooting and the bombings. He said: 'Great, isn't it - all these things happening'."

Copeland pleads not guilty to murder on the grounds of diminished reponsibility.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with film director Andy Tennant
fields.trailText: Getting personal with film director Andy Tennant
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym, and if so why?

No I haven't, but as a director I can always use Alan Smithee - although I think I'd quit before it actually came to doing that.

Have you ever lied about your age, and if so why?

No, I'm rather proud of the fact I've actually made it 44 years without being thrown in jail.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Well-meaning middle-aged guy, just doing the best he can.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

I went to Vegas. Let's leave it at that.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Played P-Ball (infant base-ball) with my kids, even though I didn't want to.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Jodie Foster. I guess you knew I'd say that.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

JO.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

Yes.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Education.

What would you never advertise?

It depends.

What wakes you up screaming at 4am?

My mortgage.

What takes you to a happy place?

My house.

Andy Tennant's Anna And The King is available to rent on video (Fox Pathe)

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Summer Of 1940/File On 4
fields.body:
In his second programme about The Summer Of 1940 (9.0pm, Radio 2), Michael Aspel talks to some of the pilots and civilians who withstood the Luftwaffe's 15-week bombardment in the Battle of Britain. Morale was sustained in part by reports of the Germans' huge aircraft losses. We know now, of course, that the figures were wildly exaggerated. German archives later showed that the 185-plane total claimed for September 15 - Battle of Britain day - was overstated by two-thirds.

The apparent rehabilitation of Britain's neo-Nazi movement is analysed by Mark Whitaker in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4). In line with far right gains in other European countries, the British National Party secured up to 20 per cent of the vote in last month's local elections. The BNP's focus on sensitive rural issues such as the farm crisis brightened its previously thuggish image. But have the major parties helped with their tough stance on asylum seekers?
