fields.headline: A fool and his money
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Last night's TV:True Stories: Pimp Snooky
fields.body:
Alot of waffle has been talked and written about TV alternatives to football as we enter the scheduling free-for-all that is Euro 2000. But if you wanted to escape far, far away from sport last night, Channel 4 had the dream ticket - or, as it turned out to be, nightmare. True Stories: Pimp Snooky was one of the most infuriating, depressing and exhilarating pieces of television to come this way for a long time - a trip deep, deep into the underworld in the demonic company of Milwaukee's premier procurer.

Snooky, a handsome man in his late 20s or early 30s, ran a stable of prostitutes from a smart-looking house in the city. He cruised around in his flash Mercedes looking for fresh talent: "gonna find me a new bitch today", he said, putting on his headhunter's charm. It didn't last long. Once the new bitch, a hapless creature named Mika, had been recruited, she was subjected to a programme of mental torture that left her - and viewers - gasping with shock.

Pimp Snooky was filmed over a 12-month period last year by Clive Gordon, a man who clearly knows no fear in pursuit of a good story. Such was the rapport between film-maker and subject that Snooky allowed Gordon to witness the most revealing moments of his life: knocking his girls around, trying to stay calm during a drive- by shooting, or coming sheepishly out of prison. He emerged, blinking and shaken, into the daylight, his drab sportswear in sharp contrast to his more usual pimp threads. "I look like a trick", he complained. "They treated me like a trick."

You might have expected the film to reveal a warm, caring side to Snooky, or to have led us to understand and perhaps sympathise with his way of life. But as he showed more and more of himself, we could only come to loathe him. His treatment of his women - and their terrified, brainwashed compliance - was jaw-droppingly horrible. He employed his nephew, a young man of about 19, to attempt to seduce the girls under concealed video surveillance; if they succumbed, they faced the wrath of "Daddy". He nutted Mika on the forehead, and would have done much worse had he not suddenly become aware of the camera's presence. He bragged endlessly about his financial acumen, and even organised a glitzy party (The International Players' Convention) to celebrate the pimp lifestyle.

If all this sounds disgusting, it was - and yet it was impossible to stop watching. The Players' Convention was shown in slow-motion, the girls writhing obediently at the feet of their men, a carnival vision of hell. Mika's training by two of her "wives-in-law", Fantasia and Unique, was a ridiculous parody of sisterhood. "You say yes and no, you call him Daddy at all times, you walk behind him, open doors, wait for him to get out of the car before you do. He puts his ho's on pedestals. He treats us like queens, so we gotta treat him like a king." And Snooky was a king in his own kingdom, a dictator no less. God help the girl who stepped out of line. Mika, who, it transpired, was only 18 and unprepared for life on the game, had her wrathful family on Snooky's tail, and we feared for her life.

Gratifyingly, this little dystopia began to fall apart in the final section of the film. After the tacky climax of the Convention, Snooky spent a night in prison, endured gunmen shooting at his house and, we suspected, had heavier foes than Mika's irate uncle to deal with. The enemy was at the gates, and it was hard to fathom what was going on. Snooky remained calm throughout, but he was running scared. At the time of transmission, Snooky was in prison - probably the safest place for him, and it's a miracle that one of his bitches didn't pick up a gun and blow his head off first.

Clive Gordon deserves to be showered with awards for having the guts to bring back this report from the pit. fields.bodyText: Alot of waffle has been talked and written about TV alternatives to football as we enter the scheduling free-for-all that is Euro 2000. But if you wanted to escape far, far away from sport last night, Channel 4 had the dream ticket - or, as it turned out to be, nightmare. True Stories: Pimp Snooky was one of the most infuriating, depressing and exhilarating pieces of television to come this way for a long time - a trip deep, deep into the underworld in the demonic company of Milwaukee's premier procurer. Snooky, a handsome man in his late 20s or early 30s, ran a stable of prostitutes from a smart-looking house in the city. He cruised around in his flash Mercedes looking for fresh talent: "gonna find me a new bitch today", he said, putting on his headhunter's charm. It didn't last long. Once the new bitch, a hapless creature named Mika, had been recruited, she was subjected to a programme of mental torture that left her - and viewers - gasping with shock. Pimp Snooky was filmed over a 12-month period last year by Clive Gordon, a man who clearly knows no fear in pursuit of a good story. Such was the rapport between film-maker and subject that Snooky allowed Gordon to witness the most revealing moments of his life: knocking his girls around, trying to stay calm during a drive- by shooting, or coming sheepishly out of prison. He emerged, blinking and shaken, into the daylight, his drab sportswear in sharp contrast to his more usual pimp threads. "I look like a trick", he complained. "They treated me like a trick." fields.headline: Wild thing
fields.standfirst: She was a hip, drunk junkie just looking for a good time. And she was the craziest thing that a young  Jenny Fabian  had ever seen. Does BBC2's new profile get anywhere close to the truth about her?
fields.trailText: She was a hip, drunk junkie just looking for a good time. And she was the craziest thing that a young Jenny Fabian had ever seen. Does BBC2's new profile get anywhere close to the truth about her?
fields.body:
Janis Joplin, far-out chick singer, was sitting with her band in the Speakeasy, mecca for off-duty musicians. She was in London circa 1969 to play the Albert Hall with her new group, the Kozmic Blues Band. What you could see of her face was pale, unmade-up, her red hair looked coarse and hung like curtains across her cheeks. She wore a tall Cossack hat, and she looked done-in.

A couple of nights later she came running onto the stage at the Albert Hall, dripping with beads, her emotional extremities cranked up, stomping her feet, hair now shimmering like a wild and glorious red aura as she shook and wriggled with rhythm and gave out with a voice cracked with the blues. It was unbelievable for a chick to be so wild and abandoned: the apparition, the sound, the vibe sent tingles down our spines. We'd never seen anything like it, she blew us away, it was the best hit.

I was excited to get invited back to her hotel with the entourage of freaks that were milling around backstage. But as we entered her suite she was waving everyone back out again, distraught, dishevelled. One of the band had OD'd and was lying in the bath, being resuscitated by a half-dressed groupie. Life on the road.

Janis's myth has grown over the years. She's become a bit of a template for liberation. She was outspoken, and made great copy. "I just wanted to get stoned, get laid, have a good time." Didn't we all, but it wasn't as easy as it sounds, back then, over 30 years ago, to act like "one of the boys", and Janis paid a price for taking the guys on at their own game.

Reputations: Southern Discomfort takes a look at Janis's life. Re-analysing her in the aftermath of feminism, all the sad old clichés of the female condition are dredged up. Lurking deep inside the ballsy chick who'd made it in a guy's world, which rock'n'roll most definitely was in those days, was a straight, middle-class gal who wanted nothing more than to settle down behind white picket fences. Janis wanted a "bear of a mountain man, throwing boulders, subduing nature," explains a remarkably healthy-looking survivor of Big Brother and the Holding Company, "but those kind of guys never came to the gigs".

Big Brother were a head group from the San Francisco underground music scene. The twisted sound of stoned guitars pierced our disordered reason, and Janis filled the void with her soul-crazed voice. To hear her singing Ball And Chain was like an intravenous depth charge. "That song's gonna get you a lot of lovers", a friend had told her. Making love with Janis could be an alarming experience, according to one senior hip photographer in Clark Kent spectacles. "There was a desperate rush for gratification that could frighten", he tells us, and I wonder if that's what turned his hair so white.

Janis was haunted by the dreary 50s role models she had rejected. Pimples made her hate herself. You'd think from this programme she never had a good time. Letters home to "The Great Nowhere" (Port Arthur, Texas) reveal that she longed for her parents' approval, but she was always onto a loser there, for to be a rock'n'roll singer wasn't considered a respectable career move in middle America, whatever your gender. She had taken the step beyond and could never go back, although she tried a couple of times, with disastrous results.

Southern Discomfort gives us glimpses of the husky, funky Janis in excerpts from some live interviews. You can feel her, coming towards you, hungry for love, drenched in patchouli and bright satin, feathers flying, bangles jangling, bottle in one hand, telling you about Zelda (Mrs F Scott) Fitzgerald's philosophy of self-determination, and rounding it all off with that famous cackle.

Being a right-on chick, Janis liked to dabble with the chicks in bed as well as the guys, and sometimes both at once. In fact, she liked to dabble with anything that made her feel good. "I want to smoke dope, take dope, lick dope, suck dope and fuck dope", she said. Although she was an acid-culture icon, psychedelics weren't her trip. When the big time beckoned in the shape of Albert Grossman (then Bob Dylan's manager), she left Big Brother wandering in their psychedelic fog. Murmurs from the counter-culture hinted that she had betrayed the hip spirit.

There was no reason for her to die that night, considering she'd finally got together the band she really wanted, Full Tilt Boogie, and was on the verge of completing her brilliant album Pearl. But the endless broken romances, the heavy drinking, the smack, the pressure of an enormous ego - yet at the same time thinking she was "the biggest piece of shit in the world" - were an obvious recipe for oblivion. "Janis was a real person, man", said Jerry Garcia (of the Grateful Dead) shortly after her death. "She was just like the rest of us, fucked-up, strung-out, in weird places. She was on a real hard path. She picked it, she chose it."

Reputations, tonight, 9pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Le Samourai/ Ronin/ The Boston Strangler/The Devil Thumbs A Ride
fields.body:
Le Samourai

(Jean-Pierre Melville, 1967)

6pm, FilmFour

In the annals of cine-cool, Alain Delon's silent hitman - played in trenchcoat, fedora, and the shadows - is an icon. His Costello, after committing murder in a nightclub, is hounded by police and by double-crossing villains. He's a cold anti-hero made human only by a samurai-like adherence to his code of honour. Delon's then wife, Nathalie, plays his girlfriend and alibi, while Cathy Rosier is witness to the crime and François Périer the cop and nemesis. Truly a Melville masterpiece.

Ronin

(John Frankenheimer, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

More modern samurai types: the ronin referred to here were 47 warriors wandering the land and looking to avenge their slain master; their present-day counterparts are a gang of veteran crooks contracted to recover a suitcase and its unknown contents. The gang - including Robert De Niro, Jean Reno and Sean Bean - has a likeably worldy air.

The Boston Strangler

(Richard Fleischer, 1968)

11pm, Bravo

Harrowing dramatisation of the serial killer's reign of terror in Boston in the early 60s. It looks like an American cousin to the director's other evocative study of a real-life murderer, Christie, in 10 Rillington Place. To play the strangler, Tony Curtis transformed those pretty-boy looks - and was never better. Henry Fonda leads the hunt; while Sally Kellerman finds herself among the victims. Paul Howlett

The Devil Thumbs A Ride

(Felix E Feist,1947)

12.20am, FilmFour

Ted North's Jimmy Ferguson is a rather square, upstanding businessman taking a road trip for a job. Unable to resist helping out his fellow man in distress, he picks up a hitch-hiker (Lawrence Tierney) who turns out to be a killer on the run with nothing to lose, and that's where his troubles begin. A low-key film noir with unremarkable performances from its two leads, but still stylish, with a sombre, understated mood and a sense of imagination compensating for a minuscule budget.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Start spreading The News

Put away those chainsaws and that blood-soaked axe as the eternally family-friendly Huey Lewis (pictured) arrives in the country this week, with somnambulant backing band The News mere yards behind. Over for no apparent reason other than to rock the Shepherd's Bush Empire as only he knows how on Wednesday evening, Lewis will almost certainly be performing his soulful classic Hip To Be Square, recently the musical backing to a particularly visceral moment of butchery in Mary Harron's American Psycho, but mysteriously absent from the subsequent soundtrack. Well, not really mysteriously at all, bearing in mind that poor Huey had just been held up as the epitome of everything faceless, soul-crushing and just plain wrong to do with 80s corporate America. And, let's face it, for the kind of artistic mind that Huey's got, that could only constitute the gravest of insults. So, people, remember to show your support on Wednesday night. Oh, go on.

Rivers Cheap

Meanwhile, as we're merrily traipsing through the dank waters of 80s nostalgia, let's give a warm-ish welcome to sometime comedienne Joan Rivers, the woman who once made a name for herself making mildly vituperative and faintly risqué comments about Nancy Reagan. So, she's over to offer similarly hilarity-packed insights into the possible sex lives of Hilary Clinton and Tipper Gore, right? Not a bit of it. No, Rivers will actually pitch up on Thursday for a three-day stint flogging her personal jewellery range on well-known cable shopping channel QVC. Should you be interested, Joan would like you to know - via her website - that "my dream was to create a line of affordable, classic pieces for today's woman, timeless jewellery that doesn't go out of style", before going on to explain that she's always "loved jewellery with a passion rivalled only by Marlon Brando's for buffets". No, Joan, stop. You're killing me.

fields.headline: Kermit 'Kim' Roosevelt
fields.standfirst: US president's grandson who masterminded CIA coup to restore the Shah of Iran
fields.trailText: President Theodore Roosevelt would have been proud of his grandson Kermit, who faithfully followed the family tradition of speaking softly and carrying a big stick. As head of the Central Intelligence Agency's Middle East division in 1953, Kermit "Kim" Roosevelt, an ever-shadowy figure who has died aged 84, masterminded the overthrow of Iran's nationalist prime minister, Mohammed Mossadegh.
fields.body:
President Theodore Roosevelt would have been proud of his grandson Kermit, who faithfully followed the family tradition of speaking softly and carrying a big stick. As head of the Central Intelligence Agency's Middle East division in 1953, Kermit "Kim" Roosevelt, an ever-shadowy figure who has died aged 84, masterminded the overthrow of Iran's nationalist prime minister, Mohammed Mossadegh.

This coup, organised from a Tehran basement by a handful of agents using vast sums of the Eisenhower administration's money, ensured America's domination of Iran for the next 25 years - an influence that ended only when Ayatollah Khomeini overthrew the Shah in 1979.

The 1953 crisis had begun two years earlier, when the ultra-nationalist Mossadegh was elected prime minister with the support of the Tudeh (Communist) party. He immediately nationalised the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, convincing the British - and the outgoing Truman administration in Washington - that he was laying the ground for a communist takeover.

Part of Mossadegh's case (subsequently sustained by the international court of justice) was that the British government was making more money from taxing the company than Iran was getting in royalties. But Winston Churchill rejected all Mossadegh's efforts to mediate the issue. In November 1952, after America had overwhelmingly elected his friend Dwight Eisenhower to the presidency, Churchill approached Kim Roosevelt, asking him to plan the overthrow of Mossadegh, and then to sell the idea to the incoming Republicans.

This was not difficult, given the views of the new secretary of state. John Foster Dulles believed the US to be the world's only protection against domination by the Soviet Union, then in the volatile aftermath of Stalin's death. In June 1953, with the comment, "So this is how we get rid of that madman Mossadegh," Dulles presented Roosevelt's plan to a small group of his senior advisers.

Operation Ajax went through on the nod, and Kim Roosevelt was sent to Tehran to carry it out. By this time, Mossadegh had become increasingly dictatorial and erratic, and was fast losing parliamentary support. On August 3 1953, having organised a plebiscite to dissolve parliament, he claimed an overwhelming vote in favour. He dissolved the legislature and organised massive street demonstrations against the Shah and the US.

In response, Roosevelt launched Operation Ajax. He took a number of pro-Shah army officers into the local CIA compound, and persuaded the Shah to sack Mossadegh and name the army commander, General Fazlollah Zahedi, as the new head of government. As expected, Mossadegh had the Shah's emisarry arrested and refused to resign. But he also organised more street demonstrations.

It seemed that the planned coup had failed disastrously. The Shah fled to Baghdad, Zahedi went into hiding and Roosevelt was advised to make himself scarce. He refused and, as uncontrolled rioting continued for three more days, persuaded Zahedi to broadcast warnings of a military clampdown. According to one later account: "The Iranian army was thoroughly bribed and the police force fixed. Some of Mossadegh's more powerful supporters were quietly spirited away, their throats slit, and their bodies buried in the Elburz mountains."

Roosevelt now induced the senior army officers he was sheltering to bring their units on to the streets to disperse the mob. They did so with surprising ease, and arrested Mossadegh and many anti-Shah officers. The Shah flew back to Tehran to see the swift trial and execution of his foreign minister and a large number of army officers. Mossadegh was given three years' imprisonment, eventually served as house arrest.

After he had finished that sentence, Kim Roosevelt was reported to have persuaded the Shah to grant the ex-prime minister a generous pension, paid until he died in 1967. Roosevelt himself melted back into the CIA shadows, reputedly to turn down an offer to do it all over again in Guatemala.

His biographical details have always been kept sketchy. He was born during the first world war in Argentina, where his father worked as a banker, but came back to America at an early age. He did well at Harvard, and worked briefly after graduation as a history teacher in California. When the US joined in the second world war, he was assigned to the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), the cloak-and-dagger operation which eventually became the postwar CIA. Roosevelt's responsibilities there included involvement in planning the allied invasion of Italy.

In the 1950s, as the senior regional CIA man, he certainly acted as a frequent intermediary with the Egyptian officers who toppled King Farouk. With his local expertise and contacts, he tried to persuade Dulles not to pursue such blindly anti-communist policies in the Middle East. The secretary of state's obtuse disregard of this advice led to President Nasser's infuriated nationalisation of the Suez canal - and Anthony Eden's disastrous response.

After Roosevelt left the CIA, he was commissioned to write the official history of the OSS, lobbied on behalf of American business in the Middle East and pushed the Shah's and other Middle Eastern leaders' interests on Capitol Hill. Possibly to his own discomfort, he once attracted an unusual public tribute from a fellow spy. In 1977, the British defector Kim Philby responded from his home in Moscow to a question from the author Leonard Mosley.

"I first met Kim Roosevelt in Washington," Philby wrote, "where he was in charge of Wisner's Middle East department. Oddly enough, I dubbed him 'the quiet American' five years before Graham Greene wrote his book. He was a courteous, soft-spoken Easterner with impeccable social connections, well-educated rather than intellectual, pleasant and unassuming as host and guest. An equally nice wife. In fact, the last person you would expect to be up to his neck in dirty tricks."

Roosevelt's wife, Mary, and their three sons survive him.

Kermit 'Kim' Roosevelt, secret agent, born 1916; died June 8 2000

Mossadegh was given three years' imprisonment, eventually served as house arrest. After he had finished that sentence, Kim Roosevelt was reported to have persuaded the Shah to grant the ex-prime minister a generous pension, paid until he died in 1967. Roosevelt himself melted back into the CIA shadows, reputedly to turn down an offer to do it all over again in Guatemala. His biographical details have always been kept sketchy. He was born during the first world war in Argentina, where his father worked as a banker, but came back to America at an early age. He did well at Harvard, and worked briefly after graduation as a history teacher in California. When the US joined in the second world war, he was assigned to the Office of Strategic Services (OSS), the cloak-and-dagger operation which eventually became the postwar CIA. Roosevelt's responsibilities there included involvement in planning the allied invasion of Italy. In the 1950s, as the senior regional CIA man, he certainly acted as a frequent intermediary with the Egyptian officers who toppled King Farouk. With his local expertise and contacts, he tried to persuade Dulles not to pursue such blindly anti-communist policies in the Middle East. The secretary of state's obtuse disregard of this advice led to President Nasser's infuriated nationalisation of the Suez canal - and Anthony Eden's disastrous response. After Roosevelt left the CIA, he was commissioned to write the official history of the OSS, lobbied on behalf of American business in the Middle East and pushed the Shah's and other Middle Eastern leaders' interests on Capitol Hill. Possibly to his own discomfort, he once attracted an unusual public tribute from a fellow spy. In 1977, the British defector Kim Philby responded from his home in Moscow to a question from the author Leonard Mosley. "I first met Kim Roosevelt in Washington," Philby wrote, "where he was in charge of Wisner's Middle East department. Oddly enough, I dubbed him 'the quiet American' five years before Graham Greene wrote his book. He was a courteous, soft-spoken Easterner with impeccable social connections, well-educated rather than intellectual, pleasant and unassuming as host and guest. An equally nice wife. In fact, the last person you would expect to be up to his neck in dirty tricks." Roosevelt's wife, Mary, and their three sons survive him. Kermit 'Kim' Roosevelt, secret agent, born 1916; died June 8 2000

fields.headline: Jonathan Solomon
fields.standfirst: Brilliant mandarin behind BT privatisation
fields.trailText: Jonathan Solomon, who has died aged 61, was a senior civil servant and the intellectual architect of the privatisation of telecommunications in Britain.
fields.body:
Jonathan Solomon, who has died aged 61, was a senior civil servant and the intellectual architect of the privatisation of telecommunications in Britain.

As under-secretary in the Department of Trade and Industry in the early 1980s, he had responsibility for telecommunications policy. At that time, privatisation was uncharted water, and telecommunications was a complex area, requiring an understanding of its technical, political, economic and social dimensions. This was a perfect vehicle for Jonathan's talents and he, more than any other individual, crafted the legislation for what was the first, and most successful, privatisation.

Jonathan had a superb mind. He went to Clifton College, and then to King's College, Cambridge, where he collected a starred first in classics and completed most of the work on a thesis. He sought to combine academic life with a career in the civil service, but only succeeded in irritating both parties. Eventually, he opted for the civil service but, throughout his career, he informed his work, and sustained his nimble and inquiring mind, through academic links in various parts of the world.

He was never a conventional person. As principal private secretary (1974-77) to Shirley Williams, then secretary of state for prices and consumer protection, he is remembered for his ability to write a superb speech on a complex subject at short notice, sitting on his desk in preference to at it; and for keeping the office going while doing a little teaching at Cambridge, and operating a small decorating business in the evenings and at weekends. Occasionally, he would appear in Williams's private office in paint-spattered jeans and spotty hair.

Jonathan was always his own man, with his own ethical framework and priorities, and, in the mid-80s, having tested ministers' patience to the limit, this led to his departure from the DTI. Eric Sharp, then chairman of Cable and Wireless, took him in as director of special projects. He thrived in the entrepreneurial climate of the times, tirelessly exploring opportunities for the company and achieving, by sheer tenacity, a valuable position for C&W in the difficult Japanese market.

There was nowhere too remote or too uncomfortable to travel. He did not need much sleep, and he was not strong on time zones. On one occasion, he called his secretary from the other side of the world. Her husband informed him that it was 3am in Britain, and that his wife was away. "I don't suppose you take dictation?" inquired Jonathan.

He had an instinctive sense of which countries would be important in the burgeoning global telecommunications market. Many years before the event, he talked about the transformation of the telephone companies and the rise of the internet. He had a gift for identifying the right destination and articulating its rationale, though he was not the best person to plan the journey. Jonathan was responsible for C&W's new business development, and brought to the company more ideas and opportunities than they could possibly handle or afford. Many of these have validated his judgment by becoming huge commercial successes. He also brought his consummate skills with words and, although an executive director of a major public company, he was never too proud or status-conscious to ghost-write the speaking briefs for his board colleagues - if it helped C&W's strategic objectives.

Jonathan was also a visionary with a strong sense of patriotism. It was always his ambition to see the creation of a world-class UK telecommunications company through the alliance of C&W and British Telecom. Towards this end, he maintained personal contacts in BT and took many risks over the years. He worked tirelessly to remove obstacles to the merging of the two companies in 1996, and was deeply disappointed when this did not occur.

Threaded through his life were many supportive strands: love for, and of, his family, particularly his wife, Hester, and his son, Gabriel; friendships all over the world; enjoyment of tennis; lifelong support for Arsenal; personal travel - revisiting the India of his childhood, walking in Sinai, exploring the silk route; and a childlike curiosity about whatever was new. An important part of his legacy is the young talent he nurtured; at least two chief executives of successful telecoms companies, and others he encouraged, have flourishing businesses.

Serious illness struck at the point of retirement. He faced it philosophically and bore its harshness with courage and dignity. To the last, he was discovering new things and dispensing advice on the next telecom alliances. He leaves a rich legacy, some of which he saw being taken forward by the next generation.

Jonathan Hilali Moise Solomon, civil servant, businessman and academic, born March 3 1939; died May 21 2000

fields.headline: Shay Brennan
fields.trailText: The footballer Shay Brennan, who has died aged 63, was two months short of his 21st birthday when he made his debut for Manchester United, then a club in turmoil. It could hardly have been a more spectacular or professionally gratifying event.
fields.body:
The footballer Shay Brennan, who has died aged 63, was two months short of his 21st birthday when he made his debut for Manchester United, then a club in turmoil. It could hardly have been a more spectacular or professionally gratifying event.

The club was reeling from the impact of the Munich air crash on February 6 1958, in which eight players died, when Brennan pulled on a senior red shirt for the game against Sheffield Wednesday. Such was the uncertainty surrounding the formation of the team that Jimmy Murphy, in charge while Sir Matt Busby fought for his life in a Munich hospital, was unable to name his makeshift 11 for an FA Cup tie. Eleven blank spaces appeared in the programme instead of players' names.

In that emotional atmosphere, Brennan, then a winger, scored twice in United's 3-0 victory. That was a third of the total number of goals he eventually scored in 355 games for the club, before he became player-manager of Waterford in August 1970.

Brennan graced football at club and international level as a right fullback, switching from attack to defence as smoothly and as elegantly as another Republic of Ireland captain, John Carey, had done years earlier, also while wearing United's colours.

He was born of Irish parents in Manchester, and became a fledgling footballer with Manchester schoolboys, a prolific purveyor of talent, especially in those days. He turned professional with United in April 1955, and went on to become the first "non-Irishman" to play for the republic, making 19 appearances for the country he adored and respected with equal passion to England.

Football in Brennan's days was a stage of expression; United men - under Busby's guidance and Murphy's back-up - were encouraged to play as much from the heart as from the head. Brennan fitted easily and contentedly into the format on the field; off it he had an Irishman's casual charm and was eminently sociable.

"He was one of the nicest boys in football," recalled John Doherty, a leading member of the Manchester United Former Players' Association. "He could be hard, but, above all, he was a players' player and a true footballer."

Wembley in 1968 was the background to the finest hour for Brennan and United. It had always been Busby's ambition to smash the barriers set by English officialdom, and lead his team to success in the European Cup, won for Britain for the first time a year earlier by Glasgow Celtic. Brennan had already won championship medals in 1965 and 1967. To the enthusiastic golfer that he was, being a member of the team that finally overpowered the elegant Benfica of Portugal 4-1 after extra time was a hole in one.

In later years, Brennan's life was dogged by heart problems, although that could not sour his love of life and golf, his sporting passion since he ceased to play football. Like many others of his time, he would have been ill at ease amid the razzmatazz and fast cars of today's footballers. He was a family saloon driver, grateful to have the strength to be still playing golf, and to die at the Tramore Club near Waterford.

fields.headline: Peter Kershaw
fields.trailText: Peter Kershaw, who has died aged 85, was chairman of the family brewer Joseph Holt, and the man who gave cheap beer to generations of Manchester drinkers. Beer in Holt's Manchester pubs remains some of the cheapest in the country; it is only in recent years that the £1-a-pint barrier has been breached for its mild ale.
fields.body:
Peter Kershaw, who has died aged 85, was chairman of the family brewer Joseph Holt, and the man who gave cheap beer to generations of Manchester drinkers. Beer in Holt's Manchester pubs remains some of the cheapest in the country; it is only in recent years that the £1-a-pint barrier has been breached for its mild ale.

Of the more than 6,000 family brewing companies that were operating in England in 1900, only 34 are left. Holt's is one of them, dating from the middle of the 19th century, when Manchester was a centre of opportunity. It was then that Joseph Holt, the son of a handloom weaver - and Peter Kershaw's great-great-grandfather - bought a beer house and established a small brewery behind it. At the time, it was safer to drink beer than the local water, and, by the 1890s, business was flourishing.

Such was the power and importance of the brewer that men could, in those days, rise from humble beginnings to the highest echelons of society, and Joseph Holt's son, Edward, was created a baronet in 1916. The "beerage" was born.

Peter Kershaw himself went to work in the brewhouse after the second world war, becoming brewery manager in 1953. Following the death of his uncle, the then company chairman, Sir Edward Holt, in 1968, he became chairman, a position he held until his death.

A private man with high principles, he considered himself a custodian of the family assets - the pubs and the people. The core thing, he believed, was a sense of well-being, community and identity, and the privilege of handing it on to another generation. He was a dogged supporter of real ale, and consistently refused to change the company's traditional brews when, in the 1960s, the keg beer revolution began. In the 1970s, Holt's even brewed a lager.

Kershaw ran no-nonsense, no-frills pubs for working people, many of which were frequented by students, attracted by the cheap prices. They, in turn, became ambassadors for Holt's, and the company's name travelled far beyond the trading area around its Empire Street brewery.

In 1971, Kershaw wrote: "I believe that the public have realised that many independent breweries brew what might be called an old-fashioned draught beer, as opposed to keg and tanker beer, and that the price is considerably less. It is, of course, more trouble to look after, but I believe something the customer is looking for."

This steadfast belief in real ale ensured that Holt's beer remains the same. The legacy that Kershaw hands on - his son, Richard, is chief executive - is that a pint of Holt's bitter tastes much as it always has done.

He is survived by his wife Heather, and three children, Margie, Rosie and Richard.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Love lost
fields.body:
Somerset

We turned off the road that leads from Frome six miles Northwest to Radstock. Frome was once a crowded cloth-making centre which Cobbett compared with Manchester, and until recently Radstock's coalfields were active, but we were passing between gatelodges into a secluded park of some 800 acres whose great lake, glades, green valleys and groves have prompted comparisons with paradise. Only the occasional glimpse of one tall factory chimney, and, in recent years, the busy passage of golf-trolleys across the sward, register the existence of a world of action. Henry Newbolt came here courting and wrote: "I bathed in the lake... it was like a bit of fairyland - glassy waters, kingfishers, silence everywhere - I was alone and felt like Adam in early days".

The narrow drive winds through mature parkland with quaint lodges picturesquely set on banks and framed by copse's. After more than two miles we saw, off to the right and in an overgrown wooded enclosure, first some crumbling outhouses and then a dark, deserted chateau. Further on again, another mile and a half, was a decaying castellated gatehouse. It rose from a jungle of cow-parsley and nettles and was entangled in the tentacles of climbing plants that had once made elegant decoration. The broken portcullis gate made a barrier to the world outside.

We turned back to look for the church which was the object of our pilgrimage. The way was from beside the chateau down a pitted track. Ahead, in the valley, were dark woods. We came to another lodge there, but could still see no sign of a church. Then a muddy lane led through dripping undergrowth to a footbridge and across to a tiny island at the lake's edge. On the island stood the ancient church. Virginia Woolf's mother, a pre-Raphaelite beauty, married, at the age of 19, a son of the chateau up on the hill. He died only three years later. No one, she claimed, could have known such extremes of happiness and grief as she. Although reputedly undemonstrative, she was remembered to have come to stretch herself on his grave in this churchyard. The setting looked aptly desolate.

fields.headline: The road to the future
fields.standfirst: We've got pickling down to a fine art, and now we're getting to grips with robot pets. Jonathan Glancey visits a remarkable exhibition of human knowledge
fields.trailText: We've got pickling down to a fine art, and now we're getting to grips with robot pets. Jonathan Glancey visits a remarkable exhibition of human knowledge
fields.body:
"From this weekend the low road to knowledge is closed." So wrote the German critic Urich Raulff in response to the opening of Seven Hills: Images and Signs of the 21st Century in the heart of old Berlin. Raulff's is a wonderful sentiment, mapping the opposite road to the one travelled by the organisers of the Millennium Dome, that monument to the beating down of knowledge, the throttling of the human imagination.

Seven Hills, in the newly restored Martin Gropius Bau, a grand 19th-century civic palazzo, is a brave and relatively inexpensive attempt to present a survey of human knowledge, and its limits, at the beginning of the 21st century. (It cost DM28m - less than £10m - compared with the dome's £758m-plus.) Such an encyclopedic enterprise could easily crack at the seams of its own pretension, and the organisers, Bodo-Michael Baumunk and Gereon Sievernich, have trodden a fine line between edification and entertainment. Their distinctive show, a map of the human mind, negotiates this cultural divide without stumbling or falling. If you like Sir John Soane's Museum in London or the Pitt-Rivers Museum in Oxford, if you like surfing the net or picking books at random from well-stocked library shelves, Seven Hills will be alive for you. If you like the dome, save the air fair to Berlin and stock up the deep freeze instead.

Seven Hills is helped enormously by being held within a grand old building in the centre of one of the world's most compelling cities. Unlike the old-fashioned Hanover Expo, with its sledgehammer appeal to nationalist sentiment (my pavilion's better than yours), Seven Hills attempts to immerse visitors in a universal experience of what it means to be alive at a time when exhilarating and frightening new technologies are opening up, when we can look deep into the universe at both macro and micro levels: in one direction into the furthest perceptible depths of interstellar space, in the other down into the world of cells, of Watson and Crick's DNA spiral.

We understand this infinite universe by placing ourselves and our world at its centre. So the design of this modern cabinet of curiosities is centred around a glowing model of the Earth, in a brooding, cathedral-like hall re-dressed for the occasion by Ken Adam, the great film set designer (Goldfinger, Dr Strangelove, The Madness of King George and so on). Adam's living earth, a ball of magma and fire, is set like some ancient religious idol atop a skeletal, space programme-style pyramid. This chariot of fire is surrounded by some of the magnificent machines and devices humankind has invented to explore the Earth and outer space.

In a darkly theatrical atmosphere, the visitor is encouraged to peer pruriently into the preserved skull of René Descartes, to walk through a section of a particle accelerator, to meet the latest humanoid robot (courtesy of those clever people at Sony) and to watch robot dachshunds play football. If this sounds a mish-mash of conflicting ideas and objects, it doesn't feel like it: one experience or exhibit prompts the next. This is a multi-layered show, a brave mix of objects drawn from historic collections, of ideas written up intelligently in captions that do not talk down to their audience, and interactive computer technology. And it works.

Adam's Nucleus is surrounded on two floors by sections labelled Cosmos, Jungle, Civilisation, Faith, Knowledge and Dream, designed imaginatively by a mix of architects (Lebbeus Woods, and Lars Gräbner and Gerrit Grigoleit from Daniel Libeskind's office), set designers and artists. Together they have created an enfilade of galleries that present our hopes, desires, dreams and ideas in a way that stirs the imagination. The Space gallery is an entertaining mixture of objects ranging from children's comics and Thunderbird-style toys and models to the most adult insights into quests for worlds where no man or woman has gone before.

The Jungle section brings out the way in which humans have slaughtered and enslaved their fellow species while celebrating their variety and beauty. There are illuminated cases of exotic insects and birds, pickled bodies of just about everything that might have lived and, most tellingly of all, real-time video projections of magnificent, if bored, tigers in the Berlin and Leipzig zoos.

The show is just the right size, an intense yet enjoyable and provocative experience that shows how today's museums and galleries could layer collections of objects with the latest in computer and presentation technology while employing imaginative architects and set designers to create the drama needed to entertain visitors even while they are learning. Its captions are well written - script-written in fact - so that they tell stories visitors enjoy reading rather than the clumsy, pseudo-academic guff you find in all too many museums worldwide.

Seven Hills isn't perfect, but it's an antidote to the absurd dome and outmoded expos. Already, there are well grounded fears in Germany that the Hanover Expo will not attract the number of visitors its organisers have trumpeted. This isn't surprising: today so much knowledge - ersatz, precise, weird, global and wonderful - is available from so many sources that the great exhibition-style show has all but lost its purpose. What makes more sense is the show that captures the imagination, that, as far as its curators can manage, interprets our gloriously complex world.

In Berlin, Baumunk and Sievernich have adopted the role of Oracle. Berlin is their Delphi. You may have had more than your fill of millennial exhibitions by now, but these Seven Hills are well worth climbing.

Seven Hills is at the Martin Gropius Bau, Niederkirchnerstrasse 7, Berlin, till October 29. Details: 00 49 30 25 48 60.
fields.bodyText: "From this weekend the low road to knowledge is closed." So wrote the German critic Urich Raulff in response to the opening of Seven Hills: Images and Signs of the 21st Century in the heart of old Berlin. Raulff's is a wonderful sentiment, mapping the opposite road to the one travelled by the organisers of the Millennium Dome, that monument to the beating down of knowledge, the throttling of the human imagination. Seven Hills, in the newly restored Martin Gropius Bau, a grand 19th-century civic palazzo, is a brave and relatively inexpensive attempt to present a survey of human knowledge, and its limits, at the beginning of the 21st century. (It cost DM28m - less than £10m - compared with the dome's £758m-plus.) Such an encyclopedic enterprise could easily crack at the seams of its own pretension, and the organisers, Bodo-Michael Baumunk and Gereon Sievernich, have trodden a fine line between edification and entertainment. Their distinctive show, a map of the human mind, negotiates this cultural divide without stumbling or falling. If you like Sir John Soane's Museum in London or the Pitt-Rivers Museum in Oxford, if you like surfing the net or picking books at random from well-stocked library shelves, Seven Hills will be alive for you. If you like the dome, save the air fair to Berlin and stock up the deep freeze instead. Seven Hills is helped enormously by being held within a grand old building in the centre of one of the world's most compelling cities. Unlike the old-fashioned Hanover Expo, with its sledgehammer appeal to nationalist sentiment (my pavilion's better than yours), Seven Hills attempts to immerse visitors in a universal experience of what it means to be alive at a time when exhilarating and frightening new technologies are opening up, when we can look deep into the universe at both macro and micro levels: in one direction into the furthest perceptible depths of interstellar space, in the other down into the world of cells, of Watson and Crick's DNA spiral. We understand this infinite universe by placing ourselves and our world at its centre. So the design of this modern cabinet of curiosities is centred around a glowing model of the Earth, in a brooding, cathedral-like hall re-dressed for the occasion by Ken Adam, the great film set designer (Goldfinger, Dr Strangelove, The Madness of King George and so on). Adam's living earth, a ball of magma and fire, is set like some ancient religious idol atop a skeletal, space programme-style pyramid. This chariot of fire is surrounded by some of the magnificent machines and devices humankind has invented to explore the Earth and outer space. In a darkly theatrical atmosphere, the visitor is encouraged to peer pruriently into the preserved skull of René Descartes, to walk through a section of a particle accelerator, to meet the latest humanoid robot (courtesy of those clever people at Sony) and to watch robot dachshunds play football. If this sounds a mish-mash of conflicting ideas and objects, it doesn't feel like it: one experience or exhibit prompts the next. This is a multi-layered show, a brave mix of objects drawn from historic collections, of ideas written up intelligently in captions that do not talk down to their audience, and interactive computer technology. And it works. Adam's Nucleus is surrounded on two floors by sections labelled Cosmos, Jungle, Civilisation, Faith, Knowledge and Dream, designed imaginatively by a mix of architects (Lebbeus Woods, and Lars Gräbner and Gerrit Grigoleit from Daniel Libeskind's office), set designers and artists. Together they have created an enfilade of galleries that present our hopes, desires, dreams and ideas in a way that stirs the imagination. The Space gallery is an entertaining mixture of objects ranging from children's comics and Thunderbird-style toys and models to the most adult insights into quests for worlds where no man or woman has gone before. The Jungle section brings out the way in which humans have slaughtered and enslaved their fellow species while celebrating their variety and beauty. There are illuminated cases of exotic insects and birds, pickled bodies of just about everything that might have lived and, most tellingly of all, real-time video projections of magnificent, if bored, tigers in the Berlin and Leipzig zoos. The show is just the right size, an intense yet enjoyable and provocative experience that shows how today's museums and galleries could layer collections of objects with the latest in computer and presentation technology while employing imaginative architects and set designers to create the drama needed to entertain visitors even while they are learning. Its captions are well written - script-written in fact - so that they tell stories visitors enjoy reading rather than the clumsy, pseudo-academic guff you find in all too many museums worldwide. Seven Hills isn't perfect, but it's an antidote to the absurd dome and outmoded expos. Already, there are well grounded fears in Germany that the Hanover Expo will not attract the number of visitors its organisers have trumpeted. This isn't surprising: today so much knowledge - ersatz, precise, weird, global and wonderful - is available from so many sources that the great exhibition-style show has all but lost its purpose. What makes more sense is the show that captures the imagination, that, as far as its curators can manage, interprets our gloriously complex world. In Berlin, Baumunk and Sievernich have adopted the role of Oracle. Berlin is their Delphi. You may have had more than your fill of millennial exhibitions by now, but these Seven Hills are well worth climbing. webTitle: Outrage over amnesty for apartheid killer

fields.headline: Outrage over amnesty for apartheid killer
fields.standfirst: The Truth and Reconciliation Commission decision on the murder of Ruth First is to be tested in a judicial challenge
fields.trailText: The unexpected amnesty given to one of the most notorious murderers of South Africa's apartheid era is to be challenged with a judicial review, lawyers for the family of two of the victims said yesterday.
fields.body:
The unexpected amnesty given to one of the most notorious murderers of South Africa's apartheid era is to be challenged with a judicial review, lawyers for the family of two of the victims said yesterday.

Craig Williamson, the former police spy, was given amnesty last week for the murders of Ruth First, Jeanette Schoon and her six-year-old daughter, Katryn. The judicial review is being sought on behalf of the Schoon family and will allow for the reopening of a civil case for damages brought against Williamson on behalf of Schoon's son, Fritz, who witnessed the death of his mother and sister.

Yesterday, Robyn Slovo, one of First's three daughters, said: "We were deeply shocked by the amnesties which are completely unwarranted and unfair - but we have not decided whether we can take the pain of going through another judicial process, and we're still consulting our lawyers."

The case is a high-profile challenge for South Africa's supreme court and for its Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC). The extraordinary reputation of Nelson Mandela, and the high profile of Archbishop Desmond Tutu, largely legitimised South Africa's Faustian pact of truth without justice.

The TRC unravelled many of the heinous crimes of the apartheid regime from the confessions of perpetrators. Many families were able to confront the men who tortured and killed their loved ones, and many bodies were uncovered and reburied.

The work of the TRC established the hidden history of apartheid, making it impossible for history to be rewritten. But in granting amnesty to Williamson, and to bomb-maker Jerry Raven, the TRC got neither truth nor justice.

The central point of Williamson's amnesty request in the First case was that he did not see the name on the envelope containing the letter bomb - the implication was that perhaps he thought the letter had been addressed to First's husband, Joe Slovo.

Mr Slovo, as the key figure in the African National Congress's (ANC) military strategy, could be considered a legitimate target for the apartheid regime; whereas First, an academic in Mozambique, though still a member of the ANC and the Communist party, was not.

Raven, the maker of the bomb, also claimed he did not see who it was addressed to. During the TRC amnesty hearings, the three judges appeared extremely sceptical of this evidence and under the law, amnesty requires full disclosure, which brings into question the decision of amnesty.

Extraordinarily, the judgement does not refer to Williamson's well-known hatred of Mr Slovo. Williamson told stories of the room with the steel ring that was specially reserved in Vlakplaas police training farm for the day when they captured Joe Slovo.

Nor does it take into consideration his relationship with Jeanette Schoon, a teacher in the southern Angolan town of Lubango and wife of a Communist party leader, Marius Schoon.

As part of his undercover police work, Williamson had infiltrated the student organisation Nusas and was elected to the leadership in 1974-75. Jeanette was on the national executive of Nusas with him, before her marriage. The Schoons were among those in the ANC who suspected him of being a spy and created the atmosphere which forced him to blow his cover and flee back to South Africa. Williamson undoubtedly knew this, though he chose to deny it repeatedly to the TRC.

Williamson is well known to have been a highly successful spy, and high up in the apartheid regime's disinformation network. He has, for instance, admitted that he planted the story in a South African newspaper that British and US intelligence sources believed that Mr Slovo had killed his wife.

By choosing to believe Williamson, despite his history as an arch-deceiver, the amnesty commission has accepted the killing of two women academics and activists, and a six-year-old girl, as legitimate acts of war; it has blurred the line between combatant and non-combatant. In other societies these would be war crimes, to be tried and punished.

Under South Africa's TRC, Williamson and Raven would have walked free without controversy if they had been seen to have told the truth. They have not been.

Within hours of the announcement of amnesty, local radio station presenters were crying and songs were being dedicated to the victims' families. The outrage being expressed about these two high-profile cases reflects the disillusion of many township victims profoundly disappointed by their own experience of amnesties given to police, and by the slowness and inadequacy of reparations payments.

The ANC is already paying a political price for its perceived failure to look after its own. These cases will be a symbol of that failure.

Williamson and Raven may be able now to resume normal life in South Africa, but they are among seven former policemen, including the former police chief, General Johann Coetzee, who bombed the ANC office in north London in 1982 and were given amnesty in South Africa.

As such, if they ever came to Britain they would face trial, the Foreign Office minister, Peter Hain, confirmed earlier this year.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Shots fired at Fiji rebel leader
fields.body:
Shots fired at Fiji rebel leader

Soldiers in Fiji opened fire on a car carrying the coup leader George Speight yesterday. They hit the car but missed the rebel who is holding 31 hostages in the parliament building.

Rebel spokesman Joe Nata claimed the attack was an assassination attempt, but the army blamed bad judgment by soldiers at a checkpoint.

Several rebels were arrested near the roadblock. But they were quickly released after Mr Speight's side threatened to harm the hostages who have now been in captivity for more than three weeks.

Congo oil minister held

Security services in the Democratic Republic of the Congo have detained Pierre-Victor Mpoyo, the oil minister. Three other ministers have been detained for over a week, but no charges have so far been announced.

Mr Mpoyo's detention coincides with a severe fuel shortage in Kinshasa and a dispute with the neighbouring Central African Republic, which has accused Kinshasa of using export oil stocks without its authorisation. Mr Mpoyo has denied the accusations on television.

Chechen hostage freed

Russian special forces freed a French photographer who had been held hostage by Chechen rebels for more than eight months. Brice Fleutiaux's captors had demanded a ransom of $1.5m for his release.

His wife has flown to meet him in Moscow and the couple are expected home in France later today.

Hare Krishna rape charges

Forty-four former students of Hare Krishna boarding schools filed a $400m lawsuit yesterday alleging 20 years of sexual, physical and emotional torture.

The case names the International Society of Krishna Consciousness and 17 of the group's leaders. An attorney, Windle Turley, said the case included rape, abuse and torture of children as young as three.

Last year, Hare Krishna leaders pledged $250,000 a year to investigate past abuse and aid survivors.

webTitle: Wine, women and the poor of Pompeii

fields.headline: Wine, women and the poor of Pompeii
fields.standfirst: A new book says the super-rich of the ancient Roman city kept resentment at bay by supplying prostitutes, booze and gladiatorial bouts
fields.trailText: The ancient Roman city of Pompeii seethed with massive economic inequality which plutocrats tried to quell with subsidised sex, wine and gladiatorial spectacles for the masses, according to a new book.
fields.body:
The ancient Roman city of Pompeii seethed with massive economic inequality which plutocrats tried to quell with subsidised sex, wine and gladiatorial spectacles for the masses, according to a new book.

Daily life was blighted not by rumbles from Vesuvius but by the yawning income gap betweeen neighbours and friends. The upper class was so rich it could spend more on one banquet than a senior imperial bureaucrat would earn in a year, according to Antonio Varone, author of Pompeii: the Mysteries of a Buried City.

Citing documents recently found on the site, the former director of the excavations painted a picture of a city riven by inequality.

"There was an extraordinarily well-off class that really enjoyed itself," he told the newspaper La Repubblica. "From the excavations we have seen that there was a huge part of the population that lived in poverty, that struggled with daily life."

Those on the bread line whose resentment risked turning violent were placated with subsidised prostitutition and wine, Mr Varone said.

"The masses were helped in this way, the powerful wanted them to remain tranquil." Entry to the amphitheatre to watch chariot races and combat between gladiators and animals was free.

Mr Varone said he had uncovered written evidence of the way in which the spectacles were financed, and the number of gladiators who took part. Inequality existed in most ancient Roman towns but Pompeii appears to have been extreme, possibly because it was a holiday resort where rich outsiders acquired second homes.

Laid out in a grid pattern with two intersecting streets, the rich took a whole block for themselves. Last month a luxury hotel and restaurant complex was discovered just outside the town during the widening of a motorway.

Built on the River Sarno with views of the bay of Naples, Villa Moregine is believed to have been intended for visiting businessmen. It had marble and bronze fixtures, and thermal baths and the latest technology, including plumbing valves to recycle water from the kitchens and laundry to provide central heating.

Private dining rooms each had couches for diners, a small fountain and wall paintings. Slabs of cut marble were stacked in a corner, suggesting work on the building was continuing when Pompeii was buried by volcanic ash and mud from Vesuvius in August AD79.

Subsidising games was regarded as a duty for wealthy citizens across the empire, but Pompeii would be unusual if entrance was totally free, said Michael Whitby, professor of classics at the University of Warwick.

"There is no doubt they went in for conspicuous consumption in the bay of Naples. It was the riviera for the elite."

The writer Petronius satirised over-the-top expenditure in his story about Trimalchio, a freed slave made good who flaunts his fortune in an epic feast to which everyone is invited.

According to Mr Varone, uncovered written testimonies have revealed that an earthquake jolted Pompeii just days before Vesuvius erupted, obliging historians to revise their accounts of the ensuing rescue operations.

Money could have been decisive in determining who survived, said Prof Whitby. "The wealthy would have had a second house to run to, they would have had mules and carts to pack their belongings, they would have had jewels and other portable valuables."

He went on: "The poor would have been slower. If their livelihood was a fast food joint, a shop or a small field, it would have taken longer to pack up and escape."

fields.headline: Free thinkers abhor royals
fields.trailText: The Guardian clearly enjoyed trumpeting its latest poll (Support for royal family falls to new low, June 12). The spectacular slide in royal popularity is down to a growing indifference to the Windsors, your home affairs editor suggests.
fields.body:
The Guardian clearly enjoyed trumpeting its latest poll (Support for royal family falls to new low, June 12). The spectacular slide in royal popularity is down to a growing indifference to the Windsors, your home affairs editor suggests.

That growing indifference is clearly not shared by whoever decreed that G2 should run a 16-page royal issue to tie in with the poll's findings. Of course, those incredibly unpopular royals do sometimes have an incredible effect on newspaper sales, don't they?

I'm sure many of your readers will have enjoyed the royal pullout - particularly the opening article by self-confessed republican Christopher Hitchens. At least he doesn't pretend to be a man of the people: anyone who launches a critique of the royals with the words "my driver..." must, at the very least, have a sense of humour or more in common with the objects of his scorn than he realises.

Free thinkers - don't you just love them?

Captain Dennis Abbott
Loughton, Essex
dennis@abbott27.fsnet.co.uk

 I went to Cheltenham Ladies College and my brother went to Eton so I can say with some authority that William's choice of educational establishment is an unrealistic training ground for real life. How many 45-year-olds, let alone 13-year-olds, have private maids, door-to-door dry cleaning services and a swimming pool and golf course on their doorstep?

Christina Sanderson
London

 Why are we inflicted with a whole G2 issue devoted to this unsupported royal family? Is this a way of reinforcing reasons not to support them, or is the Guardian trying to increase support? The fact that half the population does not support them is all the information I required. Like the royal family, maybe the Guardian should have stopped while it was ahead.

Jane Welsh
Lincoln
welsh@postmaster.co.uk

 Is it really necessary for you to feed on the media frenzy of the tabloids, as William's 18th birthday approaches? Are you not lowering yourself to the level of the tabloids? Of course, I haven't bothered to read the articles as they are not worthy of my attention.

Dr Robert Pleass
London
R.Pleass@ucl.ac.uk

 A 44% approval rating is a result that any political party would give their eye teeth for. Perhaps the drop in popularity of the royal family is a case of mid-term blues.

Lord Redesdale
House of Lords

 As amusing and wilfully tabloidal as it was, Oliver Burkeman's review (Ladies in waiting, June 12) of likely consorts for Prince William overlooks two things. The lucky lady is probably aged 10-12, and Camilla has a pea in readiness for the mattress test.

Ross Roberts
London

 Re Ladies in waiting, has Mohamed Al Fayed no eligible daughters?

Dave Sang
Bognor Regis, West Sussex

 The monarchy are just a particularly nauseating, high-profile fragment of an oppressive global "civilisation" based on the ruthless domination and exploitation of the majority of the population of the UK and the world. Humanity is capable of so much better. Let's do it.

Dave Morris
London
mclibel@globalnet.co.uk

 It would be nice to receive a day or two's notice whenever you intend to publish a "royal issue." Then we could cancel the paper before the full horror of it lands on the doorstep.

Tom Locke
Burntisland, Fife

 So, the only place where a majority believe it better to have the Queen as head of state is Australia.

Malcolm Shifrin
Leatherhead, Surrey

fields.headline: Who needs the Royle family?
fields.standfirst: Richard Billingham's latest show focuses even closer on the lives of a poor Birmingham family. The result, writes  Adrian Searle, is heartbreaking
fields.trailText: Richard Billingham's latest show focuses even closer on the lives of a poor Birmingham family. The result, writes Adrian Searle, is heartbreaking
fields.body:
Richard Billingham's photographs and videos of his family are now familiar. We know them all: overweight, tattooed, animal-loving Liz. Rheumy, red-eyed husband Ray. Younger brother Jason, now a dad. The flora and fauna of the Billingham household - the dogs, cats, goldfish, snakes and flies - are as much protagonists in the photographs as the people themselves.

As Michael Tarantino writes in his elegant essay for Billingham's solo exhibition at Birmingham's Ikon Gallery, the dogs are fully fledged participants in the family circle, but give nothing away. We must ask how much we think we know, where we are in this. We study the closed world that Billingham charts - the alarming wallpaper, the plastic flowers and knick-knacks, the piles of accumulated belongings, the mould, the grease, the houseproud moments salvaged from the clutter - and imagine we can place it all. But an enigma remains.

Who needs the Royle family or Big Brother (the frightening and morally questionable Dutch fly- on-the-wall docu-soap) when Billingham records this unadulterated everyday reality? There are no actors and no script. Even if the photographs never told us what the Billinghams sounded like, we could always imagine the bickering, the silences and taunts, Ray's drunken incoherence, Liz's constant plaint. We now know exactly the timbre of discontent, thanks to Billingham's Fishtank, shown on Channel 4 in 1998. There was Ray, maundering and mumbling and falling over; wanton Jason swatting flies; Liz, smoking, eating, angry with her life.

"I've had bastard 'nough of you today," said Liz, in Fishtank. "I don't like this kind of living, I don't." They try to leave, they say they're about to leave, but they don't. Or if they do, they always go back. Even Billingham goes back. That's what he does. The pets look on.

Billingham, at 30, is famous. He has made it to the cover of Artforum, the most important American art magazine. He has been interviewed by Lynn Barber (an equally infallible guide), and he won the first CitiBank Photography Prize, putting several social documentary photographers' noses out of joint. Ray's a Laugh, a compilation of Billingham's photographs, sold out. I saw it on the street stalls of Manhattan and Madrid.

I have always wondered what foreign audiences make of Billingham's work. Walking into a New York gallery to find the raw detail of poverty-line, problem-family life in Birmingham is a disconcerting translocation of the utterly familiar, the consummately local. If the images on the wall depicted Birmingham, Alabama we wouldn't raise an eyebrow - that would be Americana, Dirty Realism for the world at large. There are lives like these everywhere. And lives much worse, just as ordinary, just as truthful.

Billingham fascinates and appals and makes us laugh. He is no Walker Evans, getting poor southern sharecroppers to pose for him; no Diane Arbus with her misfits, no Don McCullin in the family war-zone. There is no angle in Billingham's images, no condescension, no critique. What are we - an audience of social workers, making an assessment? The Ikon Gallery exhibition is a total vindication of Billingham's art, of the quality of his photographs and videos, and of their status. It has often been repeated that he only began to photograph his family as an aid to making paintings while a student, and that what he really wants to be is a painter. He has a painter's eye, an eye for the pictorial, for pictorial drama, for the telling image, for brevity.

It is often assumed that his images are uncomposed, quick on the draw snaps. They have that back-from-the-chemist look. He likes taking pictures. But look again: the violet afternoon fog through the dirty window, framed by the inner darkness of the room, the grainy light coming in. The video of Liz in profile, smoking; the condensation on the window behind her, the rain pattering down outside, the smoke curling, the suck and draw of the smoke, Liz murdering time. A photo of the bars of the electric heater, the sallow yellow and orange. The photograph burns up all the oxygen in the room and in your head. Time for a nag and another fag. Who would pay such close attention to this object, much less photograph it? Someone who has spent a long time staring, doing nothing, staring some more.

Billingham has a feral hunger for the unregarded moment. For a long time it seemed that proximity was all, and that the claustrophobia of his images was the effect of being a man in a box, capturing a world in a box (the box of the room, the box of the camera). It is unsurprising that Billingham looked hard at the paintings of Lucian Freud and Francis Bacon while he was a student. Ray looks a bit like Freud. Billingham recognises the beauty in squalor, the plenitude of detail in a wretched room, in an image of Liz in a hideous floral dress, doing a jigsaw, Ray looking at the dog. The way the curtains hang. Billingham shows us Ray as a stumbling, incoherent fool, but he also shows us Ray's humanity. Ray staring uncomprehending at a pile of bread. Ray eyeing up dog-ends as though there were some answer in their alignment. Out of focus Ray in bed, the covers up to his neck, harried by the camera. Ray, toothless, caught in a laughing grimace in a dusty mirror. This last is an incredible image. A profound image, a terrible and terrifying image. It goes right through me. It is incontrovertible. It transcends its own cliche, and anything I might say about it. I had never seen Billingham's black and white photographs before this. They are better than he knows.

Billingham has always made memorable images - Liz like Goya's Maja, her body turned towards the camera, hands clasped behind her head. Gazing not at the camera but at the unseen TV. Liz doing a jigsaw, and giving us a stained-toothed smile as she feeds a kitten. Ray falling over. Ray and Jason together, good health and ill-health. "I do all these shows," Billingham told me, "and they always want the same old images."

Some newer works give us a battery of images, and photographs taken so close to their subject as to become almost abstract. A large triptych of Ray's hand judders in and out of focus, skin in folds and craters. And a 36-shot, multi-part work of Ray in close-up, like a giant contact print. The hand and the cigarette, the mouth pursed, the saggy neck, the empty glass inverted. The images going blam blam blam through the entire roll of film.

Of Billingham's recent video works, Playstation is the best. It is a close-up of Jason flailing at the buttons with filthy, manic fingers and bitten-down nails. A mad plastic clatter drowning out the voices in the room. Oddly, Playstation reminded me of Steve McQueen's new work, Cold Breath: it has the same inwardness, the same tight focus. The Playstation keeps the player occupied, isolated and insulated from the world.

Finally we go outside, in Billingham's photographs of the locality. There's no one about, the sky is a benign blue. Trees flip their leaves in the summer breeze. The tarmac meets old concrete. Embankments, factory buildings, a path over a field with buttercups. A parked car. The scenes are nearly bucolic. What there is in all Billingham's work, I realise, is a kind of warmth, the light of acceptance. The enigma, too, of why and how such ordinariness can be so heartbreakingly rendered and retold. "I just like taking the pictures," he told me.

Richard Billingham is at the Ikon Gallery, Birmingham (0121-248 0708), till July 16.

webTitle: Paraguayan fugitive held for political murder

fields.headline: Paraguayan fugitive held for political murder
fields.trailText: A former Paraguayan army general who once led the country's presidential polls while serving a prison sentence before becoming the continent's most wanted fugitive was last night in police custody in Brazil after being found in the tourist resort Foz do Iguacu.
fields.body:
A former Paraguayan army general who once led the country's presidential polls while serving a prison sentence before becoming the continent's most wanted fugitive was last night in police custody in Brazil after being found in the tourist resort Foz do Iguacu.

Lino Oviedo faces extradition to Paraguay where he is wanted in connection with the murder last year of the vice-president, Luis Argana, in the bloodiest incident in a series of power struggles since the dictatorship of Alfredo Stroessner was overthrown a decade ago.

Oviedo, a charismatic rabble-rouser nicknamed the "bonsai horseman" for his diminutive stature, had fled the country after the death of Argana, a bitter political rival despite belonging to the same party.

Argentina initially granted Oviedo asylum in Tierra del Fuego, but eight months later he disappeared and started giving media interviews from a location he claimed was in Paraguay; it was assumed he was plotting his political revenge from somewhere near the Brazilian border.

Oviedo was found in a friend's apartment at Foz do Iguacu, a tourist town at the triple frontier of Argentina, Paraguay and Brazil. "He did not resist, but he had an illegal revolver and many [mobile] phones with him," the arresting officer is reported to have said.

Paraguay, which has had 45 coups or attempted coups in the past 100 years - including two in the past four years authored by Oviedo - is the most politically unstable country in Latin America's southern cone. Its instability and endemic corruption is a weak point of the Mercosur trade block that includes Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and associate members Chile and Bolivia.

There will be concerns that fighting will break out in Paraguay's capital, Asuncion, since there are many in the military still loyal to Oviedo; a month ago soldiers supporting him drove tanks into Asuncion and fired on the congress buildings before they were chased out by fighter planes.

Ever since his role in the overthrow of Mr Stroessner, Oviedo has made it clear his sights were set on the presidency. He started the Colorado party and became massively popular thanks to rallies at which he spoke Guarani, Paraguay's indigenous language, as well as Spanish.

Oviedo was sentenced to 10 years in jail for an attempted coup in 1996 against Paraguay's first democratically elected president, Juan Carlos Wasmosy. Despite being behind bars Oviedo was the country's most popular politician and would have won a general election in 1998 had his status as a prisoner not negated his candidacy. Instead, the presidency went to his close ally, Raul Cubas, who immediately and unconstitutionally freed Oviedo when he came to power.

The fragility of the new government was underlined by the tensions between Mr Cubas and his vice-president, Luis Argana. When Argana was killed by a hitman, Mr Cubas and Oviedo fled the country and another member of the Colorado party, Luis Macchi, was made president.

Brazil received a request from Paraguay for Oviedo's arrest and had been searching the country's southern border since the beginning of the month.

As well as the diplomatic moves, Argana's family had offered a $100,000 (£66,300) reward for his capture. In a final ironic twist, it was Argana's son, Nelson, the Paraguayan defence minister, who announced on radio on Sunday that Oviedo had been caught.

webTitle: Disappearing bird: Gurney's Pitta faces extinction

fields.headline: Disappearing bird: Gurney's Pitta faces extinction
fields.trailText: Gurney's Pitta is about to go the way of the Dodo, gaining the dubious distinction become the first major species to become extinct in this millennium.
fields.body:
Gurney's Pitta is about to go the way of the Dodo, gaining the dubious distinction become the first major species to become extinct in this millennium.

Despite conservation efforts the ultramarine blue and black birds have slumped to one third of breeding numbers of 1989 - from 30 pairs to 10. Naturalists believe that the bird is doomed because the last remnant of its forest home is being whittled away.

The bird, named in 1875 after John H Gurney, a banker from Norfolk who travelled the world indentifying new species, was once numerous in the forests of south-east Asia but its last known habitat is disappearing.

Marcos Cohler, a naturalist, said: "This bird is the most likely candidate for early extinction. Forest in which the bird was living 10 years ago has disappeared and it is reduced to a remnant."

The bird lives in damp gullies on the forest floor digging in the forest litter for food. Mr Cohler said the place where he saw the birds nesting in 1989 was now a housing estate and a car park from which tourists could visit the forest where the bird lived. At this rate it will be gone by 2003, he said. "If they keep whittling away the forest they are whittling away the attraction. Soon there will be nothing left."

Gurney's Pitta is protected by the Thai government and the forest is a reserve but there are no wardens to stop locals cutting it down. Tony Juniper, of Friends of the Earth, said: "What is really sad is that everyone knows this beautiful bird is on the edge of extinction - people travel thousands of miles to see it, it is a boost to the local economy, and yet the Thai authorities show breathtaking complacency in allowing it to disappear."

The bird was reported extinct in 1952. However, 34 years later one was seen by naturalist Phil Round in a Bangkok bird market. He recorded its song before it died the following day. He spent years searching where the bird was trapped, using the recording to get an answering call. He succeeded and finally counted 30 pairs. It now looks as if Gurney's Pitta is about to become extinct for the second and final time.
