fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Neanderthals were fearsome predators who lived almost exclusively on meat according to the evidence of scared bones and stone-tipped and wooden spears found in Croatia.
fields.body:
Neanderthals 'were cannibals'
Neanderthals were fearsome predators who lived almost exclusively on meat according to the evidence of scared bones and stone-tipped and wooden spears found in Croatia. The human-like creatures could even have been cannibals, says a team of international scientists, including two from Oxford University.

£12,000 for 'worthless' art
A 17th century painting said to be worthless has been sold by Bonham's for £12,000. The Italian picture painted under the influence of Andrea Locatelli and showing the river god Alpheus pursuing the nymph Arethusa was in such bad condition its owner was advised to throw it away.

Actress died in window fall
An actress who had parts in Robin Hood Prince of Thieves and the original Dr Who, threw herself out of a third floor window of her flat in Kentish Town, north London, an inquest heard yesterday. Joanna Garcia, 55, had sclerosis of the liver and insulin dependent diabetes. A verdict of suicide was recorded.

Home game for appeal judge
A Newcastle United fan will be one of the court of appeal judges in a long-running battle by five supporters to hold on to their season ticket seats. Lord Justice Waller said he did not feel any embarrassment at being involved in "a sad dispute between supporters and the club".

Trail adjourned
The trial of British nurse David Chell, 57, of Stoke-on-Trent who is charged with attempting to smuggle more than 100 grams of heroin to Perth, Australia, from Malaysia was adjourned until July 3 while the judge considers her verdict.

fields.headline: Camelford inquiry refused
fields.trailText: Victims of Britain's worst water poisoning incident were told yesterday the government would not sanction a public inquiry into the disaster.
fields.body:
Victims of Britain's worst water poisoning incident were told yesterday the government would not sanction a public inquiry into the disaster.

Environment minister Michael Meacher told a meeting in Cornwall that, 12 years after the event, there was no reason to believe new information could emerge.

In July 1988, before water industry privatisation, water supplies to 20,000 customers were poisoned when 20 tonnes of aluminium sulphate were inadvertently dumped into the wrong tank at the South West Water Authority's Lowermoor treatment works near Camelford.

Victims of the poisoning have complained of suffering long term health problems as a result.

As Mr Meacher sipped a glass of tap water, some told yesterday how they had to drink bottled water because of allergic reactions to small, legal amounts of aluminium in water.

June Hills, 61, said: "I've been diagnosed with a form of Alzheimer's disease and I have got to live with that. What sort of life can I expect over the next few years before I get cancer or something like that? We need a public inquiry, please help us."

Mr Meacher told the 50 strong audience there would have been a public inquiry had Labour been in power at the time. But he did not believe that a public inquiry was the way forward.

"It is now, whether we like it or not, 12 years on," he said. "All the facts are fully known and there is no reason to believe that a public inquiry could add to that.

"There has been a complete change in the organisation and regulation of the water industry since the event took place."

fields.headline: Accused 'lied over girl's death'
fields.trailText: The man accused of raping and murdering nine-year-old Laura Kane admitted to a jury yesterday that he had lied to police about how she died.
fields.body:
The man accused of raping and murdering nine-year-old Laura Kane admitted to a jury yesterday that he had lied to police about how she died.

But Colin Bainbridge, 35, insisted her death was an accident. He told Newcastle crown court that Laura had gone with him to his home in Murton, Co Durham, to see his baby son. But when he was not there, she persuaded him "reluctantly" to play a game of "tie-up".

The jury had already heard how Bainbridge would play the game with Laura and other children.

Bainbridge told the jury that after binding her hand and feet, and gagging her he left the room to feed his dog. He returned 15 minutes later to discover Laura dead on the floor.

Bainbridge denies indecent assault, rape and murder. The trial continues.

fields.headline: £111,400 damages against GP
fields.trailText: A widower yesterday won £111,400 damages against a GP who failed to refer his wife to a specialist after she found a lump in her breast.
fields.body:
A widower yesterday won £111,400 damages against a GP who failed to refer his wife to a specialist after she found a lump in her breast.

Jean Rose, a designer and lecturer, was 49 when she died in September 1996, two years after her aggressive breast cancer was eventually diagnosed.

A home video, showing the mother-of-two in bed shortly before her death, formed part of her husband Anthony's action against Alan Duke.

Judge Elizabeth Steel, sitting in the high court in London, said it was no part of Mr Rose's case that the failure to identify the lump when the GP saw his wife at the health centre in Ramsey, Cambridgeshire, in August 1993, was negligent.

But she said Dr Duke, who has since retired, should have referred Mrs Rose for specialist opinion. If he had, said the judge, Mrs Rose's condition would have been detected by September 1993 and she would have had the chance of at least another 10 years of life.

The judge found that Dr Duke, who denied negligence, was liable in the light of expert opinion that Mrs Rose should have been referred for investigation after she told him about the lump and her mother and aunt's history of breast cancer.

She also found that the failure to refer caused injury as, in September 1993, Mrs Rose's tumour had not spread to her lymph nodes.

Dr Duke, was supported by the Medical Defence Union.

Mr Rose, 62, said: "This case was brought by Jean just before her death. I promised I would see it through. Had the GP referred Jean to a hospital in 1993 when she noticed the lump it is likely she would still be alive today."

fields.headline: No: 1654
fields.standfirst: Lawrence of Southampton
fields.trailText: Lawrence of Southampton
fields.body:
Don't you mean Arabia? The ceaseless tide of historical revisionism, old chap.

Don't patronise me. Sorry.

OK. Explain. Letters to be auctioned later this month reveal that in 1932 Lawrence wrote to an instructor at Southampton baths to enrol on a course of cold showers and stern discipline, begging for "some of the slave-driving which you tell me is your reputation".

Big deal: Medium-sized deal - the letters are expected to fetch £15,000. But major historical coup as they are further evidence of Lawrence's much-disputed masochism.

I never liked his perverted novels. I am tempted to patronise you.

Wrong Lawrence? Indeed. Thomas Edward was a lot more screwed up than David Herbert, and had a much more dramatic life. A scholar turned soldier, he was a key figure in the Arab revolt against the Turks in the first world war, and recorded his exploits in Seven Pillars of Wisdom, which was the basis of the David Lean film.

It's all coming back to me. Flogged and raped by the Turks wasn't he? He claimed to have been, but many have dismissed it as a fantasy. Lawrence attributed his personal difficulties and sexual hang-ups to the rape; others see the fantasy as part of a long-term psycho-sexual problem and blame his mother.

Is this Pass Notes or In the Psychiatrist's Chair? Just trying to be helpful.

Where do the swimming letters come in? They confirm that by the 30s Lawrence was lost in a strange, sado-masochistic fantasy world.

Lucky the News of the World didn't hear about it. They didn't go in for celebrity exposés in the 1930s.

How did it all end? Tragically/ mercifully (delete according to taste). Lawrence was killed aged 46 in a motorbike accident in 1935 when he swerved to avoid two boys on bicycles.

Do say: "Lawrence's sexual peccadillos shouldn't detract from his extraordinary achievements."

Don't say: "He would have approved of us flogging his letters."

fields.headline: Blooming? Moomin!
fields.standfirst: Kate Clanchy: Ultrasoundings
fields.trailText: Kate Clanchy: Ultrasoundings
fields.body:
Week 28

My insomnia has passed as mysteriously as it arrived. I can, and do, sleep nine hours a night. The world has regained its full spectrum of colour. I'm pink-cheeked and annoyingly bouncy. I've apologised to various people I've insulted, cleaned the cupboard under the stairs and taken up swimming regularly.

It was about time I started. I usually go to the local university gym, but I can't reach lots of the handles any more and you aren't, gloriously, allowed to do sit-ups in pregnancy. So I can only use the low-impact runner - one of those moon-walk machines - and it always seems to be occupied by an anorexic graduate student putting in 45 minutes of uphill sprinting while reading Anna Karenina.

"You have an eating disorder. I'm pregnant. Get off," my insomniac self would snarl. My new, sunnier incarnation prefers doing backstroke in the local pool, buoyant in the soupy mixture of 25% children's urine, 25% chlorine, bumping gently into plump ladies paddling slow as bath-toys and contemplating my bump rising above the water like an island.

For I seem to have grown a different body during the month-long night of my insomnia. I look properly pregnant now, with a globe of a belly curving up abruptly from my pelvis and pressing against my ribcage. I've got a new walk, too: that slightly loose, flat-footed waddle. I even find myself making pregnant gestures - stroking my belly or standing with one hand under my breast and one spread over my bump, like the Madonna.

The funny thing is, I like it. Even if my pelvis does ache a little and I'm down to one skirt and two pairs of trousers, this strikes me as a dignified and graceful state. Even if I can block an entire bus or tube carriage with my plodding entrances and exits. (No one, I've discovered, will give me a seat on public transport except middle-aged women and men of near eastern origin. City suits simply use my bump as a prop for the Evening Standard.) Even if, with my head pushed back and my stomach and my waddle, I look like nobody so much as Tove Jansson's Moominmama.

Actually, I think Moominmama is a fine role model. She is Finnish, for a start, and therefore entitled to a year's maternity pay from the state for each baby Moomintroll, followed by free access to a local community kindergarten run by graduates in childcare. Moominmama, therefore, finds it easy to maintain her cheerful smile and her supply of picnics and good advice.

I love Finland. I spent six weeks in Helsinki once and though I kept a close lookout, I never saw a single mother beating her child in a supermarket, just happy bands of little children from the community kindergarten, rolling in the snow and being taught to cross the road in a communal, calm, Scandinavian manner.

In my Moominmama guise, I also feel, for the first time in my life, immune to fashion. Moominmama is much too dignified to wear pussy-bow blouses in an ironic nod to the 80s. Still less will she be sporting tight beaded belts, in this or any other season. And the fashion for looking like a teenager at Butlin's at Clacton in 1970 seems truly to belong to an adolescent world. The models' concave stomachs and thin arms seem simply young, suddenly, not yet in use, rather than ultimately desirable.

Maternity wear, too, contrary to myth, is rather refreshing. Pregnancy clothes, on the whole, are designed to cover you up, to stretch and yield, and to be comfortable. They can't try very hard to be modish or pretend to be "investment items", so there are hardly any designer labels or high price tags. And they are designed, by definition, for women with childbearing bodies rather than for prepubescents. They're made on the opposite principle to most fashionable clothes, in short, which I assume is why fashion editors have breakdowns when they get pregnant and start running features on how to show off your bump in bias-cut silk slips.

Not that everyone's got the right idea. The tide of noxious pastel colours and teddies in hats that seems to cover all baby products also affects quite a few pregnancy garments, as if pregnant women were becoming infants themselves. Sugar-pink dungarees stretched over a bump make pregnant women look like vast toddlers, yet these garments are represented in every pregnancy book. I think it's got something to do with Princess Diana. And I saw a coffee mug the other day that said: "I'm not fat, I'm pregnant."

Tragic. Moominmama, I feel certain, would crush such a pathetically apologetic item to dust under one round, flat, heavy foot.

fields.headline: A bit of slap
fields.standfirst: Could you leave home without your make-up? Joan Smith considers women's relationship with cosmetics
fields.trailText: Could you leave home without your make-up? Joan Smith considers women's relationship with cosmetics
fields.body:
She feels sick at the prospect and has to be comforted by friends. They tell her how brave she is - and one admits she would throw herself under a bus if she had to do it. You would think they were discussing a terrifying event, like giving evidence in a particularly horrible rape trial, but Ally Edgar and her friends, who appear in a documentary on Channel 4 tonight, are talking about her decision to give up make-up for a week.

Yes, I do mean that sticky stuff most of us put on our lips and eyelids. If going without for a few days does not strike you as a reason for suicidal depression, then you do not belong to that brigade of women who would not be seen dead in Sainsbury's without the full slap. I am sometimes amazed, when I turn up at studios to take part in early-morning radio programmes, by the appearance of the other female guests. They glide in at 7.30am with unchipped nail polish and gleaming lips, when I have merely fallen out of bed into a pair of jeans - the audience can't see you on radio, for God's sake. There are women who always put on lip gloss before answering the front door and tonight's Can You Live Without is about one of them.

But our relationship with make-up is not a simple matter, dividing us into those who do and those who don't. Women often talk about pampering themselves and the kick they get from signing a credit card slip for £60 at the cosmetics counter, implying that make-up is a luxury. Yet it is often the same women who are horrified at the idea of leaving home with a bare face, suggesting it is essential - perhaps even a form of tyranny.

Even the word make-up is evocative, a relative of making up, which is what you do when you fall out with a friend. You also make up for something that's gone wrong, which may be what lots of women feel when contemplating their natural faces in the mirror. Its synonym, cosmetics, appears much more neutral at first, deriving from the Greek noun kosmos, meaning ornament. But when you realise that the same word also means both order and the universe, it is hard to resist the notion that putting on make-up is a highly significant, if not quite a cosmic, act.

Women wear it, men don't, unless they happen to be Boy George or Robert Kilroy-Silk. Although men's ranges of cosmetics have expanded well beyond aftershave, they are still concentrated in areas like body lotion. Few men wear eyeshadow and if they did, most of us would feel uncomfortable. (When a boyfriend once complained that I wouldn't let him try my make-up, even as a joke, I discovered that superficial signifiers of gender difference were more important to me than I had previously realised. I'm not sharing my Clinique Black Violet lipstick with anyone.)

This is one of those strange imbalances between the sexes we rarely question because we are so used to it. Men tend to look more or less the same, unless they have flu or a hangover. Women's appearance, on the other hand, can vary dramatically. Few of us know what Joan Collins looks like beneath her maquillage, but there are magazines that specialise in photographing stars off duty, as they return home frazzled after collecting their children from school.

There is no doubt that, for some women, make-up has a complicated and integral relationship to their idea of themselves. While movie stars are under a professional obligation to confirm to the prevailing notion of beauty, there are plenty of ordinary women whose self-esteem is intimately bound up with the face they present to the world. The Beatles captured this sense of identity as something women put on, rather than have naturally, in their song Eleanor Rigby, about a lonely woman who wears a "face that she keeps in a jar by the door".

Interestingly, there is often a gap between the way women perceive themselves, with and without make-up, and what the rest of the world sees. Ally Edgar is an extreme example, unable to believe people will like her without her public face. Yet the difference is nothing like as great as she perceives it to be, suggesting that make-up is more a prop for her self-esteem than a miracle transformation.

The gap between fantasy and reality is so great that some women, like the late Barbara Cartland, make themselves up to look positively ridiculous, yet do not seem to realise it. It is probably true that we all carry around an idealised version of the self, which can receive a rude shock in unguarded moments - unexpectedly catching sight of yourself in a mirror after a series of late nights, for instance. But there are women who pile on mascara and blusher in deeply unflattering quantities, over-riding the evidence of their senses, like anorexics. Sometimes it is a result of failing to take account of age, sticking to a routine they started in their 20s when they reach their 50s. Even the late Princess of Wales, with all the fashion advice available to her, was famous for her unwise attachment to blue eyeliner.

It is hardly surprising, in a culture that bombards us with perfect images, that we internalise them and try to reproduce the effect on our own faces. It is as though femininity, far from being innate, is something that has to be constructed - even if fashion then demands, as it currently does, that the effect be as "natural" as possible. When men say they don't like make-up, it usually means just that; they don't like it to be too obvious. And women are right when they say they wear cosmetics for themselves, for the aim is surely to be the ideal woman - at least a less imperfect woman - rather than to attract the ideal man.

It is equally unsurprising, though rather sad, that some women take make-up so seriously. Choosing lipstick and perfume are pleasures, as is the moment when you put them on. It carries with it a childlike enjoyment of dressing up, as long as it doesn't leave you feeling unbearably naked when you take it off. One question tonight's film does not address is what happens if you're a single woman, in search of a lover, whose self-esteem is dependent on a carefully constructed face. You may think you look all right at midnight, but what about over breakfast? In that sense, over-dependence on cosmetics gives new resonance to the words of the old song: "Will you still love me tomorrow?"

Can You Live Without Make-up? is on Channel 4 tonight at 8.30pm.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Put that Fray Bentos pie away! It could confound your employment prospects worse than bringing your imaginary friend to the interview with you, or breaking into a skiffle version of (I've Had) The Time Of My Life when they ask if you've got any questions.
fields.body:
Put that Fray Bentos pie away! It could confound your employment prospects worse than bringing your imaginary friend to the interview with you, or breaking into a skiffle version of (I've Had) The Time Of My Life when they ask if you've got any questions.

Latest research from the US suggests that menu choice at a lunchtime interview can seriously affect one's chances of being hired - if your prandial partner is a bloke. Asked to give their impressions of a woman who ordered chicken-salad-fruit, or burger-chips-ice-cream, men were far more judgmental of the candidate who chose the "unhealthy" option, while women rated their prospects the same. Apparently, those who took their health seriously (weedy greeny grub) were presumed to approach their job likewise. And presumption it is - what about taking pleasure seriously?

But hark: is it not the rumble of colour-coded digestive sexual politics, whereby men are allowed all things red (flesh, wine, cola cubes) and women are left with all things white (flesh, wine, lettuce). Last year, Healthy Eating magazine proclaimed that the sexes responded differently to ingestion-related odour. While men were deemed more attractive after steak and claret, women attained sexual success after fish in Chardonnay sauce. Super. Make mine a rice cake.

Sidelines, however, has heard differently. Our very own catering industry mole attests to top-secret research by the All Bar One group (bastion of gender-specific boozing and clean, clean toilets). They claim that the drink men find most attractive in the hand of the opposite sex is a full glass of red wine. Sidelines concurs (apart from the full bit). Red wine is restorative, especially after six glasses, as well as looking A Bit French. In addition, because it stains well, it makes one more visible at the bar.

A s for steak, it wins over salmon every time - the bloodier the better. Darling, it's so lunar . Dancing naked in a woodland clearing and painting pictures on bark with our menstrual blood is but an Always away. Defy the fish fascists. Seared scallops won't make you more of a woman.

M eanwhile, Sidelines' interview advice is as follows. Try not to be yourself. You'll only frighten them. Just smile. Then they'll never notice the darkness behind your eyes.

Asked to give their impressions of a woman who ordered chicken-salad-fruit, or burger-chips-ice-cream, men were far more judgmental of the candidate who chose the "unhealthy" option, while women rated their prospects the same. They claim that the drink men find most attractive in the hand of the opposite sex is a full glass of red wine. Sidelines concurs (apart from the full bit). Red wine is restorative, especially after six glasses, as well as looking A Bit French. In addition, because it stains well, it makes one more visible at the bar. A s for steak, it wins over salmon every time - the bloodier the better. Darling, it's so lunar . Dancing naked in a woodland clearing and painting pictures on bark with our menstrual blood is but an Always away. Defy the fish fascists. Seared scallops won't make you more of a woman. webTitle: World Wrestling Federation beats the analysts yet again (and this time the fight is not fixed)

fields.headline: World Wrestling Federation beats the analysts yet again (and this time the fight is not fixed)
fields.standfirst: For 30m fans, it's a business to grapple with
fields.trailText: To the unconverted it is a preposterous mix of faked fights, eardrum-bursting heavy-metal music and oversized musclemen throwing each other around a ring while displaying the sort of acting talent more usually associated with Christmas pantomime.
fields.body:
To the unconverted it is a preposterous mix of faked fights, eardrum-bursting heavy-metal music and oversized musclemen throwing each other around a ring while displaying the sort of acting talent more usually associated with Christmas pantomime.

But for the 30m-plus fans across the globe who tune in each week to follow the soap-opera-styled world of stars like "Stone Cold" Steve Austin, The Rock and The Undertaker, the World Wrestling Federation is something of a religion.

Traditionally the preserve of teenage boys, WWF - as real fans know it - now has a new and rather unlikely follower: Wall Street.

America' s leading financial institutions, including the likes of investment banks Merrill Lynch and Bear Stearns, are raving about the growth prospects of the Nasdaq-listed World Wrestling Federation Entertainment. Later this month it is likely to report quarterly figures that once again outstrip analysts' expectations.

Broadcasters Viacom and USA Networks are fighting it out in the courts for the right to broadcast WWF shows, which are consistently at the top of viewing ratings. NBC has invested $30m (£20m) in WWF for a 3% stake and the right to broadcast and jointly own XFL, the WWF's new football league slated to start in 2001.

Merchandising and broadcasting deals have helped sales surge by 67% annually and revenues by 188% of the past three years. WWF is set to record sales of $360m by the end of this year.

By any standards, the business of WWF is experiencing an extraordinary period of growth. Guiding it is the McMahon family, which owns 83% of a business valued at $1.2bn. At the helm is chairman Vince McMahon, a 54-year-old former wrestler.

Keeping control of day-to-day operations and the finances is his wife Linda, the 51-year-old chief executive. Their two children, Shane, 30, and Stephanie, 23, regularly join in with on-stage punch-ups when they're not running the sales and new-media operations. "Wrestling is in my family's blood," Mrs McMahon, who has become one of the US's highest profile female executives, says.

After conquering America, the McMahons have their eyes firmly set on world domination. Those on this side of the Atlantic who suggest that the WWF could only happen in America should take a look at the British book, video and computer game charts, where WWF products consistently figure in the top five sellers.

BSkyB has paid £23m for a five-year contract to broadcast WWF, and the show is one of the most popular programmes on Sky Sports. Channel 4 attracts 2m viewers each week to its Sunday afternoon magazine show. In WH Smith the official WWF magazine is the biggest selling import, while WWF.com is one of the country's most popular websites with young users.

All 10,000 tickets to a live event scheduled to take place in Sheffield in December sold in 90 minutes when they went on sale last month. In total WWF is broadcast in 110 countries.

"The UK is already a cornerstone of our business," Mrs McMahon says. "The attraction is that we produce a top quality action adventure soap opera. There's an underlying storyline and viewers need to come back week after week to find out what is happening."

Appropriately enough WWF has had to fight to maintain its position. For a period in the 1990s Time Warner threatened to destroy WWF by luring away stars to start a rival, World Championship Wrestling. The battle got bitter, bloody and personal, with Mr McMahon describing Mr Turner as a "son of a bitch".

She claims to have won the bout, saying: "They took us on and beat us for a while but we're now doing twice their numbers in the Monday night TV ratings."

Then there were the lawsuits. The decision to switch broadcast partners from Barry Diller's USA Networks to Viacom's CBS has prompted legal action, while the family of wrestler Owen Hart who died last year during a stunt have filed another suit. Coca-Cola recently withdrew its ads from the controversial WWF Smackdown! show.

Even so, advertising revenue has doubled over the last year and merchandising now accounts for one third of revenue. There's a record label, a sponsored dragster racing team, a series of autobiographies from the stars, a new one acre $25m entertainment complex in Times Square, New York, and talk of a late night chat show.

Mrs McMahon rejects suggestions that she might be extending the brand too far or that a change in teenage fashion could hit growth.

She says: "Like any entertainment content provider were at risk to the marketplace but we've had our finger on the pulse for 50 years now. We've changed our programming and trends in line with consumer tastes and spend. There's no reason why we cannot continue to do that."

Some hard facts to throw around

British broadcasting

BSkyB paid $35m for five-year contract. Attracts 500,000 viewers each week. A big football game like Chelsea v Man Utd attracts around 1.1m. Channel 4 pays $1.1m per year for a two-year deal for Heat, a Sunday afternoon programme. Attracts 1.8m viewers compared to around 1.1m for Football Italia

Global pay-per-view

In 1999 the WWF generated more than $170m in subscriber purchases. Wrestlemania XV on March 28 was the most popular pay-per-view event ever in the US

Merchandising

The Playstation WWF computer game Smackdown is the fourth fastest selling of all time

There are six WWF videos in the British top 20

By The Rock and By Mick Foley, two wrestler autobiographies, topped the Sunday Times hardback non-fiction best seller lists this year

Averaging merchandising spend at a British WWF live event is £12 per head

In 1999 the WWF generated more than $1bn in retail sales of licensed products

More than 3m WWF videos have been sold in Britain

Live events

32m fans have purchased live event tickets in past 12 years

New media

WWF.com generates 100m page impressions per month and is accessed in more than 100 countries

In the US it is the number one website for males aged 12 to 17

Source: WWF

webTitle: Son's body 'kept in house four years'

fields.headline: Son's body 'kept in house four years'
fields.trailText: A former accountant kept the body of his son for up to four years because he could not face up to his death, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A former accountant kept the body of his son for up to four years because he could not face up to his death, a court heard yesterday.

Tony Burt, 63, told neighbours and police his son Steven had gone travelling while he kept his decomposing corpse on the sofa where he is believed to have died.

He only decided to move the remains - then weighing just over a stone - once he agreed to sell the ramshackle bungalow they had shared in Woodbridge, Suffolk, it was stated at Ipswich crown court.

Mark Norman, prosecuting, told the jury that Burt, who had been divorced for more than 20 years from Steven's mother, then placed the mummified body in a sleeping bag and dumped it in a nearby park.

The remains, which had not been hidden, were found a fortnight later, in December 1998, by a former policeman walking his dog.

The body was only identified through DNA tests - but a sofa cushion, found in Burt's home, was indented with the shape of two human legs which matched the remains.

Burt, a former accountant for the Guardian Royal Exchange, denies failing to carry out a Christian burial for his son and causing a nuisance by depositing human remains on public grounds.

After being arrested, he insisted he did not know what had happened to his son, a one time farm labourer. His son was last seen for certain in the spring of 1994, when he was 25, but may have been spotted the following year by an environmental health officer, who went to the bungalow to complain about its condition, the court heard.

Mr Norman said: "This defendant's son died almost certainly at the bungalow they shared and he did not do anything about it. He left his son's body on a sofa for many years. He told police in interview that Steven had packed his bags and had gone away after expressing an interest in travelling."

After the remains were found, police launched a murder inquiry but could find no evidence of foul play. A postmortem concluded the body had been dead for several years but had only been placed in the Fen Meadow park for around a fortnight, Mr Norman said.

The dead man's mother, Annette McDermott, told the court she assumed her reclusive son, who lived with his father from 1992, had gone travelling after she last saw him in the spring of 1994.

She added: "When he was young he was happy and contented, but he got bullied a lot at school and went downhill after that. He became a loner."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Togas and hot tubs on the Roman way

fields.headline: Togas and hot tubs on the Roman way
fields.standfirst: 'Last outpost of civilisation' restored in £9m project excavation Segedunum
fields.trailText: The chance to take a Roman bath returns to Britain this week with the re-opening of a long-buried fortress on Hadrian's Wall.
fields.body:
The chance to take a Roman bath returns to Britain this week with the re-opening of a long-buried fortress on Hadrian's Wall.

Togas and hot tubs will be available for the first time since a bacteria scare in the 1980s ended the annual Roman Rendezvous in Bath.

The new chance to try the hypocaust treatment will be one of the attractions of the latest national lottery project, Segedunum, a £9m excavation and rebuilding of the eastern gateway to the 80-mile-long wall. Hidden for 110 years below Wallsend, whose council refused to buy the ruins for £680 in 1887, the fort also features lifts to a 100ft-high observation tower.

Groups of up to 30 will be able to take in the pattern of the three-and-a-half acre site which includes the first Roman cavalry barracks to be unearthed in Britain. An eight-course high stretch of the original wall, built in 122AD, has been excavated and a further section rebuilt to the original grandeur of 1,800 years ago.

"This is a place where civilisation ended and barbarity began," said David Fleming, director of Tyne and Wear museums, whose restoration includes the communal lavatories favoured by the garrison of the wall. "As the fort at the eastern end of the wall, Segedunum was truly the last outpost of the Roman Empire."

Built to command both reaches of a bend in the Tyne, the fort was manned by auxilliaries from Gaul, whose relics include a finely detailed altar inscribed by a 3rd century garrison commander, Aelius Rufus. Coins, bones and pottery have also been discovered since colliery and shipyard housing on the site was demolished in 1975 and a programme of excavations began.

The opening on Friday, with a wine and rose petal ceremony and greetings from the mayor of Rome, marks a further stage in the transformation of Wallsend, which has turned its back on tourism for most of the century.

Only 25 years ago, the site of Segedunum was marked only by occasional white kerbstones and a chipped tablet saying: "The inhabitants of Wallsend are requested to co-operate for the protection of this interesting memorial of antiquity from which their town derives its name."

The mayor of North Tyneside, David Charlton, said: "Everyone's very proud that the vision we had for this world heritage site has finally become reality."

In spite of its name, thought to come from the Celtic sechdun or "dry hill", the new attraction is staking much of its tourist hopes on water, via the bathhouse which is the first in the country to be fully reconstructed. Although use of the baths will be restricted to pre-booked group evenings, all visitors will tour the changing rooms, cold, warm and hot bathrooms and lavatories which formed stages of the elaborate Roman bathing ritual.

The centre is confident that this and the drawing power of the rest of the wall, will bring in visitors.

The fort, which is also close to Bede's world centre at Jarrow, whose Christian founders stole Segedunum stone to build the Venerable Bede's monastery, has chosen the bullish marketing slogan: "Be one of the legions to visit us".

fields.headline: Moves to end 'theft of history'
fields.standfirst: Archaeologist wants action on 'sickening' trade
fields.trailText: One of Britain's leading archaeologists, Lord Renfrew, yesterday demanded that the government and the British art trade act urgently to end the "sickening enterprise" of trade in looted antiquities.
fields.body:
One of Britain's leading archaeologists, Lord Renfrew, yesterday demanded that the government and the British art trade act urgently to end the "sickening enterprise" of trade in looted antiquities.

A report published yesterday by the Museums Association and the International Council of Museums suggested that the British end may be worth £50m a year, of an international trade worth billions.

The report describes the trade as "the theft of history", and outlines the increasing involvement of criminals and drug barons; sites in Africa, the far east and South America being pillaged to order for collectors; and the injuries and deaths of museum staff, particularly in Africa, where looters are targeting existing collections.

It suggests London sales may be used as a laundering exercise, to give looted objects a saleroom history before they are sold on again.

"I hope this may be a turning point in a major scandal nationally and internationally," Lord Renfrew, professor of archaeology at Cambridge, said. He has been appointed to an advisory committee, established last month by the Department of Culture, to report by autumn on how to tackle the trade.

However yesterday he denounced this and previous governments for decades of inaction, and for repeatedly refusing to sign UN and other protocols outlawing the trade.

It is not illegal to sell antiquities in Britain, even if they have been illegally excavated and exported from elsewhere. Sotheby's has recently dropped its antiquities auctions in London, though it still sells them in New York, but other leading London auction houses, including Bonham's, still hold regular sales of archaeological finds.

In some countries, such as Cambodia, massive sculptures are being hacked off sites of world importance and sold in art galleries. In others, archaeology sites are being scoured bare of small, portable, readily saleable and virtually untraceable objects.

Archaeologists are in despair over the trade because in stripping the objects of their context, the looters destroy the wealth of information which they might reveal of the cultures which made them.

Many of the most notorious cases concern Africa and the far east, but British sites are also being targeted: Wanborough in Guildford became notorious in the 1980s, when gangs of treasure hunters came by night with metal detectors and removed sack loads of Roman coins, mostly since sold abroad.

Two years ago, after reports that treasure hunters has returned, archaeologists carried out an emergency excavation to learn what they could about the site - which may have been of importance to pagans then re-used as a Roman temple.

Tony Robinson, presenter of the Channel 4's archaeology series Time Team, said: "To rip archaeology out of the earth is an attack not just on us but on our children too."

He said in touring the country for the series he had come across innumerable stories of landowners calling in the police to deal with unauthorised metal detectorists, only to find the police or magistrates interested or even amused by what they saw as a harmless hobby.

fields.headline: Damages for sex claims
fields.trailText: The co-founder of a drugs charity yesterday accepted £73,000 in libel damages and costs over an allegation that she offered sexual services to rock stars in the 1960s in return for donations.
fields.body:
The co-founder of a drugs charity yesterday accepted £73,000 in libel damages and costs over an allegation that she offered sexual services to rock stars in the 1960s in return for donations.

Caroline Coon, who co-founded the advisory service Release in 1967, told Mr Justice Eady at the high court in London that the hardback edition of the 1998 book, All Dressed Up: The Sixties and the Counterculture, suggested that Release had raised money by "less than usual methods". It alleged that "one young woman" had offered rock stars sexual services in return for money.

Ms Coon, who represented herself, added: "The book named two rock stars, claiming that one had accepted her offer and paid up while the other, having accepted her offer, had then refused to pay. I was very distressed by the publication of this allegation.

"Firstly, because the book suggested that I, as prime mover and leader in Release at that time, had used 'less than usual methods' of collecting funds. Worse still, the reference to the 'young woman' was understood by me and by others to be a reference to myself.

"Secondly, because I was concerned for the reputation and feelings of other women who had worked for Release."

Ms Coon said the author, Jonathon Green, and publisher Random House (UK) Ltd accepted that the allegation was untrue and the book was withdrawn in its original form.

Ms Coon said she planned to donate part of her damages to the modern records centre at Warwick University for the Release archive.

Daniel Gosland, solicitor for the defendants, told the judge: "The defendants did not intend anyone to understand the reference to the 'young woman' to refer to her.

 In the high court in last year, George Harrison accepted substantial damages over an allegation in the book.

Caroline Coon, who co-founded the advisory service Release in 1967, told Mr Justice Eady at the high court in London that the hardback edition of the 1998 book, All Dressed Up: The Sixties and the Counterculture, suggested that Release had raised money by "less than usual methods". It alleged that "one young woman" had offered rock stars sexual services in return for money. Ms Coon, who represented herself, added: "The book named two rock stars, claiming that one had accepted her offer and paid up while the other, having accepted her offer, had then refused to pay. I was very distressed by the publication of this allegation. "Firstly, because the book suggested that I, as prime mover and leader in Release at that time, had used 'less than usual methods' of collecting funds. Worse still, the reference to the 'young woman' was understood by me and by others to be a reference to myself. "Secondly, because I was concerned for the reputation and feelings of other women who had worked for Release." Ms Coon said the author, Jonathon Green, and publisher Random House (UK) Ltd accepted that the allegation was untrue and the book was withdrawn in its original form. Ms Coon said she planned to donate part of her damages to the modern records centre at Warwick University for the Release archive. Daniel Gosland, solicitor for the defendants, told the judge: "The defendants did not intend anyone to understand the reference to the 'young woman' to refer to her.  In the high court in last year, George Harrison accepted substantial damages over an allegation in the book.

webTitle: Hinds ensures West Indies will lead with their lefts

fields.headline: Hinds ensures West Indies will lead with their lefts
fields.standfirst: The young Jamaican will solve the tourists' opening problem  says Frank Keating
fields.trailText: The young Jamaican will solve the tourists' opening problem says Frank Keating
fields.body:
Some reporters' questions have to be unashamedly fatuous. Was the tyro West Indian leftie, Wavell Hinds, pleased with himself after his engaging, undefeated 105 pipe-opener (out of 176) on a difficult pitch in Cardiff last week? "It was good to get a start. But it is only a start," said the earnest and friendly young man. Had it set him up for Thursday's first test at Edgbaston? "I have not been selected yet," he said.

In no time, while fielding at silly-point in Glamorgan's second innings, Hinds took a fearful blow on the ankle, so he has spent the approach to the test nursing not only relieving ice-packs but the possibility of solving the tourists' one serious problem by moving up the order to open the innings with Sherwin Campbell. Which would mean five of the West Indies top-six being left-handers. "Does that matter if they are our best top-six batsmen?" asks their coach Roger Harper.

The grandest batting triumvirate of all time, the 3W's of Worrell, Weekes and Walcott, first burst upon England precisely a half century ago. Not 24 till September, WW Hinds is younger, just, than each of those immortals when they landed for the epic 1950 tour - and like Frank Worrell and Everton Weekes, Wavell Wayne Hinds comes to England the summer after a dress rehearsal on the differently difficult wickets in the Lancashire leagues. Last year Hinds was pro to the Oldham club Werneth.

That testing apprenticeship, plus a sound one with the West Indian under-19 and A sides, was thrillingly seen to blossom into colourful full bloom only these three months. And how. For in Jamaica in March, in the inter-island Busta Cup final, Hinds hit a resplendent 127. That same month, in his test debut innings at Port-of-Spain against Zimbabwe, he made a composed 46 not out out of a total 187. A fortnight later, on April 2, in only his second one-day international, Hinds hit 12 fours and a six in an undefeated 116 against Zimbabwe on his home paddock at Kingston. And when Pakistan arrived in May, at Bridgetown he sent reeling into tailspin one of the game's most outstanding attacks (Wasim, Waqar, Saqlain, and Mushtaq) with 165 with 24 fours.

Come June, and his overture for beginners was on that turner at Cardiff against Robert Croft and another century - "all power and timing," wrote one enthralled Welsh reporter. Power, that power to make extra-cover fear for his wrists and ankles, is the first word that strikes the watcher. Hinds hits with his forearms, chest, and shoulders coiled as one. The Caribbean's finest leftie of all, Sir Garry Sobers, was enraptured by the Jamaican boy when he first saw him in March: "He already oozed class. If his confidence settles he could be very, very special. He is so positive in his strokeplay that, except for the spectacles, at first I thought I was watching the young Clive Lloyd out there."

In fact, Hinds has not the gangling height, nor stoop, of the young Lloyd. Anyway, says the West Indies assistant coach and Hinds's fellow Jamaican, Jeffrey Dujon: "Wavell has his own way of doing things, he might have the same sort of power as the young Lloyd but he already has a lot more finesse; the strength of Wavell so far is power and also power of concentration. What he needs now is consistent performance, because that will breed even more confidence."

He admits his confidence took one or two blows last summer at Werneth. Ask them up there. "He was a touch too moody," says one Werneth member. "Who can blame the boy for that," says another, "his first pro season in a soggy summer on Lancashire's wet, soft tracks." Chips in someone else: "In fact, he did all right for us, he was very steady and was not only prepared to learn, but did learn." On those wet pitches, Hinds for Werneth in 1999 scored a highly creditable 840 runs at 46 (HS 107 v Middleton) and took 32 wickets at 28.

Werneth asked him to re-sign but knew he would be a test player this summer. In Jamaica, too, they had known for ages that was only a matter of time. Wolmers school is Kingston's famed cricket academy - Dujon, maestro stumper-bat, went there, as did the island's grandest batting alumni, the sumptuous right-hander Lawrence Rowe and the leftie opener Allan Rae.

The rival college, Camperdown, excelled at football and athletics (Olympians Don Quarrie and Ray Stewart) - till Hinds won the Michael Manley Cup for the island's best young cricketer three times in a row. "Lancashire was too cold and wet for him last year," says Camperdown's principal Cynthia Cooke. "He is ultra loyal to his group, his culture - and his school. Everywhere in the world he has been with his cricket, we still get a weekly postcard from him to the school, to all 1,400 of us. We are waiting now for his card telling us all about how he enjoyed Glamorgan."

webTitle: 'I'm back in the groove' says Lara

fields.headline: 'I'm back in the groove' says Lara
fields.standfirst:
West Indies 407 & 200-5 dec
Zimbabwe 275-8 dec & 108-1
Match drawn
fields.trailText:
West Indies 407 & 200-5 dec
Zimbabwe 275-8 dec & 108-1
Match drawn
fields.body:
Arundel it may have been, with its festival charm and scones for tea, but this match may just have catalysed the redemption of Brian Lara.

Not only short of runs but devoid of match practice after his three-month lay-off, Lara's century on Saturday was stunning, not just for the number of runs he made - 176 of them - but the manner of their making, at more than a run a ball on a slow pitch where others floundered.

To give Sherwin Campbell 40 overs start and then to overtake him inside 40 minutes was the innings of a man who is in a different class.

For now, Lara seems content with life. He says the team, which may have resented his return to the fold at a time when they had already begun the process of climbing out of the pit without his massive talent, have welcomed him back into the fold. Now he would like to repay their confidence and comradeship with weight of runs.

Lara is in the mood. The subject of his excursion to a New Jersey psychiatrist was taboo yesterday, but he is adamant that the break has been beneficial for all concerned."

"It was very good," he said after yesterday's match against Zimbabwe had ambled to its inevitable draw. He had spent most of the day, until West Indies declared late in the afternoon, watching Shivnarine Chanderpaul play himself into form for Thursday's first test with an unbeaten 103.

"Getting time away from the game was important, spending time with the family and friends," he said. "I haven't done that in quite a long time and I certainly don't regret it.

"Coming back, though, the enthusiasm is there. It's been a bit rusty but I'm getting into the swing of things, getting my momentum going, and I'm hoping I can climb the ladder pretty quickly."

Lara is 31 now and, as an oldtimer in a squad containing rising stars such as Wavell Hinds and the 19-year-old Ramnaresh Sarwan, he intends to pass on his experience. "It has to be beneficial," he said. "I spent two county seasons here as well as touring. I know what it is like coming to England for the first time.

"I know how tricky things can be for the new players and, in being around, I can share that. The youngsters like Sarwan and Hinds may need someone to lean on and I can provide the knowledge they expect. I'm looking forward to playing that role."

webTitle: In a right pickle and all because of a few bouncers at the WI

fields.headline: In a right pickle and all because of a few bouncers at the WI
fields.trailText: Dave Podmore When I got the call telling me that the WI were in the market for one of my celebrated after-dinner speeches, I naturally thought it meant the West Indies boys.
fields.body:
I hear that in pubs and clubs throughout the land they're still talking about Pod's appearance in front of the Beeston branch of the Women's Institute. Well, let them. It was an honest mistake which anybody could have made, and in actual fact it was made by my now ex-manager.

Everyone on the circuit will tell you that in no way hasn't Dave Podmore got a lot of time for our friends, the ladies. Call me old-fashioned but I still think it's important when starting the car to lean across a member of the fairer sex and fasten her seat belt first. The three fiancées in my life - Toni, Nikki and Jacqui - would willingly stand up in court and give evidence of that. They may have to.

When I got the call telling me that the WI were in the market for one of my celebrated after-dinner speeches, I naturally thought it meant the West Indies boys. And on being confronted by a sea of pleated skirts, I even more naturally thought that Roger Harper had initiated a pre-test bonding session by getting all the guys into fancy dress.

That's one area of their game where the Windies have always been weak (and I know Duncan Fletcher is determined to make Team England's traditional cross-dressing superiority count in the coming months).

From my times in the Caribbean I know that your average calypso cricketer likes his humour the way he likes his swordfish and akees - salty. So I tailored my speech accordingly. But no, they weren't cricketers in those frocks. They were wimmos. What's more, they were in no mood for anything that smacked of politics.

Normally I steer well clear of that kind of material in my "Twenty-Minutes-Of-No-Holds-Barred Gents' Entertainment". But, if you're taking a sideways look at people's ethnic differences, or making one or two tongue-in-cheek suggestions about sterilising unmarried mothers - well, it's fairly predictable that the goats of certain WI harridans are going to be got up.

At first I took no notice of the booing and slow handclaps - after all I've had to put up with that right through my career. But, when some old biddy at the back (whom I thought was Courtney Walsh) started calling out "What about child care, Pod?" I suspected something wasn't right. The upshot is that I'm facing criminal prosecution under various sections of various acts of parliament, not to mention staring down both barrels of an ICC life ban.

You'd think the authorities would have better things to do right now, particularly as there are those in the game so utterly contemptuous of the values of sportsmanship that they have no place on a professional cricket field.

When Herschelle Gibbs and Henry Williams reneged on a gentleman's agreement to throw a match with Mr "Banjo" Cassim of Bangalore they spat on a thousand-odd years of cricketing tradition. If the sacred bond of trust between a cricketer and his turf accountant breaks down, the betting element of the game will go down the toilet and a vital source of income at grassroots level will vanish forever.

As with most controversies that rock the game to its very foundations, there are always going to be innocent victims. Wasim Akram, for example, who has never been found guilty of welching on any kind of commitment, has been hounded out of his Channel 4 job and denied the blazer, torn T-shirt and complimentary Swiss Army penknife. And now poor Waz has got no alternative but to play cricket for Pakistan. It's sickening.

On a more positive note, it's great to see Brian Lara struggling for runs -apart from that temporary glitch at Arundel. It's been a long downhill road for the so-called Prince of Trinidad. Pod first noticed that perhaps the young man wasn't quite up to playing at the highest level during Asif Din's benefit year. The little show-pony had the nerve to duck out of a black-tie hog roast, with tip-top cabaret, provided by the Selly Oak Apples. His excuse - that he'd been out in the middle all day scoring five hundred and something - was just pathetic.

And there'll be no hiding place for him at Edgbaston on Thursday -not with Crofty on fire and that new "delivery of death" that stops halfway through about to be unleashed. It could all be over in two and a bit days again.

fields.headline: Stewart insists match was clean
fields.trailText: Alec Stewart last night denied that the crowning glory of his brief captaincy career - England's 2-1 series win over South Africa in 1998 - was a consequence of the Pakistan umpire Javed Akhtar accepting money to make a string of dubious lbw decisions.
fields.body:
Alec Stewart last night denied that the crowning glory of his brief captaincy career - England's 2-1 series win over South Africa in 1998 - was a consequence of the Pakistan umpire Javed Akhtar accepting money to make a string of dubious lbw decisions.

"We won that match fairly and squarely and decisions went against both sides," Stewart said of England's 23-run win in the Headingley test.

Peter Willey, Akhtar's fellow umpire that day, was also sceptical. "I just thought poor old Javed did not have a very good match," he said, before adding, "looking back I suppose Javed was rather quiet. But you don't know whether people like to keep their own privacy."

The England coach at the time, David Lloyd, said Akhtar had given Andrew Flintoff out caught when he clearly missed the ball. "All I would say is look at the tape ... if there was any skulduggery going on it was nothing to do with England."

Pakistan are set to hold an emergency meeting today to study Ali Bacher's claim that they threw two matches in last year's World Cup. Pakistan's board chairman, Yawar Saeed, said Shoaib Akhtar was on tour in the West Indies - not in South Africa - at the time he is alleged to have told a businessman that the team had accepted a £660,000 bribe to lose to Bangladesh.

The Bangladesh board's general secretary, Syed Ashraful Huq, was equally dismissive. "We do not believe it," he said.

Meanwhile police in Colombo will search the ground and local hotels for bookmakers when the first test between Sri Lanka and Pakistan begins tomorrow.

fields.headline: 'Umpire fixed England test' says Bacher
fields.standfirst: South African chief points finger at Headingley win and two World Cup games
fields.trailText: The South African chief points finger at Headingley win and two World Cup games.
fields.body:
England were dragged to the forefront of the spiralling match-fixing saga yesterday when Ali Bacher claimed that the umpire Javed Akhtar was paid to make seven dubious lbw decisions in England's win over South Africa in the 1998 Headingley test.

Testifying on the fourth day of the King Commission hearings, Bacher further alleged that two Pakistan games in last year's World Cup in England - against Bangladesh and India - were fixed.

Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, broke into tears as he painted a damning picture of global match-fixing corruption. He said an Indian bookmaker, revealed only as Mr R, had told him that Akhtar, the Pakistani umpire, had been bought before the match by "one of the biggest bookmakers in Karachi".

"There were 10 lbw decisions in that match," Bacher told the commission. "Nine were made by Javed Akhtar, eight were against South Africa and seven were considered dubious by knowledgeable observers.

"Mr R told me that the Karachi bookmaker had even travelled to Leeds a few days before that test to make sure his client complied."

England won on the last morning by 23 runs to clinch a thrilling 2-1 series victory.

Bacher, who also named the former test batsman Majid Khan as a source of his information, said he first met Mr R in 1995 and was confident that he was "above board". He said he could not name him because he was concerned for the man's safety.

In an even more bizarre piece of evidence, Bacher substantiated his previous claims that two World Cup games were fixed by producing a letter from a South African businessman, Jacques Sellschop.

In his letter Sellschop recounted in detail a conversation he allegedly had with the Pakistan fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar, in which Shoaib claimed Pakistan were paid $1m (£660,000) to throw the game against Bangladesh.

"So many matches were fixed that I was not able to remember all of them," Sellschop said in his letter to Bacher. "[Shoaib] said the match between Pakistan and Bangladesh was fixed and the Pakistan side received $1m. He said it was very common and that you only needed three or four players to make it work.

"He said Hansie [Cronje] had been so stupid, that you only dealt with these people through a third party and never on the phone. He also said that at least one match on Pakistan's tour to South Africa in 1998 had been fixed and that many leading players had offshore bank accounts in the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Cayman Islands."

Pakistan's 62-run loss to Bangladesh was the upset of the World Cup. Against India at Old Trafford, they were bowled out for 180 chasing 228 for victory.

Sellschop said he did not know the man who had introduced himself as the world's fastest bowler, but he had later seen a photograph of Shoaib and had no doubt that it was him.

He said "Shoaib" also implicated Australia in match-fixing, saying "The Australian authorities deal with it more sensibly but they are heavily involved in making money like this."

There was also no respite for Cronje yesterday, with his team-mates Mark Boucher and Lance Klusener hammering yet more nails into their former captain's shattered career by confirming that he had "mentioned some sort of fix" before South Africa's second test against India in March this year.

Neither player took it seriously but, with the benefit of hindsight, both admitted that the offer was probably serious. The hearing was also told that over $47,000 (£31,000) was deposited into a Cronje bank account barely a week after the match-fixing scandal first broke in April.

Cronje, though, is not due on the stand this week after all as his senior counsel, John Dickerson, has prior engagements. Bacher, asked about the impact of the revelations that Cronje had accepted money from bookmakers and offered bribes to team-mates, said: "It has devastated the country ... and I don't think we have recovered."

Testifying on the fourth day of the King Commission hearings, Bacher further alleged that two Pakistan games in last year's World Cup in England - against Bangladesh and India - were fixed. Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, broke into tears as he painted a damning picture of global match-fixing corruption. He said an Indian bookmaker, revealed only as Mr R, had told him that Akhtar, the Pakistani umpire, had been bought before the match by "one of the biggest bookmakers in Karachi". He said he could not name him because he was concerned for the man's safety. fields.headline: England beaten to the punch
fields.standfirst:
Richard Williams sees Portugal's probing style win on points against Keegan's direct approach
Full Euro 2000 coverage
fields.trailText: Styles make fights and the chemistry between England's lethal directness and Portugal's languid probing created an enthralling contest.
fields.body:
Whatever England's ultimate fate in Euro 2000 may be, last night's meeting with Portugal provided the tournament with a match full of wonderful drama, its splendour made possible by the extreme contrast between the two teams.

Styles make fights, as Lennox Lewis is fond of saying, and the chemistry between England's lethal directness and Portugal's languid probing created an enthralling contest. Essentially, neither side's defence could quite cope with the opposition's best attacks, which is how the game should be.

England treated Portugal as if they were Brazil, which is close enough to the truth. That 1-1 draw at Wembley on May 25 was clearly a valuable dress rehearsal, since Kevin Keegan sent out exactly the same side - with the sole exception of Steve McManaman, who was excused duty that day, replacing Dennis Wise. Paul Scholes and Paul Ince attempted to lock up the middle, although the manager had clearly modified Scholes's role, allowing the Manchester United man to range further forward when the opportunity presented itself, as it did almost before the match had drawn breath.

The combination of a pleasant summer day, half-strength beer and the Dutch observance of Pentecost kept the fans' temperature down before the kick-off, but it was to rise as soon as play began, and for exactly the right reasons.

England's opening goal was stamped "Made in Manchester" as Phil Neville overlapped on the right, hit a raking cross with his generally unemployed left foot and saw David Beckham return it from beyond the far post for Scholes to head home.

There was a strong Liverpool flavour to the second effort, begun when Michael Owen fed Beckham, whose cross produced a sidefoot shot past Vitor Baia from Steve McManaman.

These are not irrelevant thoughts. England played in the first half with the togetherness of a good club side. To see McManaman and the younger Neville encouraging each other in the task of controlling the right flank of Portugal's attack was to understand the spirit with which Keegan has infused the side. Neville spoke last week of the need to use attack as a means of defence, preventing Portugal's right back, Abel Xavier, from giving Luis Figo support, and the ploy certainly worked - in so far as Figo was quickly forced inside.

Unfortunately for England, it does not really make much difference where Figo is forced to roam in order to do his work. When he and Manuel Rui Costa moved forward together through the middle, exchanging passes between England's defenders, a reply to England's early lead was not far away.

In fact it was delayed only by the callow errors of Nuno Gomes, the 23-year-old Benfica forward replacing the injured Ricardo Sa Pinto. Gomes had failed to score in eight senior international appearances before last night, and his efforts to control the ball with his back to goal consistently foundered on England's central defence.

But when Dennis Wise lost the ball with his first touch after coming on as a substitute for McManaman in the 58th minute, it was Gomes who raced on to Rui Costa's clever diagonal ball to complete an epic comeback by firing Portugal into a 3-2 lead. Ten minutes later he latched on to another pass from the same provider and drove narrowly wide from almost 30 yards.

Portugal's response to England's challenge had been nothing short of majestic. Figo's long-range shot and Joao Pinto's glancing header set up the game for a second half in which nerves were exposed and courage on both sides constantly tested. England's assaults always carried the danger of creating the opportunity for Portuguese breakaways, and the departure of McManaman reduced not just the level of guile in England's midfield but also the ability to retain the ball while patiently constructing multi-phase attacks - a characteristic usually missing from England's game, but a telling feature of the team's play in the first half.

The departure of Owen and the arrival of Emile Heskey at half-time increased the weight of England's attacks without sharpening their threat. Owen had done little of great consequence in the first period, beyond setting up the move for the second goal, but he had been a swift and persistent presence at the heart of the Portuguese defence. Curiously the diminutive Scholes provided the greatest aerial threat after Heskey's arrival, forcing a series of heroic defensive headers from Fernando Couto and Abel Xavier.

But with McManaman had gone England's ability to think on the ball, to move collectively, to keep defenders waiting and guessing before threading passes between them. The attempts at all-out assault that were the response to the need to find a third goal foundered on the inaccuracy that comes from over-anxiety. The thread had been broken, which only goes to show how fine and fragile, in England's case, it is.

webTitle: Keegan lost for words as he refuses to pin the blame

fields.headline: Keegan lost for words as he refuses to pin the blame
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan burst into German to answer a question from a delighted Berlin radio reporter after the match. And he made such little sense in the rest of the press conference that some people swore he was speaking in double Dutch.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan burst into German to answer a question from a delighted Berlin radio reporter after the match. And he made such little sense in the rest of the press conference that some people swore he was speaking in double Dutch.

Keegan, shell-shocked into meaningless platitudes, agreed that England showed their defensive frailties but insisted that it was not the fault of the back four or any individuals.

He also showed the first disturbing sign of a manager under stress by referring to himself in the third person, saying: "We took part in a wonderful match played in the right spirit but that is no consolation to Kevin Keegan or the England players."

Then, clutching at straws far more firmly than any of England's defenders stuck to their Portuguese tormentors, he pointed out that Holland had won the European Championship after losing their opening game.

"We chose a formation in which we could get at them and it worked perfectly for the first 20 minutes," he said. "But it was a wonderful strike from Figo to get them back in it and they showed a lot of character to go on and win it. They left themselves a mountain to climb at 2-0 down and they climbed it. I said to the players afterwards that I don't think Portugal can play much better.

"They can go on and win the tournament. It may sound a strange thing to say but my wish is that we meet them again and have another go."

His captain Alan Shearer was even more monotone than usual. "If there is anything good to come out of it, it's that we now know what we have to do," he said. "We have to win our final two games or we'll be going home. It's a bitterly disappointed dressing room because we threw it away from 2-0 up."

Shearer echoed his manager's belief that England are capable of beating Germany and Romania to take their place in the quarter-finals and make a stab at winning the tourna ment. The words may have carried conviction when they were uttered before the team's departure but they convinced no one last night, not even, from his expression, Shearer himself.

Keegan said: "We did not defend as we can do and I am not just talking about the back four. We did not defend well in midfield and at times we paid them a little too much respect. They like to play in midfield rather than push at the defence and then defenders have to decide whether to come out."

Keegan was at least delighted with David Beckham, saying that he did not deserve to be on the losing side after a world-class performance. But Michael Owen had a world-class stinker.

"I felt we had to get someone on to hold it up a bit more", he said, "because the ball was going up and coming back too quickly."

Owen played so poorly that Keegan may already be looking to change his striking partnership and he is resigned to losing McManaman with a knee injury.

"With only five days to go to the Germany game, that could cause a problem for us," Keegan said. With that, he was off, back to that overused England drawing board.
